magit--add-face-text-property: New function

Use it to add the font-lock-face property, instead of the face

magit-mode: Disable syntactic font-lock differently

The usual way of disabling syntactic font-lock by setting the second
element of `font-lock-defaults' also enables regular font-lock which
overrides any `face' properties.  While magit proper handles this by
using the `font-lock-face' property, we should avoid forcing this on
plugins (although the user might still do that by enabling a minor
mode which uses font-lock, e.g., whitespace-mode).

magit-mode: Disable syntactic font lock

Syntactic font lock automatically fontifies syntactic elements such
as strings in Magit diffs using the 'face' property.  This clashes
with Magit's manual application of the 'font-lock-face' property.

Fixes #3950.

Fix bcb501476d

Closes #3949.

Fix magit-*-maybe-update-*-buffer functions

These functions did not show the correct objects when point was moving
quickly through the list. The object to show was stored when the
command to go to the next item was issued for the first time and then
displayed later after a timer elapsed.

This is inadequate when moving through the list quickly: By the time
the objects are shown point is actually further ahead so there is a
discrepancy between the shown object and the place where point is.

Rename some internal functions

Indicated if a log section might be abbreviated

For performance reasons log sections by default only show up to 256
commits.  The user can also set another limit N.  If a log section
shows exactly N commits, then that most likely means that there are
more commits and that the limit has kicked in.  It could also mean
that there are exactly N commits, but that is much less likely and
telling the difference would come at a cost, which goes against the
goal of making things faster.  In either case show the number of
commits as "N+" (as in "N or greater") instead of as "N".

Closes #3941.

magit-diff-visit-file: Visit the blob for uncommitted removals

Previously this visited to the file in the working tree.  There was
no way to visit the HEAD blob instead.  The HEAD blob is the last
blob that still contains the removed lines and going there is useful
because it allows blaming those lines.

Users who don't like this can set `magit-diff-visit-avoid-head-blob'.

Bind RET to bug-reference-push-button

... but only if the button is inside a Magit buffer.  In Magit buffers
users expect "RET" to visit the thing at point, so this should happen
for bug-reference buttons too.  However in file-visiting buffers "RET"
is expected to insert a newline character and we shouldn't mess with
that.  By remapping `magit-visit-thing' instead of binding "RET"
explicitly we can limit the effect to Magit buffers.

magit-apply-patch: Abort when there is no context

Applying context-free patches can lead to unintended and confusing
results.  The ability to stage a context-free hunk doesn't provide any
functionality that isn't better achieved another way (e.g., staging a
region within a hunk), so let's move magit-apply-region's guard
against context-free patches into magit-apply-patch.

Closes #3924.

apply: Adjust hunk line positions for partial application

When applying a hunk or a region of a hunk that is not the first hunk
from the file, the line number in the header for the new start
position will often be incorrect because it accounts for content of
the ignored hunk(s) from above.  This usually isn't problematic
because there is enough context for 'git apply' to locate the
appropriate spot, but, in some cases where the context is too
repetitive to identify the location, it can lead to incorrect staging.

Note that the problem here is simpler than the one that 'git add -p'
needs to solve because, due to Magit's restrictions on what makes a
valid selection, we know that the hunks are contiguous and from the
same file.

git-commit-setup-changelog-support: Fix filling

Change log entries are customarily unindented[1].  In
git-commit-mode, however, adaptive-fill-regexp picks up leading
asterisks "* " in change log entries, which are subsequently
interpreted as a fill prefix of 2 spaces.  Thus, entries like the
following:

* file: very long description...

are "indented" to column 2 when filled:

* file: very long
  description...

Instead of messing with adaptive-fill-mode, the simplest way to
avoid this fill-prefix by default (but still allow users to enforce
it by manually indenting the paragraph's 2nd line) is to enable
fill-indent-according-to-mode, as was recently done in Emacs'
python-mode for bug#36056[2].

[1]: (info "(standards) Style of Change Logs")
https://www.gnu.org/prep/standards/html_node/Style-of-Change-Logs.html
[2]: https://debbugs.gnu.org/36056

magit-push-current-to-pushremote: Specify destination

In 839aaedad (magit-push-current-to-pushremote: Use literal ref as
refspec, 2019-04-29), we switched to using an explicit ref rather than
HEAD for the src part of the refpec to avoid a race condition.  The
description for the 'git push origin master' example in git-push's
manpage suggests that a destination of the same name is always chosen,
but this actually depends on the value of push.default.  As described
in the refspec section of that manpage, dropping the destination
behaves as 'git push origin' (i.e., pushing with no refspec).  So if
push.default is 'upstream', then 'git push origin REF' pushes to the
configured upstream of REF (falling back to the remote ref of the same
name).

Explicitly specify the destination to make this work with
'push.default=upstream' while still avoiding the race condition.
Specifying the destination is a conservative change because this is
how the to-pushremote push was done prior to 7fee4089f (Refactor
commands that can set the push-remote before their main task,
2019-03-29).

Fix offset calculation when jumping from diff to worktree file

The calculation of the corresponding line in the file as performed
by `magit-diff-visit--offset' was wrong.  The new algorithm does
not need the start of the hunk and the line within the hunk as two
separate values anymore.  The final position is enough.  Adjust
`magit-diff-visit-hunk-line' and `magit-diff-visit-file--noselect'
accordingly.

magit-diff-visit-file: Always visit the blob for committed changes

Previously this behaved differently for the HEAD changes.  In that
case it visited the file in the working tree instead.  There was no
way to visit the HEAD blob instead.  This was inconsistent and made it
very annoying to blame code that was already modified in the working
tree.

Add a new option `magit-diff-visit-avoid-head-blob' for users who have
grown attached to the old inconsistent behavior, but I think it would
be better to learn to use "C-RET" (`magit-diff-visit-file-worktreee')
instead of "RET" when one wants to visit the worktree file.

magit-clone-read-args: Let user choose how to read repository

Add new function `magit-clone-read-repository' to do so.

magit-clone: Add infix arguments

Leave out arguments that are covered by the various suffix commands as
well several footgun arguments.  Other footgun and obscure arguments
are put on higher (by default inactive) levels.

magit-clone: Define as a transient prefix command

... and add suffixes for the basic variants.

By default `magit-clone' continues to act as before and a prefix
argument has to be used to make it act as a transient prefix command,
but the new option `magit-clone-always-transient' can be used to make
that unnecessary.

This breaks non-interactive uses of `magit-clone', but that command,
like most Magit commands, was never intended for non-interactive use.
`magit-clone-internal' can now be used non-interactively, which may
be desirable because that may also sets `remote.pushDefault', which
"git clone" itself doesn't do.  But as the name of that function
implies I recommend not doing that.

magit-branch-or-commit-at-point: Default to hash if not a branch

If there is no branch at point, then this function used to default to
a "short name" for the branch at point, e.g. something like "master~2".

Revisions like that may be prettier than hashes, but their use often
leads to undesirable behavior.  For example when rewriting history,
one had to carefully avoid refreshing the revision buffer because
doing so would cause the buffer to show some other commit.

In other cases using a name is more desirable, but until we somehow
give users a choice, lets use the safer of the two options.

magit-set-header-line-format: Use face for complete line

Use the face `magit-header-line' for the complete header-line because
it may set properties such as the background color and underline and
it would look weird if that were missing from some parts. Put that
face "behind" other faces if any.

have to update the section highlight because calling that function is
what calls `magit-refresh-buffer', which is normally responsible for
refreshing the section highlighting.

magit-log-goto-same-commit: Split into two functions

The new function `magit-log-goto-commit-section' jumps to the section
whose value is the commit passed as an argument.

Remove `magit-log-goto-same-commit's optional and misguided DEFAULT
argument, which was used if the previously current section disappeared
during a refresh.  But that isn't the intended purpose of this
function.

These two actions are quite different, though the latter function is
implemented using the former.

magit-log-goto-same-commit: Remove redundant calls

`magit-log-setup-buffer' calls `magit-log-goto-same-commit', so
callers of the former do not have to call the latter immediately
afterwards.

magit-diff-toggle-file-filter: Support log-like modes

While invoking `magit-show-commit' from a `magit-cherry-mode' or

a file filter, such a filter may already be in effect.  So we might
as well support *disabling* such a filter here too.

magit-reflog-limit: New option replacing magit-reflog-arguments

"-n" is the only reflog argument whose value the user can change.
Because of that it wouldn't be worth it to implement a refreshing
prefix.  The "+" key binding is already a more convenient way to
increase the limit when necessary.

Remove the `magit-reflog-arguments' option, which is a leftover
from a time when most such arguments (but not this one) were used
by `magit-popup' commands.
magit-reflog-current: Fall back to reflog for detached HEAD

The binding was inherited from `magit-log-mode-map' but isn't useful
in `magit-reflog-mode' buffers.

magit-reflog-mode: No longer derive from magit-log-mode

While a reflog can be shown using "git log -g --abbrev-commit
--pretty=online" a reflog is still rather different from a log.
Usually a reflog is shown using "git reflog show", which is an
alias for the mentioned log command and what Magit uses.

This also fixes a bug.  Previously when showing the real log for the
reflog entry at point the log arguments were picked up from the reflog
arguments used in the reflog buffer, which is undesirable because that
currently is just "-n256".
magit-reflog.el: Create new library from existing code

Update revision or blob buffer while moving through cherry list

Updating these buffers like when doing the same in a `magit-log-mode'
buffer is useful for `magit-cherry-mode' buffers also, but that did
not happen because the latter mode does not derive from the former.

Restore bookmark support

Differences to the old implementation include:

- The format of bookmark names has changed.

- It now depends on the used `bookmark' command in what window
  a bookmark is opened.  Previously both `magit' and `bookmark'
  displayed the buffer, which for some commands and buffers
  resulted in it being displayed in multiple windows.

- `magit-submodules-mode' is no longer supported because it does
  not derive from `magit-mode' and therefore does not conform to
  the interface we now rely on.  Bookmarking such buffers isn't
  particularly useful because just using the regular command is
  likely more efficient than using a bookmark.

Change stickiness of infix arguments

Replace the option `magit-use-sticky-arguments' with two new options,
`magit-prefix-use-buffer-arguments' (for `magit-diff' and `magit-log')
and `magit-direct-use-buffer-arguments' (for diff and log suffixes,
when they are invoked directly, not from their prefix).

Previously the arguments that are in use in the respective buffer were
always used by default, even if that buffer isn't the current buffer,
now both variables default to only use those arguments if that is that
is visible in a window of the selected frame.  For direct commands I
am fairly sure this is less surprising.  For prefixes I was on the
fence.

Also see the newly added documentation.

magit-get-mode-buffer: New function

This is the new `magit-mode-get-buffer', but the existing function has
an incompatible signature so we do this in two steps to give authors
time to adapt their code.  Eventually the old version will be removed,
the new renamed to reuse its name, and the temporary name becomes an
obsolete alias.

refs: Sanitize argument handling

Unlike for the log and diff prefixes there is no refresh variant
of `magit-show-refs'.  In fact because this command only acts as a
prefix if it is invoked with a prefix argument (a feature that might
be unknown to the user) or when invoked from a refs buffer, it can
be considered to be the refresh variant.  Therefore it should always
use the arguments from the current buffer if it is a refs buffer.

log: Fix and refactor argument handling

Globally setting and saving the log arguments broke with the switch
to Transient.  This commit fixes that.

- Remove variables such as `magit-log-arguments'.  The continued use
  of these variables was what caused the breakage.  Usually Transient
  stores all saved argument values in the `transient-value' alist and
  retrieves them from there, but we continued to save them in these
  dedicated variables without preventing Transient from trying to
  retrieving them from `transient-value'.

- Completely remove the `magit-log-{set,save}-default-arguments'
  functions instead teach `transient-{set,save}' about the
  peculiarities of log arguments by implementing various transient
  methods.

- Unlike trivial transient prefix commands, `magit-log' can set
  arguments for many different buffers using different major-modes.
  Normally the set (but not saved) value is stored in the prefix
  object prototype.  This wouldn't work here because we now store
  a different value per major-mode.  To keep it simple we store the
  set values in the new `magit-log-default-arguments' property of
  the major-mode.

- History is still shared between repositories as well as major-modes.

- Use the same buffer-local variables to store the arguments for
  `magit-status-mode' buffers as for buffers whose major-mode derives
  from `magit-log-mode'.  I.e. remove `magit-log-section-file-args'.

diff: Fix and refactor argument handling

Globally setting and saving the diff arguments broke with the switch
to Transient.  This commit fixes that.

- Remove variables such as `magit-diff-arguments'.  The continued use
  of these variables was what caused the breakage.  Usually Transient
  stores all saved argument values in the `transient-value' alist and
  retrieves them from there, but we continued to save them in these
  dedicated variables without preventing Transient from trying to
  retrieving them from `transient-value'.

- Completely remove the `magit-diff-{set,save}-default-arguments'
  functions instead teach `transient-{set,save}' about the
  peculiarities of diff arguments by implementing various transient
  methods.

- Unlike trivial transient prefix commands, `magit-diff' can set
  arguments for many different buffers using different major-modes.
  Normally the set (but not saved) value is stored in the prefix
  object prototype.  This wouldn't work here because we now store
  a different value per major-mode.  To keep it simple we store the
  set values in the new `magit-diff-default-arguments' property of
  the major-mode.

- History is still stored between repositories as well as major-modes.

- Use the same buffer-local variables to store the arguments for
  `magit-status-mode' buffers as for buffers whose major-mode derives
  from `magit-diff-mode'.  I.e. remove `magit-diff-section-file-args'.

- When `magit-show-commit' or `magit-stash-show' are invoked directly
  (i.e. not as a suffix of `magit-diff'), then get the arguments from
  the corresponding buffer instead of the `magit-diff-mode' buffer.

Remove option magit-remote-set-if-missing

The commands that previously respected this variable now always let
the user set the upstream/push-remote, provided HEAD is not detached.
It is no longer possible to disable this feature.

This variable was also used to configure whether "remote.pushDefault"
or "branch.<name>.pushRemote" is set by the push-remote commands.

magit--push-remote-variable: New function

magit-read-upstream-branch: Limit to existing branches

That means that "b u" (`magit-branch.<branch>.merge/remote') can no
longer be used to set an upstream that doesn't exist.  This has the
potential of being a disruptive change, but I think it is the right
thing to do.  The user doesn't gain anything from having configured
an usable upstream compared to not having configured it at all.

Only push commands, mainly "p u" (`magit-push-to-upstream'), are
capable of configuring an upstream that doesn't exist yet.  They do
so by first attempting to create it (by pushing obviously) and only
if that succeeds do they configure the target as the upstream.

The problem is that the preferred, and now only, way of creating the
upstream might not be very discoverable.  On the other hand, it is
not completely unreasonable that the "initial push" is done by, well,
pushing.  But that assumes that the user thinks of it that way.  If
someone uses "the upstream" in a way that differs from the workflow
suggested in the "The Two Remotes" info node, then things might be
more confusing.

While other parts of Magit have to be able to deal with missing or
outright invalid upstreams and despite the discoverability issue, it
is probably a good idea to prevent users from configuring unusable
upstreams.
magit-set-upstream-branch: Add doc-string

magit-fetch-from-upstream: Fallback to current remote

This command recently learned to set the upstream before fetching.
That was a mistake.  This command is all about fetching from some
remote, preferably the upstream remote; it does not matter what
branch is the upstream branch of the current branch.  "The upstream"
is a (potentially remote) branch, not a remote (repository).

It is more important for this command to be able to fetch from "the
upstream" in as many cases as possible, than for it to know what the
upstream is based on the configuration of the current branch.

Therefore this command now falls back to fetching from the "current
remote" if "the upstream" is unknown or a local branch.  If there is
a single remote, then that always is the current remote, otherwise
if "origin" exists, then that is used.

magit-get-tracked: New function

To an extend this is a replacement for `magit-split-branch-name'.
Unfortunately the latter is still needed to deal with unnamed
upstreams and non-existent refnames.

magit-get-current-remote: Always colorize returned remote

Add a new ALLOW-UNNAMED argument to allow returning the unnamed

magit-get-upstream-remote: Change meaning of argument

Never return "." because that represents the local repository and the
local repository by definition is not a remote.  Remove the NON-LOCAL
argument, which previously had to be used to enforce that.

If the upstream configuration referred to a missing (but named) remote
or an url instead of a name, then this function used to return that.
Now it returns nil instead, except if the new ALLOW-UNNAMED argument
is non-nil, in which case the returned value may also be an url.

Also if an url is returned, then propertize that using the face `bold'
instead of `magit-branch-remote' as before.

This also changes the behavior of the only caller;
`magit-get-current-remote'.

Favor upstreams that can be resolved to a branch

Most callers of `magit-get-upstream-branch' only care about the
upstream if it can be resolved to a branch, but until now this
function defaulted to return some representation of the upstream
even when that is not possible.

The optional VERIFY argument was added to let callers declare that
they are only interested in resolved upstreams, but most callers
that should have been adjusted to use that argument were not.

This commit removes the VERIFY argument and replaces it with a LAX
argument, which has the opposite effect.  By default this function
now returns the resolved upstream or nil.

Additionally this function is changed to use "git rev-parse --verify
--symbolic-full-name BRANCH@{upstream}" to determine the resolved
upstream.  Previously it accessed the variables "branch.<name>.remote"
and "branch.<name>.merge" and then tried to resolve that to a local or
remote-tracking branch itself.  The old approach resulted in incorrect
results in some edge cases.

The LAX argument is for callers such as the "push to the configured
upstream even if that doesn't exist yet" command, which cares about
configured but unsolvable upstreams.  These commands need further
work, but that will be done in other commits.  When LAX is non-nil,
then this function behaves exactly as it used to behave when VERIFY
was nil, including the bugs.

`magit-get-upstream-ref' now always returns the fully qualified and
resolved upstream or nil.
Change representation of unnamed upstreams

magit-branch: Rearrange checkout suffixes

The "b" binding is the most fundamental of these commands and should
therefore not come last.  Many checkout+checkout commands correspond
to some create-only command; these pairs should be placed next to
each other.  Taken together this means that we need two rows for the
checkout commands.

This may look a bit wasteful when some suffixes are disabled and the
forge package is used:

Checkout                               Create                 Do
 b branch/revision    c new branch      n new branch           C configure...
 l local branch       S new spin-out    s new spin-off         m rename
                                                               x reset
                                                               k delete

But when all the suffixes is available then this even looks better:

Checkout                               Create                 Do
 b branch/revision    c new branch      n new branch           C configure...
 l local branch       S new spin-out    s new spin-off         m rename
 o new orphan         w new worktree    W new worktree         x reset
                      y pull-request    Y from pull-request    k delete

magit-delete-remote-branch-sentinel: Decrease false positives

When deleting a remote ref fails, we fall back to removing the local
remote-tracking ref because a common reason for the push to fail is
that the ref no longer exist on the remote.  But it may fail for other
reasons (e.g., can't connect to the remote or a non-zero exit of the
pre-receive hook), and we shouldn't remove the local tracking ref in
these cases.

One way to tighten the check would be to search the process buffer for
"unable to delete 'BRANCH': does not exist".  (We'd need to search for
each ref with a tailored message because we wouldn't want to remove
the remote-tracking refs for multiple refs when the push failed
because one ref does not exist.)  This method relies on the message
being stable and wouldn't work for some users because that message is
marked for translation.

Instead reach out to the remote to get a list of its branches, and
check the ref against this list.  Doing so adds an expense, but it
seems like an acceptable one given that the check is performed only on
failure and that it replaces cases where the user would need to
manually call 'git fetch --prune REMOTE' to clean up otherwise.

Although not strictly necessary, narrow the check to the specific
error code that we expect to see for the "no longer exists" failure.
The exit code for a failed connection is different, so this avoids
trying to connect to the remote with magit-remote-list-branches when
the push already failed to connect.

magit-branch-reset: Improve consistency

This command can be used to reset either the current branch or another
branch.  The behavior different in arbitrary ways.  Now we do the
following for in both cases.

* Only update the upstream with a prefix argument.
* Call `magit-branch-maybe-adjust-upstream' if and only if setting
  the upstream.
* Add a "reset" entry to the reflog.
* Don't refresh more than once.

Remove magit-branch-arguments

The `magit-branch' transient has no infix arguments, but some of its
suffix commands still tried to get arguments.

"git branch" does a lot of different things related to branches.  Most
of its arguments are best thought of as sub-commands.  Other arguments
control how the output is formatted.  All of these arguments should
not be added to the transient.

The only argument that might make sense is "--force", but adding that
would be dangerous, especially if a user configured that argument to
be enabled by default.  Most commands that perform an action that
might have to be forced already do so with a prefix argument.

magit-rebase-insert-merge-sequence: Support --rebase-merges

Now that we can pass --rebase-merges for interactive rebases, we need
to be able to display several new action types: merge, reset, and
label.  Treat most of these actions in the same way as we treat exec
(i.e. don't insert a proper section) because there isn't an obvious
value to store/display.  The exception is merge actions that include
"-C/c <message hash>"; in that case, store the message hash as the
section value.

Use git-rebase.el's git-rebase-current-line so that we don't have to
duplicate all the action parsing logic here.

We may want to explore other ways of displaying the --rebase-merges
sequence because the single line display isn't ideal for showing the
branch structure, but for simple cases the current representation
gives a good enough idea and the user can always resort to other
methods (e.g., 'log REBASE_HEAD..ORIG_HEAD') to get a better view.

git-rebase: Update font-lock keywords for --rebase-merges output

git-rebase: Add commands for 'merge'

The syntax for the merge command is a bit more involved than it is for
other commands:

    merge [-C/-c msg-hash] <label> # Subject

Add two commands: one to insert "merge <label>" and one to switch
between -C (don't edit message) and -c (edit message).

The first command is a bit limited.  It doesn't allow the user to
specify a commit whose message should be reused or to edit the subject
which will be used for the message if the msg-hash isn't specified.
"merge <label>" will pop them into an editor, though, so the current
behavior may be sufficient for most needs.
git-rebase: Add 'label' and 'reset' commands
git-rebase: Add command for 'break'

git-rebase: Store line information in intermediate structure

The rebase actions all gather their information through the matches of
the git-rebase-line regexp.  This works fairly well right now; the one
hiccup is git-rebase-noop, which adds a trailing blank after the lines
it inserts so that it matches git-rebase-line.

But the possible rebase lines are going to get more complicated when
we add support for 'git rebase --rebase-merges' and for the break
keyword.  Instead of complicating the regexp and making each caller
deal with these details, introduce a new function
git-rebase-current-line that parses the line into a common structure
that callers can use.

Represent the line information as a class.  This is admittedly an
overkill because we don't need any of the object-oriented features,
but it makes access more convenient.

git-rebase-description: Correct doc-string

This face isn't applied to commented exec lines.  It seems sensible to
treat commented commit actions different than exec (or noop), so
adjust the documentation rather than the font-lock regexp.

Use the phrase "commit" action to prepare for --rebase-merge
actions (reset, label, and merge) because we won't display these with
a strike-through either (though whether we should is arguable).

git-rebase-move-line-down: Fix max bound definition

We narrow to the set of rebase lines when moving a line down because,
if git-rebase-show-instructions is non-nil, we don't want to move a
line down into the comments.  But this procedure has been broken since
12f38035 (git-rebase-line regexp did not support spaces before pick
commands, 2017-06-25).  With the new git-rebase-line regexp, the
search matches a line in the commented instructions block, setting the
maximum bound too high.

A further complication is that, once we add support for
--rebase-merges, there will be blank lines and "# Branch <label>"
comments among the rebase lines, so we can't just stop the first time
git-rebase-line-p is nil.

Another option would be to set the max bound based on a search for the
first line of the instructions block, but this isn't a good approach
because the "# Rebase ..." line is marked for translation.

magit-reset-worktree: Restrict with-temp-index scope

The temporary index is needed for the checkout-index call, but it
shouldn't be in effect for the WIP commits.  In particular, we don't
want magit-wip-commit-index to call write-tree with the temporary
index.  (magit-wip-commit-worktree, on the other hand, overrides the
index with its own magit-with-temp-index call, so its behavior isn't
influenced by magit-reset-worktree's temporary index.)

Also, refresh after the checkout-index call.  Otherwise the changes
are initially listed as staged because, at the time of the
checkout-index call, the temporary index is in effect.

Ensure all magit libraries are at least autoloaded

The optimal load/compile order is defined in "lisp/Makefile".

In lisp this is split across four places:

1. Libraries that are required by many other libraries are loaded
   in "magit-code.el".
2. Libraries that have to be loaded for "magit.el" are defined at
   the beginning of that file.
3. Other libraries that have to be loaded up-front (but may depend
   on "magit.el" being loaded) are loaded at the end of "magit.el".
4. Right after that an attempt is made to load "magit-autoload.el".
5. If that generated library cannot be found, then all remaining
   libraries are loaded up-front.  Autoloading them would be
   preferable, but since we cannot do that we have to load them
   to avoid all kinds of issues.

All libraries have to be loaded in one of these places.  Within
each place the libraries should be loaded in the same order as
in "lisp/Makefile".

This commit adds `require' forms for `magit-transient', `magit-wip',
and `magit-patch' and additionally fixes inconsistent ordering.

It is quite likely that a few libraries from (3) could be moved to
(5), but that is another issue.

magit-rebase-insert-merge-sequence: Resolve abbreviated hash

At least some Git versions dump an abbreviated hash to
$GITDIR/rebase-merge/stopped-sha.  magit-rebase-insert-merge-sequence
passes in the stopped-sha value as STOP, and this abbreviated value is
compared to the full hashes of "done" items.  Luckily this faulty
check doesn't cause any issues because the magit-patch-id calls
immediately below it end up setting STOP to the full hash.
Nevertheless ensure that it is resolved to make the comparison work as
intended and to avoid unnecessary magit-patch-id calls.

[key] magit-patch-create: Bind mail arguments to "C-m ..."

We cannot bind "-C" to "--cc" because the former is the short argument
for "--find-copies".  We do not want to keep using "=c" because we are
trying to move away from that prefix across all transients.  We also
do not want to use "-c" because we try to use "-<uppercase>" when
moving away from "=<letter>".

Right now "--cc" is the only mail argument that conflicts with a diff
argument, as described above.  But that might changes and we want a
future proof solution.

So we use "C-m ..." for all mail arguments.  For consistency we do so
even for "--reroll-count" and "--output-directory", which actually
have short arguments, "-v" and "-o".

[key] magit-rebase: Bind non-shortarg -d to --committer-date-is-author-date

magit-am already uses that binding.  Neither "git rebase" nor "git am"
have a short arguments for "--committer-date-is-author-date" but at
least Magit's bindings are consistent now.

[key] magit-log: Bind other shortarg -p to --patch

[key] magit-log:{--*order,--grep}: Bind non-shortargs

[key] magit-for-each-ref:{--contains,--sort}: Bind non-shortargs

Both "git for-each-ref" and "git log" have no short arguments for
"--contains" and "--sort".

Leave the various "--merged" and "--no-merged" bindings as-is.
A new class will be needed to deal with those properly.

[key] magit-diff:--diff-algorithm: Bind -A (no shortarg)

[key] magit-cherry-pick:--mainline: Bind shortarg
[key] magit-commit:--reuse-message: Bind shortarg
[key] magit:--gpg-sign: Bind shortarg

[key] magit-{merge,notes}:--strategy: Bind shortarg if available

* In `magit-merge' and `magit-notes' bind "-s" instead of "=s".
  Bindings for options no longer have to begin with "=" and "-s" is
  the short argument for "--strategy" for "git-merge" and "git-notes".

* In `magit-cherry-pick' and `magit-revert' continue to bind "=s"
  because for "git-cherry-pick" and "git-revert" "-s" is the short
  argument for "--signoff".

Consistency would be nice but using the short argument when possible
is more important.

Also note that the valid values for "--strategy" differ from command
to command, which is why we cannot use a shared infix argument.

magit-gitignore-*: Various improvements

* Rename `magit-gitignore-globally' to `magit-gitignore-in-topdir'
  because the term "globally" is ambiguous.  It may mean "in all
  clones of this repository" or "in all repositories on this
  machine".

  Before this commit it meant the former, but since the next commit
  will add a command that does the latter we now have to address this
  ambiguity.

* Rename `magit-gitignore-locally' to `magit-gitignore-in-gitdir'
  for consistency with the above rename and the commands to be added
  in the next commit.

* The new command names are unambiguous from a technical standpoint
  but the terms are not really suitable for the suffix descriptions.
  Use more verbose descriptions, including the file where the pattern
  will be saved.

* Flip the positions of the suffixes definitions because that works
  better with the commands to be added in the next commit.

* Improve the doc-strings.

* Use the same prompt when reading the file or pattern regardless of
  which variant is being used.

magit-read-upstream-branch: Make sure BRANCH is non-nil

Using the old approach a caller might explicitly pass nil as the
BRANCH expecting the default to be used, but that only happens if
the argument isn't provided at all.  Play it safe and use `defun'.

magit-rev-name: Exclude refs matching "*/HEAD"

Without this change `magit-upstream-branch-at-point' often returned
e.g. "origin/HEAD" when it should have returned "origin/master".

magit-rev-name: Use --exclude argument if available

We already used "--exclude" before but had to stop doing so because
that argument wasn't added until Git v2.13.  See [1: 7d61fe4e5] for
the story until now.

The benefit of this approach is that this function does not *always*
fail to return something when using an old Git version.  The drawback
is that when using a new Git version, then it *often* does not return
something even though it theoretically could return what we wanted it
to return.

Going forward use two implementations.  The >=2.13 implementation does
what we want to happen and the <2.13 implementation makes a best effort.

AFAICT, there were a few impedance mismatches:

- m-b-maybe-show-message checks the current style for the show-message
  key, but  magit-blame-echo-style is  set to the  lines visualization
  style, which only contains show-lines.

- m-b-maybe-show-message looks  for the 'heading symbol  in the commit
  alist, but the  keys returned by m-b--commit-alist  are strings, the
  first of which is "summary".

- assq uses eq  to browse alists, which  tests "Lisp object"-equality;
  to match  on a string such  as "summary", one must  use assoc, which
  uses equal.

magit-diff-inside-hunk-body-p: Handle type change hunks

Magit treats type changes as a sort of hunk.  Such hunks do not have
a body and we have to take this into account here because otherwise
we get a type error when trying to use its content slot as a number.
That in turn would prevent some other code from running resulting in
section movement commands getting stuck on this section after one of
`magit-previous-line' or `magit-next-line' was used inside the type
change hunk.

magit-req-eq: Return nil if A and/or B aren't commits

`magit-rev-eq' used to call `magit-rev-verify' on each argument, which
returns the first line of `git rev-parse --verify'.  In the case of a
range A..B, the standard output spans multiple lines, with first line
being B's hash and the second being "^A-hash".  It also return with
exit status 128, but `magit-rev-verify' ignores that.

`magit-rev-eq' should only return t if A and B refer to the same
commit and a range never refers to any single commit, so we should
return nil in that case.  Do that by using `magit-commit-p' instead.

This fixes a regression in `magit-diff-type', which (beginning with
296f8dc7) falsely concluded that a diff buffer showed unstaged changes
when diffing a range where the right side resolves to the same commit
as HEAD.
magit-rev-verify-commit: Rename to magit-commit-p

magit-rev-verify: Use magit-git-string-p

Previously this used `magit-rev-parse-save', but that failed to
return nil if REV isn't a commit but a range A..B, because it used
`magit-git-string', which returns the first line of the output even
if the exit code is non-zero.

In that case the output would be something like:

  cc998e85c00dff5b2429155b1b763b0f6e38ef97    # stdout
  ^d2c84d9a56e3cf12127ca22f72273febd92538b7   # stdout
  fatal: Needed a single revision             # stderr

I would expect git to fail without any output in this case,
but that's not what happens.

Use the new `magit-git-string-p' instead; that returns nil
if the exit code is non-zero, even if there is output.

Rename face git-commit-note to git-commit-keyword

In the rest of Magit we call [those] things "keywords".  Do so here
too.  Additionally we should avoid the term "note" because it means
something else in the context of editing text using `git-commit'.
A note is an additional text that is associated to a commit (similar
to a commit message, but unlike that not actually part of the commit
object) so the same word should not be used for a certain kind of
substring of a commit message.

magit-repository-directories: Use nil as default again

Because many users put "~/.emacs.d/" under version-control but don't
customize `magit-repository-directory', that directory should not be
a member of `magit-repository-directories'.  Otherwise `magit-status'
would not fall through to either offering to initialize the current
directory as a repository (`magit-init' would have to be used) or to
read a repository using regular file-name completion (except with two
prefix arguments), and users have grown accustomed to these fallback
behaviors.

Also update the documentation about `magit-repository-directories'
and `magit-status'.  The documentation about the latter was rather
ambiguous until now.  We trade that for making it a bit scary instead.

Revert "make: Tie git-commit's version to magit's version"

This reverts commit 2dbccdaadb6c5a69ff79165b45d635effcb2f281.

It's better not to do this unless absolutely necessary. After the new
`magit' release has made it onto Melpa it can take hours until the new
`git-commit' release is available too.  During that time `magit' would
be uninstallable.

Usually it is not necessary to bump the `git-commit' dependency
because nothing in "git-commit.el" changed.  In those cases we don't
want `magit' to potentially become uninstallable for a while.  (Well,
we never do, but here we can avoid without losing anything.)

Added a note to the release playbook instead.

git-commit-post-finish-hook: Don't run for unsafe commands

When a command like "git rebase --continue" used `EDITOR' to have the
user provide a commit message and created a commit with the message it
received that way, then it goes on doing other things that may need to
lock the index.

We therefore cannot run `git-commit-post-finish-hook' after the commit
was created because otherwise there would be a race condition between
the subprocesses of "git rebase" and whatever git commands the hook
calls.  Blacklist commands known to keep going after committing.

This was previously done in `magit-wip-maybe-add-commit-hook', but we
need to prevent all of `git-commit-post-finish-hook' to be inhibited.

git-commit-post-finish-hook: Don't run until commit was created

When "emacsclient" returns, then that doesn't necessarily mean that
"git commit", which used "emacsclient" as the `EDITOR', is already
done creating the commit.  We do not know the pid of "git commit",
so we have to use some other method of finding out when committing
is complete.

We do so by looping until "HEAD" points at another commit than it did
before the commit was initiated.  Once that is the case we run the
hook.  If "HEAD" still points at the same commit after one second,
then we give up and don't run the hook.

magit-wip-merge-branch: Change default back to nil

More work is needed before this can be enabled by default.  Merging
after committing has to be made more reliable, and log commands have
to be improved, and it must be possible to purge old wip history.
magit-wip-maybe-add-commit-hook: Add to git-commit-post-finish-hook
git-commit-setup: Add to local value of with-editor-post-finish-hook
Fix a94bc130c

magit-refresh: Run magit-post-commit-hook when appropriate

`this-command' is always nil when that hook should be run because
invoking the respective commands involves the server, which sets
that value.  In this case we have to check the value `last-command'
instead.
magit-refresh: Fix indentation

Do not merge into wipref when continuing a sequence

Running a command like "git rebase --continue" can result in the user
being asked to edit a commit message.  When the user confirms the
message then `with-editor-post-finish-hook' is run. `magit-wip-commit'
may be a member of that hook.

Trying to commit to the wipref is unsafe when "git rebase" is running.
It may result in "git rebase" failing because we hold the index.look,
or committing failing because some child of "git rebase" does so.

Teach `magit-wip-maybe-add-commit-hook', which is responsible for
adding that function when appropriate, to not do so when the commit
was initiated by a command that calls a "git" command that does other
things after creating the commit.

isn't a hack, that would be necessary even if the transition were
already complete.

magit-branch-rename: Ask before renaming on remote

On Github at least doing so would close an associated pull-request
permanently.  This would be annoying if the user actually wanted to
do the equivalent of:

  git checkout -b feature-r2 feature

  git branch -m feature feature-r1
  git branch -m feature-r2 feature
  git push --force origin feature feature-r1

This happened with #3622.

magit-with-editor-envvar: New variable

Setting this to `GIT_SEQUENCE_EDITOR' means that Emacs will be used to
edit a file on behalf of `git rebase -i' but not when creating commits.
In that case `GIT_EDITOR' (if set, else `EDITOR') will be used to edit
commit messages and similar files.  Setting one of these env variables
is the responsibility of the user; by setting this variable, they have
opted out of having Magit do it for them.

Closes #3629.

magit-reverse-files: Extend binary file check

The magit apply variants fail on binary files because they operate on
diff output that exists in the buffer, and that output isn't (and
shouldn't be) inserted with `git diff --binary'.  d0e04a14
(magit-reverse-files: do not attempt to reverse binary files,
2015-03-06) provided a more informative error message by checking for
staged binary files.  Teach magit-reverse-files to also check for
binary files when reversing files from revision and diff buffers.

For revision mode, note that we use `diff REV^..REV' rather than
`diff-index REV', but diff-index would be needed to match what the
revision buffer shows for merge and root commits.  However, using
diff-index isn't worth the added complexity.  In the case of a merge
commit, `diff REV^..REV' would still return the correct list of binary
files in the very rare case that a binary file shows up as a resolved
path in a revision buffer.  In the case of a root commit, we'd fail to
detect binary files, but this just means that we fall back to
displaying a less informative error message in the process buffer.

Closes #3625.

magit-staged-binary-files: Generalize and rename

This function exists so that we can detect when a user is attempting
to perform an invalid operation on a binary file and give an
informative error message.  To make the reverse checks more
comprehensive, we'll need to check diffs other than the one between
HEAD and the index.  In preparation for this, adjust
magit-staged-binary-files to take an arbitrary list of of git-diff
arguments.

Only merge into wipref after commit if any wip mode is enabled

The merging is done using `magit-wip-commit', which does more than
just merge.  It also creates the wipref if it doesn't exist yet and
that is clearly undesirable when the user hasn't enabled any of the
wip modes.

magit-read-repository: Fallback to reading directory when appropriate

When `magit-repository-directories' is non-nil (which it recently
started to be by default) but no repository can be found in those
directories, then read a directory instead of trying to select
from an empty list of repositories (which would cause an error).

magit-bisect-start: Error out when there are uncommitted changes

Strictly speaking it is possible to bisect with uncommitted changes,
provided these changes don't touch the same files as the commits that
are being bisected.  Otherwise checkout fails and an error is shown
in the status buffer.  However if the very first checkout fails due
to this, then the failure is silent and to avoid that we disallow
bisecting with uncommitted changes altogether.

Fixes #3604.

magit--record-separated-gitdir: Resolve symlinked gitdirs

git-annex converts submodule gitdir files to symlinks.  As a result,
magit-toplevel doesn't discover the correct working tree when it's
called from .git/modules/NAME.  The main user-visible effect is that
magit-diff-while-committing shows empty diffs.

We could address this by adding a kludge to magit-toplevel, but that
would mean risking regressions in a tricky and core part of the magit
codebase to work around the peculiar behavior of a third-party
program.

However, this is similar to the problem that was solved in
439ed762 (Record the working tree for separated git directories,
2017-02-05).  We can piggyback on that solution by teaching
magit--record-separated-gitdir to resolve symlinked gitdirs. In the
worst case scenario, we incorrectly identify the gitdir.  Then
magit-toplevel, when called from the correct gitdir, simply wouldn't
find a corresponding entry in magit--separated-gitdirs, and we'd end
up where we are without this change.

Fixes #3599.

magit-section-match: Support classes in condition

Previously the condition had to consist of type symbols, now it
can also contain class symbols.  This makes it more convenient
to use section types that derive from another.  Previously that
was cumbersome because each caller that wanted to match a class
and its subclasses had to match each subclass explicitly.

magit-section-match-2: Expect section as second argument

Previously that argument had to be the sections lineage, but that
had meant that the complete lineage was calculated even when that
was not really necessary and we need the section so that we can
start using `cl-typep' on it in the next commit.

magit-log-heading-re: Make the date field optional

'git rebase -i --root' corrupts the root commit's author field.  As a
result, the %at field for the root commit is empty, and we end up with
a log where the root commit remains unwashed, such as

    8c56a87 a
            c224010^@^@Kyle Meyer^@^@b

(This corruption has been fixed in what will be Git v2.19.0 by commits
ca3e1826a0, 0f16c09aae, and 67f16e3d3f.)

Update magit-log-heading-re to match an empty date field so that we
can detect and parse the line for a corrupted root commit.

Closes #3574.

magit-create-buffer-hook: New hook

This makes it necessary to drop `magit-mode-get-buffer's CREATE
argument and call `magit-generate-new-buffer' directly from its
caller `magit-mode-setup-internal', because turning on the mode,
which happens later, would otherwise wipe all buffer-local values

setup.

Allow specifying the face to use to highlight certain section

If the new `heading-highlight-face' slot is non-nil for a section,
then that is used to highlight its heading when it is selected.  This
is useful for sections whose headings have a background color when
they are not selected.  Without this the background would be covered
by that of the face that is always used to highlight the heading and
the body.

Something similar already exists for diff-related; this is a
simplified implementation for use by sections with fewer special
needs.
Merge branch 'status-logs' [#3518]

Change order and initial visibility of logs in status buffer

The old order and default visibility of these sections was chosen to
emphasize the commits the user is less aware of.  If you work on a
feature branch, then you naturally know that you have created commits
that haven't made it into "master" yet.  So that section was hidden by
default and placed after some other log sections.  On the other hand
you might not be aware that someone else has pushed additional work to
the public version of the feature branch ("@{push}") or the upstream,
and those commits might be relevant to what you are currently doing.
So these sections were expanded by default and placed before other
log sections, maximizing the likelihood that you would notice.

In the past users have asked me to change this, but it took me until
now to get sufficiently annoyed by the behavior described above to
change it.  Now we maximize for usefulness.

The logs that are relevant more often than the others are placed first
and not hidden by default now.  It is still easy enough to notice that
there are new commits on relevant branches even when the respective
sections come later and are collapsed initially.  The logs of unpushed
commits should *normally* not get so long that they push the logs of
unpulled commits beyond the end of the window even when it is scrolled
to the top.

Treat recent commits as a variant of unpushed commits

By default we insert either a log of commits that have not been pushed
to the upstream yet, or if there are no such commits, then a log of
recent commits.

Until now we used different section types and values for these
sections and instead used a kludge to treat those two sections as the
same section in some places.

The reason we did this was that we assumed that there would be places
where treating these sections as the same section would be wrong, and
that it would be better to explicitly handle them as the same section
in the places where we know that this should be done, instead of
undoing that in places where it shouldn't be done (and where we might
forget to do so).

As it turns out there is only one minor place where treating these
sections as the same section is a bit odd, while we failed to fully
implement the faking in some place where it would be needed.  The
section visibility was not always preserved and refreshing sometimes
jumped to a neighboring section.  There might have been other issues.

Now we use `unpushed' as the type and "@{upstream}.." as the value of
the "Recent commits" section, just like for the real "Unmerged into
<upstream>" section.

This obviously isn't correct, but currently the only downside is that,
"d d" on "Recent commits" shows the empty diff off the zero unpushed
commits.

magit-merge-into: Offer only local branches defaulting to upstream

If the upstream is a remote branch then default to

Unset $GIT_{DIR,WORK_TREE} when loading magit

Setting these environment variables for an emacs instance is a recipe
for disaster.  The problem is that environment variables are shared
across all of Emacs, so every buffer shares the same values.

Unfortunately git commit does export $GIT_DIR before calling $EDITOR,
leading to issues such as #3516, so Magit now unsets that variable
and $GIT_WORK_TREE if they are set when `magit' is loaded.

Revert "Force standard source and destination prefixes in diffs"

This reverts commit 553fdb0b25e2f3d4cd1fe43867039222a2df3afc.

Force standard source and destination prefixes in diffs

We do this for the same reason for which we used to force the use of
no prefix at all: in order to be able to correctly parse filenames in
diffs, we have to know whether a prefix is used and how long it is.

I probably chose "--no-prefix" in ebccd16914 to do so, because that
is only one argument.  Unfortunately Git in some cases ignores that
argument, namely when the "-L" argument is also used.

Forcing the use of the default prefixes instead should be safer
because it doesn't matter whether we get the desired output because
our request was honored or because the user's "diff.noprefix=true"
was ignored as well.  In both cases the default prefixes are used.

I am choosing "git -C diff.noprefix=false ..." over "git diff
--src-prefix=a/ --dst-prefix=b/" because that means we don't have to
make sure we use these arguments where ever "git diff" is called.

magit-dired-jump: Don't append slash to directory

Since GNU Emacs 26.1, specifically commit [1: 3988ceaa1c] addressing
bug#24409, dired-jump passes a non-nil FILE-NAME argument to
expand-file-name.  The expansion removes the trailing "/."  which
magit-dired-jump previously appended to directory name arguments,
resulting in a jump to the parent of the desired directory.

In place of the "/." approach of Magit commit [2: 5665ba94], call
file-name-as-directory when magit-file-at-point returns a directory.
This is necessary because magit-file-at-point returns a submodule path
without a trailing slash, and we want to jump to the submodule
directory not the parent directory.

In addition, simplify magit-dired-jump by passing a FILE-NAME argument
of nil to dired-jump when no file is detected at point, as dired-jump
will default to default-directory in this case.

[1: 3988ceaa1c]: 2016-09-14 00:04:32 +0900
  dired-jump: Expand file-name before dired-goto-file call
  https://git.savannah.gnu.org/cgit/emacs.git/commit/?id=3988ceaa1cfa2022443906750cbb30127a1e161f

[2: 5665ba94]: 2016-10-06 19:07:30 +0200
  magit-dired-jump: visit directory, not parent directory
  https://github.com/magit/magit/commit/5665ba9406b40e4cab97866b220e404211a4bd90

magit-log-wash-rev: Fix cherry mode failure on Emacs 26

magit-log-wash-rev calls member on (cadr magit-refresh-args).  This
value is a list in magit-log-mode, but it's a string in
magit-cherry-mode.  On Emacs 26 and later, calling member with a
string as the second argument fails:

  emacs25.3> (member "x" "y") => nil
  emacs26.1> (member "x" "y") => Wrong type argument: listp, "y"
     master> (member "x" "y") => Wrong type argument: listp, "y"

available on "i" by default.

The purpose of this change is to make it possible to use "i"
for `magit-imerge-popup' from the `magit-imerge' package without
making `magit-gitignore' unavailable.

magit-rebase-autosquash: Skip usual asserts

The asserts were already run when the fixup and squash commits were
created, so we don't have to ask again.  Furthermore we always rebase
all commits since the upstream, which means that (1) changes reachable
from upstream (including its tip) are never autosquashed into by this
command, and (2) that we might rebase over commits that actually are
unaffected in the end but that would be considered problematic.

Closes #3468.

Avoid error if gitk not found on windows-nt

On windows-nt, if gitk is not in the path, then the 'which' produces
nothing to stdout (although it does produce an error message to
stderr).  The magit-git-string call then returns nil, which is not a
valid input to file-executable-p, causing an error when trying to
autoload anything defined in magit-extras.el.

Include 'exe' as a first conjunct to the 'and', short-circuiting the
file-executable-p test in this case.

To deal with the different behavior of `format-time-string`

In emacs version > 25 :

If time-format contains the time zone symbol ( %z or %Z ),
use tz-in-second to format the time in committer time zone or author time zone.

If time-format doesn't contain the time zone symbol ( %z or %Z ),
assign tz-in-second to nil to format the time in local time zone.

In emacs version < 25 :

Just format the time string in local time zone

magit--github-remote-p: Use "git remote get-url" to get actual url

Using the value from the repo's ".git/config" does not expand in cases

then supports both the alias and a more complete github url to match
against).

magit-blame-process-filter: Uglify for the benefit of Emacs 24

* Consult match-data outside of `with-slots' before that messes
  with match-data on Emacs 24.
* Call the `magit-blame-chunk' with an empty string as the value
  of the positional and optional NAME argument. That argument is
  obsolete as of Emacs 25, but in Emacs 24 it isn't optional yet.
* Don't call `magit-blame-chunk' directly, instead let-bind a
  variable and then `funcall' that.  This leaves the byte-compiler
  on Emacs 25 and 26 in the dark, which keeps it from complaining.

that s/he wants to edit published commits when initiating the rebase
so that s/he won't be asked again when there are staged changes when
continuing the rebase.  Previously we tried to use a file in the
control directory used by Git, but that directory does not exist at
the time we need to remember and if we create it ourselves, then Git
trips over it.

Refactor blame commands

Previously the required information was determined in one place and
then passed along to the place where it was needed.  More specifically
all values were determined within the commands' `interactive' form and
then used in `magit-blame--run'.  Additionally the code used to
collect the necessary information was interweaved with error detection.

Now the commands take no arguments at all and call `magit-blame--run'
with a single argument, TYPE, which essentially identifies them.

The task of visiting the appropriate blob in a buffer (when necessary)
and the task of adding blame information to that buffer are clearly
separated.  The commands now
* call `magit-blame--pre-blame-assert' to avoid trying to blame when
  that is not possible;
* call `magit-blame--pre-blame-setup' to visit the appropriate blob,
  if that is necessary, and to jump to the correct line; and
* call `magit-blame--run' to add the blame information to the buffer.

When the current buffer does not already contain blame information,
then `magit-blame--pre-blame-setup' does nothing.  If it needs to
visit a blob, then it delegates that to `magit-blame-visit-prev-file'.
When the "blaming direction" changes, then it clears existing
overlays.

Refactor blame parsing

* Instead turning output into a list of lines and then dealing with
  an incomplete last line, insert output into a buffer and parse in
  there.  Look ahead to avoid parsing an incomplete line and instead
  keep track of how far we have parsed already.

* Collect chunk and commit data separately and only cache the commit
  data.

This theoretically breaks `magit-blame-chunk-get' but not in a way
that affects any of the remaining callers.  The format used for chunk
data might change in the future, so avoids making changes that later
might have to reverted.

git-commit-setup-check-buffer: Autoload

This allows using "git commit" from the command-line to connect to
a running Emacs instance in which the server has been started and
in which only "magit-autoloads.el" (but not "git-commit.el" and its
dependencies) have been loaded already loaded.

  $ cd /path/to/magit
  $ emacs -Q ... --load lisp/magit-autoloads.el \
    --eval "(add-hook  'find-file-hook 'git-commit-setup-check-buffer)" \
    --funcall server-start &

  $ cd /path/to/repo
  $ GIT_EDITOR="emacsclient -t" git commit

"..." stands for whatever has to be done to put magit, magit-popup,
with-editor and dash on the `load-path'; in my case "-L lisp -L
../with-editor -L ../dash -L ../magit-popup".

Stop advertising the Gitter chat

I am considering it a failed experiment.  The hope was that Magit
users would stick around help each other.  But very few people beside
maintainers of Magit and related packages actually do help other users
more than once or twice.  Most users leave once they got their own
question answered.

I don't find it a rewarding experience to help users in the Gitter
chat.  Users who ask for help there tend to do less research on their
own than those who ask questions on the Emacs Stackexchange site.
That is one reason why I prefer the latter, it actively encourages
those in need to do their part.  Another major benefit is that by
helping someone there, one potentially helps many users.  Unlike the
Gitter chats, the QA sites are searchable and provide lasting value.

Therefore I am removing all the links to the Gitter chat and will
visit it less often, but I will keep it open, for the time being at
least.

refs: Change look and massive refactor

* Drop support configuring the look using %-spec forms.  I don't
  thing this was actually used by anyone and if it was, then likely
  to insert the hash, which we could implement differently.

* Instead add options `magit-refs-primary-column-width' and
  `magit-refs-focus-column-width', which make customization easier.
  But overall they are less flexible.

* Change how the commits are displayed that a branch is ahead and
  behind its upstream.  But these counts in between the two branches
  and use ">" and "<" to indicate which branch has additional commits
  that the other has not (they both can have additional commits).
  Attach the count to the name of the branch that has the additional
  commits.  This also saves space.

* Likewise use "<N" in the first column instead of just "N" if a the
  branch in that row has additional commits compared to the focused
  commit.  The "@" or "*" indicating the focused branch, making it
  easier to understand the comparison: "* <N BRANCH".  If the branch
  does not have additional commits, but the focused branch does, then
  display "M>".  If neither has additional commits then "=".

magit-branch-pull-request: Use numbered branch in case of conflict

Since 4f7f55c93 we check whether the maintainer is allowed to push
to the fork and if so create a local branch whose name matches that
of the branch on the fork.

When the contributor did not bother to create a feature branch, then
that won't work, because in that case master (or whatever the default
branch is called) already exists.  Since the mentioned commit this
resulted in a (appropriate) error.

Continue to check whether we are allowed to push to the fork, but if
the branch name conflicts then never-the-less create a branch "pr-N"
instead of attempting to create one named "master", just as if we were
not allowed to push to "fork/master".

Also set the upstream repository, usually "origin", as the push remote
even though we actually could push to "fork/master".  Git's push
remote mechanism only allows specifying the remote but the name of the
push-target branch on the remote is always the same as that of the
local branch). We cannot configure "pr-N" to be pushed to
"fork/master" (Git doesn't support it) and we cannot push to
"fork/pr-N" (we don't have the necessary permissions), so we configure
"origin" as the push-remote and therefore push to "origin/pr-N".

magit-confirm: Simplify

magit-confirm: List targets at bottom of frame

Also make it more obvious that the list is "part of the question" by
not separating the list and the question with a mode-line, but make

magit-branch-commit-at-point: Prefer branch over tag

Previously if point was on a revision in a lot and both a branch and
a tag point at that commit, then tag was returned.  But this function
should return a branch whenever possible and only fall back to a tag
as a slightly nicer alternative than just a hash.

One consequence of the old behavior was that `magit-checkout' often
ended up detaching HEAD instead of checking out a branch.

For the variants that move (a) commit(s) away from the current branch,
it makes sense to offer the current branch as a completion candidate
because in those cases moving its tip is the most common use-cases.

Closes #3373.

whitespace-dont-turn-on-in-magit-mode: and maybe don't raise error

I though it was obvious that the old message implied "... therefore
do not enable Whitespace mode in Magit buffers.  Please adjust your
Whitespace mode configuration to prevent that from happening."  But
it turned out that is not the case.

Change the advice to silently prevent the activation if the attempt
is made due to the use of `global-whitespace-mode', but if the user
attempts to enable the local minor-mode directly, then show an error.

The hope is that this compromise results in the fewest invalid bug
reports.  (There is no bug - not in Magit at least.)

Closes #3374.

a star at the beginning anyway, but that is ugly so we no longer

magit-read-pull-request: Fix two bugs

Always request the individual pr even if it was part of the list
because the latter lacks some information.  That fixes #3371.

Previously we only tried to do so when the pr did not appear in
the list, but that didn't work because the use api resource was
wrong.  Fix that too.

Don't pass read-file-name's result directly to git

When Magit is used with Tramp, read-file-name will return a path like
/ssh:host:/path/to/file.  The host part needs to be stripped before
passing the path to the host's git.  bf4332c8 fixed this issue for
magit-am-apply-{patches,maildir}.  This commit should take care of the
remaining places that call git with an unconverted read-file-name
result.

Follow the approach from bf4332c8 of converting a path at the time it
is passed to the git function rather than when it is returned by
read-file-name.  Note, however, that magit-file-rename is the only
function from bf4332c8 or this commit that makes use of the full
host:path, so it might make sense to add a function that wraps
(magit-read-file-name-convert (read-file-name ... )).

Merge branch 'jb/submodules' [#2911]
Add many arguments to the module popup

Make module commands selection-aware

Act on the selection or the current module, if any, and fallback to
reading a single module instead of acting on all modules without the
option to act only on a subset.  To act on all suitable modules a
prefix argument has to be used now.

Also improve the documentation, add comments explaining differences
to Git, and show the used git commands in the popup.

Rename module commands to deal with ambiguities

* Rename `magit-submodule-init'
      to `magit-submodule-register'.
  Instead of "i" bind "r" in the popup.

  Git isn't consistent about what the term "initialize" means in the
  context of modules, so avoid using it.  The command "git submodule
  init" does NOT "initialize" a module, it "registers" the module by
  recording its url in the super-projects $GIT_DIR/config.  This
  allows editing that url before actually "initializing" it using
  "git submodule update", in which case that command does not actually
  "update" but "make available for the first time".

* Rename `magit-submodule-setup'
      to `magit-submodule-populate'.
  Instead of "b" bind "p" in the popup.

  Git doesn't use the term "setup", I came up with that.  It is such
  a generic term that it could mean basically anything.  "Populate"
  is much more obvious.

* Likewise change `magit--insert-modules-overview' to say that a
  module is "unpopulated" instead of saying it is "uninitialized".

* Rename `magit-submodule-deinit'
      to `magit-submodule-depopulate'.

  Given a sub-command "init" and another named "deinit", one would
  expect the latter to undo the effect of the former.  But then one
  would be wrong.  "init" only sets variables, while "deinit" only
  removes the working directory by replacing it with an empty
  directory. "deinit" is the opposite of "update --init", or as we
  call these actions "unpopulate" is the opposite of "populate".

* Rename `magit-submodule-sync'
      to `magit-submodule-synchronize'.

  Since none of the names of related commands contain an abbreviation
  it is nice if this one does not do so either.

* Display the actions in a single column and change the order a bit.
magit-module-confirm: Bugfix

git-commit-prev-message: Fix error in buffers without comments

When attempting to invoke git-commit-prev-message or
git-commit-next-message in a buffer without comments, the functions
would fail with the message:

git-commit-prev-message: Search failed: "^#"

Such a buffer could be the result of a prepare-commit-msg git hook
which does not emit any comment lines.

The rest of the code was already prepared to handle this scenario, so
just fix the re-search-forward invocation to not error when the regexp
was not found, and allow the caller to handle the failure.

This function relies on being able to tell whether ITEMS is nil

Merge branch 'jb/visibility-cache' [#3323]

Preserve visibility cache when killing buffers

The section visibility cache is stored in a buffer-local value.
For `magit-status-mode' and `magit-refs-mode' preserve that value
using a repository-local value when killing the buffer and restore
the buffer-local value when recreating the buffer.

Other modes are not supported because they contain no sections that
benefit from the visibility cache and/or because it is possible for
multiple buffers with that mode to exist per repository.
magit-section-cache-visibility-types: add unstaged and staged

Generalize section visibility cache

* Cache whether a section is hidden or expanded.  Previously it was
  only possible to cache that a section is hidden.  The only use-case
  was to hide a re-appearing section even though the default for that
  section is to expand it initially.

* Allow caching the visibility state of sections of any type.  The new
  option `magit-section-cache-visibility-types' controls for which
  sections the state is remembered.  As before, only the section type
  controls whether the cache is used, while (cons TYPE VALUE) is used
  as the key when doing so.

Move Github-supported documentation files into sub-directory

Unfortunately Github only finds these files if they are located at the
top-level or in a sub-directory named either "docs" or ".github".  Our
documentation directory is called "Documentation".

We used to place these files at the top-level but since I am going to
add more of the supported files this would become to noisy.  The best
work around would be to create a symlink ".github -> Documentation,
but Github doesn't support that.  The next best thing is to create a
directory named ".github" that contains symlinks to files inside
"Documentation".

Rename COPYING file to LICENSE

This filename is more common nowadays.  It is also more precise
because that file contains the text of the actual GPLv3 license,
i.e. the actual license, not a permission statement such as can
be found in the library headers.

git-commit-font-lock-keywords-2: replace ineffective element

In the past Git might have said:
  Not currently on any branch.
instead of that it now says:
  HEAD detached at abcdefg.

`git-commit-font-lock-keywords-2' used to have an entry for the former
but it did not have any effect because only the first submatch would
have been colorized but the regexp had no submatches.

As a result the face `git-commit-comment-detached' wasn't actually
ever used.  Now it is used for the "HEAD" in the new output.  Also
remove the old bogus entry and don't bother colorizing anything for
older Git versions.

git-commit-turn-on-flyspell: avoid unnecessary work

Our `git-commit-flyspell-verify' does its job as intended, but that
only keeps flyspell from actually checking words inside comments,
it does not keep it from looking at each word in comments and from
incorrectly claiming that it is checking them.

That takes time and is confusing.  To avoid it, call `flyspell-region'
on the relevant part of the buffer only.

We cannot use `forward-comment' because that is syntax based, but
we cannot use syntax for comments because the comment character only
begins a comment if it is located at the beginning of a line.

Silence byte-compiler

Due to some recent change on Emacs' emacs-26 branch the byte-compiler
started complaining that the "Lexical argument shadows the dynamic
variable values".  That's a bit annoying - it is quite reasonable to
have functions that take an argument named `values'.  Work around this
by naming those arguments `values*' instead, but make sure the
doc-strings still refer to `values'.

Merge branch 'jb/cherry-merges' [#3281]

Properly deal with merges when cherry-picking

Change all commands which cherry-pick and revert commits to use the
new function `magit--cherry-pick'.  Previously all of these functions
used `magit-assert-one-parent' to deal with merges among the commits
to be applied.  But that function wasn't adequate and this commit
removes it.

It is not possible to apply merges and non-merges at once, because
`--mainline' must be provided for merges while its use causes an error
for non-merges.  In that case aborting is the only choice.

But otherwise add or remove the `--mainline' as appropriate.  When
`--mainline' is added, then ask the user for the parent number, when
it is removed, then do so without prompting.  This makes it possible
for users to use `--mainline=1' (which is the most reasonable choice
for most merges) by default without getting an error when applying
non-merges.

Closes #2980.

Merge branch 'np/w32-encode' [#3250]

Fix encoding of data and args for git subprocess on w32

On windows-nt systems, the arguments to subprocesses must be encoded
in the current code-page.  But Windows git requires UTF-8 encoded
input.  The contradictory requirements mean we can't just set
default-process-coding-system to the right thing.  Therefore,
explicitly encode the arguments according to `w32-ansi-code-page',
and likewise encode input sent to git as `utf-8-unix'.

See #3250.

magit-git-insert: fix regression

f36ab764e6 did replace `magit-process-error-message-re'
with `magit-process-message-regexps', but did not adapt
the use in `magit-git-insert'.

Closes #3272.

make: target install must depend on versionlib

`versionlib' is not a dependency of `lisp` because it install
is skipped, then "magit-version.el" would just get in the way
of more up-to-date information.  But when installing from the
Git repository, then we have to create that file.

Closes #3271.

magit-format-ref-labels: remote refs may contain only two slashes

Most remote refs look like "refs/remotes/REMOTE/BRANCH"
but something like "refs/remotes/git-svn" is also valid.

Fixes #3266.

magit-insert-recent-commits: make sure

We put `magit-log-section-commit-count' before
`magit-log-section-arguments', which by default contains "-n256".
Because the last occurrence of "-n<N>" wins, this results in a
very high upper bound.  We also use a range "HEAD~N..HEAD" as an
additional limit, but when there are many recent merges, then that
limit likely has no effect.

We fix this by stripping the "-n<N>" from
`magit-log-section-arguments' in this particular case.

For why we use both "-n<N>" and "HEAD~N..HEAD", see 55a61d15e85fe.

Fixes #3270.

Fix return value from magit-branch-read-args

...when magit-branch-read-upstream-first is nil.

Fixes #3268
magit-blame-popup: fix magit-blame-reverse's description

refs: preserve cherry-less, expanded sections on refresh

Expanding a cherry-less section results in an empty body.  Normally,
during refresh, an empty body causes the section to be removed by
`magit-cancel-section' (in this case called by `magit-git-wash'), but
because inserting the body is delayed in this case (for performance
reasons) until it is expanded `magit-insert-section--current' is nil
at the time this happens, which causes `magit-cancel-section' to do
nothing.

That's actually what we want, but that wasn't by design.  However when
the user then refreshes the buffer, the section remains expanded and
because it is being recreated during a refresh `magit-cancel-section'
does its job.

Prevent that by binding `magit-insert-section--current' to nil while
calling `magit-git-wash'.

Fixes #3267.

magit-ref-namespaces: fix magit-refname regexp

The fallthrough regexp is "\\'\\(.+\\)" as of
e0af5b39 (magit-ref-namespaces: improve regexps, 2017-11-15), but this
will always return nil, leading to an error when a refname doesn't
match any of the preceding regexps.  Replace "\\'" with "\\`", which
was presumably the intended change in e0af5b39.

magit-submodule-fetch: fetch multiple modules in parallel

Use "git fetch --recurse-submodules -j N" to fetch submodules.

Previously we used "git submodule foreach 'git fetch || true'",
because for older Git versions an error while fetching one module
caused the command to abort, so later modules were not fetched.
User of old Git versions can fix this regression by updating to a
reasonably new version.

Another consequence of this change is that fetching modules now also
fetches the super-repository.  Unfortunately "git fetch" cannot be
told not do that, but I think that's acceptable.

Starting with Git v2.8.0 start fetch multiple submodules in parallel.
That is the motivation for this change.  For older versions silently
fallback to fetch one by one.

Closes #3261.

Combine related refs when displaying them in logs

instead of BRANCH REMOTE/BRANCH
           [blue] [green------]

That does not only preserve space, it also informs the user
