don't use section bindings from other buffers in process buffer

Ultimately all sections are inserted using `magit-insert-section',
which binds a few variables dynamically, to pass information to nested
invocations, among other things so that those invocations know what to
use as the parent section of the section that they are inserting.

Normally I avoid the use of dynamic bindings to pass around information,
but in this case it seems appropriate, because the "nested"
`magit-insert-section' invocations often cannot be found lexically
inside the outer invocation, and the cost of passing these values around
as arguments would therefore be very high; a great many functions (which
shouldn't have to concern themselves with this particular implementation
detail) would need additional arguments.

Also the current approach works quite well, because normally the process
of inserting a section and its subsections is fully completed before
other, unrelated sections are inserted into another buffer.

However there is an exception which wasn't handled properly.  While
inserting sections in some buffer, it can become necessary to insert a
section into the process buffer.  This would for example be the case if
`magit-git-debug' is set to `t', and some section inserter runs git to
get a value but gets a non-zero exit status instead.  That normally is
not an error from Magit's perspective, but when `magit-git-debug' is
non-nil, then the error message is logged to the process buffer anyway.

In cases like this, outer bindings for `magit-section-insert--parent'
and `magit-section-insert--oldroot' are still in effect but we failed to
determine whether they are valid, which they are not because they are
about another section being inserted into another buffer.

Because process buffers are never refreshed (the refresh commands just
silently forgo doing so), this can be fixed easily, by binding these
variables to the appropriate values (`nil' or the buffer-local value of
`magit-root-section') around all calls to `magit-insert-section' which
insert a section into the process buffer.

We do not have to do the same for `magit-insert-section--current'
because the value is not used by `magit-insert-section'.  This variable
might be used in the BODY of the macro, but by the time that happens the
macro has already bound the variable to the correct value, overriding
and ignoring all bindings that might be in effect outside of the BODY.

add magit-display-buffer-fullframe-status-topleft-v1

This function is an alternative to
magit-display-buffer-fullframe-status-v1 that makes Magit buffers pop up
on the same side as they would with magit-display-buffer-traditional.

Do this by calling display-buffer-pop-up-window call and then swapping
the windows.  This will work best with magit-bury-buffer-function set to
its default value of magit-restore-window-configuration, but a few
window parameters are adjusted so that magit-mode-quit-window and
quit-window behave sensibly.

Another approach would be to make a variant of
display-buffer-pop-up-window that pops up on the desired side.  However,
doing this would require either relying on several internal window.el
functions or re-implementing these functions.  A third approach would be
to define a display-buffer-above-selected analog of
display-buffer-below-selected, but this has the same problem as the
second approach and also deviates from
magit-display-buffer-traditional's behavior in that it hardcodes a
horizontal split rather than respecting split-window-preferred-function.

magit-popup-describe-function: use correct window

If we let `display-buffer' (called by `describe-function') decide where
to put the *Help* window, it may (if the frame is wide enough) decide to
split horizontally instead of using the window we were creating earlier
with `split-window-below'.  This results in 3 windows, 2 of which are
the popup buffer, and is generally not very helpful.

To avoid this, let-bind `display-buffer-alist' to tell `display-buffer'
that it should reuse the window we made.

Merge branch 'jb/apply-reject' [#2647]

use --reject to apply at least non-conflicting hunks

When applying changes to files in the working tree results in conflicts,
then `git apply' aborts and does not apply anything.  What we would like
it to do, is to perform a 3-way merge, just like when applying changes
to the index, but unfortunately that is not possible.

When reversing changes and when discarding staged changes while there
are unstaged changes, then use `--reject'.  This won't insert conflict
markers into files in the working tree, but it ensures that changes that
can be applied are applied even when there are other changes that cannot.

For changes that could not be applied `--reject' causes the creation of
diff files which contain those changes.  We would have liked for Git to
create conflict markers - using such "conflict files" is the closest we
can get to that.

magit-pull-from-upstream: don't explicitly specify remote branch

Previously we used `git pull REMOTE BRANCH' and now we just use `git
pull REMOTE'.  This has the advantage that tags that point to commits
which are being pulled are also fetched.  Users have come to expect
that behavior.

We did not do this previously because I considered it to be unsafe.
The documentation of `git push [REMOTE]' claims that it pushes to the
upstream and fails to mention the various variables that can cause it
to push somewhere else.  The documentation of `git pull [REMOTE]' also
does not mention any such variables, but as the push documentation
demonstrates, this is no guarantee that there are none.  On the other
hand, unlike with pull, I am not actually aware of any such variables.

I have decided to drop the BRANCH argument because accidentally pulling
something different from what one wanted to pull, is much less dangerous
than accidentally pushing to the wrong place.

Instead of using `read-file-name', which allows selecting a path which
is not a repository, use `magit-completing-read' to select the relative
name of a known repository located inside the outer repository.

This also fixes a second issue: Previously an absolute path may have
been used as initial input.  If the user used that and the chosen
repository was not located at the top-level of the outer repository,
then `read-file-name' considered that an invalid choice and prompted
again, this time without a default.

magit-insert-unpulled-from-upstream-or-recent: even if no upstream

Show the recent commits if the upstream is not configured.
A faulty test used to prevent that.
magit-file-popup: autoload it

magit-commit-squash-internal: commit synchronously before rebase

Previously it was possible for the commit process to still hold the lock
on index.lock, when the rebase process was trying to acquire it.  Now we
run the commit process synchronously if we are going to also rebase, and
we also forgo refreshing between the two processes.  If we don't rebase,
then still commit asynchronously and refresh.

git-rebase-mode: disable save-place-local-mode

Do so in a way compatible with older Emacsen,
i.e. set the local value of `save-place' to nil.
magit-pull-and-fetch-popup: fix key conflict

magit-cygwin-mount-points: use magit-git-executable

Instead of hardcoding "git" as the executable.  This lets the default
value for magit-cygwin-mount-points correspond to the user's choice for
magit-git-executable.

magit-diff-wash-diff: fix -L kludge false positive

f06edb2 (magit-log-{popup,buffer-file}: add ‘-L’ argument, 2015-09-30)
stripped the first two characters of the file name to account for
--no-prefix not working with when -L is used with git log.  However,
magit-diff-wash-diff is also called in log mode when --patch is used
without --graph, and in this case --no-prefix has an effect, so the file
name gets truncated.  Check that -L is in magit-refresh-args to avoid
this.

Fixes #2622.

magit-merge-editmsg: always use --no-ff

Use `--no-ff' even if it is not specified in the popup.  Otherwise Git
would to a fast-forward merge if possible, which clearly isn't what one
would expect to happen.  The intention is to create a merge commit, but
have the opportunity to change the commit message before creating that
commit.  To not create the commit but still perform (and finish) the
merge, is something very different.

Fixes #2620.

magit-merge-nocommit: always use --no-ff

Use `--no-ff' even if it is not specified in the popup.  Otherwise Git
would to a fast-forward merge if possible, which clearly isn't what one
would expect to happen.  The intention is to create a merge commit, but
have the opportunity to inspect the merge before creating that commit.
To not create the commit but still perform (and finish) the merge, is
something very different.

stash: clarify worktree-related descriptions

magit-stash-worktree, magit-snapshot-worktree, and
magit-insert-stash-worktree are limited to unstaged changes in the
stash (stash@{N}^2..stash@{N}).  Update their doc-strings to refer to
these changes as "unstaged".  Likewise, rename the section "Working
tree" in magit-stash-mode to "Unstaged".

For consistency, describe the index counterparts as "staged".

Although it would be clearer to also rename the commands as "*-unstaged"
and "*-staged" rather than "*-worktree" and "*-index", the keys in the
popup are aligned with the current names (w, W -> worktree, i, I ->
index).  Stick with the current names to avoid either 1) extensive
changing of the popup keys or 2) having keys that don't have an obvious
connection to the command name.

magit-read-{remote,upstream}-branch: remove duplicate choices

In both cases, the collection to choose from is created from an
argument (local branch) turned into a remote ref, plus a list of all
remote or all branches.  The latter part can already contain the refs
constructed in the former, leading to duplicates.

Since we use dash anyway and the order in the collection is irrelevant,
replacing nconc by -union should get rid of these duplicates.

magit-diff-wash-submodule: use appropriate range for rewinds

When `diff.submodule' is `log', then `git diff' prints one of

    Submodule <module> <from>...<to>:
    Submodule <module> <from>..<to>:

for modules with new commits, as appropriate.  But for rewinds it
always prints:

    Submodule <module> <from>..<to> (rewind):

In that case `git log --online --left-right <from>..<to>' prints
nothing.  Inject the additional period to get the same range and
similar output as `git submodule summary'.

magit-diff: hide trailing CR chars on Windows

Windows users are more likely to interact with CRLF files, in which case
their diffs will have trailing CR characters. We keep them around, as
they are useful for staging (or otherwise applying) hunks without
mangling line endings but users are usually not interested in seeing a
diff full of trailing ^Ms, so we make them invisible.

This behavior can be disabled using the `magit-diff-hide-cr-characters'
variable.

magit-process: ensure unix eol conversion

This ensures that diffs coming from files with DOS (CRLF) line endings
don't lose CR bytes. This would case line endings to be mangled when
staging (or otherwise applying) hunks from such files.

Fixes issues #2401, #2403 and #2583.

magit-apply: use buffer-substring-no-properties

We don't need the text properties at this point, so discarding them is
more efficient and eases debugging.

magit-apply: refactor patch construction

Changed the various callers of buffer-substring to go through
magit-apply--section-content, a new function.

magit-insert-stash-untracked: recurse into sub-trees

Without the -r flag, ls-tree will return the top-level directory name
rather than the file name for an untracked file that is not in the
top-level directory.  As a result, the diff of stash@{N}^3 is limited to
the directory rather than the untracked file.  This leads to all other
files in directory being shown as deleted.

Re: #2575

magit-ediff-show-stash: new command

Add command that runs a three-buffer Ediff on a file's state in
stash@{N}, stash@{N}^1, and stash@{N}^2, ignoring any untracked changes
in stash@{N}^3.

For choosing a file, this only focuses on files in stash@{N}^..stash@{N}
based on the reasoning that if a file was renamed in the stash, it will
be present in the merge commit stash@{N}.  Even if the file is renamed,
staged, and then deleted in the working tree before creating the stash,
it will be present in stash@{N}.  Likewise, for a file to be considered
renamed in stash@{N}, it must have been staged and will be in
stash@{N}^.

magit-diff-wash-submodule: rewrite from scratch

The old implementation was a hack, which got extended when I got myself
into a situation where the current version failed.  This time around it
was "(not checked out)" which was not handled properly.  Upon inspecting
`show_submodule_summary' in `submodules.c' it turned out that "(revision
walker failed)" also wasn't handled, and why there sometimes is a
trailing colon and sometimes not (there's a colon when commits follow,
so the colon cases should be handled separately even though that leads
to a bit of duplication).

At present, when `diff.submodule' is `log', then these are the lines we
have to look for.

    Submodule <module> contains untracked content
    Submodule <module> contains modified content
    Submodule <module> <from>...<to>:
    Submodule <module> <from>..<to>:
    Submodule <module> <from>..<to> (rewind):
    Submodule <module> <from>..<to> (submodule deleted)
    Submodule <module> <from>..<to> (not checked out)
    Submodule <module> <from>..<to> (new submodule)
    Submodule <module> <from>..<to> (commits not present)
    Submodule <module> <from>..<to> (revision walker failed)

This commit also changes how some of these variants are represented in
Magit.  Previously some information was lost in some cases.

When `diff.submodule' is `short', then there are no lines matching
"^Submodule" and `magit-diff-wash-diff' takes care of washing it.

There already where some necessary kludges in place to make this work.

Now, if the user sets the variable `magit-auto-revert-mode' or the
obsolete alias `magit-revert-buffers' to nil anytime during startup,
before or after `magit-autorevert' is loaded, then the mode is not

a similar kludge in use, which did this only for `magit-revert-buffers'.

magit-maybe-show-margin: ensure the margin is restored

If the buffer-local value of `magit-show-margin' is set, then call
`magit-set-buffer-margin' with its value as ENABLE value.

In [1: f77325e] I thought it would be enough to just forgo calling
`magit-set-buffer-margin' again with the default value of
`magit-{log,reflog}-show-margin', but that is only the case if the
buffer is still being displayed in the same window as before.  But
since margins are local to windows, we actually have to recreate
them when we might just have displayed the buffer in a new window.

Note that this only affects the selected window.  All other windows
which might be displaying the same buffer are not affected, but I've
decided that this is a feature.

Merge branch 'jb/set-remote-head' [#2520]

magit-clone: no longer create symbolic-ref origin/HEAD by default

Actually, since `git clone' always creates that symbolic-ref,
automatically *remove* that symbolic-ref right after cloning.

The default is to remove that symbolic-ref because it isn't actually
very useful.  Right after running `git clone' one knows which of the
remote branches is the "remote HEAD" without having to rely on that
symbolic-ref, because the local branch is automatically setup to use
that as upstream.  At all other times that symbolic-ref is unreliable
because it is not automatically updated then the "remote HEAD" changes.

But some users might want it anyway, so add a new option
`magit-clone-set-remote-head', which can be set to `t' to preserve the
symbolic-ref.
magit-remote-{set,unset}-head: new commands

magit-read-remote-branch: fix sanity check

If REMOTE is non-nil, then the value has the form "BRANCH", not
"REMOTE/BRANCH".  Do not throw an error if the user selects a
branch whose name that does not happen to contain a slash.

magit-branch-reset: do not set upstream by default

Resetting a branch to another branch, causes the former to be configured
as the upstream of the latter.  That behavior was introduced by accident
when the argument `--track' was replaced with the variable
`branch.autoSetupMerge' in the popup.  Because it would be undesirable
to restore the `--track' argument in the popup, one now has to use a
prefix argument to set the upstream while resetting.

Re #2517.

Fixes #2517.

magit-generate-new-buffer: deal with nil uniquify-buffer-name-style

If `uniquify-buffer-name-style' is `nil', then let-bind it
to `post-forward-angle-brackets', like we already do when
the global value is `forward'.

Fixes #2516.

magit-update-ref: new function

By default Git only maintains reflogs for refs in certain namespaces.
To force it do so for other refs it was necessary to manually create the
appropriate file .git/logs/<ref> before calling `git update-ref'.  Since
v2.6.0 that command supports the `--create-reflog' argument, and we now
use it if available.

To make that easier, wrap `git update-ref' in the new function
`magit-update-ref', which also falls back to the old approach for older
Git versions.  Also remove the function `magit-reflog-enable', which is
where the hack used to be located.

This also fixes #2515.  The old hack failed when creating a stash in a
linked working tree when the repository did not already contain another
stash.  The problem was that a file .git/worktrees/<worktree>/logs/<ref>
was created, instead of .git/logs/<ref>.  Like the `--create-reflog'
argument, support for linked working trees was added in Git v2.6.0, so
it's okay to use the old "touch file" approach for older Git versions
(not that we have a choice anyway).

default state according to `magit-{log or reflog}-show-margin', when a
command was invoked which changed what log/reflog is being displayed.

require magit in log and diff commands

The dependencies between magit libraries are not strictly linear, which
is problematic when someone uses a command that is defined in a library
that is a dependency of `magit', but that also depends on code located
in `magit', relying on autoload definitions and without first using a
command which causes `magit' to be loaded.

To work around that, require `magit' in the body of such commands.
Actually, because the diff and log entry-point commands all use
`magit-diff-setup' or `magit-log', `magit' is required inside those
functions.

Merge branch 'jb/auto-revert' [#2474]

revert buffers using a globalized variant of auto-revert-mode

Replace the old magit-specific auto-revert implementation with the
mode `magit-auto-revert-mode', a globalized variant of the built-in
`auto-revert-mode'.  By default Magit still explicitly triggers the
reverts after running git for side-effects.  Automatic reverts are
still enabled by default, and Magit is less verbose about it.  The
behavior can be tuned using `magit-auto-revert-' and `auto-revert-'
options.

The main benefit of this change is that this implementation caches
whether a file is tracked or not.  The old implementation determined
this on every revert cycle, which did not perform well when there
were many open buffers and/or many tracked files.

revert: no longer update the VC information in the mode-line

No longer add `magit-refresh-vc-mode-line' to the default value of
`magit-after-revert-hook' and `magit-not-reverted-hook', because
it causes a noticeable delay when there are many open buffers or
many tracked files.

I assume that most Magit users rely on the status buffer for status
information, not VC's mode-line information.  User who rely on that
information will have to customize the hooks.

performance), but because there is a tiny change of data loss with that
setting when combined with odd work flows I am changing the default.

Unfortunately that means that thousands of users will needlessly suffer
from bad performance, and they will certainly complain about that, but
that criticism will be pleasant in comparison to what I would have to
expect from users who lost data.

Merge branch 'jb/pull-and-fetch-popup' [#2452]

magit-pull-or-fetch-popup: new popup

Combine `magit-pull-popup' and `magit-fetch-popup' into one common
popup.  By default the old popups are still bound in `magit-mode-map'.

Add this to your init file to use the new popup:

  (with-eval-after-load 'magit-remote
    (define-key magit-mode-map "f" 'magit-pull-and-fetch-popup)
    (define-key magit-mode-map "F" nil))

One advantage of the new popup is that it is once more possible to
press the same key twice to fetch.  However that binding now is "f f",
not "F F", and it fetches all remotes not just the current remote.

The new popup also lacks the commands for fetching from only a single
remote.  You can add them to the new popup by adding something like this
to your init file:

  (with-eval-after-load 'magit-remote
    (magit-define-popup-action 'magit-pull-and-fetch-popup ?U
      'magit-get-upstream-branch
      'magit-fetch-from-upstream-remote ?F)
    (magit-define-popup-action 'magit-pull-and-fetch-popup ?P
      'magit-get-push-branch
      'magit-fetch-from-push-remote ?F))

magit-branch-prefer-remote-upstream: use saner interpretation

Do not consult `magit-branch-prefer-remote-upstream' when determining
the default choice when reading the starting-point on behalf of
`magit-branch' and `magit-branch-and-checkout'.  Just offer the branch
at point as default.  Remote branches are preferred, but no remote
branch is substituted for a local branch.

Instead make these commands behave similar to how `magit-branch-spinoff'
already behaves.  Do use the chosen starting-point as starting-point,
but possibly set the upstream of the starting-point as the upstream of
the new branch.

simplify calls to magit-read-other-branch-or-commit

Do not explicitly pass the current branch as
`magit-read-other-branch-or-commit'.  That is redundant because
that is branch which is excluded if the EXCLUDE argument is nil.

better defaults for reference completion

Add the new functions `magit-name-branch', `magit-name-local-branch',
`magit-name-remote-branch' and `magit-name-tag', and use them in the
respective `magit-{*}-at-point' functions.

This affects the various `magit-read-{*}' completions functions which
now offer the branch or tag at point as the default completion candidate
even when the type of the section at point is `commit'.

magit--push-current-to-pushremote-desc: correct description

Previously the description contained "@{push}", which isn't precise.
What is being pushed by the respective command is configured using
either `branch.<name>.pushRemote' or `branch.pushDefault'.  So we
should use "pushRemote" as the shorthand.  If these variables are
set, then "@{push}" is usually based on their values, but when they
are unset, then "@{push}" might be defined anyway, based on other
variables.

"@{push}" simply means "where `git push' would push to" (provided a
single branch is being pushed), and not "the branch on the configured
push remote we would push to".

keep "unpulled/unpushed" sections hidden when switching branch

generalize visibility cache

Currently only the visibility of `file' sections is being cached.
Generalized the code used to do so to make it possible to use the
cache for other types too.

This is done by renaming the involved symbols and adding convenience
utilities.  Also `magit-section-show' now explicitly removes entries
from the cache.

Despite the names of the new functions, it's still only possible to
store the information that a section, which by default is expanded,
should be hidden when it reappears.  That might change eventually, so
that it becomes possible to remember that sections which are hidden by
default should be expanded when they reappear.  But we don't need that
currently.

Also note that this feature should only be used selectively, using it
for every section would not be good for performance.

magit-branch-read-starting-point: new function

magit-get-@{push}-branch: new functions

The new `magit-get-@{push}-branch' and `magit-get-push-branch'
often, but not always, return the same value.  `magit-get-push-branch'
directly consults Git variables while `magit-get-@{push}-branch' runs
`git rev-parse --symbolic @{push}'.

This is an important distinction because Git considers @{push} to be
undefined when the value of the variable `push.default' does not allow
a 1:1 mapping.  At the same time `magit-get-push-branch' would happily
ignore `push.default' and return a value based on
`branch.<name>.pushRemote' or `branch.pushDefault'

Fix typos in documentation

Catched by ispell and ispell-comments-and-strings.

remove magit-specific git-variable branch.autoSetupPush

It turned out that this is not actually necessary but has downsides.

Users should instead set `remote.pushDefault' once per repository.
Doing so has the advantage that this variable affects all branches,
including branches that already exist.  `branch.autoSetupPush' on the
other hand only takes effect when new branches are being created.

Furthermore needlessly setting a variable per-branch (using
`branch.<name>.pushRemote') which could just as well be set per
repository (because it is the same for all branches) has the
disadvantage that changing that value becomes much more work.

In rare cases the push-remote of a branch might be different from that
of the other branches.  In that case `branch.<unicorn>.pushRemote'
should be set manually.  Whether `branch.autoSetupPush' exists or not,
doesn't matter, if the unicorn needs a different push-remote, then
`branch.<unicorn>.pushRemote' always has to be set explicitly.

magit-branch-popup: change some action bindings

magit-branch-popup: add the relevant variables

Add all variables to the popup that are relevant when creating a new
branch.  This allows users to see what the current values are and also
to change the values.

Also add the variables related to the current branch and the variables
that are consulted when the branch-specific variables are unset.

For each variable define the necessary command and format function.
These commands have to form `magit-VERB-VARIABLE'.  VERB is one of
"set", "edit", or "cycle".  VARIABLE is the name of the Git variable.
For branch-specific variables, VARIABLE is `branch*SUFFIX', where
"*" stands for ".<name>."

Remove `magit-branch-unset-upstream', and replace
`magit-branch-set-upstream' with `magit-cycle-branch*pushRemote' and
`magit-branch-edit-description' with `magit-edit-branch*description'.

branch.autoSetupPush: new Git variable

Add new function `magit-maybe-set-branch*pushRemote' and call it from
the commands `magit-branch' and `magit-branch-and-checkout'.  When the
variable `branch.autoSetupPush' is set, then this function sets the
value of `branch.<name>.pushRemote' to the same value.  The value has
to be an existing branch, if it is not, then it is ignored.

`branch.autoSetupPush' is a Magit invention, Git knows nothing about it.
It was inspired by the standard Git variables `branch.autoSetupMerge'
and `branch.autoSetupRebase'.
magit-{branch-edit,insert-branch}-description: move definitions

magit-pull-popup: replace --rebase with branch.<name>.rebase

improve transfer popups and their actions

Improve the popups `magit-fetch-popup', `magit-pull-popup',
`magit-push-popup' and `magit-rebase-popup', and their actions.

Each popup feature three actions which acts on the current branch and
the push-remote, the upstream, or any other source or target.  Some of
these popups also feature other actions and continue to do so.

If one of the mentioned actions isn't usable, because the branch it is
supposed to act on is not currently configured, then it is hidden.  If
such a command is invoked while it is unusable, then that now results
in a user-error.

The commands are renamed and the bindings are changed, both to increase
consistency among these popups and to be make them more self-explanatory.
Three of these commands were previously missing.

                                p: `magit-fetch-from-pushremote'
  f: `magit-fetch-current'   => u: `magit-fetch-from-upstream'
  o: `magit-fetch'           => e: `magit-fetch'

                                p: `magit-pull-from-pushremote'
  F: `magit-pull-current'    => u: `magit-pull-from-upstream'
  o: `magit-pull'            => e: `magit-pull'

  Q: `magit-push-quickly'    => p: `magit-push-current-to-pushremote'
  P: `magit-push-current'    => u: `magit-push-current-to-upstream'
  e: `magit-push-elsewhere'  => e: `magit-push-current'

The bindings of some other actions were also adjusted.

  `magit-rebase-edit-commit': e => m

popup: support functions as descriptions of actions

When the description of an action is a function, then insert its value
as the description.  If the function returns nil, then forgo inserting
the action.

This is a hack and only intended to be used for descriptions that are
actually branch names.

popup: support functions as subsection headings

When a member of one of the event lists is a function, then treat it as
a subsection heading.  Call the function and use the returned string as
the heading.  If the function returns nil, then forgo inserting the
complete subsection.

magit-pull-read-args: remove function

magit-push-current: fallback to magit-push-elsewhere or magit-push

If HEAD is detached, then fall back to `magit-push'.  If the current
branch has no upstream, then fall back to `magit-push-elsewhere'.
That is a temporary approach, eventually this command will raise an
error if HEAD is detached or the upstream is not configured.

This was the last command which still used `magit-push-read-args',
remove that now.

magit-push-elsewhere: always push the current branch

Previously this command let the user choose what branch to push;
now `magit-push' should be used for that.

If HEAD is detached, then fallback to `magit-push'.  That is a
temporary approach, eventually this command will raise an error
in that case.

magit-push: always read target

Previously the upstream branch, if any, was used without requiring
confirmation or letting the user pick another target.

use a single representation for remote branches

In Magit and the Git porcelain remote branches are often represented
using the form REMOTE/BRANCH.  However `git pull' and `git push' have
different semantics and that leaked into Magit too much.

Always use the REMOTE/BRANCH form and only convert right before calling
`git pull' and `git push':

  REMOTE/REMOTE-BRANCH-NAME
  => git pull REMOTE REMOTE-BRANCH-NAME

  LOCAL-BRANCH-NAME REMOTE/REMOTE-BRANCH-NAME
  => git push REMOTE LOCAL-BRANCH-NAME:refs/heads/REMOTE-BRANCH-NAME

The translation is done by the new function `magit-split-branch-name'.

Remove `magit-get-remote-branch', which returned (REMOTE . BRANCH).
We can now always use `magit-get-tracked-branch', which returns
REMOTE/BRANCH, or for a local branch just BRANCH.

Replace the two arguments REMOTE and REMOTE-BRANCH which a single
argument SOURCE or TARGET in many pulling and pushing commands.

magit-git-{fetch,pull,push,rebase}: new functions

Add new functions `magit-git-fetch', `magit-git-pull', `magit-git-push'
and `magit-git-rebase', and use them in many of the existing fetching,
pulling, pushing and rebasing commands.  Also make all arguments of
these commands mandatory.  When these commands are called interactively,
then all these arguments are provided, and they should no longer be
called non-interactively, the new functions should be used in that case.

  Upstream: 20abf46missingorigin/master Merge branch 'pr/no-fake-priority'
Merge branch 'pr/no-fake-priority'

stop faking negative overlay property priorities

Face attributes set in overlays always have a higher priority than the
corresponding text properties.  Magit highlights the current section
with an overlay whose face sets the background color, as a result all
text in the current section would lose its background color.

We used to fake negative priorities for such text which has a background
color, by using an overlay to set the face where one would usually use a
text property.  So instead of giving the highlighting overlay a negative
priority, i.e. one lower than the 1 priority of text properties (because
that's impossible) we instead gave the text properties a higher priority
(by using overlay properties instead).  Conceptually that was equivalent
to giving the highlighting overlay a negative priority.

But we should not have done that for three reasons:

- Giving ref labels (and a few other things) a background color caused
  the buffer to be much noisier than it otherwise would have been.  So
  at least in my opinion, giving labels a background color was not only
  a hack, and difficult and expensive, it was also undesirable.  In the
  v2.1.0 release I dropped the background color of all ref labels and a
  few other faces.  This was generally well received.

- Using overlays is inefficient, and should therefore be avoided when
  not necessary.  Every time Magit comes up Eli tells us about it.

- Using overlays complicates the code and makes necessary changes more
  difficult.

Dropping support for faked negative overlay priorities, might mean that
some third-party themes have to be adjusted.  Which is why I did not do
it in v2.1.0, but now the time has come.

magit-revert-buffers: avoid unnecessary remote connections

Before checking whether a file is inside the repository for which
buffers are being refreshed, first check whether it is at least located
on the some host, using `file-remote-p'.  This optimization is necessary
because `file-in-directory-p' calls `file-truename' on both the file as
well as the directory, which, for remote files, requires a round trip to
the remote host(s).  (It would be better if `file-in-directory-p' itself
implemented that optimization, but for now we have to do it ourselves.)

Re http://emacs.stackexchange.com/questions/17929.

magit-stash-drop: verbosely to be able to undo mistakes

When a branch is deleted then the old hash is printed to the process log
buffer.  We would like to do the same thing here, but unfortunately that
is not possible because `git reflog delete --verbose ...' does not print
the commit hash as one would expect.  Instead it prints the commit
message, which is quite useless.

So instead we have to print similar information using `message'.

magit-toplevel: ignore .git/gitdir

4d035b5 (magit-toplevel: return correct wtree from within
.git/worktrees/ID, 2015-10-15) taught magit-toplevel to look in
.git/worktrees/<name>/gitdir to find the worktree path.  However,
magit-toplevel now also reads .git/gitdir if it exists, which contains
".git" rather than a linked worktree.  In this case, magit-toplevel
fails to identify the top-level despite being inside a repo.

These .git/gitdir files are created in a repo when a .git file specifies
a gitdir path that points to the repo.  They result from a bug [1] that
is present in at least the version 2.6.2 release and that was likely
introduced in version 2.5.2.

Add a check to prevent this file from being processed as a worktree
gitdir file.

[1] http://thread.gmane.org/gmane.comp.version-control.git/280307/focus=280313

Re: #2364

magit-clone: use magit-convert-git-filename

The problem this avoids is that while cygwin does mostly support win32
paths as well, when git clone does the equivalent of "mkdir -p
c:/tmp/magit" it splits by slash and makes each of "c:", "c:/tmp", and
"c:/tmp/magit".  Under cygwin, creating "c:" means making a directory
called "c" (cygwin uses a special unicode encoding for characters that
would otherwise be illegal for Windows filesystems) in the current
directory.  Therefore we must convert to a cygwin path to avoid this
extra directory being created.

magit-clone: don't create parent dirs of dest

git already creates these directories, as of 2008 Jun 25
(8e21d63b02f1b26f7695ca515e51e4622a995af2 "clone: create intermediate
directories of destination repo").

This reverts 2e9f833f508894bad674857be30128d04a776a71 "magit-clone:
create parent directories of destination".

If a buffer exists which visits the file to be blamed and if it has
unsaved changes, then unconditionally save it.  Saving the buffer is

and so the line numbers it prints would not correspond to the line
numbers in the buffer.

Merge branch 'dc/auth-source' [#2311]

magit-process-find-password-functions: new option

Add new option `magit-process-find-password-functions' and advertise
adding `magit-process-password-auth-sources' to its value, but do not
actually do so.

We don't use that function by default, because most users will be
unaware of this functionality and that might cause issues.  For example
a user may have configured `auth-source' at some point, and then stopped
using it and also changed the password without also changing it in the
source used by `auth-source'.  In such a case `auth-source' would return
the wrong password and that would then be feed to git.  The user likely
would not note that this is what is happening and report a Magit defect.

Try to find the password before asking user

When git asks the user for a password, this patch first asks the auth-source library. If no password is found, prompt the user.

magit-diff-wash-diffstat: prevent invalid hash

As of 36fb789 (populate revision buffers using section inserter
functions, 2015-08-27), making a log with --stat and without --graph
results in a log like

    19a19a6 magit-maybe-save-[...]
    1 file changed, 2 insertions(+), 1 deletion(-)
    lisp/magit-mode.el | 3 ++-

 -> 26e688 improve [...]
    3 files changed, 30 insertions(+), 19 deletions(-)
    Documentation/magit.org  |  4 ++--
    Documentation/magit.texi |  4 ++--
    lisp/magit-mode.el       | 41 ++++++++++++++++++++++++++---------------

where the first characters of all hashes following the first entry are
deleted.

Instead of deleting a character after inserting a diffstat, move forward
if looking at a blank line (which is true in revision and diff buffers).
Otherwise, insert a newline (which is true in non-graph log buffers with
--stat).

limit diff washing when creating log

Add limit argument to magit-diff-wash-diffs, and use it in
magit-log-wash-rev to prevent the diff washing from going beyond the
next commit.

magit-toplevel: fix gitdir of submodule over Tramp case

When the control directory of a submodule is located inside the
.modules/ subdirectory of the control direct of the super repository,
then `git rev-parse --show-cdup' returns an absolute filename, which
makes `expand-file-name' on that filename a no-op.

When that directory is on a remote host accessed using Tramp, then
that means that `expand-file-name' does not expand the filename to
also include the remote part of `default-directory'.

So we have to add that explicitly.

magit-status-maybe-update-{revision,blob}-buffer: new functions

These are variants of `magit-status-maybe-update-revision-buffer'
and `magit-status-maybe-update-blob-buffer', which are adjusted to

separate updating of revision and blob buffers

Add new hook functions `magit-log-maybe-update-revision-buffer'
and `magit-log-maybe-update-blob-buffer', and add the former to the
hook `magit-section-movement-hook'.  They replace the hook function
`magit-log-maybe-show-commit' which previously was a member of that
hook.

Remove the variable `magit-update-other-window-timer' variable, the two
functions now use separate variables `magit--update-revision-buffer' and
`magit--update-blob-buffer' to prevent multiple timers from running in
parallel.  There may be two timers now, one for the revision buffer and
one for the blob buffer.

Remove the option `magit-diff-auto-show' is removed.  To disable the
automatic updates of the revision buffer, users now have to remove a
hook function from `magit-section-movement-hook', and to enable updates
of the blob buffer, they have to add a function to that hook variable.

Define `magit-section-movement-hook' as an option.

Due to the removal of `magit-update-other-window-timer' the function
`magit-blame-maybe-update-revision-buffer' has to be adjusted too.

magit-diff-auto-show: drop log-oneline variant

Previously `log-oneline' was the only remaining member of
`magit-diff-auto-show'.  It is being replaced with `log-follow'.

`magit-log-maybe-show-commit' now only ever updates the revision
buffer being displayed in another window of the same frame.  It
does not automatically displays the buffer in another window if
it is not already being displayed.  The user now has to create
the buffer and window once, by pressing `SPC'.

magit-diff-auto-show: drop blame-follow variant

`magit-blame-maybe-update-revision-buffer' now updates the revision
buffer without consulting an user option.  To turn off automatic updates
to the revision buffer when moving through a blamed file, one now has to
remove that function from `magit-blame-goto-chunk-hook'.

Add new option `magit-commit-show-diff' to control whether a diff for

magit-mode-get-buffer: avoid default-directory test

If default-directory is used to check for an existing buffer, an
inappropriate magit buffer may be returned if its default-directory is
let-bound.  This is a similar problem as discussed in #2054 and #2060.
01cf031 (don’t bind default-directory to pass topdir to
magit-mode-setup, 2015-07-13) changed magit-status-internal to bind
magit-mode-setup--topdir instead of default-directory.  This fixes the
corner case with C-u C-u magit-status, but can still fail on third-party
code that let-binds default-directory.

One example of this is switching projectile projects with projectile-vc
as the action.  To switch to a new project, default-directory is
let-bound to the new project's root and then projectile-vc calls
magit-status-internal.  But if this is done from a status buffer that
doesn't belong to the new project, magit-mode-get-buffer mistakenly
thinks the current status buffer belongs to that new project and updates
it with the status of the new project.

To avoid this, add a new buffer-local variable,
magit--default-directory, and set it to the value of default-directory
when the buffer is created.  This makes the magit-mode-setup--topdir
variable (now called magit-mode-get-buffer--topdir) unnecessary.
magit-maybe-save-repository-buffers: avoid repeating message

improve after-save refreshing of status buffer

Rename `magit-refresh-status' to `magit-after-save-refresh-status'.
Also ensure that a save which was triggered by a refresh, does not
in turn trigger a refresh, and delay refreshes that were triggered
by saves until `post-command-hook' to avoid refreshing the same
buffer more than once.

magit-discard-files: avoid collateral damage

When deleting "the untracked files inside a directory", then do just
that.  Do not also delete the tracked files in the directory.
magit-untracked-files: add FILES argument

magit-generate-new-buffer: check uniquify style

magit-buffer-name-format requires %t to be at the end for uniquify to
work properly.  However, if uniquify-buffer-name-style is set to
`forward', the buffer names are inappropriately formed as
"path/*magit: repo".

assert that remote git can be found and is recent enough

In `magit-status-internal' call the new `magit-tramp-assert' to make
sure that when it shows the status of a remote repository using Tramp
git can be found on the host and that it is recent enough.

For local repositories `magit-tramp-assert' bails quickly and is not
very expensive.  Once `magit-tramp-assert' has found a good git for a
given host, then it caches that information.

The assert is only performed in `magit-status-internal' because it
(`magit-status' actually) it the main entry point.
magit-version: warn about unknown Magit and/or Git
magit-git-version: new function
magit--minimal-{git,emacs}: new constants
magit-stash-sections-hook: fix order
magit-display-buffer-traditional: display stash in other window
with-editor: replace occurrences of "looping" with "sleeping"

use remap bindings in section keymaps

Bind [remap magit-visit-thing] instead of "\r" and
bind [remap magit-delete-thing] instead of "k" in
all section keymaps that previously used the latter.

This allows binding other keys to these commands in `magit-mode-map'
and having that take affect in the section keymaps without having to
also change any bindings in these keymaps.
README.md: mention Kyle and Noam as maintainers
magit.el: mention Kyle and Noam as maintainers in library header
magit-refresh-status: new function
magit.org: take recent changes to key bindings into account

add new magit-maybe-show-margin to magit-mode-setup-hook

It's intentional that `magit-log-show-margin' is
not respected in `magit-reflog-mode' buffers.

run magit-mode-setup-hook after displaying the buffer

In [1: 9eb318b] the order of of events in `magit-mode-setup' was
changed from

  1. display buffer
  2. run setup hook
  3. turn on mode
  4. refresh buffer

to

  2. run setup hook
  3. turn on mode
  1. display buffer
  4. refresh buffer

because `magit-display-buffer's behavior now depends on the major-mode.
I considered removing `magit-mode-setup-hook' completely because given
the above order of events it is not necessary, one could just use
`magit-mode-hook' or a more specific `magit-{*}-mode-hook'.

But it turns out we actually need a hook that runs after displaying the
buffer (see next commit).  So change the order to

  3. turn on mode
  1. display buffer
  2. run setup hook
  4. refresh buffer

By the way, it would be preferable if we could use this order

  3. turn on mode
  1. display buffer
  4. refresh buffer
  2. run setup hook

but that is currently not possible because some section inserters only
work properly if the buffer the insert into, is being displayed in a
window.  Also note that `magit-display-buffer' has to run outside any
`with-current-buffer' or `safe-current-buffer' forms.

Also define `magit-mode-setup-hook' as an option instead of as an
undocumented variable.

1: 9eb318b02a5d2df127c213ab11a3ff199a7e9301
   concentrate display-buffer logic in one place
magit-process-sentinel: remove old debugging binding

magit-process-sentinel: refresh even if buffer is no longer alive

Call `magit-refresh' even if the buffer that was current when the buffer
was started is no longer alive.  This ensures that the status buffer is
refreshed.

magit-refresh: refresh status buffer regardless of current buffer

Refresh the status buffer even if the major-mode of the current buffer
does not derive from `magit-mode'.
Makefile: clean some more generated files
Merge branch 'jb/display-buffer' [#2282]
2.3.0.txt: add entries for #2282
magit-bury-buffer-function: move definition
support locking a magit buffer to its current value
magit-buffer-name-format: new option

uniquify names of magit buffers by default

Add new option `magit-uniquify-buffer-names' with a default value of t.

Due to how `uniquify.el' is implemented, buffer name cannot be made
unique before they have been created, so part of this has to be
implemented in `magit-generate-new-buffer'.

Modes are added to `uniquify-list-buffers-directory-modes' on demand
instead of upfront, because this way derived modes implemented in
third-party extensions are automatically taken care of.

find existing magit buffers by mode instead of by name

Also remove the command `magit-rename-buffer', because renaming a buffer
no longer prevents it from being reused to display different values.  A
different mechanism to lock a buffer to a value will be added in a later
commit.

magit-generate-buffer-name-function: new option

Add new option `magit-generate-buffer-name-function' and new function
`magit-generate-buffer-name-default-function' as its default value.

Also add new function `magit-generate-new-buffer' as a wrapper around
the calls to `magit-generate-buffer-name-function' and
`generate-new-buffer'.

remove redundant code which sanitizes directory paths

In `magit-mode-get-buffer' and `magit-status-internal' remove redundant
code which sanitizes directory paths.  We don't have to do this here
because all we do with these paths is to feed them to `magit-toplevel',
which already takes care of expanding the directory as necessary.
rename magit-mode-{setup => get-mode}--topdir

magit-mode-get-buffer-create: remove function

It was no longer used more than once, and that one caller can
just use `magit-mode-get-buffer' directly with a non-nil value
for the CREATE argument.

magit-process-buffer: don't use magit-mode-get-buffer-create

We already did not use `magit-mode-setup' in order to avoid unnecessary
work every time a process is run for side-effects and because that would
run `magit-mode-hook' which by default results in git being run, which
could have lead to an error (see below).

Now `magit-process-buffer' also finds or else creates the buffer itself,
instead of using `magit-mode-get-buffer-create' for that purpose.

If `default-directory' isn't inside a repository, then it walks up the
directory until it finds "the" root directory (usually "/", but when
using Tramp or MS Windows, then something else), and finds or creates
the buffer for that directory.  Even if the root directory isn't also
the toplevel of a repository (which it seldom is) it is never-the-less
used in the buffer name, e.g. *magit-process: /*, and as the
`default-directory' of that buffer.

Previously when this function was called for the first time with a
`default-directory' that isn't located inside a repository, then a
buffer *magit-process: -* was create and the `default-directory' which
was current when this function was called was used as the buffer-local
value.  That value was never changed, which was a problem if that
directory was ever deleted (e.g. the `magit-mode-hook' issue mentioned
above).

take full advantage of magit-display-buffer-noselect

Remove the NOSELECT argument of `magit-show-commit' and
`magit-show-stash', and stop let-binding `magit-display-buffer-noselect'
inside these commands.

Instead let-bind `magit-display-buffer-no-select' directly in their
callers `magit-diff-show-or-scroll', `magit-log-maybe-show-commit',
and `magit-blame-update-other-window'.

concentrate display-buffer logic in one place

Use low-level `display-buffer' instead of high-level buffer switching
functions.  In combination with other changes described below, this
gives users complete control over how buffers are to be displayed,
without having to fight against hard-coded defaults.

Instead of hard-coding the rules that govern how windows are selected to
display certain buffers, define them in one place.  The existing rules
are collected in the new function `magit-display-buffer-traditional'.

That function is the default value of the new option
`magit-display-buffer-function', which specifies the function used by
`magit-display-buffer' to actually display the buffer.

All Magit buffers are displayed using `magit-display-buffer', which is
called by `magit-mode-setup' and `magit-process-buffer'.  Together these
two functions are responsible for the creation of each and every Magit
buffer.  `magit-display-buffer' should never called directly by anything
else. (Popup buffers are not Magit buffers, their major-mode does not
derived from `magit-mode'.)

Unlike `display-buffer', `magit-display-buffer' also selects the window,
unless the new variable `magit-display-buffer-noselect' is let-bound to
a non-nil value.  This variable is only intended for special cases.

Two options, and therefore quick ways of customizing the behavior, fall
victim to this change: `magit-status-buffer-switch-function' and
`magit-diff-switch-buffer-function'.  We cannot preserve these options
and use them in `magit-display-buffer-traditional' because they were
used to specify arbitrary high-level buffer switching functions, which
we cannot simply map to low-level display actions.

magit-{pre,post}-display-buffer-hook: new variables

Also rename `magit-mode-display-buffer' to `magit-display-buffer'.
magit-mode-setup: define as a function

magit-mode-hook: add magit-xref-setup

Instead of hard-coding that in `magit-mode-setup'.

magit-process-buffer: absorb magit-process

Define `magit-process-buffer' as a command, replacing the very badly
named command `magit-process'.  Also by default display the buffer,
because many of the callers, not just the user, need that.  Add new
optional NODISPLAY argument for the callers that don't.

magit-process-buffer: truncate sections if appropriate

Now that `magit-process-buffer' always creates the buffer if it doesn't
exist yet, we can perform all the housekeeping here.  When appropriate
truncate the sections here instead of in `magit-process-setup'.
magit-process-buffer: always create buffer if it doesn't exist yet
magit-process-finish: determine process buffer just once

derive name of refresh function from mode name

Remove the buffer-local variable `magit-refresh-function' and
`magit-mode-setup's REFRESH-FUNC argument, which was used to set the
former.

Instead `magit-refresh-buffer' determines the name of the refresh
function based on the name of the mode.  If that function is defined,
then it is used to refresh the buffer, otherwise the buffer is not
refreshed.

This is possible because the names of all refreshers consistently follow
this naming schema.  Not passing the value around has the advantage that
the code gets simpler and it also helps enforcing this convention.

`magit-process-mode' is currently the only mode without a corresponding
refresher function.

remove DIRECTORY argument of magit-mode-get-buffer et al.

Remove `magit-mode-get-buffer's PWD argument,
remove `magit-mode-get-buffer-create's DIRECTORY argument, and
remove `magit-process-buffer's PWD argument.

The only real purpose these arguments served was that this allowed not
raising an error when `magit-process-buffer' requested a buffer outside
any repository.

The place where we assert that we are inside a repository moves from
`magit-mode-setup' to `magit-mode-get-buffer' and we now explicitly
check whether the mode is `magit-process-mode' in which case we don't
raise an error.  This allows removing the confusing "directory"
arguments.

remove magit-{*}-buffer-name-format options

This temporarily removes the ability to change the buffer names.

magit-mode-get-buffer{,-create}: remove FORMAT argument

Remove the FORMAT argument.  Instead derive the variable whose value
should be used as the format string used to create the buffer-name
from the MODE argument.  We already did that before, but the FORMAT
still existed and allowed to override the format which now isn't
possible anymore.

magit-mode-setup: derive the buffer-name format from the mode

Remove the FORMAT argument.  Instead derive the variable whose value
should be used as the format string used to create the buffer-name from
the MODE argument.  The code which does this is already in place in
`magit-mode-get-buffer-create', so `magit-mode-setup' just has to call
that with `nil' as FORMAT.

Also switch the positions of `magit-mode-setup's MODE and SWITCH-FUNC
arguments.

magit-mode-setup: remove redundant code

`magit-toplevel' already respects `find-file-visit-truename',
so we don't need to fixup the value returned by that function
when that variable is non-nil.

magit-mode-{setup,display-buffer}: re-calibrate responsibilities

Determine, and if necessary create, the buffer inside `magit-mode-setup'
instead of inside `magit-display-buffer'.

For both functions the first argument previously had to a buffer or a
buffer-name format string.  Now `magit-mode-setup' expects a format
string and `magit-mode-display-buffer' expects a buffer.  Additionally
`magit-mode-display-buffer's MODE and TOPDIR arguments are removed
(they were only necessary in order to create the buffer), it no longer
performs any sanity checks, and it no longer returns the buffer (the
callers already know the buffer).

magit-mode-{setup,display-buffer}: remove doc-strings for now

I don't want to massage them during refactoring.

squash! magit-mode-display-buffer: remove doc-string
magit.org: update section on quitting windows
magit-refresh-buffer-hook: fix doc-string
magit-refs-namespaces: improve doc-string

magit-{after-revert,not-reverted}-hook: improve doc-strings

I.e. mention the other hook.
magit-save-repository-buffers: recommend `dontask' setting

magit-git-debug: warn that it is only intended for debugging

Also, since we are talking about the executable
talk about "git" instead of "Git".
magit-revert-buffers: recommend `silent' setting
add all major-modes to a Custom group

change Custom group of some options

The `magit' group should only be used for options that are "truly"
global and/or which are so important that we want to increase the
odds that most users actually read their description and make a
conscious choice.
magit-log-wash-rev: fix #2316

magit-pop-revision-stack-format: support arguments

Allow git show arguments to be specified to give more control over the
format.  For example, this makes it possible to use --date=short to
create a point format like the one frequently used by git.git:

  4679d9b (implement a revision stack for inserting revs into messages,
  2015-09-22)

magit-pop-revision-stack: rework eob formatting

* Go to the beginning of a comment block at the end of the buffer
  instead of the first commented line in the buffer, which might not be
  the same position (and can even be before point).

* Make sure entries start on newline, which wasn't the case when a
  buffer with no commented lines did not end in a newline.

* Consistently add spaces before and between entries.  This was already
  the case if the buffer contained commented lines.  When there were no
  commented lines, no spaces were inserted before the first entry or
  between the entries.

magit-copy-section-value: extend doc-string

Mention magit-pop-revision-stack so that there is a more useful link to
follow in the help buffer.  Its doc-string provides a good description
of the revision stack functionality, unlike magit-revision-stack, which
is undocumented.
fix typos in revision stack documentation
magit-pop-revision-stack-format: fix type spec
magit-git-environment must be a list
fix fresh apply bugs

Use the "real" git of Git for Windows 2+

Git for Windows 2.x reorganized the directory structure so both cmd/git
and bin/git are just wrappers that call the real thing.  Try to find and
use the "real" one instead (it's faster) by executing `which' via the
wrapper.  We also need to set PATH so that git can find all its
utitilities and dlls, this can be retrieved from the wrapper as well.

close #2259

git-commit-setup: handle cygwin paths

Cygwin git passes paths like /cygdrive/c/foo/.git/COMMIT_EDITMSG which
causes windows-nt Emacs to look for the non-existent
c:/cygdrive/c/foo/.git/COMMIT_EDITMSG.  We now attempt to switch to
c:/foo/.git/COMMIT_EDITMSG in thise case.

Re https://github.com/magit/magit/issues/2284#issuecomment-143927798
Merge branch 'jb/apply-selection' [#2271]

magit-discard-hunks: new function

`magit-discard' now supports all scopes.
magit-discard-{region,hunk,file,apply-n}: new functions
magit-discard-files--discard: rearrange
magit-discard-files--discard: don't raise bogus user-error

magit-reverse-hunks: new function

`magit-reverse' now supports all scopes.
magit-reverse-{region,hunk,file}: new functions

magit-reverse-files: don't use magit-reverse-apply

Instead use `magit-apply-diff' or `magit-apply-diffs' directly.

magit-apply-{diffs,hunks,-get-selection}: new functions

Previously "regular apply" was the only apply variant which did not
support applying multiple files at once.  Now it is among the first
variants to support all scopes (the others being stage and unstage),
including multiple hunks.
magit-apply-patch: support multiple sections as first argument
magit-apply-patch: expect a file section as first argument

magit-apply--get-diffs: new function

Currently only `magit-apply-diff' (from which the code in the new
function derives) uses it.  But soon `magit-apply-diffs' will use
it directly.

magit-apply: use magit-am-popup for multiple untracked files

Fall back to calling `magit-am-popup' when the user has selected
multiple untracked files.  Previously we only did that for a single
file.

apply: add dummy implementations for unsupported scopes

In the dispatcher commands of all apply variants mention each diff scope
explicitly in the `pcase' form.  This makes it obvious that `hunks' were
never handled at all.  They still aren't handled properly, but at least
they are now handled like a single `hunk'.  Similarly `magit-apply' did
not handle `files' at all (all other apply variants already do), but now
they are at least handled like a single `file'.

apply: avoid more unnecessary refreshes and wip saves

Remove the variable `magit-apply-inhibit-wip'.  Instead of consulting
that variable `magit-apply-patch' now consults `inhibit-magit-refresh',
and if that is set it neither refreshes nor saves to the wip refs.

The end result is the same, except that `magit-reverse-files' now not
only avoids needlessly saving to the wip refs, but also avoids repeated
refreshes.
magit-region-sections: add TYPES argument
limit number of commits in reflogs and selection logs again

magit-section-goto-successor: bugfix

File sections with previously unresolved conflicts but which haven't
been staged since those were resolved, may not have any children.
magit-stash-drop: speedup dropping multiple stashes

magit-reset-index: behave as advertised

Fixes #2296.
magit-stash-format-patch: new command

magit-popup-mode-setup: add kludge to force proper window start

In v24.4 `fit-window-to-buffer' seems to "fit to buffer, except for the
whitespace at the end of it".  In v25.0.50 it does even scroll the
window down so that the beginning of the buffer is no longer visible in
the window.

By counting the lines in the buffer and passing that as the MIN-HEIGHT
to `fit-window-to-buffer', we avoid these issues.
Merge branch 'jb/log-misc' [#2226]

use regular `commit' section type in stash buffers

This is necessary to allow creating patches from the individual
commits that form the stash.  Also there's not really any benefit
in using different section types for the sections in stash buffers.

Also change the headings of these commit sections - now that the
header-line shows the stash number, that information no longer has
to repeated for each commit section.
use header-line in stash buffers

magit-log-{popup,buffer-file}: add `-L' argument

Support is pretty basic and will be improved eventually.  It won't be
improved incrementally, i.e. I won't add related arguments as they are
being requested, but only when I feel that the time to do so has come,
i.e. once I have the time to tackle this exciting area of Git properly.

magit-log-popup: add `-S' argument

Also change the key bindings for the `--grep=' and `-G' arguments.

don't use a separate variable for the `-n' log argument

Add the `-n' argument to the `magit-log-popup' and add "-n256" to the
default value of `magit-log-arguments', and in turn remove the variable
`magit-log-cutoff-length'.

This will lead to invalid reports about a performance regression in the
log buffer.  But what actually happened is that the user customized the
global value of `magit-log-arguments' and that value did not get updated
when the default values was changed.  Instruct users to add "-n256" to
the customized value.

This change is motivated by the drastic difference in showing a log with
and without diffs.  It should therefore be possible to quickly increase
and decrease the number of shown commits, without having to customize a
variable manually (i.e. not from the popup or using a dedicated
command).

Also add new the commands `magit-log-toggle-commit-limit',
`magit-log-double-commit-limit', and `magit-log-half-commit-limit' to
make this even easier, and replacing `magit-log-show-more-commits'.

For reflogs we no longer impose a limit because they never come with
graphs and washing them is quick.
support showing more inline information for commits in logs

magit-log-wash-rev: wash inline diffs

Teach `magit-log-wash-rev' how to detect and wash inline diffs.
This is only possible when no graph is shown.  When the graph is
shown then this still displays an unwashed, non-actionable diff
as printed by git.

support showing actionable diffs inside commit sections

This just teaches a few functions what to do when they encounter such
commits whose children are files, whose children are hunks.  We don't
actually use this feature yet, but will start doing so in subsequent
commits.

use same washer function for oneline and verbose log variants

Remove the washer functions `magit-log-wash-verbose' and
`magit-log-wash-line' (which was used for all other variants beside
"verbose") and replace them with `magit-log-wash-rev' (which is now
used for all variants).

That's not very nice, this function is turning into a monstrosity and
it's only going to get worse over the next few commits.  Eventually
this has to be split up, but right now combining the two variants is
the right thing to do.

The verbose log now shows the same oneline summary as the "oneline"
variant instead of something resembling `--format=medium'.  This
will come back in a different form in a few commits (in the form of
the `++header' argument).  The term "verbose" now only refers to the
use of an argument like `--patch' or `--stat' (i.e. we should stop
talking about "verbose" logs).

magit-log-remove-graph-args: new option

Add variable `magit-log-remove-graph-args' replacing the old
`magit-log-remove-graph-re', because that makes it easier to
change the value.
magit-reflog-show-margin: new option
magit-log-refresh-popup: show all arguments in log buffers
Merge branch 'jb/reflog-margin' [#2300]
reflog: don't show author in margin
magit-format-log-margin: insert the date even if AUTHOR is nil

reflog: show the dates recorded in the reflog file

Re #2297.
magit-commit-{extend,reword}: update documentation

w-ed-emacsclient-version: handle empty output

This avoids throwing an error when trying emacsclientw.exe which
displays output in popup dialog boxes instead of stdout.

with-editor-debug: use full paths

This is required if there are paths with-editor-emacsclient-path that
are not on exec-path.
with-editor-debug: handle nil server-socket-dir

w-ed-locate-emacsclient: don't shell-quote result

Only shell-quote when passing things to shell: i.e. in the `with-editor'
macro.

magit-log-refresh-buffer: disable graph speed hack for some args

When calling `git rev-list' to determine the number of commits, so that
`git log --graph' can later be called with a limited range to avoid
needlessly calculating the graph for the complete history, use all the
specified arguments.  Otherwise we might end up limiting the history too
much.

When certain arguments are used, that would actually double the time it
takes to determine the commits to be shown (because we would be doing it
twice), which by far outweighs what we gain from avoiding to needlessly
calculate the complete graph.

Add new variable `magit-log-disable-graph-hack-args' which lists these
arguments and consult it in `magit-log-refresh-buffer' when determining
whether the hack should be used or not.

Fixes #2287.

magit-commit-{extend,reword}-override-date: change default to t

I.e. behave like Git would by default.  This change is primarily
motivated by the realization that the committer date is what gets
recorded in reflog files when modifying HEAD and recording a fantasy
date here can be confusing.

Re #2297.
magit-mode-map: bind "U" to magit-unstage-all again

magit-toplevel: use magit-expand-git-file-name for Cygwin

Fixes #2284.

magit-bisect-run: fix implementation and use

* Add `magit-bisect-run' as a sequence action of `magit-bisect-popup'.
  Previously it was only offered as a regular action, but did not work
  when used that way.

* Teach `magit-bisect-run' how to start bisecting if no bisecting
  sequence is in progress yet, i.e when called as a regular action.

* Describe `magit-bisect-run' using "Start script" resp. "Run script",
  and bind "s" to this command, when used as a regular action and also
  when used as a sequence action.

Re #2294.

use vc-refresh-state when available

In Emacs v25.1 `vc-find-file-hook' will be renamed to `vc-refresh-state'.
Use the latter if it is available, else fallback to the old name.

magit-pull-{,current}: use magit-run-git-with-editor

While the `magit-pull-popup' does not feature the `--edit' switch, a
user might have added that herself or set GIT_MERGE_AUTOEDIT to yes,
so we have to make sure git knows how to call home.  To do that use
`magit-run-git-with-editor' instead of `magit-run-git-async' as we
usually do in such cases.

Fixes #2285.

magit-ediff-resolve: clean up failed resolution

When the user indicates that the resolution was unsuccessful, don't
modify the original buffer.  This prevents markers like

    ++<<<<<<< HEAD
    [...]
    ++||||||| parent of [...]
    [...]
    ++=======
    [...]
    ++>>>>>>> [...]

from being converted to

    ++<<<<<<< variant A
    [...]
    ++>>>>>>> variant B
    [...]
    ++####### Ancestor
    [...]
    ++======= end

Re: #2289.

magit--with-safe-default-directory: support Tramp and MS Windows

"/" isn't always "the root".

Use the "noglob" option on Cygwin and MSYS2

By default, Cygwin and MSYS2 executables attempt to expand globs when
called by a program other than a Unix shell.  The intent is to provide
globbing when, for instance, using Cygwin's grep from the Windows
command prompt.

However, this causes problems when calling the Cygwin or MSYS2 git from
Magit in a native Windows Emacs.  The solution is to detect this
behavior and, when present, add "noglob" to the "CYGWIN" and "MSYS"
environment variables to disable it.

See https://cygwin.com/cygwin-ug-net/using-cygwinenv.html

magit-commit-diff: respect diff arguments

If the diff arguments aren't passed, the return value of
magit-diff-arguments is unintentionally affected in future calls.  For
example, even if the magit-diff-arguments return value included --stat
before the commit, a revision buffer created after a magit-commit-diff
call will not have a diffstat section (assuming the diff buffer is still
around and the arguments haven't been explicitly changed since the
commit).

Drop file restrictions so that the commit diff always shows the full set
of changes.  The act of committing probably shouldn't reset file
restrictions that would otherwise be carried over between non-commit
diff calls, but this was already the situation before this change, and
it seems better than limiting the commit diff to a set a files from a
previous diff, which is unlikely to be what the user intended.

magit-rebase-popup: change two bindings

Bind "i" instead of "e" to `magit-rebase-[i]nteractive'.
Bind "e" instead of "s" to `magit-rebase-[e]dit-commit'.

Such changes are often not well received, so here we go:

Back in the days before I even used Magit, "r" was bound to a primitive
rebase command and "e" was bound to a primitive interactive rebase
command, probably "i" was already used for something else.  Eventually I
improved these rebase variants and added additional variants, all of
which are usually being invoked from the new rebase popup.  Both "r" and
"e" were bound to the popup command to make the transition easier.

So it was possible to press "rr" to start a non-interactive rebase and
"ee" for an interactive rebase (of course "er" and "re" would have
worked too).  But then some new, unrelated commands were added and we
needed to find keys that could be bound to those.  That's how the rebase
popup lost the privilege of being the only command which has two
top-level bindings, and only "r" remained.

Inside the popup we kept "e" bound to the interactive rebase variant,
because, as you are probably aware of if you read this, changing key
bindings lets muscle memory go to waste and some people find that very
disturbing.

But because in this case maintaining the old bindings leads to many
inconsistencies, I have decided to fix it now - the complains will pass.

"interactive" begins with "i" not "e".  The rebase popup also features
an "--interactive" switch in addition to the "interactive" command (this
switch allows turning the non-interactive actions into interactive
actions, which can be useful in some cases).  That switch's binding is
"-i" not "-e".  The popup also features a "edit only this particular
commit" variant `magit-rebase-[e]dit-commit' which originally "s" was
bound to because "e" was taken (cannot remember why "s", probably
because it is used to change a [s]ingle commit).  That command was
invoked using "rs" and was a shorthand for "ree".  The "s" and "e" serve
the same purpose here so they should be the same key, and after this
change they are: "re" and "rie".

magit-log-refresh-buffer: handle non-existing rev

address issues concerning `git read-tree'

The macro `magit-with-temp-index' used `git read-tree' to create a
temporary index file.  Only reading into the index without performing a
merge is expensive, so it is preferable to use `-m' to perform a merge.
But then the command would refuse to run if there are any conflicts.

The needs of the various users of this macro are different and so they
need to be able to specify whether `-m' is should be used or not, and
whether any other arguments should be used.

Add a new argument ARG to `magit-with-temp-index' as well as to
`magit-commit-worktree'.  In both cases this can be a single argument or
a list of arguments (but we don't need that currently).  Then adjust the
users.

When creating a stash `magit-stash-create' uses `magit-with-temp-index'
twice.  In one case the TREE is nil, so ARG is irrelevant and we pass
nil for that too.  In the other case we pass `-m' to avoid the slowdown
and also because we want to error out if there is a conflict.

When creating a wip commit `magit-wip-commit-index' now passes `--reset'
to `magit-with-temp-index' to avoid the slowdown and to add the conflict
to the index, pretending it was resolved.  If there is a conflict then
it is staged including the conflict markers.  This actually is what we
want, we want to save the current state of the *file* (not the index),
including possibly partially resolved conflicts.

In `magit-sequence-insert-sequence' a dummy commit is created using
`magit-commit-worktree'.  It is used to figure out whether the changes
introduced by the stopped at commit still exists in the worktree.  Here
we use `--reset' to avoid the slowdown and in case there are conflicts
any errors.

magit-sequence-insert-sequence: don't assume ONTO is non-nil

For cherry-pick and revert sequences ONTO is nil when stopping at the
last commit to be applied (because Git discards that information to
early).  If that happens, then use "HEAD" instead.

avoid `git log --graph' inefficiency

`git log --graph --max-count=N' calculates the graph for the complete
history; the `--max-count=N' only affects the output phase.

`git log --graph HEAD~N..HEAD' only calculates the graph for
HEAD~N..HEAD but the graph is not the same; commits that are reachable
from HEAD but do not descend from HEAD~N will appear as root commits.

Address this by using `--max-count' and REV~M..REV to together when
possible.  More precisely do so when showing the log for a single rev
in the log buffer.  M is usually twice as large as N but at least 1024,
which greatly reduces the risk of the graphs for REV~M..REV and REV to
differ.

In the status buffer also limit the range for the log section inserted
by `magit-insert-recent-commits', but without avoiding that non-root
commits appear as root commits (because that happens for the sections
inserted by `magit-insert-{unpulled and unpushed}-commits' too).

Also see http://www.spinics.net/lists/git/msg232230.html.

Merge branch 'jb/goto-to-next-change-block' [#2227]

* jump to next block of changed lines after staging region

jump to next block of changed lines after staging region

After using the region to stage or discard parts of a hunk, jump to
the beginning of the next block of changed lines.  After staging the
last block, instead jump to the previous block.  This is implemented
using regexp searches, not by counting lines.

Previously we just jumped to the beginning of "the" hunk (staging a
region may add or remove a hunk), but that can be very far away from
where point previously was.

It might be better to jump to "the next line which still exists",
but it would be rather complicated to figure out what line that is.

This function was previously named `magit-xref-insert-buttons',

populate diff buffers using section inserter functions

Instead of inserting the diff directly in `magit-diff-refresh-buffer',
just run the new hook `magit-diff-sections-hook', which for now has
just one member, the new function `magit-insert-diff'.

This is mostly done for consistency with how other buffers are created.

populate revision buffers using section inserter functions

Instead of avoiding to call git more than absolutely necessary, use
several separate section inserter functions which can be reordered,
removed or extended using the new `magit-revision-sections-hook'.

This simplifies parsing, makes this more customizable, and prepares
for faster, asynchronously created diffs.

Call `magit-revision-insert-related-refs' earlier in
`magit-diff-wash-revision', placing them right after the metadata which
was inserted by `git show' and format them the same way, instead of like
diffstats.  Also no longer group these lines inside a separate section,
and forgo inserting the redundant information previously used as the
heading of that section.

magit-rev-format: always treat REV as a commit, add ARGS

This function is intended to print information about a commit, so cast
it as a commit by appending "^{commit}" to REV.  This is useful when REV
actually is a tag, in that case `git show' always prints tag related
information before the information requested using FORMAT, and so this
function used to return incorrect information in that case.

If the return value would be an empty string, then instead return nil.

Also add the new argument ARGS.  These arguments are passed to `git
show' and should be used for arguments such as `--date=' which are
respected by certain placeholders in FORMAT.

`magit-mode-get-buffer' can derive the name of the variable whose value
