magit-diff-wash-diff: fix diff header regexp

The diff header looks like on of these:
  diff --git a b
  diff --cc a
  diff --combined a

Change the regexp so that both "a" and "a b" fall into the second
submatch.  For `--git' that means that the variables `orig' and `file'
are set to wrong values, but that does not matter, since in that case
they are later set again from other headers.

Fixes #2211.

magit-blame-popup: use read-string for -C and -M

These arguments expect a number as value, but the value can also
be omitted in which case git uses some default value.  By using
`magit-popup-read-number' we forced the user to input a number.

Now we use just `read-string', allowing the user to input a number,
nothing, or something invalid (which unfortunately won't be noticed
until git tries to use it).

Fixes #2208.

with-editor-locate-emacsclient-1: match debian alternatives

Fixes #2217.
magit-wip-commit: fix doc-string typo

with-editor-return: use server-done instead of server-edit

This fixes #2197.  We don't actually want to show the buffer belonging
to another client, so we call `server-done' instead of `server-edit'.
The latter calls the former and then also tries to select a buffer,
using `server-switch-buffer' which favors buffers belonging to another
client.  This does matter when Emacs was started in daemon mode and the
user connects to the instance using the emacsclient and then uses Magit
to invoke.  When s/he then completes the commit, then their always is
another client, the one used to connect to the instance in the first
place.

Later in `with-editor-return' we restore the window configuration from
before `with-editor' was used, so one would think that needlessly
showing another buffer before restoring the window configuration would
not matter.  However the previous window configuration has to be
explicitly stored by the caller of `with-editor', so we cannot rely on
a configuration being stored and have to fix the above issue anyway.

In the case of committing using Magit this should not have made a
difference because that does save the previous window configuration, but
unfortunately it does it to late, when the configuration has already
been modified somewhat.  I am not sure if that can be fixed, but in any
case that's a different issue.

magit-blame: fix calls from indirect buffers

Make sure that default-directory stays set at the top-level directory.
When magit-blame is called from an indirect buffer, the find-file call
sets default-directory to the file's directory, so the downstream git
call (now from the file's directory) fails when given a path relative to
the top-level directory.

This isn't an issue when magit-blame is called from a buffer visiting a
file.  The call to find-file does not override the default-directory
let-bound by magit-with-toplevel because the file is already being
visited by the current buffer.

Fix this by let-binding the find-file call separately.

While this makes it possible call magit-blame from an indirect buffer,
point is not placed appropriately in the base buffer.  This probably
isn't worth taking the time to fix given that calling magit-blame from
indirect buffer isn't very common (since the above error has yet to be
reported).

magit-section-goto-successor: avoid falling back to back button

Depending on option `magit-revision-show-xref-buttons' diff buffers may
end with a "back" buttons.  When refreshing a buffer we try to select
the reincarnation of the previously current section and if that fails
fallback to the reincarnation of some "related" section, like the next
sibling or parent.  The final fallback is whatever section came after
the selected section before the refresh and has a reincarnation after
the refresh.  In diff buffers that very often is the "back" button, but
focusing on that section is useless.  Instead we explicitly detect this
case and instead of going to that button go to the beginning of the
buffer.

magit-insert-head-header: don't hardcode HEAD hash

Despite its name, magit-insert-head-header is used by magit-cherry to
insert information about a commit that is often, but not necessarily,
the repo's HEAD.

Previously, magit-insert-head-header inserted commit information for
HEAD regardless of the BRANCH argument.  As a result, giving
magit-cherry a branch other than the current one as the first argument
resulted in an incorrect header:

  Head:     wrong-commit correct-branch wrong-subject
  Upstream: correct-commit correct-branch subject

To fix this, use the BRANCH argument to retrieve the revision
information if BRANCH is non-nil.

magit.org: fix a typo, and all of its copies

use async-bytecomp to guarantee untainted builds

When `package.el' is used to update a package whose libraries have
already been loaded in the current session, then parts of the loaded
version can leak into the new version during byte-compilation.

This can be avoided by compiling the libraries in a separate Emacs
instance.  The library `async-bytecomp', which is part of the package
`async', does just that by advising the function `package--compile'.

So add `async' as an Elpa dependency, soft-require `async-bytecomp', and
if that succeeds, then turn on `async-bytecomp-package-mode' to activate
the advice.  Because it is undefined which package is updated first, and
which library is loaded first, we have to this in both possible
candidates `with-editor' and `magit-popup'.

Users may update `magit' without updating the dependencies, so we have
to further force the updates of all the Elpa packages that are build
from the Melpa repository.  To do so we depend on "20150808" snapshot
versions instead of "2.2.0".

When installing Magit manually, then `async-bytecomp' is not required,
because Magit is then compiled using the Makefile which already uses a
separate, untainted Emacs instance.

to the new command `magit-whitespace-disallowed' which informs the
user that whitespace is disallowed.  If the user manages to insert
whitespace through other means, then raise an error.

Add the new function `magit-read-string-ns' which is a wrapper
around `magit-read-string' which always sets NO-WHITESPACE to t.

Use the new `magit-read-string-ns' in most places where previously
`magit-read-string' was used.

magit-cherry-refresh-buffer: mark arguments as unused

Mark the arguments to `magit-cherry-refresh-buffer' as unused by

The `magit-refresh-function' is always called with the buffer-local

Fixes #2069.

magit-diff-mode-refresh-popup: new variable

The commands `magit-diff-switch-range-type' and `magit-diff-flip-revs'
are only useful in `magit-diff-mode' buffers.  They are not useful in
buffers whose mode derives from `magit-diff-mode' or in
`magit-status-mode' buffers.

Use the new variable `magit-diff-mode-refresh-popup' for the
`magit-diff-refresh-popup' when inside a `magit-diff-mode' buffer.
Elsewhere use `magit-diff-refresh-popup' from which the mentioned
commands are removed.

magit-diff-refresh-popup: allow changing the file filter

Add the `-- FILE...' pseudo argument to the `magit-diff-refresh-popup',
allowing users to change that filter for the current buffer.  Previously
it was not just not possible to do so, but changing another argument
would have removed the file filter.

For buffers that use `magit-diff-section-arguments' add an additional
buffer-local variable `magit-diff-section-file-args' to hold the value
of the file filter.  The refresh suffix command from the popup now
update both variables, and `magit-diff-arguments' includes its value
in the return value when appropriate.

The `magit-insert-{unstaged,staged}-changes' functions respect the new
variable and because the user might otherwise not be aware that a file
filter is in affect in the status buffer, a new section inserter,
`magit-insert-diff-filter-header', is added to the default value of
`magit-status-headers-hook'.

The new function `magit-popup-import-file-args' takes care of combining
the file filters into the pseudo argument form used inside diff popups.

preserve buffer-local diff arguments

Previously `magit-diff-popup' used the value of `magit-diff-arguments'
to initiate the values of its infix arguments.  (Usually the global
value, but due to user errors it could also have been the buffer-local
value).  That made it impossible to change what diff is shown and at the
same time to keep using the previously modified arguments.  (Unless the
modification was explicitly saved, but that caused the value to be used
in all repositories.)

When the `magit-diff-mode' buffer exist for the current buffer, then
`magit-diff-popup' now gets the arguments from that buffer's
`magit-refresh-args', even if that buffer is not current when the popup
is invoked.  Unfortunately that is even the case when the user then goes
on invoking the `magit-show-commit' suffix command, which uses the
`magit-revision-buffer'.  We cannot do anything about that because we
cannot read the users mind.

magit-diff-arguments: absorb wrappers

Create a new `magit-diff-arguments' function which combines
the features of the old `magit-diff-arguments', as well as
`magit-diff-section-arguments' and `magit-diff-refresh-arguments'.

set magit-diff-section-arguments buffer-locally

Previously `magit-diff-refresh' set the global value, affecting all
buffers that respect `magit-diff-section-arguments'.  That never was
the intention.

Also `magit-diff-refresh-popup' now uses `magit-diff-arguments'
internally instead of `magit-diff-section-arguments'.
magit-popup-export-file-args: new function
magit-mode-get-buffer: allow FORMAT to be nil

preserve file arguments when changing other diff args

Changing the arguments used in a diff buffer did previously cause the
file arguments to be lost.  Now the commands from the refresh buffer
explicitly reset the file part of `magit-refresh-args'.

preserve command-specific arguments when changing other diff args

Changing the arguments used in a diff buffer did previously cause
command-specific diff arguments to be lost.  For example when the
diff buffer showed the staged changes, then changing the arguments
did also drop the `--cached' argument, resulting in the unstaged
changes to be shown instead.

Now the buffer-local value of `magit-refresh-args' in diff-derived
buffers has the form (REVS CONSTS ARGS FILES).  CONSTS are the
command-specific arguments.  They can only be changes using a diff
command, but not from the refresh popup.

magit-diff-arguments: always include the files in return value

The function `magit-diff-arguments' now always returns a list with two
elements, the list of regular arguments and the list of file arguments.
Commands that use that function, and didn't do so already, are adjusted
to accept that additional argument and pass it along.  The functions
that they pass it along to are adjusted accordingly, which in some
cases does not have an effect yet.

magit-diff-arguments: absorb magit-diff-read-args

Remove `magit-diff-read-args' and teach `magit-diff-arguments'
to do what the removed function used to do.

define diff popups without using magit-define-popup

The popups `magit-diff-popup' and `magit-diff-refresh-popup' require
features missing from `magit-define-popup'.  Instead of using that
macro, define all the functions and variables manually, that the
macro would generate.

Integrate the old advice for `magit-diff-refresh-popup' directrly
into the function definition.
magit-diff-setup: new function
magit-diff-{switch-range-type,flip-revs}: drop unused ARGS
magit-diff-{dwim,staged}: pass along FILES argument
magit-diff-set-context: don't try to access non-existent match
magit-diff-visit-file: sanitize getting rev in rev buffer

magit-git-command: don't call git inside the process buffer

`magit-git-command' may run git in any directory, not just the top-level
directory.  Previously we made the process buffer current and then
let-bound `default-directory' to the subdirectory, but that confused
`magit-process-buffer' (called by `magit-run-git-async').  It was able
to find the correct process buffer by name, but then it concluded that
the `default-directory' was wrong because it did not match
`magit-toplevel'. The reason for that is that the let-binding was still
in effect.

So instead call `magit-run-git-async-args' first, with the
`default-directory' of whatever buffer is current in effect.  And only
then call `magit-mode-display-buffer'.  Let-binding `default-directory'
inside a process buffer is now considered a bug (but this was the only
place where we did it).

magit-process-insert-section: add mandatory PWD argument

The `default-directory' of a process buffer is the top-level directory
of the corresponding repository, but it should also be possible to run
git in a sub-directory without having to let-bind `default-directory'.

When `magit-process-insert-section' is called then the process buffer
always is the current buffer.  This made it impossible to pass the
working directory to this function except by let-binding
`default-directory' inside the process buffer, which had some rather
nasty side-effects.  The new PWD argument makes it possible to do so
without causing any problems.

replace TOPDIR argument with PWD in process buffer getters

Rename the TOPDIR arguments of `magit-mode-get-process',
`magit-mode-get-process-create', and `magit-process-buffer' to PWD.

The original intention was that callers could pass TOPDIR, in
order to avoid calling it again inside `magit-mode-get-buffer' when
its value is already known.  However in practice TOPDIR is in some
cases not actually the top-level directory but some sub-directory of
the repository.

In `magit-mode-get-process' always call `magit-toplevel' and find or
create a buffer with a matching `default-directory'.  Take non-nil PWD
into account by let-binding `default-directory' to it while determining
the top-level.

Previously we used `string-match-p' but we can just test for equality.

re: #2100

magit-mode-get-buffer: fix sub-directory case

Previously a caller could set TOPDIR argument, so that this function
could avoid calling `magit-toplevel' if the caller already knew that
value.  But the assumption that we could do that was wrong: we cannot
get around calling that function because in some cases we actually want
to run git in a directory which is a sub-directory of a repository, not
a repository top-directory (or outside any repository at all).

Revert "suppress bogus compile warning"

This reverts commit d2ada2262404aaa539883f134b96f25e3541e9ae.

define hooks like we are supposed too

Users are allowed to use `add-hook' et al. to add hook functions to hook
variables which have not yet been declared.  That means that the default
value of hook variables should not be set inside `defvar' and defcustom'
forms, because those definitions are only evaluated if the variable has
no value yet (in case of `defcustom' it would be used to get the default
value though).  When the user used `add-hook' earlier, then it obviously
has a value.  So we are supposed to set the default value outside of the
declaration form, using `add-hook'.  But that has a few downsides too.

If we set the default value outside of `defcustom', then Custom would
think that the default value is `nil' (and would be right about that)
and tell the user about it, which could confuse her a lot.

So we set the default value inside `defcustom' *and* outside using
`add-hook'. Sight.  That's still not good enough though.  Re-evaluating
the file or buffer containing these `add-hook' forms would override all
user customization.

So we place the calls to `add-hook' before that to `defcustom' and
additionally wrap the calls to `add-hook' to make sure they are only
ever run once.  Sight.

(unless (find-lisp-object-file-name 'HOOK-VARIABLE 'defvar) ...)
  (add-hook 'HOOK-VARIABLE ...) ...)
(defcustom HOOK-VARIABLE '(...)
  :options '(...)
  ...)

Double sight.

We *don't* do the above for section hooks, which users are supposed to
modify using `magit-add-section-hook'.  Instead we teach that function
to raise an error when the user attempts to add a hook function to a
hook variable which has not been defined yet.

re #1999, #2035

don't bind default-directory to pass topdir to magit-mode-setup

In `magit-status-internal' do not let-bind `default-directory' to "pass"
the top-level directory to `magit-mode-setup'.  Generally doing so would
be okay for this particular variable, while one should of course usually
use function arguments to pass values.

In this particular case binding `default-directory' confuses
`magit-mode-get-buffer' which is used by `magit-mode-setup'.  The result
would be that it were no longer possible to use `C-u C-u C-x g' from
within a repository to switch to another repository whose top-level
directory has the same basename as that of the current repository, when
`magit-status-buffer-name-format' contains `%b', i.e. when we only show
the basename in the mode-line.  It would think that we are already in
that buffer (because the dynamic binding of `default-directory' appears
to claim that we are).

So instead we should pass the path to the repository to be visited by
passing it to `magit-mode-setup' using a new function argument.  But
that's not possible because it would break existing code. We have to
use a new variable `magit-mode-setup--topdir' to pass the value to
`magit-mode-setup'.

refs buffer: RET on a ref checks out

Starting with v2.1.0, "RET" no longer checked out the reference at
point, instead it was shown using `magit-show-commit'.  I have decided
to restore the old behavior, which unfortunately requires the below
hack because the references in this buffer use the same section types
`branch' and `tag' as in other buffers, and `magit-show-commit' is
bound in the respective section type keymaps.

So replace that command with `magit-visit-ref' in the those keymaps.
Except in `magit-refs-mode' buffers this command simply calls the
regular `magit-show-commit' command.  In refs buffers, on a reference,
it instead checks out that reference, like RET used to do.  With a
prefix argument it instead just focuses on that reference.

eval modified cl-defstruct at compile-time to help package.el

7c41b8e3d54471dc9b45cb743906bf10a7d4e349 renamed a slot in the
`magit-section' struct.  Because `package.el' recompiles libraries in
alphabetic order, the modified `magit-diff.el', which uses the new slot
accessor `magit-section-diff-header', is recompiled before the new one
defined in `magit-section.el' has been loaded.  In order to use the new
definition add a copy of that `cl-defstruct' form to `magit-diff.el' and
evaluate it at compile time.

store complete diff headers in section structs

Previously we stored just the blobs in the BLOBS slot and later when the
file or parts of it were applied we constructed an (incomplete) header
in `magit-diff-file-header' using the BLOBS, FILE, and ORIG slots.  That
didn't work on new, deleted, and renamed files, because some information
was left out which is required in these cases.

Now just store the complete header in the new DIFF-HEADERS (which was
created by re-purposing and renaming BLOBS, which is no longer needed).

magit-diff-hunk-region-patch: do less

`magit-diff-hunk-region-patch' used to return the concatenation
of the file header and the adjusted hunk header, now it returns
just the latter.  So `magit-apply-region' now also has to call
`magit-diff-file-header' directly.

`magit-diff-hunk-region-patch' also used to perform some sanity
checks useful when applying a patch.  But since it is also used
by `magit-diff-hunk-region-header' which in turn is used to
adjust a hunk's heading when there is a hunk internal region,
this should not be done here.  Move the checks to
`magit-apply-region'.

Merge branch 'ediff-quit-hook'

magit-ediff-resolve: offer to save buffer

Since this command is usually invoked from the status buffer and we
restore the previous window configuration when done, the file-visiting
buffer usually won't be current after finishing the Ediff session.  So
telling the user that she can now save the buffer isn't helpful.

magit-ediff-quit-hook: new hook variable

We set the local value of `ediff-quit-hook' to a function specific
to the Ediff variant being used.  This has the advantage, that
`ediff-cleanup-mess' is not run; that function is not suitable for
our needs.  But it also means that additional functions added by
the user will be ignored.

So add an alternative hook variable `magit-ediff-quit-hook', which
replaces `ediff-quit-hook' when Ediff is invoked using a Magit
command.

Add the existing function `magit-ediff-cleanup-auxiliary-buffer' and
the new function `magit-ediff-restore-previous-winconf' to the new
hook variable.  Users who add something to `magit-ediff-quit-hook'
will likely want to remove `magit-ediff-restore-previos-winconf'.

magit-diff-show-or-scroll: handle branch sections properly

Show the revision buffer in another window for commits that are at the
tip of a branch and therefore have the section type `branch' instead of
`commit'.

magit-version: wrap package.el parts inside ignore-errors

Internal functions of that package (which we have to use because
there is not suitable public api) sometimes change in incompatible
ways.  Wrap code that uses such functions with `ignore-errors' so
we get a more meaningful error message when that next happens.

Re #1972.

magit-blame-mode: refuse to activate when run interactively

The commands `magit-blame' and `magit-blame-popup' would be used to
turn on this mode.  Previously turning on the mode directly also
worked, because the mode function then called `magit-blame', but
because that in turn calls the mode function, that ended up being
called twice.  And that resulted in the buffer becoming read-only.

Since `magit-blame-mode' was not intended to be called interactively
we now just raise an error (with usage instructions) if the user
attempts to do so.

This allows binding `C-w' and `M-w' to these commands, without losing
any functionality.

The children of the "Bisect Log" section are such sections, their

magit-section-show-child-count: do it by default

magit-log-cutoff-length: increase default value

The intention when setting this to allow value, is to make it faster.
However the problem isn't that Git is slow at outputting the log or
Magit is slow at parsing the output, the problem is that `git log
--graph' has a constant overhead which does not depend on how many
commits are being displayed but the total number of commits.

Therefore if this number is to low, it becomes more likely that a
user has to endure that delay several times until doubling the number
of displayed commits until finally all commits which she wants to be
listed are indeed listed.

Suggested-by: Kyle Meyer <kyle@kyleam.com>

ediff: cleanup auxiliary buffers

Previously the intention was that `ediff-cleanup-mess' would take care
of this.  That function expects that the control buffer is current when
it runs, but our own hook function, which runs firsts, restores the
pre-ediff window configuration, making that buffer non-current.  So
`ediff-cleanup-mess' ended up doing nothing.

Reversing the order does not work because our function also expects that
the control buffer is current.  Also `ediff-cleanup-mess' does things to
the file-visiting buffers that we are not interested in.

So instead set the local value of `ediff-quit-hook' to a single
function, our own cleanup lambda.  This means that the global hook value
is ignored, including `ediff-cleanup-mess'.  `smerge-ediff' does this
too.  However that function directly calls `ediff-quit-hook' while we
call the trimmed down variant `magit-ediff-cleanup-auxiliary-buffers'.

update the mode-line element vc-mode more efficiently

For file-visiting buffers the VC package show the file's status in the
mode-line.  We used to call the *function* `vc-find-file-hook' after
reverting such a buffer to help VC keep it up-to-date.  However that
function is terribly inefficient and does other things we usually don't
need.

Instead use a new function `magit-refresh-vc-mode-line' which is like
`vc-mode-line' but simpler, more efficient, and less buggy.

Then instead of calling that function unconditionally add it to the
relevant hooks; allowing users to disable even this more efficient
implementation.

By not using `vc-find-file-hook' we also stop calling `vc-follow-link'.
But that should not matter much, because that function is still called
when the buffer is first created.

magit-show-commit: Fix commit check

commit transient changes to two dedicated wip refs

Previously two modes existed which saved transient changes (i.e. changes
that have not been committed to regular refs yet) by either committing
to a work-in-progress ref or by creating a stash.

These two modes are being replaced with three new modes which all save
changes to two different work-in-progress refs.  Previously only one wip
ref existed (per branch); it was used to save changes in the worktree.
Now there are two such refs; one for the worktree and one for the index.

The old `magit-backup-mode' which saved changes using stashes, is
removed without a direct replacement.

The old `[global-]magit-wip-save-mode's are renamed to
`magit-wip-after-save-[local-]mode', they behave mostly the same as
before.  This mode is similar to `make-backup-files', but it creates
a backup whenever the buffer is saved, not only the first time (and
obviously it saves the "backups" elsewhere).

However "editing a file" is not the only way for users to change a file
when using Git/Magit.  One can also "apply" a change to a file, in fact
that's the only way one can change the "index version" of a file.
`magit-wip-after-apply-mode' covers this case.  When that mode is
enabled the Magit commands that apply changes to files and/or the index
then also explicitly commit the changes they have made to the wip refs.

They only commit the changes that were just made, which avoids having to
check each and every file for changes.  Doing it this way is very
important for performance reasons.  However if a user makes changes
through other means, then these changes are not being committed to the
wip refs after they are made and therefor it is possible to lose those.

`magit-wip-before-change-mode' solves that problem.  When that mode is
enabled, then commands which may discard changes that have potentially
not been saved to the wip refs yet save them before making their own
changes.  Again only the files known to be affected by the upcoming
change are saved.

Sometimes it might be useful to explicitly safe all changes to all files
to the wip refs, which can be done using the command `magit-wip-commit'.

Besides the performance gain, another advantage of explicitly saving
some changes instead of blindly saving everything, is that we can use
commit and ref-update messages which indicate which command caused
saving changes to which files.  Those more informative messages make it
easier to find the changes one needs to recover from such wip commits.

improve usage information shown by magit-log-select

Each caller of `magit-log-select' now provides its own and adapted usage

whether and where the usage information is displayed.

magit-rename-buffer: new command
make magit-diff-switch-buffer-function customizable

magit buffers no longer visit truename of toplevel

Previously we used `git rev-parse --show-toplevel' to determine the
toplevel directory of the current repository and used that as
`default-directory' of Magit buffers.  `--show-toplevel' always chases
symlinks, and so we ended up visiting the truename of that directory.

That's not nice and so we now use `--show-cdup' and construct the
absolute filename from that and `default-directory' using
`expand-file-name'.

Also remove several kludges where filenames had to be normalized
using `file-truename' and similar, before being compared to the
`default-directory' of Magit buffers.

However a user may explicitly set `find-file-visit-truename' to t.
To cover that case `magit-mode-setup' now respects that variable
when first creating a buffer.

consolidate the functions that return the repository toplevel

Remove the variants `magit-get-top-dir' and `magit-toplevel-safe' in
favor of just `magit-toplevel'.  This function now combines all the
special cases previously handled by the removed functions.

`magit-toplevel' differs from `git rev-parse --show-toplevel' which it
uses internally, in that it also works from inside the .git directory
and in bare repositories.  The new STRICT argument can be used to
suppress these fallbacks.

Also add the new `magit-with-toplevel' macro which just let-binds
`default-directory' to the toplevel directory.

argument is gone (and STATUS too as it makes no sense without FILE).

of what `magit-discard-files' does.

previously not have worked properly ever since we started using `-z'
without making the necessary adjustments.

Re #1318.

use overlays to hide section bodies

Previously we used text properties but we never managed to fully teach
Emacs what we mean by "invisible".  We mean "cannot be seen with the
eyes", as opposed to "position that has the `invisible' text property
set, when taking into account text property stickiness and whatever else
is relevant".  We did force the appropriate stickiness and added a post
command kludge to work around that not having the desired effect.  And
maybe there was a bug in that.  But I do suspect there is a bug in Emacs
itself with regards to "taking into account text property stickiness"
when moving to the edges of the abyss - but I am not sure.

Anyway, by using an overlay we bypass all that.  When using an overlay
the default rules seem to lead to "invisible" := "cannot be seen by the
eyes".  For the most part this is implemented by copying the respective
code from `outline-flag-region', so it is code that has been around for
a long time.

There is one difference; when hiding a section body, we do *not* hide
the newline at the end of the heading but *do* hide the newline at the
end of the body - `outline-flag-region' does the opposite. That means
that hiding the body does not remove the background color of parts of
the heading - and that we cannot display an ellipsis at the "end of the
heading" (that wouldn't be visible).

This change will also allow isearching invisible section bodies, but
that isn't enabled yet - it still needs some work.

README.md: adjust minimal Emacs version

use more semantic colors for reflog faces

Use the color to indicate how dangerous the logged action is.

Creating a new commit is totally safe.  Amending to an existing commit
is more dangerous as it might not only add to but also remove from the
commit.  And resetting is very dangerous as it throws away one or more
commits.

Like creating commits, checking out a commit is also safe, but because
there are notable differences we use another "safe color".

Also lose the background colors for consistency with refname faces,
which also no longer have a background color.
define some hook variables as custom options

rename magit-rebase-onto to magit-rebase-from

This breaks consistency with Git's terminology, which is a good thing
because that does not make sense here.

What differs between these two:

  git rebase UPSTREAM BRANCH
  git rebase --onto NEWBASE "UPSTREAM" BRANCH

isn't that the later rebases `--onto' something; all rebases do.  The
difference is that in the former case everything not in UPSTREAM is
rebased, while in the latter case only a subset of the "local" commits
is rebased.  So NEWBASE is actually the same thing as UPSTREAM, and
"UPSTREAM" should actually be named START-POINT or something like that.
And instead of an `--onto' argument there should be a `--from' argument
or instead of a branch it should be possible to specify a range:

  git rebase UPSTREAM --from START BRANCH
  git rebase UPSTREAM START..BRANCH

magit-diff-highlight{*}: rename argument SIBLINGS to SELECTION

This better describes what kind of sibling sections these are:
sibling sections which form a valid multi-section selection.

fix list highlighting corner case

When the region is active and point is at the end of a `list' section,
then do not highlight its heading and those of its children.  Without
this the region overlay would be completely covered by heading overlays.

avoid painting selected hunks twice after refresh

Previously these sections were first painted as unhighlighted and then
painted again as highlighted.

Never call `magit-diff-paint-hunk' directly in `magit-diff-wash-hunk'.
Instead rely on `magit-section-show' triggering the (second) painting.

That means that `magit-diff-paint-hunk' now has to be able to figure
out whether it is expected to highlight or unhighlight.  That could be
somewhat expensive, so caller which know which is the case continue to
pass on that information.  But `magit-section-show' doesn't know.

When `magit-diff-paint-hunk' is called without the HIGHLIGHT argument
then it used the new `magit-section-selected-p' to figure out whether
it should highlight or unhighlight.

`magit-section-selected-p' needs to check whether the section it
is called on is a member of the multi-section selection, which is
expensive if we were to do it several times.  So the functions that
do unhighlighting now pass along that information, just like the
functions that highlight already did.

avoid un-/refining invisible hunks until expansion

The new function `magit-diff-un-/refine-hunk' takes care of
everything now.

Also remove the variable `magit-diff-refine-hunk-related', which was
a temporary hack.  Like in the last release and before, it once more
is only possible to refine all hunks or the one and only current hunk.
Remove the option to refine all selected hunks.
avoid painting invisible hunks

avoid un-/highlighting hidden hunks until expansion

When a hidden hunk section is selected it is no longer highlighted, and
when it is deselected it is no longer unhighlighted.  In many cases this
avoids unhighlighting and the rehighlighting again when moving back,
both of which would be useless because the affected part of the hunk is
not even visible.  This also affects un-/refining.

Instead hidden hunks that are not yet highlighted are highlighted when
they are expanded.

The heading of the hunk, which usually is visible, is un-/highlighted as
before, when ever the section is de-/selected.

When forgoing to unhighlight a hunk section
add it to `magit-section-highlighted-sections' and
remove it from `magit-section-unhighlight-sections'.

Hunks are still the only sections which are ever added to these
variables.  Which means that all other sections are always
un-/highlighted, even when that would not be necessary.

The old reason for why we don't avoid un- and rehighlighting other
sections is that doing so is believed to be cheap.  Implementing the
necessary housekeeping to avoid doing so might be more expensive even.

There is a new reason now: if an ancestor section of a hidden hunk
section whose body highlighting is not correct were marked were added to
the list of fully highlighted sections, then the delayed highlighting of
the hunk would fail.

All members of `magit-section-highlighted-sections' are known to be
fully and correctly highlighted.  Other sections might or might not
be fully and correctly highlighted, but we don't keep track of it.

avoid re-highlighting when moving within the same section

In `magit-section-update-highlight' check whether the current section is
the same as the one that was current before.  If that is so do nothing.
This makes moving inside diffs much cheaper.  We keep track of the
current section using the new variable `magit-section-highlighted-section'.

Because sibling selection overlays are highlighted during highlighting
and therefor not tracked as region overlays, their removal has to be
forced by setting `magit-section-highlighted-section' to nil.  Therefor
we might still do some unnecessary re-highlighting after deactivating
the region.

separate hunk region painting and section highlighting

When there is an active hunk-internal region, then no longer create
the necessary overlays during section highlighting.  Instead create
these overlays by hooking into Emacs own region overlay mechanism.
Also no longer make the regular region overlay invisible (doing that
relied on an error which prevented the overlay from being visible).

Instead just don't create that overlay if we create other overlays
to represent the region.  Beside the hunk-internal region overlays,
this also includes the overlays that are created when highlighting
sibling sections.  However these sibling section overlays are still
being created during highlighting.

require at least version 24.4 of Emacs

That release is the first to implement parts of the region overlay
handling in elisp.  The change in the next commit depend on the ability
to do just that; it allows decoupling hunk painting from section
highlighting.  And that in turn enables various significant performance
improvements.

So we have to do it - poor performance is most often voiced criticism.
This had to happen eventually.  There have been many small reasons why
dropping support for older Emacsen would have benefited the maintainer
and the majority of users.  Now there is a big one.  Note that one of
the reasons I released 1.4.0 was to have a recent release which still
works with older Emacsen.

Remove all the backward compatibility definitions which now are no
longer required.

with-editor-post-cancel-hook: new hook

We will need to pass information from the pre-cancel to the post-cancel
hook, so add a variable to do that.

At the time the post-cancel hook is run, the buffer no longer exists, so
we have to preserve the local value using a let-binding.  Because we use
lexical scope the byte-compiler would complain that we don't use the
variable (which isn't true), so `with-editor-cancel-alist' has to be
declared globally.  Somehow the use of a let-binding causes the hook
functions to be run twice - seems like the let-bound value is considered
to be both the local as well as the global value.  So remove t from the
hook list.

Makefile: explicitly define dependencies between libraries

Previously it was necessary to use `make clean lisp' to be on the safe
side.  Now `make lisp' is enough even when macro definitions changed.

avoid needlessly loading optional libraries

Aside from just not doing that at load-time, there are some additional
requirements to make this work.

* When using `make lisp' to compile outdated libraries, the targets are
  first removed.  Otherwise compiling e.g. `magit-stash.el' would result
  in `magit' to be loaded, which in turn would result in the outdated
  `magit-stash.elc' to be loaded and the byte-compiler to complain about
  it.

* The name of the loaddefs file has to be hardcoded in `magit.el' as
  well as the `Makefile'.

* `magit-maybe-backup', which is called before applying a change, to
  create a backup stash, in case `magit-backup-mode' is enabled, as to
  be defined outside of `magit-backup.el', because that's one of the
  libraries we try to avoid loading.  The old `magit-maybe-backup' is
  renamed to `magit-backup-maybe', and the new `magit-maybe-backup' just
  checks whether the latter is defined and if so calls it.  The latter
  is still ultimately responsible for deciding whether to backup or not,
  and does it exactly as before, there's just an additional redirection
  now.

* Many commands that are defined in the delayed libraries were not
  autoloaded.  It is important that we do that now.

* When the delayed libraries cannot be autoloaded because
  `magit-autoloads.el' does not exist, then we have no choice but to
  fall back to loading them upfront.

Note that we have to continue to always load certain libraries after
providing `magit'.  These are the libraries that define section
inserters which are used by buffers, whose major-modes are not defined
in these libraries themselves.

require at least version 1.9.4 of Git

This version was released a year ago for all platforms except
MS Windows.

The MS Window port which can be downloaded from
http://git-scm.com/download/windows never saw a release named 1.9.4,
instead something named 1.9.5 was finally released two weeks ago.
Previously the port was stuck on an even older release.  Git proper
itself never used the v1.9.5 tag - I don't know what's going on here.

So for MS Windows users the new minimal version now is the so-called
v1.9.5, for users on other platforms it is the actual v1.9.4.

I would have liked to go with v2.0.0, but cannot do so until an easily
installable port of that exists for MS Windows.

magit-file-relative-name: fix for W32 with Cygwin

On Windows, Emacs formats file names as e.g. c:/path/to/somewhere. This
causes a mismatch with Cygwin's git, which uses /path/to/somewhere.

Bridge these two by calling `expand-file-name' on the result of
`magit-get-top-dir' before calculating its length, so that it's in the
same format as the file's name. The file's name is in that format via
`file-truename', and also because it probably came from Emacs rather
than git.

do not revert buffers in which magit-blame-mode is enabled

When a buffer, in which `magit-blame-mode' is enabled, was reverted due
to `magit-auto-revert-mode' being on, this was done by first disabling
`magit-blame-mode, then reverting, and finally enabling the mode again.

Until 0576e69b3f2299a3a47332116b4c6250d3fe6be4 the same was done for
`auto-revert-mode' too.

Unfortunately turning the mode on again, caused the file-visiting buffer
to be also displayed in the window that was selected when the action
which triggered the refresh (and thus the revert).  The reason for this
is unknown, see #1731.

To work around this keep `magit-auto-revert-mode' from reverting when
`magit-blame-mode' is on.  Keep doing so for `auto-revert-mode'.  In
both cases how show a warning.
magit-define-popup: fix doc-string typo

popup: fix inserting gaps

The problem was that we inserted a gap by *completely* filling the
column with spaces.  Padding happens when inserting the *next* column
and because buttons *never* are long enough to fill the column, the
code responsible for doing that came to the conclusion we are about
to insert column n+1 when we were about to insert column n.  It then
noticed that the space reserved for column n was not completely used
up (actually not at all) and inserted spaces for that column.

By inserting a single space we fix that.  Inserting nothing at all for
a gap would not work, because then we would have the same problem in
reverse.  The code responsible for padding would then, when inserting
the next item think we are still at column n-1 when we actually are at
column n.

magit-read-range-or-commit: provide completion for second rev

This uses `crm' whose purpose actually is to complete an arbitrary
number of items, not one or two as we need here.  So users could insert
something like "a..b..c", but they are not gonna do that, I hope.  Also
after inserting e.g. "master" this claims that's the only completion; it
would be better if it offered "master", "master..", and "master...".
For now this only offers completions for the second revision once ".."
or "..." has been inserted explicitly.

`pcomplete' would be more suitable, but as far as I understand it this

fix various diff scope related issues

Remove `magit-diff-scope's SINGULAR argument, if that actually behaves
as it was already previously described in the doc-string when SECTION
is non-nil, then this is not necessary.  I.e. when SECTION is specified
return the type of that, not that of a possible selection.

As a result, also treat the `region' type as a singular, because that's
what it is.  `list' is a singular to, by the way.  Only `hunks' and
`files' are not, the presence or absence of the "s" suffix helps
remembering what is plural and what not.

Make `magit-section-internal-region-p's SECTION argument optional, and
when it is present actually use it.  Also make sure the region is inside
SECTION (or the current section if that is nil).  Previously we instead
did something strange in `magit-diff-scope', which resulted in `region'
being treated as a plural with the respective singular being `hunk'
which isn't correct.

The bugs being fixed by all this is that previously `magit-diff-scope'
returned `files' when it should have returned `files' (this was the case
in `magit-discard-apply' and `magit-reverse-apply') and that this bug is
fixed in a way that does not introduce a new bug where `magit-diff-scope'
returned `hunk' instead of `region', as the previous attempt at fixing
the first bug using c3535abe38e2cee9b65d7ef798a22989d1eb0419 did.

magit-get-tracked-{branch,ref}: assume sane configuration

The default value of the Git variable `remote.<remote>.fetch' is
"+refs/heads/*:refs/remotes/<remote>/*".  It can be useful to add
_additional_ values, e.g. to fetch notes.  However it does _not_
make sense to change the default value used for fetching branches.
But it's possible and Git seems to deal with it just fine.  These
functions used to do the same, but it's to expensive - and if a
user actually changes this then she has nobody but herself to
blame.

magit-git-string: report non-zero exit status

Rename the existing `magit-git-string' to `magit-git-str'; it should
only be used when a non-zero exit status is expected and does not
constitute an error.

Add a new `magit-git-string' which uses `magit-git-insert' and, when
`magit-git-debug' is non-nil, therefor reports a non-zero exit status
in the message area as well as by creating a section with Git's stderr
in the process buffer.

Most callers of `magit-git-string' keep calling that function, i.e
switch to the new implementation; they start reporting errors.  Note
that this does not cause an Elisp error to be raised.  The purpose
of this change is to make it easier to debug, and not to gracefully
recover from errors.

Likewise add `magit-rev-parse-safe' as a variant of `magit-rev-parse'.

magit-git-lines: report non-zero exit status

Provided `magit-git-debug' is non-nil report non-zero exit status in
`magit-git-lines'.

In `magit-get-all' bind `magit-git-debug' to nil around the call to
`magit-git-lines', because here a non-zero exit status is expected.
magit-git-debug: new option

magit-process-buffer: add optional CREATE argument

When the new CREATE argument is nil, then return the existing buffer,
otherwise nil.  When CREATE is non-nil, then, as before create the
buffer if it does not exist yet.

Use this distinction in `magit-process-setup' to avoid trying to
truncate the sections in a non-existent buffer.

do not define any obsolete variable aliases

For the following reasons:

1. Trying to do so for an automatically buffer-local variable is not
   allowed and causes an error.  Don't know why it has to be that
   way, but that's certainly not something I'm gonna complain about.
   This means that for some variables we would be unable to use such
   aliases even if we wanted to.  See #1711.

2. I (a) would want to define them in a single block not sprinkled
   across the various libraries, and (b) they have to be defined before
   the new option is defined, or customized values would be lose.  See
   #1693.  But I also would rather not have that block be pretty much
   the first code someone looks at when starting to read the source
   code.  Not such a big deal in itself, but combined with the others...

3. The removed set of aliases is an essentially random subset of aliases
   out of the much larger set of alias that could be defined.  It
   doesn't really make sense to define these but not the others, and
   determining the others would be a lot of work.  I would much rather
   spend that time doing something more productive.

fix stashing in repositories accessed using tramp

Tramp does not support setting the environment for a single process,
but we need that to set GIT_INDEX_FILE when stashing and in some other
places.

`tramp-sh-handle-start-file-process' and `tramp-sh-handle-process-file'
to inject the variables into the command executed on the remote.

refs: make unmerged-commits counts optional

In `magit-insert-branch-1' only calculate the number of unmerged files
if FORMAT (`magit-local-branch-format' or `magit-remote-branch-format')
contains "%c".  In `magit-insert-tags' only do so if `magit-tags-format'
contains "%c".  Add new variable `magit-refs-indent-cherry-lines'.

Calculating the number of unmerged commits is less demanding than
calculating cherry commits, but it's still to slow in big repositories.

To avoid doing so use something like:

(setq magit-local-branch-format "%C %-25n %U%m\n"
      magit-remote-branch-format "  %-25n %m\n"
      magit-tags-format "  %-25n %m\n"
      magit-refs-indent-cherry-lines 0)

Also see #1674.

magit.el: cosmetics

sanitize after-revert hooks

Rename the hook `magit-revert-buffer-hook' to `magit-after-revert-hook',
for consistency with the built-in `after-revert-hook'.  Run the hook,
after potentially re-enabling `magit-blame-mode' (which is a special
case explicitly handled in `magit-revert-buffer'), previously we did
it before.

Add the new hook variable `magit-not-reverted-hook' which is
run by `magit-revert-buffer' if, and only if, it does *not* run
`magit-after-revert-hook' (because there was nothing to be reverted,
i.e. the file did not change on disk).  This is for the benefit of
third-party extensions which do need to do something in that case.

Finish by always calling the _function_ `vc-find-file-hook'.  This
function is intended as a member of the hook `find-file-hook'.  It
is also called directly in a few other places, this is one of them.
Previously this function was only called when the buffer had to be
refreshed, now it is always called, mostly so that the mode-line
get's updated (that might need updating even if the file did not
change).

magit-revert-buffers: refactor for speed and sanity

Use `magit-toplevel-safe' instead of `magit-get-top-dir'.  The latter
returns non-nil in bare repositories also, which is not helpful because
we only refresh files in the working directory anyway.

Use `file-in-directory-p' instead of `string-prefix-p', because the
former is safer.  Only check that the file is in the repository; do not
also check that it is _not_ in the git directory.  That's unnecessary
because a git repository cannot track a file ".git/FILE" anyway, and we
already check whether the file is a member of the list of tracked files.

Note that `magit-toplevel' and by extension `magit-toplevel-safe' use
`git rev-parse --show-level' which chases symlinks.  So we have to take
care when using `file-in-directory-p' or similar: we have to compare the
`buffer-file-truename' and not `buffer-file-name'.  We already did that.

Depending on whether there are more tracked files in the current
repositories or open buffers overall, take a different code path,
avoiding unnecessary work.  Move some of the shared code into the new
function `magit-revert-buffer'.

magit-insert-untracked-files: respect status.showUntrackedFiles

Showing all untracked files can be slow.  So respect the Git variable
`status.showUntrackedFiles' allowing users to make it faster at the
cost of not being able to stage every untracked file individually.

That variable defaults to "normal" which means that when directory
contains nothing but untracked files then only the directory is shown.

Before respecting this variable Magit showed each untracked files using
an initially collapsed tree.  Doing that would probably be the more
reasonable default, but I will delay the final decision until after the
following and just do what Git would do for now.

In the future we might use `magit-status.showUntrackedFiles' instead of
sharing `status.showUntrackedFiles' with Git.  Then we could also have
another default ("all") without anyone being able to say that doing so
was wrong.

variables".  This fixes #1630.

improve magit-show-refs variants

Add `magit-show-refs-current', like `magit-show-refs-head' previously
did it compares the other refs with that branch.  The latter now
compares the other refs with `HEAD'.  The difference is that the
"current" variant locks the refs buffer to a branch; after checking
out another branch and refreshing the buffer, it continues to compare
the other refs with the (previously current) branch, while the "head"
variant locks to the `HEAD', checking out another branch or detaching
`HEAD' will cause the refs to be compared with another rev, the one
`HEAD' then points to.

Low level support for this distinction was implemented quite some
time ago but the commands did not take advantage of this distinction.
The only thing that changes is that level is that "HEAD" now stands
for itself, previously the "head variant" was represented by `nil'.

When an argument is set which requires the use of verbose log then
automatically use verbose log; when no such argument is set then don't.

Previously we did add/remove certain required/incompatible arguments,
based on whether the user then went on using a oneline or verbose log
command.  This wasn't transparent and did contain bugs.  Now there is
just one way to get a verbose log - use an argument that results in a
verbose log.  Currently the only such arguments are `--patch' and
`--stat'.

magit-log-popup: remove most expert arguments

In the past I have been criticized for both, (a) adding useless
confusing arguments, and (b) refusing to add essential arguments.

Different users have different needs and I won't be able to make
everyone happy.  Here I have chosen to remove lesser used arguments
which would confuse the non-expert.  The expert is welcome to add
these arguments back, I have invested quite some time making that
possible - use the functions `magit-define-popup-switch' and
`magit-define-popup-option'.

magit-log-popup: bind lowercase keys to arguments, most actions

For keys that change the values of arguments, give up on only using
keys corresponding to the short form of the respective Git argument.
Instead use all lowercase letters and try to make them consistent
within this popup.

For action keys we cannot do completely without uppercase letters,
we use uppercase for the "verbose" variants.  However use "o"/"O"
instead of "b"/"B", for consistency with other popups where we also
use the former for the "act on something other than the default"
action variants.

but just dropping them into the popup as is, really doesn't cut it.

add new push and pull commands

Previously only one command to push a branch and one command to pull a
branch existed.  Now there are several variants for pushing as well as
pulling.  They are all available from the respective popup which makes
it much easier to push to or pull from a branch which is not the already
configured upstream branch of the currently checked out branch.

Previously one had to remember exactly how many prefix arguments on had
to use to do something "unusual" and even then most "unusual" things
were not possible.  I for one did at least 2/3 of my pushes and pulls
in a terminal, but no more.

Add new commands `magit-pull-current', `magit-push-current',
`magit-push-elsewhere' and `magit-push-matching'.  Add the functions
`magit-pull-read-args' and `magit-push-read-args.  And adjust the
`magit-pull-popup' and `magit-push-popup popups, as well as the
function `magit-read-remote-branch' accordingly.

magit-push: provide just one way to enable --set-upstream

The `magit-push-popup' features the `--set-upstream' argument, which is
how this sort of thing is usually done in Magit.  Until now `magit-push'
might also have asked the user whether she wants the upstream to be set.
The option `magit-set-upstream-on-push' was used to control under which
conditions the user was asked and the use of two prefix arguments did
override the option.  Remove the option and ignore prefix arguments with
regards to this.

Most things that was possible before are still possible, but there are
no longer multiple ways of doing the same thing.  The only exception is
that it is no longer possible to tell `magit-push' to refuse to push
when the upstream is not set.

magit-pull-popup: remove --force

This is only required when the user has modified the default fetch rules
which by default begin with "+", i.e. forcing is the default, also it is
confusing.

magit-push-popup: add --force-with-lease

Because that is only supported since Git 1.8.5
we also have to keep plain old `--force'.

add magit-confirm-files, improve magit-confirm

Also adjust the various callers and the option `magit-no-confirm'.

This is another milestone in the efforts to make completion consistent.
Here we do so by coupling confirmation with completion.

When a command can either (a) do something with the items represented
by all sections in the region, (b.1) the item represented by the
current section, (b.2) some item which is the default for some other
reason or (c) an item read using the minibuffer, then combine (b) and
(c).  I.e. instead of asking "Delete branch master?", give the user
the opportunity to confirm, abort _or_ to choose another branch:
"Delete branch (default master):".  This is especially useful because
the default is not always the thing-at-point, so we would have to
request confirmation anyway.  When the default is what the user wanted
then "RET" is just another way of saying "yes", and "C-g" means "no".

If the user only had the choice between "yes" and "no", then we would
have to provide another way to pick something other than the default,
i.e. using a second command or a prefix argument.  That's much less
convenient.

For such commands which may act on the selected section(s) _or_ some
other default, do _not_ provide the possibility to disable confirmation.
If acting on one item requires confirmation, then acting on multiple
items should also require confirmation.

For other commands which may act on a single thing or multiple things
but in a fully predictable way (always act on the section at point or
the sections in the region) we don't allow the user to pick something
other than the default.  In these cases allow disabling the need for
confirmation.  This mostly concerns commands that act on files.

Finally there are commands that perform actions that are not tied to a
certain a set of items out of a larger possible set, e.g. aborting the
ongoing merge.  Here too allow disabling the need for confirmation.

do not enable the backup mode by default

`magit-backup-mode' creates a stash whenever the user applies
(e.g. stages) a change.  This necessarily takes time and is being
perceived as a performance regression.  Do not enable the mode by
default, so that users have to opt-in.

Also no longer include untracked files in the stash by default.
This takes even more time, especially in repositories lacking
proper ignore rules.

Currently we remove the diff headers when washing diffs.  Instead

magit-{status,init}: fix and improve

When `magit-init' or `magit-status' is used to create a new repository,
then directory chosen by the user likely does not exist.  In that case
we cannot use `magit-get-top-dir' because that only works in existing
directories.  Create `magit-toplevel-safe' to use when it is unknown
whether the directory in question exists.

In `magit-status' cleanly separate the "initialize" special case from
the rest, previously it was not possible to create a new repository
inside another using this command.  As a result this command is no
longer suitable for non-interactive use and `magit-status-internal'
has to be factored out.

In `magit-init' create its parent directory before creating the new
repository.  Refactor some more.

Improve the doc-string.

magit-diff-visit-file: bugfix

preserve visibility of files in revision buffer

Moving point in the log buffer automatically updates the revision
buffer.  In that buffer file sections (and most other sections) start
out expanded, but if the user collapses a section then it stays that
way when displaying another commit.  Except that it doesn't always,
e.g. if commits A and C modify foo, but B only modifies bar, then
hiding foo in A will be forgotten in B and once C is displayed it is
expanded again.

Counter that by keeping a buffer-local list of files that are to be
hidden again the next time they are encountered.

magit-section-set-visibility-hook: new variable

Add new hook variable `magit-section-set-visibility-hook'.  Run it
in `magit-insert-section' to set the visibility of a section, before
all the other approaches used to decide whether the section should
be shown or not.  Hook functions have to return nil if they don't
care, else `hide' or `show'.
magit-diff-dwim: bugfix

magit-{,branch-or-}commit-at-point: in rev buffers return shown rev

In `magit-revision-mode' buffers `magit-branch-or-commit-at-point' and
`magit-commit-at-point' now return the commit shown in that buffer.

magit-diff-visit-file: use magit-find-file when appropriate

When visiting a committed change and the commit isn't the HEAD commit
then visit the file using `magit-find-file-noselect' instead of visiting
the working tree.

This partially implements #1566.

magit-revision-refresh-buffer: Avoid file refname

When both a file and revision have the same name, 'git show' fails:

    fatal: ambiguous argument 'foo': both revision and filename
    Use '--' to separate paths from revisions, like this:
    'git <command> [<revision>...] -- [<file>...]'

As a result, `magit-revision-refresh-buffer' showed an empty buffer.

Use '--' to specify that this argument is a revision.

Merge branch 'n/diff-args' into next

magit-diff-dwim: new command

In the `magit-diff-popup' bind "d" to the new command, which means that
we can no longer use that for `magit-diff-unstaged'.  Instead "u" shows
unstaged changes and "s" shows changes, which by the way I intended to
do eventually every since I started using "d" and "i" for these
variants.

This also means that we have to rearrange the actions in the popup.
And that in turn is a good opportunity to also make `magit-stash-show'
available from this popup, allowing that command to take advantage
of its use of `magit-diff-arguments' in the `interactive' form added
in the previous commits.

allow changing diff arguments used in current buffer

Add a new popup `magit-diff-refresh-popup' and a new command
`magit-diff-refresh' invoked from that popup, to allow changing the diff
arguments used in the current buffer.  In a diff buffer this changes the
value of `magit-refresh-args' and refreshes.  In other buffers which may
contain other things besides diffs change `magit-diff-section-arguments'
and refresh.

Also add `magit-diff-set-default-arguments' and
`magit-diff-save-default-arguments' which additionally set/save the
default value of the appropriate variable.  In diff buffers that is
`magit-diff-arguments', not `magit-refresh-args'.

add "-M" and "-C" to diff popup

Remove the variable `magit-diff-extra-options' which was always intended
as a kludge.  Instead make "-M" and "-C" available from the diff popup.

Do _not_ add these arguments to the popup default value or to that of
the variable `magit-diff-section-arguments'.  Note that these arguments
were _not_ previously used "by default", the were used unconditionally,
because there was no other way.  Enabling this by default isn't
desirable because it decreases performance.

Also use "--no-prefix" (which also was a member of the removed variable,
but unlike the other arguments is mandatory) explicitly where previously
the variable was used.

respect arguments set in magit-diff-popup

Some time ago this broke and the arguments set in the popup were simply
ignored.  The last few commits improved how we deal with diff arguments,
now we also need to teach the diff commands to actually retrieve the
arguments from the popup (using `magit-current-popup-args') and then
use them when calling `git diff'.

use a variety of variables to hold diff arguments

Use different variables for diff arguments depending on the mode.

In diff-only buffers (whose major-mode derives from `magit-diff-mode'),
continue to use `magit-diff-arguments'.  This _should_ then be used
to set the buffer-local value of `magit-refresh-args'.  But this is
currently not the case and won't be fixed until the next commit.

In also-diff buffers (which contain diffs but also other sections,
e.g. status buffers) we cannot use `magit-refresh-args' because
the diff sections would compete with other sections over who gets
to store their information in there.  So we use the new variable
`magit-diff-section-arguments'.

A later commit will add a new popup which actually allows changing the
value of either `magit-refresh-args' or `magit-diff-section-arguments'.

To make dealing with these complications easy add the new utility
functions `magit-diff-arguments' and `magit-diff-arguments-variable'.

temporarily remove "update diff arguments" functionality

Previously the same popup was used to show a "new diff with the selected
arguments" and to "update the arguments used by the current diff", which
was rather confusing.  A bigger issue however is that in the former case
the arguments are not actually respected.  To make it easier to fix that
first remove the ability to do the latter.  Once the former has been
fixed, the functionality removed here will also be restored, but then
using a dedicated popup and new setter commands.

magit-diff-{set-context,context-p}: new functions

Add the new function `magit-diff-set-context' to do all the heavy
lifting for `magit-diff-{less,more,default}-context'.  This replaces
`magit-diff-previous-context-lines' which only determined the
current (aka previous) value.

The main advantage of this approach is that this will allow using
different variables in diff-only and also-diff buffers, which will be
implemented in a later commit.

By default Git shows three context lines, but until now we did not avoid
having the redundant argument "-U3" as a member of the arguments list.
`magit-diff-set-context' is now capable of doing that, but that also
means that `(not (member "-U0" args))' no longer is sufficient to check
whether any context lines are shown.  Add new `magit-diff-context-p' for
that purpose.

magit-read-range-or-commit: replace alias with actual definition

Previously this was just an alias for `magit-read-branch-or-commit',
now it provides additional functionality useful when reading a range;
the commit at the end and beginning of the region are used as "E..B".

improve appearance of sibling selections and hunk regions

The region can be used to select either several sibling sections or a
range of lines within a single hunk section.

When several sections are selected they are now all displayed the same
way each one of them would be displayed if it were the current section.
If the selected sections are diff file or hunk sections then their
headings are additionally displayed in a different face to make it more
obvious that multiple sections are selected.

When the region spans lines within a hunk then only these lines are
propertized using the usual distinct faces for added and remove lines
lines.  Lines inside the hunk but outside the region are propertized
using the context face, that includes lines beginning with "+" and "-".

Highlighting of the current section now works like this.  The section
is highlighted using an overlay with covers all of the section.  If
multiple sections are selected each one of them is highlighted using
a separate overlay.  Each highlighting overlay has to be added to
`magit-section-highlight-overlays'.  After each command all of these
overlays are deleted and new ones created as needed, which isn't as
wasteful as it may sound.

Highlighted hunk sections and sections that contain such sections
also use an overlay but it only covers the heading.  Hunk bodies are
propertized using text properties.  Each section which uses properties
for highlighting has to be added to `magit-section-highlighted-sections'.
These text properties are not discarded after every command; properties
are only changed for those sections which are newly or no longer
highlighted.

prefix diff faces with "magit-diff-"

There also exist a few faces prefixed with "magit-diffstat-".

magit-diff-scope: add optional STRICT argument

Certain sections (diffstats and untracked files) are treated like diffs
but actually are not (they have no hunks).  In some cases we want to
treat them differently, the STRICT argument causes `magit-diff-scope'
to return nil for such sections.

magit-diff.el: move definitions

magit-diff-hunk-region-{patch,header}: new function

in `magit-apply-region' except the "apply" part.

Add `magit-diff-hunk-region-header' which used the other new
function and returns just the header.

magit-face-remap-set-base: new function

We cannot use `face-remap-set-base' because it is broken at least in
24.3; first it turns the input into an atom and then it tries to get
the car of that.

This isn't just a copy of that function; our implementation is simpler
but doesn't attempt to deal with any possible input we won't be using,
then again it does not barf on any input.
magit-section-make-overlay: return the overlay

make the current section part of the section selection

Until now only sections that had at least one character inside the
region were part of the section selection, and so the current section
usually wasn't part of the selection.

Commands that only know how to act on a single section simply ignore
the selection and instead act on the current section.  When the current
section wasn't considered part of the selection yet this was problematic
because users don't necessarily know which commands use the selection,
so they might select A and B, while point is on C and invoke a command
with the intention to do something with A and B but instead end up
having something done to C.  Now they would expect something to happen
with A and B, and it would only happen to B, which is much less
problematic.

replace magit-current-section with magit-section-highlighted-sections

Replace the variable `magit-current-section' whose value was a single
section with `magit-section-highlighted-sections' whose value is a list
of sections.

Currently all sections are still highlighted using overlays and because
these overlays are stored in existing `magit-section-highlight-overlays',
we don't actually have to store all highlighted sections in the new
variable yet.

This commit makes it possible to use text-properties instead of overlays
to highlight diff sections, but that follows in a later commit.

replace magit-current-sections with magit-region-values

Add function `magit-region-values' replacing `magit-current-sections'.
Both functions take an optional TYPES argument and return nil if the
sections in the region don't match.  But while the old function returned
a list of section objects the new function returns a list of section
values.  And while the old function did fallback to a list consisting
only of the current section if the region only spanned one section or
wasn't in use, the new function simply returns nil.

Use `magit-region-values' in places where `magit-current-sections' or
`(magit-region-sections 'magit-section-value)' was previously used.
Drop `magit-region-sections' now unused KEY argument.

use stashes to backup uncommitted changes

Add a new backup mechanism which uses stashes to saving uncommitted
changes, replacing the old mechanism which used patch files.  This
preserves more information and also makes it easier to restore
discarded changes.

Implement this in the new library `magit-backup.el', but most of the
heavy lifting is done in `magit-stash.el'.  Some of the functions
defined there are generalized so that they are no longer restricted
to refs/stash.

Backups are automatically created before making changes to the index or
working tree.  Where the old mechanism created a backup, the new one
does to, there might be other places where it would make sense to do so.

magit-refresh-buffer: wrestle with window-point again

There have been various attempts at this but they only worked in
some cases and tended to make matters worse in more cases.

The problem we have to solve is that when a non-status buffer is
refreshed and the respective status buffer exists, then that has to
be refreshed too; but unless we take extra precautions `point' would
later (when we actually display the buffer) be reset to the value of
`window-point'.  Now we update `window-point' during refresh for all
windows which do or used to display the buffer being refreshed.
add new library magit-sequence.el

with-editor-server-window-alist: new variable

Add new variable `with-editor-server-window-alist' to allow libraries
that use `with-editor' to override `server-window' for the files they
handle.  Users may add entries too, but it is generally a bad idea to
change or remove entries added by packages.

Add function `with-editor-server-window' which determines the
appropriate value on behalf of `with-editor-process-finish' and our
advice to `server-switch-buffer'.  Previously that function and that
advice arranged for the buffer-local value of `server-window' to be
used.

That hack had one advantage: it allowed packages to only _sometimes_
disrespect the value of `server-window'.  That is no longer possible,
e.g. Magit forces the use of `pop-to-buffer' for commit messages even
when it was not involved in initiating the commit.  (Actually it does
not use that function, but the effect is the same).  On the other hand
this allows the removal of all kinds of ugly kludges from Magit.

make use of with-editor-server-window-alist

Add entries for commit message and rebase sequence buffers to the new
variable `with-editor-server-window-alist'.  Previously we arranged
for the buffer-local value of `server-window' to be set and then be
respected by `with-editor' every time a Git command that would create
such a buffer was called.  That was an ugly hack, because we used a
global variable to "pass information" to the code that would later
create and display the buffer.

Remove that hack consisting of the variable `magit-server-visit-args'
and the functions `magit-server-visit-args' and `magit-server-visit'.

`magit-server-visit' was also used to fiddle with window configuration
when showing the changes that are being committed; and to save the
commit arguments, to help `magit-diff-while-committing' later show the
correct "other meaningful diff".  Turns out this function doesn't need
our help to do so. And the window configuration tricks are now performed
in the new `magit-commit-switch-to-buffer'.

use same specialized sentinel for all sequence commands

Remove `magit-rebase-async', instead use `magit-run-git-sequencer'
for all the other sequence commands too.  This function now uses
`magit-sequencer-process-sentinel' which was previously named
`magit-rebase-process-sentinel' and is now adjusted to find
commits in non-rebase sequence sections too.

remove unnecessary option magit-success-executable

Instead just use "true".  Git uses that too so we can
safely assume it is available, even on a crappy OS.

magit-section-forward: handle "\n after children" special case

There often is a newline after all children which does not belong to
the last child but to its parent.  Iff the parent section is expanded
this newline serves as separator.

When point was on that newline `magit-section-forward' used to go to
the first child instead of the next sibling.

remove last section gap

Each section, except for the root section, begins with text which
directly belongs to it.  For sections which have children that is the
heading.  Then come the child sections and almost all text that follows
is part of these child sections.  The only exception is that after all
children there may be a single empty line, which serves to separate the
expanded section from its next sibling.  When the section is collapsed
that newline is also hidden.

This is the "newline after children" exception.  Until now there was one
other section: after the headers in the status buffer there was an empty
line separating from the following section which was not part of the
sections that wrap the headers.  It has been like this for a long time
and the reason I did not change it was that I felt that there should be
a separator between the headers and the first non-header section even
when the headers are collapsed (meaning that only the "Head" header is
showing).  I haven't really changed my mind on that but feel that the
elimination of this special case is much more important.  (We could
emulate the old look by adding a separator section after the headers,
which consisted of only a newline).

use selected window to edit note

Since we do the same for commit messages.  (It might
not look like we so in that case, but we really do).

use selected window to edit rebase sequence

Move the call to `magit-server-visit-args' from
`magit-run-git-sequencer' to `magit-rebase-async'; other
callers of the former don't need to set the visit arguments.

Call `magit-server-visit-args' without providing any values for the
arguments OTHER-WINDOW and ARGS.  Previously we attempted to provide
a value for ARGS, but ended up making OTHER-WINDOW non-nil (which we
don't want) and omitting ARGS (which didn't matter because that value
wasn't used anyway).

magit-define-popup: better default name for arguments variable

The macro `magit-define-popup' defines one command and two variables.
The names of these symbols are based on the NAME argument.  The command
and the internal variable which holds constant data are both named just
`NAME'.  There are no restrictions imposed on what `NAME' can be but it
should be something like `PACKAGE-TOPIC-popup' or just `PACKAGE-TOPIC'.
Magit uses the first form so NAME is something `magit-TOPIC-popup'.

The second variable, whose value are the selected shell arguments, was
previously named `NAME-defaults', unless the `:variable' keyword
argument was used.

For most popups this name makes sense because the variable never hold
anything but the default shell arguments.  But for the diff popup this
didn't work well, because that variable is used for other things also.
So we used the name `magit-diff-options' in that case.

Now we change the names of all argument variables (including that of the
diff popup) to `magit-TOPIC-arguments'.  Note that there is no `-popup'
in that name; if NAME ends with "-popup" then the macro removes that
before appending "-arguments".

magit-show-refs-head: new command

The key "y" is bound to `magit-show-refs-popup', which is one of these
popups which be default are suppressed and instead just invoke the
default action.  The default previously was `magit-show-refs' but that
command always prompts for a branch and does not allow the user to
select "HEAD", which is what we want when HEAD is detached.

So add a new command `magit-show-refs-head' which alwyas uses the
current branch, HEAD if it is detached.  When the popup is invoked
with a prefix argument the user can use `magit-show-refs' instead.

  "Snapshot on <branch>: <hash> <summary>"

which would be like
