magit-branch{,-and-checkout}: base default name on starting-point

In `magit-branch-read-args' which is used by these commands, read the
starting point first and if a remote branch is chosen use the branch
part of that as the default when reading the name of the new local
branch.

Previously we read the branch name first and then the starting-point,
which I feel is a more natural order (and also how these arguments are
passed to `git branch|checkout').  But doing it in that order did also
mean that we could not provide a default based on the starting point
when reading the branch name, because that obviously meant that we did
not know yet what the starting point was going to be.

magit-checkout: remove "tracking branch confusion"

This is a backport of 9af9551470d1f10295ebd0aa5c1fac079a829e1d from
next, but where that completely removes the ability to create a local
branch whose upstream is a remote branch when using `magit-checkout',
this only removes the unnecessary complications that resulted from a
misunderstandings of what "tracking branches" are.

Similar functionality might later be restored on next.

Also see #1476.

git-commit-prev-message: fix first usage

Variable `log-edit-comment-ring-index' has to be buffer-local but isn't
marked as automatically buffer-local and since `git-commit-mode' cannot
derive from `log-edit-mode' we too have to explicitly mark it as such
in `git-commit-setup'.

`git-commit-prev-message' differs from `log-edit-previous-comment' in
that it saves the current buffer content in the message ring before
replacing it in the buffer with the previous message using the latter.

`log-edit-comment-ring-index' is nil until `log-edit-previous-comment'
is first used, at which point it is initialized to point to the last
(if going backward) or the last (if going forward) message in the ring.
Because the last message is the one we just save, we have initialize
ourselves *before* calling `log-edit-previous-comment' otherwise we
would "go back" to the current message.  When going forward or when
there was no message to be save this is irrelevant, or rather doing
so would actually be counterproductive, so we don't.

add hooks magit-section-{,un}highlight

evaporate section highlighting overlays

We already did that for other overlays.  We now also do this for
highlighting overlays, which is necessary because refreshing the
buffer does not first delete these overlays.

highlight all headings using overlays

Unlike other sections hunks, and parents of such sections, are not
highlighted using a single overlay.  Instead all of their parts where
highlighted using text properties.  Until now that included section
headings, which wasn't a problem because all these headings where
uniform, they used a single face for all text.

In subsequent commits we are going to display diffs in more places,
making additional section types parents of hunks.  Some of these
sections have more colorful headings; overlays have to be used to
highlight these headings or their text properties would be lost due to
highlighting.

When expanding the section involves inserting and washing it, then

Merge branch 'n/read-branches' into next

add various branch and commit readers

Previously mainly one function, `magit-read-rev', was used to read all
kinds of branches and arbitrary commits and ranges from the user.  Two
other, specialized functions already existed, `magit-read-local-branch'
and `magit-read-remote-branch', but these functions weren't used much.
Because `magit-read-rev' was very generic all callers had to duplicate
code responsible for determining the default choice and other things
that could have been abstracted away.  Aside from the duplication the
main problem was that the various defaults were not always consistent,
i.e. there were several commands that should have defaulted to the
current branch, but instead defaulted to just "HEAD".

The functions whose names do not contain "no-commit" now only complete
branches.  The functions whose names do contain "no-commit" also offer
branches for completion, but also other refs, and furthermore they do
not restrict what the user can input, and even the default choice may
not be a branch.  When the default isn't a branch these functions try
to use a relative name such as "master~3" but we do not yet impose any
restrictions against which branches relative names are created.  Users
may also insert complete or abbreviated hashes.

In fact users could input arbitrary non-sense and there is no protection
against that yet, like there wasn't with `magit-read-rev'.  We currently
use this "feature" in an additional new completing function
`magit-read-range-or-commit'.  For now this is merely a stub, actually
it even is just an alias for `magit-read-branch-or-commit'.  Eventually
we need a completing function which can complete on both sides of "..".

The functions that contain "other" in their names take an optional
EXCLUDE argument.  When that is non-nil then these functions offer
branches different from that branch for completion, instead of those
different from the current branch.  Of course the excluded
branch (whether given explicitly or when defaulting to the current
branch) is never used as the default choice.

The new and improved completing functions are now consistent in what
they use as the default choice.  They use the branch at point (or commit
at point where appropriate) as default.  If there is no branch/commit at
point they use the current branch as default, except for the functions
whose name contain "other" which use the previous branch as default, and
prevent the current branch from even being selected explicitly.  Most of
the completing functions now take an optional argument DEFAULT, which
can be used to override the secondary default, i.e. the branch/commit at
point remains the default (if it isn't the excluded branch), but there
is nothing at point, then the value of this argument is used as default
instead of the current or previous branch.  There are only a few callers
which make use of this, but for a few it makes much more sense to
e.g. default to the tracked branch.

avoid needlessly connecting to unrelated tramp remotes

In `magit-save-repository-buffers' avoid needlessly connecting
to unrelated tramp remotes by first checking whether the absolute
path to the top-level of the current directory is a prefix of
`buffer-file-name'.  Only if that is so check whether
`buffer-file-name' is actually directly in that repository (it
may also be part of a submodule or other nested repository).

Fixes #1473 on next.

to unrelated tramp remotes by first checking whether the absolute path
to the top-level of the current directory is a prefix of
`buffer-file-name'.  Only if that is so check whether `buffer-file-name'
is actually directly in that repository (it may also be part of a
submodule or other nested repository.

Fixes #1473.

begin rearranging magit.el

Actually we already began with that some commits ago, but this is the
beginning of the final step.

The goal is to have five top-level sections: Options, Inspect,
Manipulate, Transfer and Miscellaneous.  The main split, which makes it
necessary to move many second level sections is between Inspect,
Manipulate and Transfer.  Because not everything fits perfectly in these
three categories, we also need Miscellaneous.  Even so some things that
will be placed in one of the tree main sections, will not fit perfectly.
Some inconsistency cannot be avoided.

This commit renames Modes to Inspect and moves Porcelain>Visit to
Inspect>Files.  Because Visit was the first subsection of Porcelain and
now is the last subsection of Inspect, we can do so by moving the
Porcelain heading instead of the Visit code.

Also change the names of the subsections of Porcelain, losing the "-ing"
suffix.  Now Porcelain is a misnomer, because other sibling sections are
just as much about porcelain - and just as much *not* about that.  We
cannot split Porcelain into Manipulate and Transfer yet, because the
subsections are not in the right order yet.

implicitly/explicitly depend on cl-lib and dash

Libraries that are an integral part of Magit no longer explicitly
depend on `cl-lib' and `dash'.  These libraries are explicitly
required in `magit.el', so requiring that library implies that
these other libraries are also loaded.

But for libraries that are *not* an integral part of Magit *do*
explicitly require `cl-lib' and `dash' when appropriate.  These
libraries will be split of into separate packages/repositories,
so they should list their dependencies explicitly.

Also explicitly require `cl-lib' and `dash' in `magit.el'.

`magit-popup.el' has to explicitly require `cl-lib' and `dash'
because it loaded before `magit.el'.  Clearly separate the
respective require forms from those for other external
dependencies.

use "magit-diff-" as prefix of all diff related functions

Previously some used just "magit-".
magit.el: delay requiring epa

magit.el: remove undead dependencies

Stop requiring libraries which no longer use.

add custom group magit-commands

Add a new Custom group for options that control the behavior of certain
commands, and for which no other suitable Custom group exists.

Many of these options tune the behavior of commands that *create*
commits.  These options were previously placed in the `magit-commit'
group, but that group is for functionality related to the inspection
of *existing* commits.  The other options were previously placed in
`magit-modes' group, which is wrong because none of them have directly
to do with any of the various major modes provided by Magit.

An alternative to creating `magit-commands' would have been to place
these options in `magit', but I would prefer to reserve that for options
with "global" effects, the exact opposite of what these the options in
question do.

Fix font-locking of action and file

This patch changes the regular expression that is supposed to match the
lines containing "modified:" or "some-file.txt" in the example below. It
is desirable that this regexp does not match multiple lines.

    #       modified:   git-commit-mode.el
    #
    # Untracked files:
    #       some-file.txt

The reason is that if the commit message contains a diff (i.e. "git
commit -v" was run) the "[^:]:" regexp can match multiple lines if there
is a colon in the diff. In the example above, the match would span from
'some-file.txt' up to the colon in the diff. This results in overriding
the font-locking in the diff.

Signed-off-by: Michal Sojka <sojkam1@fel.cvut.cz>

refactor rebase commands, slightly changing their behavior

Refactor the commands `git-rebase-move-line-up',
`git-rebase-move-line-down', `git-rebase-kill-line',
`git-rebase-rebase-exec', `git-rebase-show-commit' and as well as the
utility function `git-rebase-edit-line', which is used by many of the
other commands.

The behavior of these commands changes slightly, in that they no longer
try to avoid moving point to the beginning of the line.  Previously
some of them did, while others did not.  Now they consistently do what
I prefer (move to bol) and which is also easier to implement.

Thanks to that we can now remove the utility functions
`git-rebase-looking-at-action' and
`git-rebase-looking-at-action-or-exec', and replace the constants
`git-rebase-action-line-re', `git-rebase-exec-line-re' and
`git-rebase-dead-line-re' with just `git-rebase-line'.  Also define
some regexps directly in `git-rebase-mode-font-lock-keywords'.

magit-rebase-exec: change semantics

When there is a command on the current line then always edit it.
Even when it is commented out, like before that is uncommented
but the prompting also happens.

A prefix argument now forces prompting for a new command, instead
of editing the command on the current line.  So the behavior of
the prefix argument is more or less reverses.

This also allows the removal of the utility functions
`git-rebase-looking-at-exec' and `git-rebase-looking-at-killed-exec'.

This will allow users to customize it and extension packages, such as

to it.

magit-commit-add-log: Use symbol boundary in function name REGEXP

Use symbol boundary instead of word boundary in function name REGEXP. This is
because using word boundary causes partial function name being matched. As an
example, let's say we have two diff hunks, one in the function `foo' and the
other in `foo-bar'. When the word boundary REGEXP is used, the REGEXP matches
both function name `foo' and `foo-bar', which will prevent
`magit-commit-add-log' from adding a log entry for function `foo-bar' if an
entry for function `foo' already exist.

remove magit-insert-header, add magit-string-pad

Remove the macro `magit-insert-header', a very thin wrapper around
`magit-insert-section'.  The defining feature was that the leading
keyword was padded.  We factor out that functionality into the new
generic `magit-string-pad'.

remove variable magit-status-line-align-to

This variable was used when padding the leading keywords of header lines
in the status buffer.  Its purpose was to allow third-party extensions
that use headers with keywords that are longer than those used in Magit,
to adjust the padding accordingly.  By removing this variable, we remove
that - so far unused - feature.  If needed this can add such a variable
again.

For why we "needlessly" do that, see the next few commits.

magit-refresh-buffer: do nothing if magit-refresh-function is nil

This is done to avoids unnecessary work.  But it also prevents
`magit-refresh-buffer-hook' from running, which might be a problem for
third-party code which for some reason expects this to run even if the
buffer was not actually refreshed.  If this turns out to be the case
then we could change back to always run that hook.

magit-branch-popup: removed unused arguments

Remove the `--merged', `, `--no-merged' and `--contains' arguments from
the `magit-branch-popup'.  This popup does not feature a "list branches"
command and these options are only meaningful with such a command.  Not
only do this options no longer serve any purpose, if a user actually
sets them and then uses one of the commands which actually respect
`magit-current-popup-args' then that results in an error.

Once upon a time these switches were used by `magit-branch-manager'
which no longer is available from this popup, and which not even exists
anymore.  Its successor `magit-show-refs' no longer supports these
arguments. It could possibly make sense to restore support for these
arguments.  If we implement that, then it should be done using a popup
`magit-show-refs-popup', with only one action `magit-show-refs'.

These faces are only used inside comments, and the names of all

remove "-face" suffix from face names

The names of faces are not supposed to end with "-face", that is
redundant.  There are some internal faces (most prominently the
font-lock faces) whose names do end with "-face" but these are

git-commit-check-style-conventions: ask specific questions

Instead of asking whether the user wants to commit despite unnamed
stylistic errors, ask for each error individually and explicitly.

Also remove `git-commit-has-style-errors-p', its functionality
is now sprinkled across `git-commit-check-style-conventions'.

We still ignore certain errors and we shouldn't be doing that.

fontify comments in the regexp pass

In Git commit messages comments are lines beginning with # (actually
`core.commentchar').  A # later in a line does not begin a comment,
so it is common to use #N to refer to the issue N.

Until now # and everything that follows was always fontified as
comment because we used syntactic fontification.

We already defined a keyword regexp for comments, but that was
redundant.  We also set `comment-use-syntax' to nil, but that only
affects the commands in `newcomment', not actual fontification.

We now turn off syntactic fontification by not adding `core.commentchar'
to the syntax table as a comment starter .  Instead we add it as
punctuation.  (The major mode might already have added it as a comment
starter, we need to override that).

For some reason when a syntactic-pass string appears inside a
regexp-pass comment, then nothing on that line actually is displayed as
comment.  Until we know the cause of this, we work around it by also
defining potential string delimiters as punctuation.
respect git variable core.commentchar

magit-insert-child-count: massive speed-up

Previously we used `looking-back' to check whether a section's heading
ended with ":" indicating that a child count should be inserted.  That
had a devastating effect on performance.  We now use `char-before'.
And generally avoid all unnecessary work.

magit-section-show: trigger highlight after delayed washing

When expanding a section involved creating its content (i.e when the
washing was delayed for performance reasons), then set variable
`magit-current-section' to nil to force `magit-highlight-section' to
highlight the complete section, including the newly inserted text.

magit-highlight-section: always set magit-current-section

In `magit-highlight-section' always update the value of variable
`magit-current-section' (previously named `magit-highlighted-section')
even when we don't actually highlight the new current section (because
it is the root section or to avoid shadowing the region).

If we don't do that, then the previously current section remains the
"highlighted" section and when we later go back to that section then
it isn't highlighted because we "didn't select another section".

To avoid confusion rename the variable to `magit-current-section'.
But note that it is still better to use the function by the same name
to determine the current section in arbitrary contexts, because if a
command changes point then the value of the variable might not be
correct until after `post-command-hook' and thus
`magit-highlight-section' has run.

with-editor-process-filter: expand relative file name

The child process might call the $EDITOR with a relative file name,
so we have to remember the working directory when the process is
created and then, if we get a relative file name, expand it in
`with-editor-process-filter'.

The easiest way to pass the `default-directory' from our advice to
`start-file-process' to `with-editor-process-filter', is to store it
in the process object.
magit-reset-soft: actually do a *soft* reset

with-editor-process-filter: set with-editor--envvar in correct buffer

Make sure that `with-editor-process-filter' sets the buffer-local value
of `with-editor--envvar' in the buffer being visited.  Previously we
relied on the function specified by `server-window' to keep that buffer
current, but while it is unlikely that it doesn't do so, there is no
guarantee.

use built-in internal-default-process-filter, if available

Emacs has `internal-default-process-filter' since version 24.4; use it
if it's fbound.  Otherwise define a lisp implementation.  Previously our
function was named `with-editor-standard-process-filter', now we call it
`internal-default-process-filter' too.
advice(start-file-process): cosmetics

with-editor-locate-emacsclient: cosmetics

Instead of `when-let' use `let' because the value always is non-nil.

magit-blame-process-filter: avoid empty lines

When splitting partial output from `git blame --incremental' drop empty
lines, i.e. very partial output which we cannot process in a meaningful
way.  There are not actually empty lines in the output, but we might
receive partial output which only consists of a newline.  Dropping the
newline does not cause any problems latter when we combine partial
output, because we store partial output as a list of lines.

magit-blame: bind inhibit-magit-refresh to t

Without this the blame information is created and then immediately
destroyed again in `magit-revert-buffers' called by `magit-refresh'.

magit-start-process: respect inhibit-magit-refresh

Dynamically binding `inhibit-magit-refresh' to t previously had no
effect for asynchronous processes because the refresh is triggered
by `magit-process-sentinel' which is run outside that binding.

Now `magit-start-process' saves the value of `inhibit-magit-refresh'
in a property of the process and `magit-process-sentinel' forgoes
calling `magit-refresh' if that is non-nil.

magit-mark-commit: use magit-mode-get-buffers

instead of `magit-map-magit-buffers' which was just removed.
add magit-mode-get-buffers, remove magit-map-magit-buffers

magit.el: cosmetics

sanitize preparation of arguments to Git

Add a single function `magit-process-git-arguments' which prepares
the arguments to Git.  This includes flattening the list of arguments,
prepending `magit-process-standard-options', and when Cygwin Git is used
the quoting of certain problematic strings.

All of this is now only done for Git processes, previously we did also
flatten arguments in `magit-call-process' and `magit-start-process'.
Also avoid repeatedly flattening the arguments, by only doing so at the
lowest possible level, in calls to built-in process functions, i.e. in
`magit-git-exit-code', `magit-git-string', `magit-git-insert',
`magit-git-lines', `magit-run-git, and `magit-start-git'.

Arguments are now fully flattened.  Previously only the first level was
flattened.  Or at least that is what the doc-strings claimed, in reality
a varying number of levels was flattened (because the "one-level only"
flattening happened several times).

Because the argument list is now fully flattened - just before calling
Git - we can also drop several uses of `apply'.

Remove the option `magit-process-quote-curly-braces' (for Cygwin Git)
and instead put the test previously used to set its value directly into
`magit-process-git-arguments'.  While there never is absolute certainty
with things concerning Windows, there also have been no reports about
the quoting happening when it shouldn't, or not happening when it
should.  So remove the option to avoid confusing users (also the
doc-string was not really correct).

magit-revert-buffers: don't use auto-revert-handler

`auto-revert-handler' does quite a few things we don't need, so instead
of using that just call `revert-buffer', `vc-find-file-hook' directly.

Since that also means that our advice to `auto-revert-handler' is
no longer used also turn `magit-blame-mode' off and on again when
appropriate.  But do not remove the advice, it is still needed when
`auto-revert-handler' is called outside of our control.

magit-blame-mode: bugfix

Users should use `magit-blame' or `magit-blame-popup' to turn on
`magit-blame-mode', but the intention was to also support using
the mode command for this purpose.  For that to work we have to
bind `magit-blame-mode' to nil around the call to `magit-blame',
because that otherwise thinks we are doing an recursive blame.
advice(auto-revert-handler): bugfix

magit-wash-diff: present submodules like git-status

Present submodules more like `git status' does.  I.e. use the adjective
"modified" for modified submodules and not "dirty" or "modified" with an
additional suffix.  To differentiate modified submodules from regular
modified files now append "new commits" and or "modified content", just
like `git status' does.

There is one exception `git status' doesn't present a newly added
submodule any different from a newly added file ("new file"), we do by
using "new module" when appropriate.

This commit also fixes parsing of newly added modules, previously that
failed completely.

A typechange is treated as a hunk because it can be staged like a hunk
and because it saves a lot of work if we don't have to explicitly teach
many commands how to handle typechanges.  But `magit-paint-hunk' only
knows (and needs to) paint real hunks, so make it stop attempting to do

Merge branch 'n/ediff-resolve' into next

magit-ediff-resolve-file: new command

Add `magit-ediff-resolve-file', a simple wrapper around `smerge-ediff',
as a replacement for `magit-interactive-resolve'.  This fixes #256, i.e.
only unresolved commits are shown.  Ediff was created in the age of vcs
that are bad at merging and has not yet been adjusted for dvcs like Git
and Mercurial, and so it actually wants to do all everything that needs
to be done to do a merge.  However we want to initiate the merge using
Git and then we want Ediff to help us with the conflicts Git could not
automatically resolve; we don't want to also have Ediff attempt to
resolve the conflicts that Git already resolved, especially because
Ediff fails more often than Git, causing the user additional work.
That's why the command name contains "resolve" not "merge", we only
use Ediff to resolve conflicts, not to do a merge.

create a backup whenever git-apply is used

Always backup the applied diff when `git apply' is used.  Previously we
only did so when `git apply --reverse' was used.  We now backup more
diffs, but this still is not sufficient, so add appropriate warnings to
the relevant doc-strings.

The fate of this backup mechanism is undecided, I might replace it with
a mechanism based on `git stash' or I might improve it.  The problem
with the former is that it requires a (trivial) patch to git-stash, and
latter likely leads to complications elsewhere.

Because this no longer is only used when `--reverse' is used (which we
used to wrongly refer to as "revert") rename the involved functions and
variables, `magit-{revert => apply}-{backup,backup-file,undo}'.

Save the arguments used when applying the diff as diff pretext, and in
`magit-apply-undo' use the inverse of these arguments (which might mean
adding or *removing* the `--reverse' argument).

change key bindings for magit-show-refs and magit-cherry

The old `magit-branch-manager' command was only bound in popups while
the old `magit-wazzup' command was only bound in the mode map (and the
dispatch popup).

Since there now is only `magit-show-refs', we can do better.  Because
this command is important enough give it the mode map.  But don't use
"w" which was used by `magit-wazzup' (and which we are going to use for
one of the sequence commands) instead use "y".  "y" was previously bound
to `magit-cherry', which can be considered a lightweight, but less
important, variant of the cherry-feature of `magit-show-refs', and is
now moved to "Y".

Do not bind `magit-show-refs' in any popups (except for the dispatch
popup).  Commands that are bound in the mode map don't need to be
available from popups (except the dispatch popup whose purpose is to
help users who don't know the binding in the mode map).

add magit-refs-mode and magit-show-refs

Add a new mode `magit-refs-mode' which replaces the two old modes
`magit-branch-manager-mode' and `magit-wazzup-mode'.  The new entry
command is `magit-show-refs', replacing `magit-branch-manager' and
`magit-wazzup'.

Originally these had to be different modes because wazzup was so
slow that users would only tolerate it when they actually needed the
additional information it provided compared to the branch manager.
I have made wazzup fast quite some time ago but until now didn't get
around to merging the two modes.

The new mode is called "Refs Mode" because it lists all kinds of
references not just branches (that was already the case of the old
"'Branch' Manager" too).

try harder to locate a suitable emacsclient executable

Improve how the default value of `with-editor-emacsclient-executable'
is determined.  If we fail to do so, show a warning.

We determine whether an emacsclient executable is compatible with the
current Emacs instance by comparing its version with `emacs-version'.
The versions don't have to match exactly, but at least the major part
has to do so.  This commit changes how an executable's version is
determined.  We now use `emacsclient --version' to do so.  Relying on
a version-suffix does not work, because most often these executables
do not have one.

Merge branch 'n/apply' into next
magit-revert-{backup-file,undo}: move definitions

magit-reverse: extend scope

Teach `magit-reverse' how to reverse multiple files (region and list),
at once.  Also teach it when reversing doesn't make sense: when the
change isn't tracked by Git throwing it away is enough.  The correct way
to make an unstaged change go away is to discard it, the correct way to
make an untracked file go away is to delete it (which is a variant of
discard).

Add new functions `magit-reverse-files` and `magit-reverse-apply', to
implement this.

rename magit-revert to magit-reverse

While both "revert" and "reverse" are used for some kind of "undo",
these actions are only somewhat related and definitely not the same.

While a `revert' Git command exists, there is no `reverse' command.
That term appears in form of the `--reverse' argument to the `apply'
command.

Because it is confusing that the command `magit-revert' does *not*
use or do the same thing as the command `git revert', rename it to
`magit-reverse', which makes sense because it ultimately ends up
using `git apply --reverse'.

Also move the definition of `magit-revert-commit' (which is Magit's
wrapper around `git revert') away from the `magit-reverse'.

improve discarding of changes

I.e. (1) clearly separate it from "reversing" and "unstaging" and
(2) teach it about all the change units and sets a user might want
to discard.

Git doesn't know how to discard a change, so we have to use various
commands to implement this.  Require confirmation from the user for
each discard variant individually.  The variants are `delete' an
added file, `resurrect' a deleted file, undo a `rename', `discard'
an edit, and `resolve' a conflict by picking a side (and therefor
discarding the other).

magit-wash-diff: use " -> " as rename indicator

Previously we used " => ", now use what Git uses.

magit-section: rename DIFF-SOURCE slot to SOURCE

and only set its value if it's different from that of slot VALUE.

add option magit-no-confirm and function magit-confirm

Add it in most places where we previously used `yes-or-no-p'.  For
some of these, options existed to disable the confirmation; remove
these options `magit-stage-all-confirm', `magit-unstage-all-confirm',
and `magit-revert-confirm'.  In other cases it was previously not
possible to turn off confirmation.

allow discarding just the un-/staged part of a file

Previously it was only possible to discard a file if it had either
staged or unstaged changes.  Remove that limitation.  Note that
discarding staged changes is done in two steps by first unstaging
and then applying the same changes in reverse to the worktree.
This second step can fail due to conflicts.

Merge branch 'n/pcase' into next

for pcase, require at least version 24.1 of Emacs

Sooner or later this had to happen.  While I would have preferred to
delay this move until after releasing version 2.1.0, it was always
clear, that I was only willing to maintain backward compatibility as
long as the cost was not very high.

Denying myself the use of `pcase' is such a cost.  I am going to use
this macro a lot, and while it would be possible to implement the
things to come without using `pcase', doing so would not be pleasant.
So unpleasant in fact, that the temptation would be big to write a
specialized "case" macro, similar to `magit-section-case'.  But my
experience with that, and `magit-section-action', has taught me that
going down that road leads to over-specialized abstractions which
eventually end up being rather featureful, but never-the-less to
restrictive even for its intended use-cases.

improve how a section is selected during buffer refresh

Do not attempt to restore `window-start' and do not fallback to
restoring `point' in case no successor section can be found.

Instead handle a few special cases (mostly related to un-/staging)
explicitly.  And if everything else fails then simply go to the
beginning of the buffer (which, while not perfect, is a better
fallback than the old "scroll everything off screen" :-).

In other words, don't try to be smart, just get the work done.

git-rebase-show-commit: don't bind default-directory

Do not let-bind `default-directory' around the call to
`magit-show-commit'.  That function works in the gitdir without any
problems, so changing to the worktree is not actually necessary.

However `magit-show-commit' causes `magit-repository-buffers'
to be called.  That function then uses `magit-inside-worktree-p'
to determine whether it should offer to save a file; and the
unnecessary let-binding removed here, tricked it into believing
`.git/rebase-merge/git-rebase-todo` is not actually in the gitdir.

which is outside of the scope of Git commit mode.

Conflicts:
	magit-svn.el

try harder to locate a suitable emacsclient executable

Improve how the default value of `magit-emacsclient-executable' is
determined.  If we fail to do so, show a warning.

We determine whether an emacsclient executable is compatible with the
current Emacs instance by comparing its version with `emacs-version'.
The versions don't have to match exactly, but at least the major part
has to do so.

This commit changes how an executable's version is determined.
Previously we simply used the version suffix of the executable.
Unfortunately when Emacs is installed manually, then the emacsclient
executable usually does not have a version suffix, and so we did fall
back to the suffix-less executable which comes first on `exec-path',
which is a lottery.

Now we use `emacsclient --version' to determine the version, and the
order in which version-suffix-less emacsclient executable appear on
the `exec-path' therefor no longer matters.

always fallback to magit-checkout-stage when discarding

When the user "discards" a conflict, then always offer to a side using
`magit-checkout-stage'.  Previously we only did so when acting on a file
section that was listed below the "unstaged" changes, but not when it
was listed below "staged".  Because these section really refer to the
same conflict, it does not make sense to redirect the reasonable action
in one case, while throwing up our hands in the other.

To allow this change (and others to follow) move most of the work
involved in discarding an individual file to `magit-discard-file'.
Previously it was randomly split across that function and
`magit-discard'.

names we have to parse several header lines, and then, depending

Merge branch 'n/hunk-background' into next

highlight hunks without overriding semantic background colors

Generally speaking, highlighting the current section using the
background color means that any text in that section which also sets
a background color different from that of `default' loses its special
appearance.  For things like ref names we work around this by using
overlays.

But we didn't do that for added, removed, and context lines in diffs,
even though the default values of the respective faces did only set the
background color but not the foreground color.  This was fixed by some
third-party color themes by instead using the foreground color instead
of the background color to differentiate lines in diffs.

This commit makes such kludges unnecessary.  It is still possible to do
it the old way, but it is not recommended, because doing so makes it
much harder to come up with faces for hunk refinement which both look
good and are sufficiently visible.  (Using bold is not a good option;
it's easy to overlook, and for whitespace it doesn't have any effect at
all.)

So hunks are now treated as a special case when highlighting; instead of
`magit-section-highlight' the new faces `magit-hunk-heading-highlight',
`magit-diff-added-highlight', `magit-diff-removed-highlight', and
`magit-diff-context-highlight' are used.

Furthermore we don't use overlays to apply these faces but the face text
property.  Doing it this way avoids problems with `diff-refine-hunk'.
If we did use overlays these overlays would in some cases override the
refinement overlays.

define magit-diff-{added,removed,context} faces from scratch

No longer inherit from `diff-{added,removed,context}' because these
faces only define the background color.  It is better to also define the
foreground color because other faces that overlay the text propertized
with these faces might also set the background color (which would shadow
the background colors of the diff faces, but not their foreground colors).

This is specially problematic because in Magit the current section is,
by default, highlighted using the background color.  That will be fixed
in the next commit, but the same applies to the region.

use shades of grey for highlighting and refname faces

Previously `magit-section-highlight' inherited from
`secondary-selection'.

Doing so had the advantage that for most themes this face is
sufficiently distinct form other faces without requiring any further
customization.  The default background color for `secondary-selection'
was selected so that it works regardless of what changes were made to
other faces.  This is done by using a background color which unlikely
to be used as background or foreground color for any face in most
reasonable themes.  The disadvantage, and result, of this is that
this face always looks very out of place.

For `secondary-selection' this works (not the "secondary").  But for
`magit-section-highlight' it doesn't; we use that face all the time,
and we want Magit to look okay when using the default faces (dark or
light).

use shade of grey for magit-log-date

So that is different from magit-log-author.

use shade of grey for magit-hash

Hashes should not stand out because, from a human perspective, they are
usually not very interesting.  So use some shade of grey instead, to
make them *less* visible.  Previously some red was used which was also
semantically wrong; red is the color used for e.g. *removed* lines,
while the main even in a commit's life is its *creation*.
add face magit-refname-stash
magit-refname-wip: inherit from magit-refname

use magit-diff-file-heading only for text, not complete line

For most headings the heading face is only used for the actual text but
not for the following newline.  This makes a difference when the
background color is set for the heading face.

For hunk headings we also propertize the newline and by default also set
the background color, which makes diffs more readable because this
clearly separates different hunks from one another.

Until now we also did that for files because a diff may contain several
files and separating them clearly makes sense the same way it does for
hunks.  We did not actually set the background color by default, but
users who wanted to visually separate files the same way that hunks are,
just had to do so.

However if the background color actually is specified and spans the hole
line then the region is not visible when selecting multiple files.  This
would be very confusing so remove the ability to set the background for
the complete file heading line.
add face magit-conflict-heading, replacing magit-diff-merge-{*}
magit-file-heading: cosmetics

rename faces magit{-diff => }-{file,hunk}-head{er => ing}

Rename `magit-diff-file-header' to `magit-file-heading', and
rename `magit-diff-hunk-header' to `magit-hunk-heading'.

Drop the "diff" from the name of "file" face because it is also used
outside of diffs, i.e. for untracked files.  Drop it from the name of
the "hunk" face too for consistency.

Replace "header" with "heading" because we only use the term "header"
for those one-line headers that appear at the top of some buffers.  For
the part of a section that remains visible even in collapsed state we
use "heading".  Consistently using distinct terms helps avoid confusion.

use lowercase and CamelCase color names

For color names that consist of a single word use lowercase.
For color names that consist of multiple words use CamelCase.
rearrange face definitions
compress face definitions
remove faces magit-{log-message,signature-none}
add faces magit-diffstat-{added,removed}

rearrange section utilities

Create just one section "Section Utilities" by absorbing the directly
preceding, one-definition section "Section Utilities" and moving some of
the definitions previously in "Section Actions" here.  The latter is the
reason we are doing this; we have to move these things up so that we can
use the `magit-section-case' macro in code which is defined earlier than
where it used to be defined.  The `magit-{*}-at-point' functions are
moved elsewhere, putting them below "Section Api" was a mistake in the
first place.

remove option magit-section-highlight-face

This option served to purposes:

It allowed disabling highlighting of the current section.  The ability
to do this was added because of performance considerations, not as an
aesthetic choice.  The effect on performance is not noticeable and so
it is okay to drop support for this.  It is still possible to have the
visual effect of not highlighting the current section by unsetting all
face properties or setting these property to the same value it has in
the `default' face.

Once a theme has set a face property it is not possible for user to
unset that property again, she can just change it to something else,
but not nothing.  This was a problem until recently, but now this can
be worked around by setting that property to the same value it has in
the `default' face.

remove option magit-use-overlays

Make `magit-insert' and `magit-put-face-property' always use overlays.
Previously it was possible to use text properties which theoretically
gives a small performance boast.  But the option to do the latter was
more confusing than helpful and I doubt that anybody actually made use
of it, especially because doing so would force the use of something
other than the background color for highlighting the current section.

is nice, but soooooooo slow on Windows".

to expensive to run over and over again.  And I don't like caching.

Merge branch 'n/save-buffers' into next

save modified file-visiting buffers more often

Previously we did save, or offer to save such buffers when:

* Before refreshing (g) the status buffer.  (Which also happens when
  refreshing some other Magit buffer, but unfortunately at the wrong
  time; after updating the other buffer.)
* Before creating or jumping to the status buffer (C-x g).
* Before creating and/or checking out a branch.

Now we do so when:

* Before refreshing any Magit buffer.
* Before creating or jumping to any Magit buffer.
* Before calling git in `magit-call-git' and `magit-start-git',
  which means that we do so for many more Magit commands, which
  end up running Git using one of these functions.

This is controlled using the following new hooks:

* magit-mode-setup-hook
* magit-pre-refresh-hook
* magit-pre-call-git-hook
* magit-pre-start-git-hook

Revert "Package-Requires: add emacs-23.2"

This reverts commit 3f2f81b347bff884ad4759ed4c8b12c204ce75e0.

No version of `package.el' which works with Emacs 23.x
understands the "emacs" virtual package.  See issue #1369.

prevent crazy point adjustment

Under a seemingly harmless condition, set `disable-point-adjustment' to
t using `post-command-hook' to prevent the event loop's usually helpful
point adjustment from going berserk.  The following was also added as a
comment:

  So we ended up at the beginning of a section, which also is
  the end of the preceding sibling section, if any.  There are
  two markers here.  If the preceding section is hidden, then
  we are also at the end of an invisible text range.  So far
  so good.

  But if we ended up here because we moved upward (but not when
  moving downward), then "point adjustment" messes up badly.
  Visually point would still be in the right spot but according
  to the function `point' we would be somewhere else; at the
  beginning of the preceding section, which isn't even the
  first position "at the other end of the invisible text".
  The existence of markers appears relevant, but not their
  insertion types.  Wtf!

  If we are not at the start of a section then do not disable
  "point adjustment", because when we truely end up *inside*
  an invisible range, then moving outside is a good thing.

Merge branch 'trim-apply' into next

remove obsolete iswitchb support

In version 24.4 of Emacs iswitchb will be obsolete and so we
should remove support at some point; let's get it over with.

Besides if I keep post phoning the Magit release, then Emacs
will beat me to it anyway :-(

If someone actually complains, then we can restore this in
`magit-extra.el'.
magit-apply-{hunk,diff}: use with-temp-buffer

remove section heading "Mode Utilities"

Having a section for just one minor utility is a bit much.
add magit-region-patch, replacing magit-insert-region-patch

let the command loop move point outside of invisible text

The reason we needed this kludge was that process sentinels which may
cause point to move inside invisible text and which also have to be
considered part of some command did not actually run until after the
command returned.  The editor command loop then went on to do its point
adjustment and then run "threads", including the sentinel of the process
started by the command which just returned.

These sentinels were likely to cause point to end up inside invisible
text, but when they ran it was to late for the command loops point
adjustment to kick in.

We used to work around that by using `post-command-hook' which happens
to be run even later than pending "threads".  Running such sentinels
after the command has already returned caused other issues besides this
one and so that was fixed by waiting inside the command for the process
to return.

This is the right thing to do because the only reason why asynchronous
processes are used in the first place is that this allows sending input
to the process.  But as far as Magit is concerned these processes should
be synchronous.  Now we wait, making at least the commands "synchronous"
and this kludge unnecessary.
simplify magit-insert-region-patch, remove magit-insert-current-line

simplify moving point outside invisible text

This should not be necessary at all anymore, and will be removed
completely in the next commit.  There is a slight risk that I am
wrong about this so I am adding this commit so we have something
more civilized to go back to than the old implementation in case
we need an emergency fix.

See next commit for why we needed this and why we don't do so
anymore.

restore behavior of "x" on a commit

Commit 11dc61ec479d671510e4c18ac73dfe096ad89518 intentionally changed
the behavior of pressing "x" on a commit.  Starting with that "x" did a
hard reset instead of a mixed reset, because "U" already does a mixed
reset.  Unfortunately many users would not notice this change until
they had already nuked some uncommitted changes.  So let's revert to
the old behavior.  "x" does a mixed reset again and "C-u x" has to be
used for a hard reset.

Despite the face being used, too many users fail to realize that the
lines in the process buffer are sections and thus never try to show
the output by pressing TAB.

On the `next' branch this is being countered by creating all sections
expanded and only collapsing a section once the command returned
successfully, see 160ed937ff28bcf0c9fc84763376e7c88f3d836a.  That hasn't
made it to `master' yet, where we are doing something less reasonable.
So for now change `magit-process-setup' to never automatically collapse
a section.

magit-wip-save is failing with no such file of directory /something/index4176xhf

In magit-wip-save, expand the index file name

Git is creating the index in the git topdir, but magit-wip-save was

magit.text: mentioned that staging only works from status buffer

magit-wash-diffstat: use preliminary filenames as value

The filenames that Git prints when --stat is used may be abbreviated.
For that reason we set the values of the file subsections of the
`diffstat' section once we parse the corresponding file section that
is part of the actual diff.  However when showing a merge commit it
is possible for diffstat information to be displayed even though
there is no diff.  Therefor set the value of the diffstat subsection
when it is created and possibly change that value if there actually
is a corresponding diff.  Setting the proper filename can still fail
when a filename is actually is abbreviated and there *also* is no
corresponding diff.  Previously it always failed when there was no
diff.  Furthermore the error displayed when it actually does happen
is more useful now.
magit-commit-assert: bugfix

magit{,-status}-mode-map: remove bindings for M-{h,H,s,S}

Also see issue #1357.
Merge branch 'n/section-maps' into next

remove magit-section-action

Remove `magit-section-action'.  All commands that need to dispatch based
on the type of the section at point now do so using `magit-section-case'.

The most important of these commands are `magit-stage', `magit-unstage',
`magit-discard', and `magit-revert'.  These commands now only act on
hunks, files, and the sections containing file sections.  Until a short
while ago these commands used to also act on other section types but
that caused these commands to be severely overloaded and their purpose
to be obscured.

This has been fixed by instead using per-section-type keymaps which only
have an effect within the sections of the respective type.  By using
text-property keymaps, the same keys are bound to commands that do
things *similar* to what the respective *diff* commands mentioned above
do - but only when point is within the appropriate sections.  While e.g.
"discarding a hunk" and "deleting a branch" indeed do something similar
("throw something away"), these actions are not similar enough for it
to make sense to have one command which is capable of doing both.
Using the same key on the other hand is reasonable.

The new mechanism, per-section keymaps, is not only cleaner, it is also
more flexible and easier to understand by contributors and authors of
third-party extensions - because it is the mechanism used by everything
else for this purpose.  The alternative would have been to improve
"section actions" until finally we would have effectively reimplemented
keymaps.

magit-{,un}stage: use magit-section-case

In `magit-stage' and `magit-unstage' use `magit-section-case' instead of
`magit-section-action'.  These were the last two commands that used the
latter.

magit-stage: fix staging of multiple submodules

Previously when the region being staged contained one or
more repositories `magit-stage' ended up either staging
just the one at point and nothing else, or staging the
contents of the repositories.

Also start using `magit-submodule-add' to do actually add
each module individually.  Before doing so add all regular
files if any.

magit-stage: small fix

Stop using `-u' when staging a tracked file, it's redundant.  Instead
proceed files with `--' guarding filenames that beginning with a dash.

magit-stage-modified: new command, replacing magit-stage-all

The old command was badly named.  It uses `git add', which happens to
have an argument `--all', but the command did not use that (except with
a prefix argument), it used neither `--all' nor `--update'.

The new command uses `--update', so now deleted files are also removed,
in addition to changes to modified files being added.  Because the new
command also takes a prefix argument which means to use `--all' it is
not named `magit-stage-update' but `magit-stage-modified', which is
sufficiently distinct from the names of the arguments to `git add',
which might or might not be used.

sanitize reset commands

Add a dedicated command for each reset variant; index, head, soft, and
hard.

Remove `magit-unstage-all' (optionally asks for confirmation) in favor
of the new `magit-reset-index' (asks for a commit, defaulting to the
commit at point).

In `magit-unstage' do not replace `magit-unstage-all' with
`magit-reset-index' because there is no way to keep it from asking for
a commit, effectively asking for confirmation.  Instead move the code
previously in `magit-unstage-all' directly into `magit-unstage'.
magit-discard-file: new function, replacing magit-discard-diff

magit-discard: limit to changes to files

No longer dispatch `magit-stash-drop', `magit-branch-delete', and
`magit-remote-remove' from `magit-discard'.  Instead bind these
commands in the appropriate section keymaps.

Since we do not want users to extend this command (instead section
keymaps should be used), remove the ability to do so, by using
`magit-section-case' instead of `magit-section-action'.

magit-revert-commit: turn into command

Turn `magit-revert-commit' into a command in its own right, instead
of dispatching it from `magit-revert'.  Also bind the new command
in `magit-commit-section-map'.   Stop binding `magit-revert' in
`magit-mode-map' and instead bind it in `magit-hunk-section-map'
and `magit-file-section-map.

magit-revert: no longer fallback to magit-discard

Reverting is not the same as discarding, so `magit-revert' should not
fallback to `magit-discard' for unstaged files and hunks, as well as
the `unstaged' section.

remove magit-apply in favor of section keymaps

This includes renaming `magit-apply-commit' to `magit-cherry-apply'
and turning it into a command.

remove magit-visit in favor of section keymaps

Also turn `magit-visit-file' into a command, which now knows
how to do the right thing with the file or hunk at point.
remove magit-rename in favor of section keymaps

no longer overload magit-cherry-pick

Previously `magit-cherry-pick' did cherry-pick the commit at point, or
if the section at point was a stash it did pop that stash.  Popping a
stash has nothing to do with cherry-picking, and since the name of this
function rather explicitly says that it does cherry-pick it should not
pop stashes too.  But it does indeed make sense to use the same key to
invoke these two technically unrelated actions, because from a user
perspective they do something "similar".

Replace the old `magit-cherry-pick' with what `magit-cherry-pick-commit'
used to do, but be a bit smarter about it.  Remove the latter.

Use the new "section keymap" functionality added in the previous commit
a first time.  Pressing "A" on a stash no longer uses the buffer-wide
binding `magit-cherry-pick' but instead uses `magit-stash-pop', as bound
in the new `magit-stash-section-map'.  Also bind `magit-cherry-pick' in
the new `magit-commit-section-map', but that is actually redundant.

drop support for overloading magit-copy-as-kill

In `magit-copy-as-ill' use `magit-section-when instead of
`magit-section-action'.  In the unlikely case that a third-party
extension needs to use the same binding to do something with a
section type unknown to us, section text property keymaps are
an option.

drop support for overloading magit-dired-jump

In `magit-dired-jump' use `magit-section-case' instead of
`magit-section-action'.  In the unlikely case that a third-party
extension needs to use the same binding to do something on a
section type unknown to us, section text property keymaps are
an option.

bind magit-{,un}stage{,-file} in the appropriate keymaps

In the most useful spots for un-/staging (i.e. "inside diffs") act
on the change at point using `magit-{,un}-stage'. Elsewhere give
the user the opportunity to stage arbitrary files.

magit-hunk-section-map: add binding for magit-commit-add-log

Bind `magit-commit-add-log' in `magit-hunk-section-map' instead
of `magit-status-mode-map', because it only works on hunks.

add support for per-section-type keymaps

Teach `magit-insert-section' to detect whether a keymap is defined
for the section being inserted and if so propertize the section's text
accordingly using the `keymap' text property.  The keymap variable has
to be named `magit-TYPE-section-map'.

Also define several such section keymaps.  The bindings will be added
in subsequent commits, when we move away from `magit-section-action',
which provides a similar but less flexible and more complicated way to
accomplish the same.
replace section types `file', `diff', and `diffstat' with just `file'

magit-{apply-{diff,hunk},insert-{*}}: name argument SECTION

Rename the arguments DIFF and HUNK of `magit-apply-diff',
`magit-apply-hunk', and the related `magit-insert-{*}'s to SECTION.

It isn't obvious that these functions expect section objects (strings
would also make sense).  However once we know that some kind of section
is expected, it is obvious what kind of section that is.

reduce nesting inside "Apply" section

Section "Apply" is itself a subsection of toplevel "Porcelain", and was
previously divided into "Apply Commands" and "Apply Core".  This soon
won't make sense anymore, since many functions that were located inside
the latter will be turned into commands.

Move the definition of `magit-apply' next to the other functions that
are used for "applying, in the strict *and* loose sense" (other
functions, in other subsections do e.g. "stage" changes, which isn't the
same as applying in the strict sense, but is implemented by using the
low-level "apply" functions never-the-less.  These generic apply
functions were previously located in the "Apply Core" subsection).
Also move the definition of `magit-discard-diff'.

magit-{,un}stage-file: new commands

Remove the ability to stage something other than the change at point
from `magit-stage' and instead add the new command `magit-stage-file',
which stages the file at point, if any, and else prompts for one.

Likewise create `magit-unstage-file'.  (Since `magit-unstage' never
allowed picking a file in the minibuffer, we don't have to touch that.)
magit-unstage-1: new function
magit-submodule-add: new command

improve magit-submodule-popup and its commands

Rename `magit-submodule-update-init' to `magit-submodule-setup',
change order of command definitions and of actions in the popup,
and improve doc-strings.

magit-git-repo-p: new function

This function used to exist before but was removed because it did
neither do what its name suggests nor what its only caller expected
(which wasn't the same).  Now this function returns t for any Git
repository and it also has a doc-string.

allow inhibiting refreshes

Add new variable `inhibit-magit-refresh'.
When it is non-nil `magit-refresh' now does nothing.
magit-{headish,{modified,staged}-files}: new functions
magit-{file-tracked-p,{,un}tracked-files}: new functions

magit-discard: act on staged hunks despite unstaged changes

`git apply --index' refuses to apply any patches if the file to be
patched is not up-to-date.  But in many cases that would work without
any conflicts.  So when there are both stages as well as unstaged
changes and the user requests that a staged change is discarded,
first discard it in the index only using `--cached' and then also
attempt to do so to the working tree.  If the second step fails
due to conflicts, then the result is equivalent to unstaging,
which isn't so bad.
magit-discard: call magit-remote-remove interactively
magit-diff-stash: default to stash at point

no longer use integers to represent stashes

* Add new function `magit-stash-at-point'.
* `magit-read-stash' now reads a string instead of a number and
  may default to the stash at point without asking.
* `magit-stash-as-refname' is no longer needed and is removed.

magit-remote-rename: various improvements

* Use more descriptive prompts.
* Do not use old name as initial-input when reading new name.

magit-branch-rename: various improvements

* Use current branch as default if there is no branch at point.
* Use more descriptive prompts.
* Do not use old name as initial-input when reading new name.

magit-branch-delete: improve prompt

Also make use of the improved prompt by calling `magit-branch-delete'
interactively from `magit-discard'.

magit-show-commit: various improvements

* With a prefix argument let the user choose a commit different from
  that at point.
* When the commit at point is a submodule commit, then deal with that
  too.

magit-section-when: new macro

Add new macro `magit-section-when' which unlike `magit-section-case'
cannot be used to dispatch based on section type.  Instead it used
to match a single section type (or a single set of section types),
and therefor serves well as a predicate.

Like `when' and for that matter `if', `magit-section-when' is not
strictly necessary.  But it is semantically more clear and, especially
it is further optimized for how it is commonly used, also less verbose.

magit-insert-local-branches: no longer use "." as value

of the section containing the sections representing local branches,
which in turn represents the "local remote" for which Git uses ".".
But while Git uses that only in a narrow context, Magit did overdo
it.
magit-branch-manager-mode-map: remove inconsistent bindings

magit-mode-map: add bindings for magit-gitignore{,-locally}

Bind `magit-gitignore' and `magit-gitignore-locally' in
`magit-mode-map' instead of `magit-status-mode-map' and
the former also in `magit-wazzup-mode-map'.
magit-insert-status-headers: always insert some text
magit-insert-diff-patch: bugfix, insert the header
magit-merge-assert: use user-error to abort, not error
magit-status: cosmetics
magit-push-tags: simplify logic, remove dead code

magit-get-current-remote: do not fallback to "origin"

Return the configured remote, else nil.  Do not return "." which
represents the local repository, not a remote; and also do not
ever fallback to return "origin", just because that often (but
not necessarily) happens to be the most likely choice.
remove leftovers from rewrite functionality
remove unused magit-get-remote/branch

remove magit-get-remote, sanitize magit-{push,pull}

Until a short while ago Magit had very poor support for setting
the (remote or local) branch tracked by a branch.  Actually the
only way to do so was as a side-effect of `magit-push'.  We now
have proper support for setting the tracked branch and no longer
"need" `magit-push' and `magit-pull' to fallback to "origin" to
make dealing with this less painful (and potentially dangerous).

Nuke `magit-get-remote' which is where the now unnecessary
fallback was implemented.

remove magit-insert-ref-labels

Remove `magit-insert-ref-labels' and use `magit-format-ref-labels'
again.  The former was a kludge which was only needed while
`magit-insert' did not exist yet.
remove unused magit-push-hook

use magit-bind-match-strings when appropriate

Also use `match-string' instead of `match-string-no-properties'
in a few cases because what doesn't exist also doesn't have to
be explicitly ignored.
use --map and --mapcat when appropriate
cleanup deprecated "marked commit" functionality

unconditionally add binding to git-commit-mode-map

Do not check whether `git-commit-mode-map' is
bound before adding a binding; it always is.
assorted doc-string improvements
capitalize Git and Magit in doc-strings and comments

move obsolete alias definitions to eof

Well there is just one, but eof is where all those yet to be created

Previously .mailmap was generated by make to avoid an unnecessary file.
However some git commands take advantage of this file so while it isn't
necessary, it's still nice to have.

Users and projects that have fully embraced Git don't use ChangeLog
files, they use commit messages.  Since their are users and projects

`magit-add-change-log-entry-other-window' still do server a purpose.
But these functions are not essential to Magit and are therefor moved

add "LIBRARY.el ends soon" section headers near end of all libraries

This is indeed silly, but so is adding "LIBRARY.el ends here" (in the
age of version control), and that is a convention!  The reason I am
doing this now, is that I once more have yanked a new section before
"LIBRARY.el ends here" while all existing sections were collapsed
(committed but fixed before being pushed).  Theoretically I know doing
so results in the new section being placed after the `provide' form and
file-local variables, but it seems I always forget when I actually do
insert a section right before the library end, so let's make sure that
doesn't cause any harm.

magit-{branch,branch-or-commit,commit,file,remote}-at-point: new functions

Actually some of these functions already existed under another name or
replace a similar but different function.

* `magit-commit-at-point' was previously known as `magit-current-commit'

* `magit-branch-or-commit-at-point' replaces `magit-guess-branch'.

  When on a commit that is the child of a `wazzup' section, the new
  function returns the commit, the old function returned the branch
  represented by the containing `wazzup' section, which is silly.

* `magit-remote-at-point' replaces `magit-guess-remote'.

  The new function no longer falls back to `magit-get-current-remote'

  Also stop returning "." to represent "the local repository, being

magit-{stgit,svn,topgit}-mode-lighter: new options

magit-{stgit,svn,topgit}.el: add longer library commentaries

In return remove information about these extensions from `magit.texi'
and `magit.info' generated from the former.
magit-topgit.el: cosmetics
magit-svn.el: cosmetics
magit-stgit-popup: new popup

magit-topgit-wash-topic: keep flags

Refactor `magit-topgit-wash-topic', making in readable and shrinking
it considerably.  In the process stop losing information (by no longer
removing the flag characters, only two out of seven were and still are
represented with face attributes), remove the unnecessary and ugly
`magit-topgit-parse-flags' and add the face `magit-topgit-empty'
(instead of hardcoding the appearance).

magit-push: absorb magit-push-dwim

For a while we had a command `magit-push-dwim' separate from
`magit-push' for two reasons:

`magit-push' used to run hook `magit-push-hook' allowing `magit-topgit'
to override its behavior.  Since the previous commits we no longer use
it that way.

Since that hook existed anyway I decided to rename `magit-push's legacy
implementation to `magit-push-dwim' and add a new `magit-push' that did
run that by default.  This was done in preparation of the still
outstanding deprecation of the legacy implementation, which I think is
fairly bad, because it overloads pushing with only marginally related
functionality and departs to much from what Git does.

However there likely are some users who disagree and I intended to keep
the old implementation which for a while was known as `magit-push-dwim'
under the name `magit-push-oldschool', it is now known as just
`magit-push' again and is still going to be deprecated eventually.

magit-topgit: don't overload core commands

Previously `magit-topgit-mode' added specialized functions to four
different command-specific hooks run by fundamental commands that are
part of Magit's core.  These commands did only run these hooks so that
`magit-topgit' could override the behavior of these commands.  I think
the behavior should never be overwritten in such a way.  And the core
of Magit certainly shouldn't be obfuscated to accommodate an extension
hardly anybody uses (280 downloads from Melpa, Magit itself has 57000).

Regardless of whether doing what we used to do is okay or not, we don't
have to do so because there is a better option: use a popup just for
TopGit commands.  Being parasites the TopGit "commands" where not
actually commands but regular functions, so that has to be fixed too.

magit-{stgit,topgit}: don't use action hooks

Do not use "action" hooks such as `magit-visit-hook' run by the command
`magit-visit' to add "specialized variants" of these actions for section
types added by extensions.

Such hooks are implemented using `magit-section-action' and I think that
adding this extension mechanism was a mistake in the first place.  Emacs
already has an extension mechanism that can be used to do this sort of
thing: the `keymap' text property.

Replace all uses of action hooks in `magit-stgit' and `magit-topgit by
using that `keymap' property for the text that is part of such
additional sections.

Both extension mechanisms have advantages and disadvantages.  Most
importantly the use of the `keymap' text property means that it is no
longer possible to change just one keymap to use another key for an
action, not only for core commands but also those defined by extensions.
On the other hand there now is a place where users can look to get a
list of all "special commands for a certain section type", the
respective keymap.

Merge branch 'n/no-items' into next

there are no items, just sections and things

Until now the term "item" was used as a second order observation.  It
denotes that we do *not* differentiate between the gui element and the
object it represents.  The former is not a useful distinction and should
be avoided by removing "item" from symbol names and documentation.

The above actually makes sense, but unless you have read your share of
Luhmann, the information is lost.  So let's try again, using more words.

The main gui elements in Magit buffers are called "sections".  Sections
always have a "type", and either represent some object, in which case
they also have a "value", and/or serve as containers for other sections.

In Magit the object represented by some gui element could be something
like a file, commit, or hunk.  In Emacs speak the term "thing" is
usually used for an object that generally could be categorized, when we
don't actually want to or cannot make that distinction.  We don't use
"item" for that.

When we name a command `magit-VERB-item' we are neither saying "VERB the
thing represented by this gui element", nor "VERB this gui element".  We
are saying "VERB (either the gui element or the object it represents)".
So `*-item' does not make it any more obvious whether something is done
with the gui element or the represented object.  What it emphasizes is
that we *don't* make that distinction, i.e. the distinction it makes is
that we don't make the distinction that could actually be useful.  That
is less useful than not making a distinction at all.

Maybe "item" used to be a synonym for exactly one of "section" or
"thing"; but if that ever was so, then that meaning has long been lost.
Contemporary uses include "highlight the item at point", but also "open
the file whose name can be seen at point".

So, lets rename symbols whose names used to contain "item", in most, but
not all, cases by simply removing the "-item" suffix.  Also remove
"item" from doc-strings, where it is replaced with either "section",
"thing", or in some cases the actual type or types of the "things", as
appropriate in the individual cases.

Merge branch 'n/insert-section' into next

improve process sections

Create all process sections "expanded".  Previously we did initially
collapse sections unless the *magit-process* buffer was already visible
in the current frame.  That was inconvenient because one might switch
to that buffer to see why something is taking long, only to first have
to expand the respective section.

Never-the-less it is useful to hide sections whose output the user
"probably doesn't want to see" in most cases.  So when a process returns
with exit code then the section is automatically collapsed.

Likewise inserting the exit code into the process sections buffer is now
done in a more reasonable way, without ending up putting point somewhere
inside the heading, instead of at its beginning.

Also do not put an extra empty line between sections and remove some
other kludges.  Now that headings are inserted before their bodies we no
longer need to do that.

magit-insert-header: change signature

This follows similar changes to `magit-insert-section'.

magit-git-wash: new function

Separate the task of inserting and washing output from a command from
the task of creating a section.  This in a sense was already the case
previously in that `magit-cmd-insert-section' made use of the macro
`magit-insert-section' to do the creation part.

Replace `magit-cmd-insert-section' and `magit-cmd-insert-section' with
`magit-git-wash'.  It is just a thin wrapper around `magit-git-insert'
which additionally calls some function to wash the inserted text.  It
also knows how to cancel the section currently being created if either
Git produces no output or washing the output completely.  That is
different from what `magit-cmd-insert-section' which never canceled
before calling the washer.

Code that previously used `magit-git-insert-section' now has to
explicitly use `magit-insert-section', `magit-insert-heading', and
`magit-git-wash'.  That usually means that it takes four lines of code
instead of tree to do so, but it also makes this more flexible and
prettier to look at.

There is no substitute for `magit-cmd-insert-section', i.e. we now only
provide a "insert-and-wash" function for Git but not arbitrary commands,
because, well that's what Magit is about.  There were only two direct
uses of `magit-cmd-insert-section', one in `magit-stgit.el' and one in
`magit-topgit.el'.  These uses are now replaced with a bit of code
duplication.

rename magit-with-section to magit-insert-section

Because this is a macro that does "something with something" the term
"with" actually does make sense.  However the "something it does" is
different from that that macros that are part of Emacs do.  We do not
make something current that already exists and we also don't create
something which is disposed of again after the macros BODY.  I.e. our
macro is neither like `with-current-buffer' nor like `with-temp-buffer'.

The side-effect of inserting a section is the raison d'être of this
macro.  Reflect that in the name.

magit-cancel-section: new function

Previously we depended on the return value of `magit-with-section'
being nil to trigger the cancellation of the section currently being
inserted.  Now we use the new function `magit-cancel-section' which
does a non-local exit from a catch setup in `magit-with-section'.

Doing it this way is not necessary at this point yet, but it does give
us additional flexibility.  I.e. code that inserts a section no longer
has to be lexically within `magit-with-section's BODY.  We will use that
in a subsequent commit.

magit-with-section: insert the heading before the body

Remove the HEADING argument from `magit-with-section' and instead expect
the callers to insert the HEADING themselves, using the new
`magit-insert-heading'.  Besides inserting the heading text in a fashion
similar to how the more general `magit-insert' works, this function also
sets the sections CONTENT slot to the position after the text previously
inserted.  The default value of that slot now is nil, indicating that
the section isn't divided into a heading and a body, i.e. it cannot be
collapsed.

Previously `magit-with-section' did evaluate its BODY to insert the
sections body text, and only then went back to the beginning of the
section and inserted the heading it had received as a separate argument.
This was done because when HEADING ending with ":" indicates that the
number of child sections shall be shown in the heading.  We no longer
delay inserting the heading until we know how many children there are.
Instead we insert the heading without the count and then later go back
and insert the count.  Inserting the heading later than the body
complicated things a lot and lead to difficult to fix bugs.

magit-{insert,put-face-property}: move definitions

These functions are intended for use in `magit-with-section's BODY only.

magit-with-section: make NAME argument optional, move before ARGLIST

There actually are very few cases where the BODY of `magit-with-section'
has to refer to the section object, so it doesn't make sense to always
have to specify the name of the "symbol which isn't being used".

rename section struct slot CONTENT-BEGINNING to CONTENT

Currently this slot always holds a marker (though sometimes it points
somewhere strange and cannot be relied on).  Starting in subsequent
commits this slot will be used to hold either such a marker, nil (to
indicate that the section has no body), or a function (which is then
used to actually create the body on expansion).

rename section struct slot BEGINNING to START

This causes the accessor `magit-section-beginning' to be renamed to
`magit-section-start'.  I'll admit it, I am doing this just because
"start" is shorter than "beginning".  Because the section code is
currently being refactored heavily anyway, doing so now causes only
little additional harm (in form of third-party code that might have
to be adapted), if any.

clarify distinction between a section's type and value

Originally there were these three related but distinct slots: `type',
`info', and `header'.  The last one was unnecessary and only existed
because someone got confused about the distinction between the other
two and was removed when I last refactored the section code.

Now the time has come to make the distinction between the "type" and the
"info" more clear.  We start by using the term "value" instead of
"info", because that's what it is.

There are two categories of sections: those that represent a thing, and
those that serve as containers for other sections.  A section can fall
into both categories.

Every section has a type, a symbol.  Sections that represent a "thing",
such as a file or hunk also have a value, usually a string (but that is
not enforced).  Sections that only serve as containers do not have a
value (i.e. the value is nil).

Together the type and value of a section and the types of recursively
all parent sections can be used to uniquely identify a section within
a buffer.  For container-only sections the types are sufficient because
there always is only one section of a particular container-only
type.  (That is a convention and isn't enforced.)  Meanwhile there can
be many e.g. `commit' sections and to tell them apart the values (here
the commit hashes) also have to be compared.

Sadly someone got confused along the way and started to use the just
the values (then more ambitiously called "info") to identify sections.
Since many sections don't actually have a value the result was that
for sections that would otherwise not have a value, the type was stored
in the `value' slot as well.

This commit adds function `magit-section-ident' which returns a list of
conses that can be used to uniquely identify a section as described.
Function `magit-find-section' is changed to use that value, instead of
using the value-except-when-it-actually-is-the-type.  For sections that
have no value the value of the `value' slot now is nil.

give each header section a suitable type and value

And for headers that don't have a value use `header' instead of `line'
as type.

problematic because its implementation has not kept up with improvements
elsewhere.  I.e. the section it inserted was initially expanded and

washing" code.  The pending changes section, unlike staged and unstaged,
does not use raw washing.  It would be a major undertaking to teach the
raw washing how to deal with pending changes.  I don't want to do that
especially because having an additional raw washing cycle is a mistake
itself, which I have already fixed on the `next' branch.

magit-{insert,put-face-property}: don't specify overlay priority

We cannot specify the default priority because the overlays created to
refine hunks (by code in `smerge-mode.el') also are created without the
priority being explicitly specified.  When the priority is undefined,
then it defaults to 1.  In our case there are several overlays with that
priority at the same buffer position, but it seems the correct on wins.

Apparently if there are multiple overlays with the same priority then
the one which was created later is prioritized.  It so happens that this
is what we need here, but we just got lucky and this should be fixed in
Emacs.
