Merge branch 'mushroom'

magit-get-current-tag: avoid using --dirty

Don't use the Git `--dirty' argument unless the function argument
WITH-DISTANCE-P is the symbol `dirty'.  This makes `git tag' much faster
on file-systems that don't properly cache access times.  Inside Magit we
currently are not ever interested in knowing whether there is any dirt,
but some third-party code does (well, some of my local hacks, that is).

magit-refresh-diff-buffer: specify -p explicitly

allow staging file mode change separately from other changes

improve look of headers of files inside diffs

Generally speaking make them look more like what `git status' would

Also make the headings using a dedicated face, by default by making

magit-wash-diff: delete Git's diff headers

Replace the file and hunk diff headers after they have been parsed and
the Magit equivalents have been inserted.  This change is motivated by
to things: the standard headers are redundant and therefor only make the
diffs noisier, and it improves performance to remove these headers and
therefor also not having to paint them using overlays.

There is a downside too: it is no longer possible to save a Magit diff
buffer to a file and then pass that patch to Git or something else that
understands unified diffs.

magit-wash-diff: refactor

Refactor `magit-wash-diff', mainly because the old implementation was
dead ugly and to prepare for subsequent changes.  But this might also
give a slight performance boost.

dispose of unnecessary diff washing cycle

Previously staged and unstaged changes as displayed in the status buffer
were washed in two washing cycles.  All other diffs are and always were
washed in just one washing cycle, like everything else is too.  This was
either a historic accident or a failed attempt at improving performance.

If it was the latter then the motivation probably was that this allowed
delaying the insertion and washing hidden diffs until the got expanded.
However this actually decreases performance because it means Git has to
be called several times (at least on Windows where starting a process
seems to come with a huge overhead).

Getting the diff from Git once isn't what takes a long time, its Magit's
inefficient parsing and painting of the diff.  These steps have already
been made faster and we will be further improved.  If it turns out that
we cannot speed up the diff washing enough even for huge diffs then we
can still delay *washing only*.  To do that we don't have to also delay
the insertion of the diff.

magit-wash-hunk: turn the first line into a proper heading

Previously the first line of a hunk looked like it was a heading but as
far as the section code was concerned it was actually just dressing up
as one.  The fact that it still worked like a section heading does not
contradict this statement, it just means that there is code within the
section handling that can deal with such broken sections, these kludges
could now be removed.  (We first have to make sure that no other section
remain that are broken in the same way, though.)

This commit turns the first line into a proper headings but due to the
inflexibility of `magit-with-section' with regards to how headings are
painted we have to delay the creation of the overlay until after the
`magit-with-section' has returned.  (The overlay is also a hack which
in turn is necessary because Emacs doesn't support negative overlays.)

magit-diff-item-insert-header: generate string, don't parse text

Generate the inserted string from information stored in the diff section
object instead of parsing the information in the buffer once more.  Now
it is a choice to keep the diff headers in the buffer, no longer a
necessity.

magit-wash-hunk: highlight whitespace errors only on added lines

For real this time.
magit-wash-hunk: cosmetics

fixup diffstat sections in more civilized manner

Git may truncate filenames in diffstats, and because we use these string
for more than just showing them to the user we have to fix that.

The real filenames become available once when the diffs are washed, at
which point store these filenames in the diffstats section objects too.
For that to work we have to somehow pass the diffstat sections to the
code that washes the diffs.  Previously that was done using the variable
`magit-diffstat-cached-sections'.

By merging `magit-wash-diffstat' into `magit-wash-diffstat' we can now
do the civilized thing and pass the information using function arguments.

magit-run-{git-gui{,-blame},gitk}: use call-process

Start the subprocess using `call-process' with argument DESTINATION
being 0.  I.e. start the subprocess and immediately return 0 without
caring what happens to the subprocess afterwards.  Previously we used
`start-file-process' but that had the disadvantage that the process
object still existed when the subprocess was still running when Emacs
was being quit, needlessly forcing the termination of the subprocess.

when setting the default value of `magit-git-executable'.

On Windows, explicitly use the "git.exe" executable instead of "git".
If that fails accept any "git".

Merge branch 'faster-diff-1'

use overlays to propertize various parts of logs

Ever wondered why faces used for refs such as branch names have a
border?  It is because of this limitation mentioned in info node
`(elisp)Overlay Properties':

  Currently, all overlays take priority over text properties.
  Please avoid using negative priority values, as we have not
  yet decided just what they should mean.

So when a section is highlighted by changing the background (the
default), then all background colors things like reflabels that are
located inside the section loose their background color.  It seems
someone decided that just the foreground color being different from
surrounding text is not enough and also added a border to the faces
used for such things.  This has been reverted in some color themes
in others it has not.  After this change it is solely a matter of
taste, not visibility whether someone wants to keep the borders.

The borders will probably be removed from the defaults of these
faces eventually.  But this isn't urgent.

magit-highlight-line-whitespace: avoid false-positives

Avoid false-positives when displaying combined diffs.

properly encapsulate overlay hack and properly dispose overlays

Add the function `magit-put-face-property' as a substitute for
`magit-put-text-property' to work around a limitation mentioned
in info node `(elisp)Overlay Properties':

  Currently, all overlays take priority over text properties.
  Please avoid using negative priority values, as we have not
  yet decided just what they should mean.

We already did the same before, but re-implemented that in every case
in which it was needed.  Unfortunately each of these implementations
contained the same severe bug: the overlays were not removed when the
diffs got updated.  Overlays negatively affect performance and so these
buffers got slower over time.  Now these overlays "evaporate" when they
become empty, i.e.  they are automatically removed.

magit-diff-while-committing: improve amend detection

When Magit directly invoked `git commit', then we do know whether we
are creating a new commit or amending.  When `git commit' is invoked
by e.g. `git rebase -i' then we don't, so we have to try harder to
guess what is going on.

magit-server-visit: use for commit and rebase

Generalize `magit-server-visit' and use it when rebasing, not only when
committing.  Add a function and a variable `magit-server-visit-args'.
Together this variable and these two functions handle all of the
"asynchronous argument passing logic" related to the use of the
Emacsclient.  And yes, I normally would not do that but here I
see no other way.  Remove `magit-commit-amending-alist'.

magit-commit-log-buffer: check whether magit-commit-mode is non-nil

Previously we checked whether the `major-mode' derived from
`git-commit-mode', but since that is a minor mode now, we
have to instead check whether the variable is non-nil.

magit-commit-fallback: use with-editor-finish-noclient-hook

instead of `git-commit-commit-hook', which no longer exists
and was replaced by the former.

git-commit: allow use of arbitrary major mode

Decouple the "edit session" logic from the major mode used for editing
a commit message.

Previously `git-commit-mode' was a major mode deriving from `text-mode',
which got turned on for Git commit message files due to an entry in
`auto-mode-alist'.

Aside from "being the major mode" `git-commit-mode' was also responsible
for turning on `with-editor-mode', further setting up font-lock and the
comment logic, and then a bunch of other things.

The different concerns are now split up:

The new minor mode `global-git-commit-mode' serves the same purpose as
the entry in `auto-mode-alist' previously did: tell Emacs to use the
tools defined here when opening a Git commit message file buffer.  It
does so by adding `git-commit-setup-check-buffer' to `find-file-hook'.

Because this logic is defined in `git-commit-mode.el' and not built into
Emacs, it is no longer sufficient to autoload that library.  It has to
be loaded.  If it isn't loaded then the code which could cause it to be
loaded also isn't loaded yet.  Magit loads `git-commit-mode', so this
should not cause any problems for most users.  However users who do not
also use Magit will have to require this library in their init file.
There is no way around it.  All attempts to autoload the dispatch logic
would end up as being effectively equivalent to:

  ;;;###autoload (require 'git-commit-mode)

When appropriate, i.e. when the file opened actually is a Git commit
message file `git-commit-setup-check-buffer' then calls
`git-commit-setup', which does the following:

* Turn on `with-editor-mode', and add the commit specific hook functions
  to the `with-editor' hooks.  After this `git-commit-mode' does not
  have to worry about anything related to finishing the edit session
  logic anymore.

* Turn on the major mode.  Currently this can only be configured
  globally using the new option `git-commit-major-mode', but the idea
  is that `git config' can be used to set per repository major modes.

* Turn on `git-commit-mode'.  All that this mode now does is to setup
  the "pseudo header" and the "message history" key bindings.

* Setup font-locking and the comment logic using
  `git-commit-setup-font-lock'.  This currently cannot be disabled or
  further customized.

* Set `save-place' to nil and possibly modify the text
  slightly (inserting a newline).  This also cannot be disabled.

* Run the `git-commit-setup-hook'.  This is a user customizable hook
  that can be used to disable several things that were forced upon the
  user in the old implementation.  This can also be used to add
  additional features.

It is possible to change the major mode while editing the commit
message.  This is not generally recommended but it does not mess up any
of the most important features that without special steps would be lost
by the mode change.  This is done by making some variables permanently
buffer-local and by re-running `git-commit-setup-font-lock' after the
mode change.  However some of the auxiliary features that were enabled
by `git-commit-setup-hook' might end up being disabled.

with-editor: new mode

Define a new minor mode `with-editor-mode' and the commands
`with-editor-finish' and `with-editor-cancel' which are used to end the
current buffers edit session.

Previously similar commands were defined for both `git-commit-mode' and
`git-rebase-mode'.  The "finish" and "cancel" commands for these two
modes should have been almost identical, however the "rebase" variants
were very insufficient and failed to cover most of the special cases the
"commit" variants knew about.  The "commit" variants on the hand also
weren't properly designed upfront and as a result were rather magical.

Instead of improving these to variants independently, this commit
generalizes the concept, adds hooks to adjust the generalized functions
to the needs of its users, uses the generalized mode and commands for
committing and rebasing, and defines the hook functions necessary to
make the generalized implementation work for these two users.

magit-with-emacsclient: always use pop-to-buffer as server-window

* Add the constant `magit-server-window', replacing the options
  `magit-server-window-for-commit' and `magit-server-window-for-rebase'.

  We now support showing "the relevant diff" when committing and when
  rebasing (and in some other cases), but that only works reliably when
  we know where files opened by emacsclient show up.  Otherwise the
  buffer opened on behalf of the emacsclient might use the window in
  which we just displayed the diff.

  So we cannot have user change this.  Actually users who really really
  wants to, can still do so by setting `magit-server-window', *after*
  loading `magit.el'.

* Also change how the value of `server-window' is temporarily set to
  that of `magit-server-window'.

  Previously we used a timer in `magit-with-emacsclient' but that was
  not reliable.  Now we advice `server-switch-buffer' to use the local
  value of `server-window' in the buffer which is about to be displayed
  on behalf of the emacsclient.  Additionally we have to actually set
  that local value.  We do so by adding the new `magit-server-visit'
  function to `server-visit-hook'.  That function sets the local value
  to that of `magit-server-window' if the `buffer-file-name' matches
  the regexp `magit-server-window-filename-regexp'.

  That probably sounds rather complicated, but the old approach wasn't
  exactly straightforward either.  And additionally the latter was not
  reliable.

bring auto-reverting of file-visiting buffers under control

Do not rely on `auto-revert-mode'.  Instead add a new global minor mode
`magit-auto-revert-mode' which is explicitly called by `magit-refresh'
and only reverts buffers that visit files that are tracked in the
current repository.

Buffers are no longer reverted if they change for any other reason than
running a Magit command.  Doing that was a bad idea because users where
not aware of this happening and those that were aware might not want it.

Users who do want the old behavior back can instead (or additionally)
turn on `global-auto-revert-mode'.

magit-show-level*: remove bogus condition

What does `magit-no-commit-p' have to do with hiding/showing sections?!

magit-show-level{,*}: rename functions

Rename `magit-show-level' to `magit-show-level*' and
Rename `magit-section-show-level' to `magit-show-level'.

Loose the doc-strings (see next commit) and move the order of the
two definitions.

magit-show-only-files{-all}: remove commands

Remove `magit-show-only-files' and `magit-show-only-files-all',
because what they do _not_ "show only files".  They show level 1
except when the mode is `magit-status-mode', in which case they
show level 2, just like `magit-show-level-{1 resp. 2}{,-all}' do.

So keep the effect by the key bindings the appropriate and
properly named and documented commands.  I.e. bind "M-h"/"M-H"
to `magit-show-level-1{,-all}' in `magit-mode-map' and
to `magit-show-level-2{,-all}' in `magit-status-mode-map'.
magit-section-lineage: move definition

magit-get-previous-branch: make sure it's not the same as current

Because @{-1} refers to the previously checked *branch* the previous
branch would be the same branch as the *current* branch when detaching
HEAD and then going back to the same branch.  So we how keep increasing
@{-N} until there are no more branches or we find another branch.

magit-get-current-branch: return unambiguous shortname

Previously we got the full ref and then manually removed the
"refs/heads/" prefix.  Now we pass `--short' to `git symbolic-ref',
just like `magit-get-refname' used to.  Remove that now.  Also remove
`magit-get-ref' which got the full ref and was only used in the old
version of `magit-get-current-branch' so that it could do it wrong.

This function now returns "head/master" instead of "master", iff
e.g. refs/tags/master also exists.  That's a good thing, it's what
git would do.

magit-process-mode: don't turn on view-mode

This was a leftover from the old implementation, which didn't use a
major mode derived from `magit-mode'.  Back then `view-mode' was used so
that we could just use `view-mode-exit' instead of having to implement,
something similar ourselves.  Likewise that took care of making the
buffer read-only.

Now that we actually do use a mode derived `magit-mode' we also get that
for free.  So the use of `view-mode' no longer any benefits, and at the
same time has at least the drawback that we loose some key bindings
which are potentially useful.

Close #1259.

Fix magit-insert-untracked-files & 'status.showUntrackedFiles' git config

Commit 1c4136e cleaned up magit-insert-untracked-files to always rely
rely on status.showUntrackedFiles, however it's broken when this
configuration is not set:
in such case 'git config status.showUntrackedFiles' returns nothing, not
the default value as the code expected.

Then git status was run just with "-u", which is equivalent to "-u
all". It's not what the user specified by not defining
'status.showUntrackedFiles'. It should be "-u normal" in such case.

This commit fixes and simplify this by removing the git config retrieval
altogether since git status reads this config, even with the
"--porcelain" flag.

(This git status behavior is a little ambiguous in the man: it says the
output format will be stable "regardless of user configuration", so one
can wonder why the 'status.showUntrackedFiles' user config is not
ignored. But it's about the output *format*, and not the output itself.)

magit-with-emacsclient: use --socket-name even with default server-name

When actually using a socket for communication, then always pass the
`--socket-name' argument to the Emacsclient.  Do so even when neither
the `server-name' nor `server-socket-dir' have been set to something
different from the default values.

Just because a user did not configure Emacs to use something else,
doesn't necessarily mean that she did not attempt to so, but stopped
after making adjustments to shell init files.  I.e. there are users
with incomplete configurations, who gave up on using the Emacsclient
after having shot themselves in the foot by incompletely configuring
client/server communication.  Magit requires cannot do without the
Emacsclient and so we have to override such mistakes.

magit-list-interesting-refs: remove function and related crap

Instead use the recently added `magit-list-refnames'.

This is (only) the starting point to implement more meaningful revision
and reference completion.  `magit-list-interesting-refs' was very very
bad.  Basically it and the code which surrounded it (not all of which
has been replaced yet) took the "when in doubt, pick the worst possible
option" approach.  E.g. instead of asking "what do we have to complete?"
and answering that with (in nine out of ten cases) "branches", and then
going on to "how do we get a list of branches?"; what we actually did
was "find some git command that gives us a list of refs, pick the first
one, it doesn't matter whether there are better ones", then start using
it, notice that the completion candidates contain many refs that we are
not interested in, implement "filter out the uninteresting refs", and
then keep on complicating things, making it less and less likely that
this will ever be fixed.  Well, I have had it, this crap has to go.

magit-completing-read: be strict about REQUIRE-MATCH

`completing-read's REQUIRE-MATCH means "require the user to exit with
a match, but there are exceptions in which case an empty string is
returned".  That's not so useful because every caller has to check
for that empty string.

Previously `magit-builtin-completing-read' did detect that case and
raise an error if `completing-read' returned an empty string.  Now

Merge branch 'n/dash' into next

use external dash library

Five months ago I tried to have a discussion about starting to depend
on the external Dash library.  Unfortunately a troll appeared, making
any meaningful conversation impossible.  This was very stressful and
shortly after I almost had a burnout.

Back then I said I would eventually reopen the discussion.  I have now
decided not to do so and instead have start to depend on dash without
any further discussion.  I have considered the concerns raised back
then and have come to the conclusion that me having to work around
Emacs Lisp's limitations is a greater cost (not only to me, but also
to Magit as a project and to its users) than any of the concerns that
were raised.

---

I write Emacs extensions because working with "the buffer" as opposed
to e.g. "the dom" is rewarding.  On the other hand Emacs Lisp leaves
much to be desired.

Using Dash makes some of the major pain points go away.  That's why
many in the new generation of extension authors use Dash.  It makes
our lives easier if we don't have to constantly reinvent the wheel,
just so that we too get to use some of the improvement made to LISP
over the last few decades.

Users benefit too, because by using a library we can focus on the
project specific issue.   And when we use well tested and widely
used libraries instead of quick hacks, then bugs are less likely.

On the other hand this might cause some inconvenience for some users.
But it is the author not the user who gets to decide what language
(and in this case language libraries) the author uses.  By improving
Magit I provide a lot of convenience to its users.  A troll who attacks
me for occasionally doing things that make my life easier, instead of
his life, misses the bigger picture.  Consider it a reward for working
on Magit.

---

At this point I have just quickly scrolled though the code and started
to use forms from Dash in places that jumped at me.  There surely are
many more places where doing so would be beneficial.  As I run into
these places I will start using Dash there too.

magit-extras: adopt marked commit functionality

WAS: remove almost unused "marked commit" functionality

Until recently this was used for three things:

- When selecting the target commit when creating a fixup/squash commit.
  That was a mistake and the result of me being urged to merge the
  squash functionality before I was fully satisfied with it.

- For the "rewrite" functionality which was removed in the previous
  commit.  If that is restored in a separate package, then the mark
  functionality would also have to be restored in that package.

- For the `magit-diff-with-mark' command which is being removed in
  this commit.

Aside from the rewrite stuff, `magit-diff-with-mark' was the only
command that actually did require the concept of a "marked commit".

I don't think acting on some marked commit like this command does, is
really necessary - there are usually other ways to get "that other
commit".  Also the diff popup and commands have been improved a lot
lately and will continue to be improved, making this particular special
command even less useful.

Regardless of the usefulness of this particular command, a single such
command does not justify the increases complexity that comes with the
"marked commit" functionality.  Maybe at some later time we can bring
back this functionality and then use it for more things.  If many things
used this, then maybe it would be useful.  But a single command, that
only few know about, is not useful.

Merge branch 'n/removals' into next

magit-clean: new command

Add new command `magit-clean' replacing `magit-reset-working-tree'
which did amalgamate `git reset --hard' with `git clean ...'.  While
former users of the removed command will likely disagree initially,
the old command made very little sense.  Yes, it is likely one would
want to do both things at the same time but one might also want to
only do the cleaning, which was not possible with the old command.

remove magit specific "pretty refs" functionality

Git knows short human friendly names for refs like local branches,
remote branches and tags.  Until now Magit supported an additional,
incompatible representation, which had to be converted back and forth
and made refactoring related things impossible.  This commit removes
it, and I think that is no loss at all.

The only benefit I can see in the Magit specific representation is that
it might make completing refs slightly easier, because the thing that
one often wants to complete against is at the beginning of the string.
However that is not always the case, sometimes the thing one wanted to
complete against would have been at the beginning, if Magit had not
interfered.

Using a completion algorithm or framework that supports non-prefix
completion serves this purpose better.  Magit, to some extend, already
supports using alternative completion frameworks.  This can be further
improved.

ref                        refname        "branch-then-remote"
--------------------------------------------------------------
refs/heads/master          master         master
refs/remote/origin/master  origin/master  master (origin)
refs/tags/v1.0             v1.0           v1.0 (tag)

This commit only removes the "branch-then-remote" format; it does not
yet remove all of the complications, inconsistencies and bugs, that
were, at least in part, the result of this unnecessary and counter-
productive feature.

remove broken magit-change-what-branch-tracks

Currently Magit does not provide a sane way of settings a branch's
upstream branch.  This command kind of served this purpose but it
is rather bad, e.g. it assumes we only ever want to track a remote
branch.  Nuke it to make room for something less crappy.

remove magit specific "rewrite" functionality

Please consider the following and also read issue #966.

(1) I think that by removing this feature, I do its users a service.
    Sure they will have to find an alternative in `cherry-pick' and
    `rebase --interactive', but once they have learned about these
    tools, they will be using vastly superior tools.

(2) For now this patch only lives on the `next' branch and I have
    already stated that, in the case I fail to convince everyone of
    the above, I will make the rewrite functionality available as
    a separate package.

no longer store current diff range in sections

The "diff range" of each diff can be unambiguously determined when the
information is actually required.  For diff buffers the range can be
extracted from the buffer-local `magit-refresh-args' and for diffs in
the status buffer (staged and unstaged) the "section context" can be
used to do so.

So we shouldn't store that information in each hunk section before it
is even required.  Also we shouldn't loose information in the process.

This commit removes the code that did store the information but does not
replace it with code to get the same (well better) information when it
is actually required.  That isn't necessary yet, because Ediff the only
feature which actually made use of the static information has been
removed in the previous two commits.

Dynamically determining the diff range will be implemented when Ediff
support is being reimplemented.

magit-read-rev-range: remove function

While Magit needs good "range completion", what this
function provides, cannot possibly contribute to that.

magit-show: temporarily loose ability to guess rev from current diff

That feature and more will be restored later.  It's a chicken and egg
problem: if I don't remove this incomplete implementation then I don't
know how I should ever arrive at a better one.  So it has to get worse
before it can get better.

temporarily remove ediff support, except resolve

Remove this implementation of Ediff support in Magit, to make it easier
to write a new more consistent and less "if cursor is where it is then
I am just gonna raise an error"ish implementation.

Keep `magit-interactive-resolve' because that is the most useful and
most often used part of the old Ediff support, and it also happens to
be the least problematic part.  It is less problematic than the rest
because it doesn't depend unrelated code to prepare data on its behalf
like the rest does.

magit-commit-internal: optionally show appropriate diff

When option `magit-expand-staged-on-commit' (to be renamed) is non-nil
and the new optional argument DIFF-FN is non-nil, then use that function
to show the appropriate diff while showing the commit message buffer.

Previously the function `magit-commit-maybe-expand' (remove in this
commit) was used to do that.  Doing it in `magit-commit-internal' is
better because that function has greater control over where which
buffers (commit and diff) are displayed.  To make that possible, also
add the new variable `magit-diff-switch-buffer-function' and use it
in `magit-diff'.

All callers of `magit-commit-internal' have to be adjusted, even
those that do not request a diff to be shown.

In `magit-commit-assert' also continue to optionally show the
appropriate diff, but do so without using `magit-commit-internal'

The variable `magit-current-popup-args' serves a purpose similar to that
of `current-prefix-args' and should therefor be processed inside the

Previously these commands either used the commit at point (or the marked

providing a default.  Now a default is provided by putting point on the
commit that was at point in the previous buffer.

This also looses the ability to use the marked commit (whether
unconditionally or as default).  That option being available was the
result of me being urged to merge the squash functionality into master
before I considered it fully ready.
Merge branch 'n/rebase-popup-1' into next

magit-rebase-popup: new popup

* Add a new popup for initiating and continuing a rebase,
  depending on whether a rebase is already in progress or not.
* Add new rebase-start command variants `magit-rebase-onto'
  and `magit-rebase-autosquash'.
* Add new rebase-continue command `magit-rebase-edit'.
* Change key bindings.
Merge branch 'n/read-char-case' into next
magit-read-char-case: new function
Merge branch 'n/log-popup-1' into next
Merge branch 'n/diff-popup-1' into next

magit-log-select: new log mode/buffer just for selecting a commit

The commands `magit-commit-fixup' and `magit-commit-squash' previously
used some custom code to select a commit from a log buffer.  Here we
generalize that to make that feature more flexible and also so that
we can use it elsewhere.

magit-diff-context-lines: remove variable

Teach `magit-diff-{less,more,default}-context how to store `-U{N}' in
`magit-diff-options', making the `magit-diff-context-lines' variable
unnecessary.  Remove function `magit-diff-U-arg'; all of its former
callers also use the value of `magit-diff-options'.  In two places
`magit-diff-context-lines' was used directly; change them to use
`magit-diff-options' instead.

log: goto commit that was current in previous buffer

`magit-mode-refresh-buffer' which is used to refresh any magit
buffer (which includes creating it) tries to keep point at the
same section.  However it only knows about one buffer at a time.

So if point is e.g. at a commit inside one of the "mini logs" in the
status buffer and the log buffer is brought up, then point is usually at
the beginning of the buffer but may also end up at some random position.

This commit teaches log how to goto the commit that is at point in the
buffer that was current before the log buffer was created.  This is done
mostly for logs that are used to select a commit.  Support for such
special logs will be added in the next commit.  But instead of limiting
it to just these special logs we do this here for all logs.  This should
be further generalized so that it can be used in other situations too.

magit-diff-{less,more,default}-context: rename variables

Rename `magit-diff-default-hunks' to `magit-diff-default-context',
rename `magit-diff-smaller-hunks' to `magit-diff-less-context', and
rename `magit-diff-larger-hunks' to `magit-diff-less-context'.

"smaller/larger hunks" is ambitious, it might mean "split hunks into
more hunks"/"combine several hunks into one", or what these commands
actually do "show more context around added/removed lines".

"diff context" on the other hand is not ambitious.

magit-log-popup: add --show-signature

This replaces the variable `magit-log-show-gpg-status'.  It is now
possible to toggle this on the fly.

For oneline logs this argument is dropped and instead "%G" is made
part of "--pretty".
magit-diff-{smaller,larger,default}-hunks: move before refactor

magit-log-{*}: make more intuitive

* Use the terms "Oneline" and "Verbose" to describe the two log types.
  Previously "Short" and "Long" was used, and the latter is rather
  ambitious and depending on how you look at it simply wrong.
* Make sure the action buttons are arranged in a helpful manner.
* Rename the log commands to better reflect their purpose.
* Move the heavy lifting to the "core" functions instead of
  offloading it to the "variations".

And most importantly focus on showing logs for refs and revs, not
ranges.  Showing logs for ranges really isn't all that useful, there are
cases when it is, but showing the history of a branch different from the
current branch is VERY useful.  That was previously already possible by
abusing the "ranged log" to show a branch (by omitting the end of the
range), but that was VERY confusing to users.  Now one has to abuse the
"branch log" to show a "ranged log" and in that case the completion is
less helpful than it used to be.  That will change though.
magit-visit-item: dispatch more magit-diff-{*} variants

magit-diff-popup: new popup

This is the first popup which can be used to invoke git with some
arguments as well as to set the variable used when refreshing the
current buffer to these arguments.  It is therefor possible to either
create a new diff buffer using certain arguments, or to update the diffs
in the current buffer.  That buffer isn't necessarily a diff-only
buffer, the status buffer for example can also contain diffs.

For diff buffers the ability to set the arguments used for refreshing as
a buffer-local value isn't strictly necessary, one could just invoke the
command that created the buffer again, this time using different
arguments.  This isn't the case for the status buffer, there is no way
to pass arguments intended for `git diff' to `magit-status'.  In the
future we might do the same for `git log' arguments.
magit-diff-staged: with prefix prompt for commit

magit-diff-working-tree: silently default to HEAD

instead of offering it as default choice in mandatory completion.
Now a prefix argument has to be used to be able to select another
commit.

magit-diff-paths: new command

Now Magit supports all forms supported by `git diff'.
magit-diff-{unpushed,unpulled}: new commands
Merge branch 'n/popup-lib-1' into next
magit-diff-{unstaged,stash,with-mark}: improve doc-strings

magit-popup.el: move compatibility definitions to here

It's a bit odd to define this here, but since this library is a
dependency of `magit.el' it works.  And I prefer doing this for
now, instead of adding a library just for compatibility stuff.

magit-diff: improve doc-string

Yes, that really is an improvement - it's less misleading. "Diffing
a range" means to compare two endpoints, while log actually does
something with every commit in between those.

We still use `magit-read-rev-range' to get the endpoints, but that
has to be fixes as part of #876.  We keep using that function for
now because that allows using "a..b" OR "a...b", but that also isn't
obvious yet, unfortunately.
magit-popup.el: add some of the missing doc-strings

magit-insert-staged-changes: stop abusing magit-diff-options

Previously `magit-diff-options' was let-bound in
`magit-insert-staged-changes', which meant that
it could no longer fulfill its intended purpose.

Replace it with another ugly kludge, an additional
argument STAGED to `magit-insert-diff'.  That will
have to go too, but at least `magit-diff-options'
now has an effect on staged changes again.

magit-popup-setvar-mode: remove mode

Remove `magit-popup-setvar-mode' for now.  Currently `magit-popup-mode'
can be used instead, but that might change again.

magit-refresh-commit-buffer: honor magit-diff-options

The diffs in the commit buffer ain't no different from diffs in
dedicated diff buffers and the status buffer, and so it should come with
the same flexibility these other diffs have, i.e. it should respect this
variable.

add library magit-popup

... or rather rename library `magit-key-mode' to `magit-popup'.

During the last ~90 commits the popup functionality was completely
refactored, and renaming the file is the final step in replacing the
old library with the new implementation.

Declare that I am the author of `magit-popup.el' but add a prominent
note to the library header about it being inspired by Phil Jackson's
`magit-key-mode'.

Without the latter there would also be no `magit-popup.el'.  On the
other hand there is virtually nothing left from `magit-key-mode.el',
in the new implementation.

Also adjust the library summary and add a library commentary.

popups: use list of strings for all popup options

Previously the value of "popup default arguments" custom options were
alists, now they are lists of strings, i.e arguments that can be
passed to git without any pre-processing.

Using an alist was a bad idea because (1) we cannot do the same when
the value is used directly (what the "setvar" mode does), (2) and as
a result of that a lot of code had to exist in two variants.

It would have been better to remove this completely from history, but
reverting this feature when I added it would result in to many commits
with difficult merge conflicts.  Sorry in this case history reflects
what I have actually done, not what I came to know I should have done :-)
magit-popup-mode-map: cosmetics
magit-define-popup: add GROUP argument
magit-popup-sequence-mode: new mode

magit-popup-{setup-hook,default-setup}: new hook var and fn

Add new hook variable `magit-popup-setup-hook'
and new hook function `magit-popup-default-setup'.

popups: use a struct as internal representation of events

Use a struct to represent popup events (both arguments and actions).
Previously we used a plain list, which had to be accessed using
(nth MAGICAL-NUMBER ev).  Being able to say `magit-popup-event-SLOT'
is an improvement.  Unfortunately there is no free lunch; doing this
obfuscates `magit-popup-setup-events'.  Oh well.

magit-popup-setvar-mode: new mode which uses "flat options"

For each option a custom variable is defined which holds the default
arguments.  The format (an alist) of the values of these options is
optimized for use inside popups.

But for certain popups it is desirable to use the value of that option
outside of the popup.  In such cases the value should be a list of
arguments (strings) which can be passed to a process as command line
arguments, not a list of cons cells which represent such arguments but
cannot be used without being reformatted.

Using the new `magit-popup-setvar-mode' for some popup allows doing
just that.

popups: add support for using alternative popup modes

Now each popup can define the mode to be used in the popup buffer.  The
mode should derive from `magit-popup-mode'.  It no mode is explicitly
defined default to the latter.
magit-popup-previous-winconf: move definition

magit-invoke-popup-option: improve how value is toggled

When the value is set, unset it without prompting.  When then invoking
the option again prompt for a new value, using the old one as initial
input.

popups: add support for quickly saving default arguments

Add new commands `magit-popup-set-defaults' and
`magit-popup-save-defaults' that can be invoked from popup
buffers (instead of an actual action) to set/save the arguments
as they are currently setup in the buffer as defaults for future
uses of the popup.

popups: add support for default arguments

Allow specifying arguments that are enabled by default when defining a
popup using `magit-define-popup'.  This feature used to be implemented
in a very hackish way, so it was removed earlier in this patch series.

Now that the feature is back, and better than ever, also restore the
defaults that used to exists.  Actually there was only one.

The next commit will add support for customizing these defaults.

popups: add support for default actions

For each popup, define a default action.

Add option `magit-popup-use-prefix-argument' which controls when the
default action is used.

Because the old implementation used the prefix argument in an
incompatible fashion and changing that without users being aware of
it could lead to tears the default is this:

Don't show the popup and also don't use the default action, instead
make the user aware of the alternatives and make her choose one:

* Without a prefix argument show the popup,
  with a prefix argument directly invoke the default action.

* With a prefix argument show the popup,
  without a prefix argument directly invoke the default action.

* Ignore the prefix argument and always show the popup.

popups: optionally show help section with popup commands

Popup commands, are regular commands that are used inside a popup to
manipulate the state of the popup, e.g. to move to the next button.
They differ from "actions" invoked from the popup.

popups: add support for special command sections

Both "commands" and "actions" are implemented as Emacs commands.
They differ in that the Emacs commands that implement an "action"
aren't invoked directly (but still using `call-interactively')
allowing them to see the value of `magit-current-popup-args',
but otherwise "commands" are more flexible.

magit-{popup-mode-setup,refresh-popup-buffer}-hook: new hooks

Add the new hook variables `magit-popup-mode-setup-hook'
and `magit-refresh-popup-buffer-hook'.

popups: show better help from within popups

* Allow jumping to new "Popups" info node.
* Allow showing help for individual arguments.
* Use a bigger window to show help buffer.
* Restore previous window configuration when quitting help.

To do so add the new functions `magit-popup-woman', `magit-popup-info,
and `magit-popup-describe-function', as well as the auxiliary minor
mode `magit-popup-help-mode'.

popups: refactor insertion of buttons

Replace `magit-popup-format-button'
with `magit-popup-format-argument-button'
and `magit-popup-format-action-button'.

And various other small changes that allow the appearance of buttons
and sections to be customized.

popups: handle "q" event explicitly

An event explicitly bound in `magit-mode-map' cannot be bound to an
action without explicitly using a popup local keymap that overrides
that binding.  Because all letters should be available for actions,
stop binding q to `magit-popup-quit' and instead explicitly call that
command in `magit-invoke-popup-action' if no action uses it.  We have
to do so because Magit users are used to using q to quit the popup.

popups: refactor invocation of popup events

The macro `magit-define-popup' is used to define a popup, i.e. a command
to insert the popup; the arguments that can be set in the popup; and the
commands that can be used to exit the popup, using the set arguments.

Prior to this commit that meant defining a Emacs command and *three*
variables; one variable uses the same name as the command and is used to
store the popup plist.  Another is a customizable variable used to store
default values for the arguments.  And finally there was a variable that
used to store the popup specific keymap.

This commit removes the need for that keymap variable.  Now there is
only one keymap which uses remapping and default (`t') bindings to bind
the commands `magit-invoke-popup-action', `magit-invoke-popup-switch,
`magit-invoke-popup-option'.  Prior to this commit these were not Emacs
commands but non-interactive functions, and for each "binding" in each
popup an anonymous lambda command had to be defined.  Now they are
commands and they use information stored in the popup variable to do key
lookup.

* Add function `magit-invoke-popup' which is now called by each popup
  entry command generated by `magit-define-popup'.  Previously
  `magit-popup-mode-setup' did fill that role (and currently the former
  does nothing more than calling the latter).

* Add buffer-local variable `magit-this-popup-events' replacing
  `magit-popup-args'.  We now need to store actions in here too because
  we want to switch to an internal format, different from the alist
  stored in the "definition variable".

* Add function `magit-popup-get' which works like `plist-get' but
  knows whether the requested property is stored in the "definition
  variable" or in `magit-this-popup-events'.  It's also less verbose
  to use because the PLIST argument is omitted.

* Add function `magit-popup-get-args' which returns the list of
  arguments the way they are exposed as `magit-current-popup-args'.

* Add function `magit-popup-setup-events' which converts information
  from the "definition variable" to the internal format.  Currently
  it looks simple enough, unfortunately that will change as the
  internal format get's more complex.

* Remove function `magit-define-popup-keymap', because, there is but
  one keymap.

* Promote `magit-invoke-popup-{*}' to commands.  They should not be
  used outside a popup.

* Let-bind `magit-current-popup' when invoking an action from a popup.
  This is similar to `magit-current-popup-args' but holds the symbol
  identifying the popup, as opposed to the selected arguments.  This
  might be useful for actions that can be invoked from multiple
  popups.
magit-{change,remove}-popup-key: new functions

magit-define-popup-{*}: use for customization

Previously the `magit-define-popup-switch', `magit-define-popup-option',
and `magit-define-popup-action' were used by `magit-define-popup-keymap'
to create a keymap from a popup definition.  That is now done directly
in the latter.

These functions are now repurposed to let users customize an existing
popup definition.  In other words they now serve a similar purpose as
`define-key' does for regular keymaps.

Because each popup is still stored in two places, once as keymap and
once as an alist, these functions are still quite ugly.  That will be
fixes soon, when we stop using a keymap per popup.

popups: represent each event using a single characters

Since we only support event sequences that are one event long (for the
time being) use a character instead of a string to represent such an
event.  (Argument sequences are actually two events long, but the first
event is constant across each argument type and cannot be changed for an
individual popup definition or even for an individual popup event
definition.  That's also a temporary restriction.)
popups: define a button type for each popup event type
magit-popup-mode-map: use vectors for events

popups: use event sequences of constant length

Give all event sequences in popups a constant length.  For switches
and options always use a sequence that is two characters long; and
for actions always use a sequence that is a single character long.

There were only two popups that used sequences that did not already
conform with this new restriction: `magit-log-popup' and
`magit-commit-popup'.  In both cases it was not necessary to use
longer sequences in any way, there are enough fine shorter sequences
left that are nicer to use.

One reason for this change is that these shorter key sequences are
nicer.  Another reason, which should not be concealed is that imposing
this restrictions will make many upcoming changes much easier.

magit-this-popup: new variable

Instead of passing the symbol that identifies the current popup around
as an argument, store it in the buffer-local variable `magit-this-popup'.

This allows turning `magit-popup-help' into a proper command, instead of
having to wrap it with an interactive lambda expression in each popup's
keymap.  In the next commit we will really benefit from this change, by
doing the same for other such lambda commands, effectively making popup
specific keymaps unnecessary.

magit-popup-args: new variable

Replace the variables `magit-popup-current-options' and
`magit-popup-current-switches' with just one new variable,
`magit-popup-args'.  This name was chosen because it is to
`magit-current-popup-args' what `prefix-arg' is to
`current-prefix-arg'.

popups: new symbol names for magit popups

The popup command and variable are now both usually named
`magit-VERB-popup'. VERB should be in infinitiv form (e.g. "commit").

Previously the command was named `magit-key-mode-popup-VERB', and VERB
was in -ing form.  The verb form is (and was) just a convention, and it
didn't even have to be a verb.  Actually it is now possible to use any
symbol name, because now the full symbol name has to be given.

We do not have to enforce uniformity by constructing the symbol names,
as there are other ways of enforcing consistency within Magit, and if
someone should happen to re-use the popup functionality outside of
Magit, then they are probably happy these symbols no longer are prefixed
with `magit-'.

Actually there is one more variable per popup: `...-map'.  That will be
removed soon, but yet another additional variable per popup will be
added, which will be named `...-defaults'.  In both cases the suffix is
fixed.

popups: define popups next to their commands

Define popups (using the new `magit-define-popup') right before the
definitions of the commands that implement the "actions" that can be
invoked from the popup.  This separates the functionality implemented
in `magit-key-mode.el' from its uses, and as a result this library and
`magit.el' no longer depend on one another.  `magit-key-mode.el' now
does not depend on anything else in Magit, and can theoretically be
used outside of Magit.

magit-define-popup: new macro

This completes the move from one monolithic variable that holds the
data of all existing popups, to separate variables for each popup.
That makes it *much* easier to customize existing popups and add new
ones.

The intermediate step was, that to define a popup one had to manually
define a command, an alist variable, and a map variable.  Now all of
that can be done using this new macro.  By the way the map variable
will soon be made unnecessary and instead a new "default argument
custom option" will be added.  If it weren't for this macro such
changes would require many changes to boilerplate code all over the
place.

magit-popup-quit: don't use magit-invoke-popup-action

Instead of calling `magit-invoke-popup-action' from `magit-popup-quit',
call the latter from the former.  As a result the former no longer has
to deal with the special case of its FUNC argument being nil.
magit-popup-options-in-cols: rename from magit-key-mode-options-in-cols

magit-popup-prefix-arg: remove variable

Do not forward the prefix argument used to bring up the popup to the
command invoked from the popup.  This is unnecessary (the prefix
argument can be provided while in the popup) and we want to use the
initial prefix argument for other purposes.

magit-popup-buffer-name: remove variable

When defining a popup the full symbol name has to be specified, and that
symbol, which is supposed to properly prefixed with a package "namespace"
(currently only "magit-") and by convention end with "-popup", is now the
only popup identifier.  Additionally prefixing that with "*magit-key: "
in the buffer name is redundant.
magit-popup-abort: rename from magit-key-mode-abort
magit-popup-help: rename from magit-key-mode-help
magit-popup-show-usage: rename from magit-key-mode-show-usage
magit-popup-buffer-name: rename from magit-key-mode-buf-name

magit-popup-mode-{setup,display-buffer}: new functions

Define `magit-popup-mode' using `define-derived-mode' and move
most of the code it used to contain into the new functions
`magit-popup-mode-setup' and `magit-popup-mode-display-mode'.

The new functions are modeled and named after `magit-mode-setup'
and `magit-mode-display-mode' but are implemented independently,
because `magit-key-mode' should not depend on `magit' and because
we actually need these functions to behave differently.

The various `magit-key-mode-popup-{*}' function now have to call
`magit-popup-mode-setup' instead of `magit-popup-mode'.
magit-popup-mode-map: rename from magit-key-mode-map
magit-popup-mode: rename from magit-key-mode

magit-current-popup-args: rename from magit-custom-options

This variable serves a role similar to that of `current-prefix-arg'.
Furthermore the likeness will only increase. Its name should reflect
the kinship.

magit-popup-previous-window-configuration: rename variable

Rename `magit-pre-key-mode-window-conf'
to `magit-popup-previous-window-configuration'.
magit-popup-format-button: put values right behind options
magit-popup-format-button: align descriptions

magit-popup-format-button: propertize all arguments

Give all arguments a distinct look whether they are enabled or disabled,
and whether they are options or switches.  Previously only enabled
switches used a face different from `default'.

Add the new font `magit-popup-disabled-argument' for disabled arguments,
and the existing font `magit-popup-argument' for switches and now also
options.

magit-popup-option-value: inherit from font-lock-string-face

Previously this face inherited from `widget-field' and its look therefor
suggested that the text propertized with it could be edited "in-buffer".

This isn't the case.  It makes more sense to inherit, like most other
Magit Popup faces do, from a Font Lock face: `font-lock-string-face'.

magit-key-mode.el: rename faces

Change the prefix of all popup faces from `magit-key-mode-' to
`magit-popup-', like we have already done for many other symbols,
and remove the redundant `-face' suffix (that should only be used
for variables that can be used to select a face).

Rename `magit-key-mode-BUTTON-face' to `magit-popup-KEY', because it is,
and always was, used for the key part *of* a button, not *the* button.

Rename `magit-key-mode-SWITCH-face' to `magit-popup-ARGUMENT', because
starting with the next commit we will also use it for options, the other
kind of arguments.

Rename `magit-key-mode-OPTION-face' to `magit-popup-OPTION-VALUE',
because it is, and always was, used for option *values* never for the
option itself.

Make *most* of the old faces alias for the new face and mark them
obsolete.

Do *not* define an alias for the renamed `magit-key-mode-args-face'; if
users and theme authors did take inspiration from the default look, then
we *want* to break that, as the text propertized with this face is not
editable the same way a `widget-field' is.  The actual face definition
still has to be adapted accordingly.

magit-invoke-popup-option: disable options properly

Previously providing no input would not disable the option (but visually
indicated that it did) but just set the value to the empty string.  Now
exiting the minibuffer with an empty string means to turn off the
option.  Exiting with a whitespace-only string means use the option but
with no value (i.e. the value is the empty string).
magit-popup-current-options: use alist instead of hash-table

magit-key-mode.el: refactor button and popup handling

Remove the existing maze of drawing functions consisting of
`magit-key-mode-draw-switches', `magit-key-mode-draw-options',
`magit-key-mode-draw-actions', `magit-key-mode-draw-buttons', and
`magit-key-mode-draw-in-cols'; replacing them with just
`magit-popup-insert-buttons' and `magit-popup-format-button', and
doing a bit more work in `magit-refresh-popup-buffer'.

This change could theoretically come with a bunch of small improvements
to popup appearance and at the same time remove a few lines of code.
But I avoid doing so for now.

The new options are `magit-popup-switch-format',
`magit-popup-option-format', and `magit-popup-action-format'.
magit-define-popup-keymap: rename from magit-key-mode-build-keymap

magit-invoke-popup-{switch,option,action}: rename functions

Rename `magit-key-mode-toggle-switch' to `magit-invoke-popup-switch',
rename `magit-key-mode-set-option' to `magit-invoke-popup-option', and
rename `magit-key-mode-perform-action' to `magit-invoke-popup-action'.

magit-define-popup-{switch,option,action}: new functions

Define the new functions `magit-define-popup-switch',
`magit-define-popup-option', and `magit-define-popup-action',
by splitting of generic code previously located inside
`magit-key-mode-build-keymap'.

This will eventually makes it easier to customize existing popup
keymaps (and the other popup variables, but that isn't implemented yet).

Also add the argument POPUP to `magit-key-mode-perform-action', even
though the function body does not use it.  Most commands bound in popup
keymaps are anonymous functions, which is inconvenient for users who
inspect them.  Now all these functions contain a call to some function,
followed by the popup symbol and the other argument (switch, option, or
command).  That lessens the pain a bit.
popups: arrange argument, option, switch, and action things consistently

popups: use terms argument, option, switch, and action consistently

Arguments come in two forms, switches and options.
Switches are arguments that can be toggled on or off.
Options are arguments that take a value.

Actions are commands whose invocation cause an actual change, as opposed
to setting the value of an argument, which is also implemented using
Emacs commands but only arranges for the subsequent invocation of an
action to have a different effect.

In the future there will also be "positional arguments" but currently
the popup code does not handle these.  Currently some action commands
always prompt the user for some minibuffer input, while others only do
so when a prefix argument (only loosely related to "argument" as defined
above) are used.

Do *not* define an alias for the renamed `magit-key-mode-args-face'; if
users and theme authors did take inspiration from the default look, then
we *want* to break that, as the text propertized with this face is not
editable the same way a `widget-field' is.  The actual face definition
still has to be adapted accordingly.

magit-key-mode.el: rename arguments FOR-GROUP to POPUP

FOR-GROUP is over-specific, in some cases it was also wrong because we
did something "with" or "to" a "group". GROUP would have worked for me
but since we are changing this anyway, use the more approprate POPUP.

magit-key-mode.el: lose many doc-strings

In `magit-key-mode.el' lose the doc-strings of many variables and
functions.  The reasons vary but generally it is done because the
existing doc-strings are either insufficient or document things that
are about to change or to be removed.  Better doc-strings will be
added once the current refactoring is over, for things that actually
need to be documented.  Removing the old doc-strings now makes the
refactoring easier, and writing new ones will also be easier without
"inspiration" from not so great ones.

The only doc-strings that are kept are those of faces and those of
`magit-define-popup' forms.

Also shorten Commentary (to be extended later) and lose some
unnecessary comments.

magit-key-mode-build-keymap: don't warn when overriding a binding

When defining a binding in a "regular" keymap, then `define-key' also
does not warn when overriding an existing binding.  Since we are working
toward using more "regular" keymaps, we can also stop doing that.  We do
it now because that makes subsequent refactoring easier.

magit-key-mode-map: new variable

This keymap is used as the parent of all generated popup keymaps.
Having such a parent saves us from having to define the same bindings
over and over again, and might in some cases allow users to customize
the bindings of all popups (for things that don't get overridden by
the individual popup keymaps).

magit-key-mode-abort: new command

Previously that command was defined twice as an anonymous function.
magit-key-mode-help: move to correct section

magit-refresh-popup-buffer: rename from magit-key-mode-redraw

Also lose its doc-string.
magit-key-mode-options-for-group: remove function
magit-key-mode-build-exec-point-alist: remove function
magit-key-mode-draw-in-cols: don't propertize leading space
magit-key-mode-redraw: absorb magit-key-mode-draw

magit-key-mode-redraw: limit to drawing

Move things that don't have anything to do with drawing from

There was a comment saying that this isn't necessary but it certainly
doesn't hurt doing it, so I do it anyway.
magit-key-mode-{prefix,current-args,current-options}: make buffer-local
magit-key-mode-draw-buttons: absorb magit-key-mode-draw-header
magit-key-mode-redraw: cosmetics
magit-key-mode-redraw: assume there always is an action
magit-key-mode-draw: cosmetics

magit-key-mode-draw: assume there always is an action

In function `magit-key-mode-draw' assume that every popup has at least
one action.  It's save to do so, a popup without a single action would
not make any sense.

popups: store keymaps individually in magit-popup-{*}-map

Instead of storing all popup keymaps as an alist in
`magit-key-mode-keymaps' store each map in an individual variable.
Do not delay defining the keymaps until they are first used, instead
define them when the library is loaded.

* Define a variable `magit-popup-{*}-map' for each popup.
* Remove variable `magit-key-mode-keymaps'.
* Remove function `magit-key-mode-get-key-map'.
* Adapt function `magit-key-mode-build-keymap' accordingly.
* Adapt function `magit-key-mode' accordingly.

magit-key-mode-insert-{argument,switch,action}: remove functions

* Remove variable `magit-key-mode-groups'.
* Remove function `magit-key-mode-add-group'.
* Adapt function `magit-key-mode-options-for-group' accordingly.

magit-key-mode-popup-{*}: define explicitly

It looks wasteful now, but it will get better.

Remove `magit-key-mode-generate'.

popups: temporarily drop hardcoded default popup arguments

This feature will be restored later in a much more powerful way.
Eventually users will be able to add their own defaults without patching
`magit-key-mode.el'.  Until then remove this feature completely, as
doing so makes refactoring easier.

Actually the only such default being dropped here is `--graph' used for
logging.  That's the only one left after the more complex and flexible
"diff option" support has been removed in the previous commit.  But this
does not only remove this one particular default, it removes support for
this hacky feature all together.

popups: temporarily remove the special "diff options" popup

Removing this now will make refactoring easier.  Once the refactoring
is over, customizing of popup arguments "from within the popup" will
be supported by all popups, not just this special one.

Remove the functions `magit-set-diff-options',
`magit-set-default-diff-options', `magit-save-default-diff-options', and
`magit-reset-diff-options'.  But keep the variable `magit-diff-options'.

magit-key-mode-last-buffer: remove variable

It was basically a buffer-local variable whose value was...
that buffer itself!

Function `current-buffer' serves us just as well.
magit-key-mode-{delete-group,de-generate}: remove functions

magit-key-mode.el: merge some toplevel sections

Merge three toplevel sections because the are going to be refactored
so heavily that the current split and headings would become rather
confusing.  Use a temporary section heading, later to be replaced.

Normalize sha1 length for commands that don't respect core.abbrev

Some commands (like `git cherry') don't respect core.abbrev. Fix this by
explicitly passing --abbrev=N (where N=core.abbrev when set).

Adapted-by: Jonas Bernoulli <jonas@bernoul.li>

Rename new utility functions and move their definitions.

Use the correct face for cherry marks

Currently, the `magit-cherry-equivalent' and `magit-cherry-unmatched'
faces are applied incorrectly to the opposite case in
`magit-wash-log-line'. Fix this by swapping them.

Add a space between the cherry mark and the sha1

The output of `git cherry' looks like this:

    + cf1464f7b9 iommu: msm: always use 32-bit physical addresses
    + eea2a9eaa1 iommu: msm: simplify address discovery in secure register dump code
    + 5a9311887b iommu: msm: create some helper macros for generating register addresses
    + ac26cf1da3 iommu: msm: remove unused field from struct dump_regs_tbl_entry
    + b6cc994641 iommu: msm: dump some global registers on page faults

but in magit the `+' is currently squished up against the sha1:

    +b6cc994641 iommu: msm: dump some global registers on page faults
    +ac26cf1da3 iommu: msm: remove unused field from struct dump_regs_tbl_entry
    +5a9311887b iommu: msm: create some helper macros for generating register addresses
    +eea2a9eaa1 iommu: msm: simplify address discovery in secure register dump code
    +cf1464f7b9 iommu: msm: always use 32-bit physical addresses

This is inconsistent with the expected `git cherry' UI. It also causes
minor problems for people using custom commands that operate on a sha1
with `word-at-point' or similar since you also get the `+' with the
sha1.

Fix this by adding a space.

abbreviate hash for cherry logs

Unlike for real logs we don't specify a format for cherry logs which
contains "%h".  So we have to tell git to abbreviate the hashes using
`--abbrev'.  (When `--abbrev=<N>` was removed only the `<N>` should
have been removed.)  Close #1191.

Refresh file visiting buffers synchronously after running Git using
one of `magit-run-git' and `magit-run-git-async', and their variants.
magit-refresh: allow doing it synchronously
magit-refresh-all: always do it synchronously

To not refresh right after starting the asynchronous process.
Instead rely on the sentinel of that process to do so when the

magit-pull: don't be verbose

Close #1176.  There's really no point in being verbose; users usually
don't see the output anyway and those who do would be overwhelmed by
the verbosity if there are more than a few branches.  The only lose I
can see is that the output no longer contains any information about
from where we didn't pull anything.

magit-git-command-topdir: fix #1190

Add new utility function `magit-git-command-read-args' instead
of attempting to play tricks with prefix arguments.  Also improve
doc-strings of `magit-git-command' and `magit-git-command-topdir'.

magit-diff-toggle-refine-hunk: follow rename

When cherry-picking renaming `magit-toggle-diff-refine-hunk'
to `magit-diff-toggle-refine-hunk' accidentally went through.

So we complete this now by also changing the binding in
`magit-mode-map'.

magit-log-count: limit scope

We only cut of logs after a certain number of commits when they are
shown in a log buffer, other logs usually are not long enough for that
to be necessary anyway.  Nevertheless, we now establish the dynamically
bound counter in `magit-wash-log', which is used for all logs.  Doing
so is cheap because it only amounts to calling `cl-incf' N times, where
N is usually fairly low.

log: respect core.abbrev

Remove the variable `magit-sha1-abbrev-length' and instead just respect
the git variable `core.abbrev'.  This allows users to set this per
repository.

Also remove the function `magit-diff-abbrev-arg' which used the value
of the option and returned "--abbrev=<N>".  Beside that, the only place
where the elisp variable was used was when aligning lines in logs that
contained only part of the graph.  Because we move the hash to the
beginning of the line we have to align based on the default length of
the hash.  We can get that by using `git config core.abbrev' once per
log, so it's cheap.

magit-{refresh-log-buffer,insert-bisect-rest}: drop --abbrev-commit

It is not required because we explicitly use "%h" for oneline
logs and for verbose logs this argument it is ignored anyway.

Just like the doc-string already claims it does.

Merge branch 'pr/section-case'

magit-section-context-type: sections always have a type
end misguided uses of magit-section-context-type
magit-revert-item: ask more specific questions

remove rewrite clause from actions' default clauses

This prepares for the removal of the "rewrite" functionality.
(Which might come in the form of a separate package, but I am
hoping that won't actually be necessary.)

section actions: refactor how new struct and its slots are bound

This adapts the api to how it is actually used in the wild.

* Always bind the symbol `it' to the section struct.
* The ARGLIST now consists of an arbitrary list of `magit-section'
  slot names (symbols) which are bound to the respective value.
* Actually other symbols but those identifying slots are allowed.
  The only restriction is that a function `magit-section-SYMBOL'
  which takes a section struct as argument has to exist.
* Add `magit-section-parent-info' because that information (the
  value of the INFO slot of the PARENT section of the section)
  is required quite a few times.

section actions: refactor how additional clauses are added

This adapts the api to how it is actually used in the wild.

* Run the action hook before the default clauses.
* Remove `magit-add-action-clauses'.
* New actions are now added individually.
  * There was not a single case that made use of the possibility
    to add multiple clauses at once.
  * To add a clause to things are required:
    * Use of `add-hook' to add to `magit-OPNAME-hook'.
    * Use of `set' to set `magit-section-action-context' for the
      hook function.

magit-section-match: if CONDITION is t then return t

Previously this special case (being the non-special case :-)
was taken care of in `magit-section-case'.
magit-guess-branch: fix section matching

magit-section-{case,action}: change order of type context vectors

Expect clause type context vectors to be in the order in which they
are actually processed.  That is the most narrow section now has to
come first.  If that doesn't match, then the rest doesn't even matter.
If it matches go on checking whether the parent (second element) also
matches and so on, until no more ancestor requirements are defined.

cosmetic changes to uses of magit-section-{case,action}

If SECTION or INFO is unused, use `_' as variable symbol.

magit-section-{case,action}: support multiple types per clause

  (magit-section-case (item info)
    (a-thing ...)
    ([also just one thing] ...)
    (([another thing] yet-another-thing) ...))

This is actually implemented in `magit-section-match'.

magit-section-{case,action}: section paths are now vectors

This is actually implemented in `magit-section-match'.

Because `magit-section-case' is loosely modeled after `case' it should
work similar to that with regards to matching multiple things:

  (case EXPR
    (thing ...)
    ((two things) ...))

So this is not so good:

  (magit-section-case (item info)
    ((a-thing) ...)
    ((also just one thing) ...))

This commit changes this to:

  (magit-section-case (item info)
    (a-thing ...)
    ([also just one thing] ...))

The next commit will extend it to:

  (magit-section-case (item info)
    (a-thing ...)
    ([also just one thing] ...)
    (([another thing] yet-another-thing) ...))
magit-section-match: support CONDITION being an atom

magit-section-{action,case,match,match-1}: remove doc-strings

These removals are only temporary.  The old doc-strings will be
replaced with better ones once the upcoming refactoring is over.

magit-section-match-1: rename from magit-prefix-p

This function is not generally useful, it is intended for
use by `magit-section-match' only.  Rename it accordingly.

magit-section-action: dumb down message about unsupported section

Previously we attempted to include information about the type of the
section which does not support a particular action in the warning
message.  As identifier the value of `magit-section-type', a symbol, was
used.  If the `magit-description' property was set for that symbol, then
that was used.  However there was not a single symbol for which this was
the case.  Even if we did set such a description for all relevant
symbols, that wouldn't do us much good.  Many sections are only properly
identified using a vector.  Since vectors aren't symbols, they don't
have symbol properties...

magit-{stage,unstage,discard}-item: remove dead mystery code

These functions use `magit-section-action' and mostly identical clauses
that try the section context against `(diff diff)' and `(diff diff hunk)'.
This is wrong there exists no section type for which instances can be
the child of a section an instance of the same type.

We use symbols to uniquely identify section types, and a long time ago
someone made the mistake to use the same symbol to identify two distinct

Merge branch 'pr/user-error'

Use `user-error' instead of `error'.

Function `user-error' is new in GNU Emacs 24.3.  A fallback to `error'
is provided for older version.  It is supposed to be used in case of an
incorrect manipulation instead of a real error.  GNU Emacs will not
enter the debugger for a `user-error' even if `debug-on-error' in
enabled.  Which makes life a lot easier for us elisp developers.
