magit-{call,start}-process: flatten arguments ARGS

Flatten the first level of `magit-call-process' and
`magit-start-process's rest argument ARGS before passing the arguments
to `process-file' and `start-file-process'.  This also affects
`magit-call-git and `magit-start-git', as well as the high-level api
functions `magit-run-git{*}'.

This in most cases (all as of now) makes it unnecessary to use `apply'
when the arguments to git (or some other process) have to determined
at runtime.

Function`magit-run-git-async' shows the ARGS in the echo area, so
flatten them here too.
magit-flatten-onelevel: new function

magit-{call,start}-{git,process}: new low-level process api

Move away from having one Eierlegende Wollmilchsau that does everything
related to any kind of process: `magit-run*'.  Instead add one primitive
for asynchronous processes and one for synchronous processes.  Doing so
is now possible because the common things have already been factored out
of `magit-run*'.  For each of them have a small wrapper specialized to
Git processes.  Keep the existing high-level process api functions.

* Add the low-level process api function `magit-call-process'
  and `magit-start-process', replacing `magit-run*'.

* Add `magit-call-git', replacing `magit-run-git*'.
  Add new `magit-start-git'.

* Likewise add `magit-call-topgit', replacing `magit-run-topgit*'.
  Add new `magit-start-topgit'.

* Keep existing `magit-run-git' and `magit-run-git-{*}' functions,
  but define them using the new low-level functions above.

* Keep existing `magit-git-{*}' functions.  They still don't use
  our low-level api, they directly use `process-file'.

* Replace calls to `magit-run-git*' and `magit-run*' with calls
  to `magit-call-git', and in one case `magit-run-git-async'.

magit-run*: better return values

For asynchronous processes always return the process object instead of
t, just like `start-file-process' does.

For synchronous processes always return the exit code.  Previously a
boolean was returned; if NOERROR was non-nil that was always t.

magit-process-finish: change arguments and return value

Change `magit-process-finish's arguments and return value
so that it is nicer to use in the synchronous case.

magit-process-finish: always call when process returns

Previously `magit-process-finish' was only called when an error
occurred, which was okay because it was effectively a noop when
everything went fine.  But conceptually that is wrong, and soon
`magit-process-finish' will start do things regardless of the
exit status.  That also means that `magit-process-finish' must
never use `error'.

magit-process-{finish,error-message-re}: move definitions

The old location of `magit-process-finish' somewhat made sense
originally because it was located in between the two functions
from where code migrated into this new function.  But now that
is only of historic interest, so move it to a more reasonable
place.  Move the variable it uses along.
magit-run*: don't sleep after sending region

support multiple synchronous processes

That was easy.  Basically Magit had to be told not to refuse to start
a second process.  Well almost - I first had to make sure that process
output isn't clobbered when several processes write to the same buffer,
but maybe we should have taken care of this a bit earlier: close #24,
the oldest issue which was still open.

magit-process: new command

Split `magit-process-display-process' into two functions.  Reserve
the old function for use by `magit-run*' and name the new command
`magit-process'.

magit-process-{mode,setup,buffer}: new functions

While `magit-process-mode' derives from `magit-mode', it is special.
E.g. `magit-process-setup' is quite different from `magit-mode-setup'.

There are no functions like `magit-process-buffer' for other modes yet
but that will change.

Define variable `magit-process-mode-map' explicitly.  Move definition
of `magit-process-buffer-name' into new "Process Mode" subsection.

Also split up the "Git Process" section up into tree new subsections.

magit-process-error-message-re: match more

Emacs cannot tell stderr from stdout, so we have to go through all
output and look for something that could be an error message.

Tune that regexp stored in `magit-process-error-message-re', which
is used for that purpose.

magit-process-error-message-re: new variable

Emacs cannot tell stderr from stdout, so we have to go through all
output and look for something that could be an error message.

Store the regexp used for this purpose in the new variable
`magit-process-error-message-re', so that it can be fine tuned.

magit-process-finish: take a single argument

For asynchronous process we are going to need to provide more
information to this function, which is actually contained within the
process object.  For synchronous process object exists, so we had the
callers provide each required information as a separate argument.

Simplify that my replacing these arguments with just one PROCESS
argument, which may also be a list, consisting of the values in the
correct order.
magit-process-keep-history: remove variable
magit-run-{,git}*: remove unused NOERASE argument
magit-run-{,git}*: remove unused LOGLINE argument
magit-process-set-mode-line: split arguments, cleanup

magit-process-sentinel: a real sentinel again

It is no longer necessary to use `apply-partially' to get a function
that can be used as sentinel.  The buffer in which the command was
invoked is now stored in the process object, so `magit-process-sentinel'
now get that information from there instead.
magit-run*: semantic scope fix
magit-run*: cosmetics
magit-git-quote-arguments: new function
magit-run*: no longer support input to fake sync processes

magit-run*: with input always use pipe

When sending input to a process always use a pipe (otherwise that
depends on option `magit-process-connection-type').  We have done
that ever since issue #20 was "fixed" but not in all cases.

Previously we did so when sending input to a "synchronous" process
(which is an asynchronous process, but we wait until it is done
before returning), but not for asynchronous processes.  That didn't
makes any sense.

This might, or might not, fix #487.  (I am just guessing, I don't
have Windows and until someone who does, actually investigates the
root cause of that issue, guessing is all I can do.  Let's hope I
am guessing right.)

magit-run*, magit-run-git*: drop FILTER argument

This argument was only used by `magit-run-bisect-git-bisect'
but that uses `magit-run-git-with-logfile' now.

magit-{run-git-with-logfile,process-logging-filter}: new functions

Only asynchronous processes can have a filter which we need to be able
to log to a file and send the output to *magit-process* too.  So when
we also want to wait until the subprocess has finished we use an
asynchronous process, and then just loop until it is done.

Now there is a dedicated function to this sort of thing.  This will
allow simplifying `magit-run*'.

magit-run-git-with-input: fake the synchronous process here

Only asynchronous processes can receive input.  So even if we want to
wait until the subprocess has finished we use an asynchronous process,
and then just loop until it is done.

Previously this was done in `magit-run*' but that caused that do be much
more complicated than it need be.  `magit-run-git-with-input' is much
more suitable so we do the looping here now.  (Actually `magit-run*'
also still supports looping, but that will change in few commits.)

magit-process-display-buffer: add kludge for quick processes

Add a kludge to `magit-process-display-buffer' to avoid mistakenly
displaying the process buffer for asynchronous processes that have
already consumed their input very quickly.

This function is rather messed up.  Eventually I will fix the mess
I have created here properly.

magit-process-display-buffer: rename from magit-display-process

... for consistency with the other `magit-process-*' functions.
magit-process-sentinel: use magit-process-finish

magit-process-sentinel: separate different concerns

This results in a bit of duplication, but that's
okay because this is an intermediate commit.

magit-process-finish: new function

Create new function `magit-process-finish' from parts of `magit-run*'.
Later commits will merge code from `magit-process-sentinel' and thereby
remove duplication and accidental differences between how errors are
reported depending on whether the failed process is synchronous or not.

magit-process-set-mode-line: absorb utility function

Merge `magit-process-indicator-from-command'
into `magit-process-set-mode-line'.
magit-process-unset-mode-line: new function
magit-process-set-mode-line: rename from magit-set-mode-line-process

magit-init: use magit-run-git

In `magit-init' use `magit-run-git' instead of the more low-level
`magit-run-git*'.

The latter should only be used in special cases, and should otherwise be
avoided.  Creating a repository now results in a refresh which is rather
pointless and has no effect because there cannot be any buffers to
refresh yet.  On the other hand checking whether anything has to be
refreshed also isn't costly enough to actively avoid it in this case.
The benefit is that I will not once more have to think about whether
there actually a reason `magit-run-git*' is used :-)

magit-git-command: use magit-run-git-async

In `magit-git-command' use `magit-run-git-async' instead of the more
low-level `magit-run-git*'.

The latter should only be used in special cases, and should otherwise be
avoided.  Now that we use the correct function the message "Running git
<...>" is displayed in the echo area.  Since the *magit-process* buffer
is also shown that isn't really necessary, but it also does no harm.

Merge branch 'pr/native'

let Emacs adjust point

Previously we did adjust point ourselves, because "Emacs often leaves
point in invisible regions, it seems."  However we did not actually
succeed in doing so because `disable-point-adjustment' is only set to
nil when a Magit mode is turned on, not for each and every command that
could possibly be run in a Magit buffer.  But that variable's doc-string
reveals that this doesn't have the desired effect:

  After a command is executed, if point is moved into a region that has
  special properties (e.g. composition, display), we adjust point to the
  boundary of the region.  But, when a command sets this variable to
  non-nil, we suppress the point adjustment.

  This variable is set to nil before reading a command, and is checked
  just after executing the command.

So I am removing our code that does the same, doing so does indeed not
change the behavior.

Merge branch 'pr/autorevert'

make refresh more explicit

Remove the macro `magit-with-refresh' and the function
`magit-refresh-wrapper' which was used to implement it.

This macro was used to setup a dynamic scope in which a only a single
refresh could happen.  But it turned out that this is not actually
useful and only makes it harder to understand what "refreshing" means.
While that wasn't always the case there now is not a single case where
the use of `magit-with-refresh' actually prevented a second refresh.

Also remove the variables `magit-refresh-needing-buffers' and
`magit-refresh-pending', which were the variables that were dynamically
bound by `magit-refresh-wrapper'.

Also remove the function `magit-need-refresh' which was used to mark a
buffer as needing to be refreshed inside a call to `magit-with-refresh',
by adding it to `magit-refresh-needing-buffers'.

The only function kept are `magit-refresh', and a variation of that
`magit-refresh-all' only intended for interactive use.

The functions `magit-run-git', `magit-run-git-with-input',
`magit-run-stgit', `magit-run-topgit', and (on behalf of
`magit-run-git-async') `magit-process-sentinel', now call
`magit-refresh' explicitly after git has returned.

The "process" functions (some of them) are the only generic functions
that call `magit-refresh'.  Everywhere else `magit-refresh' has to be
called explicitly.  That's a good thing it encourages more fine tuned
refreshing.

magit-rewrite-set-commit-property: use magit-refresh

In `magit-rewrite-set-commit-property' use `magit-refresh' instead
of `magit-need-refresh'.  That isn't exactly equivalent, but will
do until the former is removed too in the very next commits.

magit-section-action: don't use magit-with-section

Stop wrapping the body with `magit-with-section' when expanding
the `magit-section-action' macro.

Previously this macro already had an argument that allowed not
using `magit-with-section'.  Closer inspection revealed that using
the latter is actually never necessary anymore.

repurpose help-mode's xref support

Previously we had our own history mechanism, which was more complicated
and leaky, and was specific to the commit buffer.  Now we wrap around
`help-mode's xref support.  Unlike the old implementation, the new
wrappers can easily be used by other Magit modes.

magit-stgit-show: add doc-string

magit-stgit.el: remove concept of a marked commit

Supporting a "marked" commit is problematic because that for every
feature being implemented it has to be decided whether that acts on the
"top", "marked", or "at point" commit, provide a way to select the
other.  And then "the other" is yet again divided. Etc.  And then that
also differs between various features.  And then there might be
different opinions among users what is the right thing to do.  Etc.

Let's just not do it.  Also Magit's StGit is rather basic anyway, given
the few commands we actually have it is not necessary to have this
convenience feature (for users, for maintainers it's not a feature but a
nightmare).

magit-with-emacsclient: correct bogus server-use-tcp

On startup `server-use-tcp' is set to t if local sockets cannot be used.
That doesn't protect users from later setting it to nil, so we now undo
that mistake if necessary.
magit-with-emacsclient: cosmetics

magit-with-emacsclient: remove a needless check

In one particular case do not check whether the `system-type' is
`windows-nt' because the value of `server-use-tcp' is what is relevant
and that we also check in the same place.

magit-with-emacsclient: delete leftover server

It is possible that a server file is not properly deleted after the
Emacs instance in which the server was running has terminated.  That
could happen if Emacs has crashes; there might be other reasons.

If the `server-name' is "server", then this isn't a big problem as we
then just append the pid of the process to the `server-name' and use
that instead.  If the server named "server" does indeed no longer exist,
that is not so nice, because we needlessly use a non-standard name.  But
we cannot do anything about it without jeopardizing performance (by
attempting to connect to the server, just to see whether that works).

If we cannot use "server" then we append the pid.  In the unlikely case
that the server file for "serverPID" already exists, we now
unconditionally force delete that server.  That server cannot possibly
be still in use because PID is unique and we already know it is not
running in the current instance.

magit-with-emacsclient: start the server if necessary on Windows

Start the server if it is not running yet on Windows too.  Previously
this was not done on Windows, and there is no reason that would justify
that exception.

Merge branch 'pr/log-overlay'

refactor author/date margin in logs

To begin with use the term "margin" instead of "overlay".  The fact that
we use an overlay to do this is an implementation, which is not of
interest to users.  So we use the term "margin" as part of symbol names
to give users an idea what this is about.  Remove the terms "author" and
"date" from symbol names; we might later allow displaying other
information instead.

Rename the option
`magit-log-show-author-date' to
`magit-log-show-margin'.

Remove the functions
`magit-log-make-author-date-overlay',
`magit-log-create-author-date-overlays',
`magit-log-refresh-author-date', and
`magit-log-setup-author-date'.

Add the function
`magit-format-log-margin'
and the options
`magit-duration-spec' and
`magit-log-time-unit-as-character'.

No longer let git format the age of commits as human readable durations.
Instead use the recently added function `magit-format-duration'.  If we
kept on letting git do it we would have to parse git's output because it
sometimes uses two different units (which doesn't work for as because we
the available width is very constrained).  And we would have to do this
for N languages supported by git.  So let's just do it ourselves.  Users
have to customize the new option `magit-duration-spec' to use another
language.  That option can also be used to drop time units, e.g. to go
from days straight to months, omitting weeks. The algorithm used to
create time strings should probably be improved.

Use the recently added functions `magit-set-buffer-margin' and
`magit-make-margin-overlay' instead of spreading their (related but
separate) tasks across the removed functions and their callers.

magit-format-duration: new function

The algorithm is fairly stupid and can certainly be improved.

Rename `magit-log-author-date-max-length' to `magit-log-margin-width'.
The margin will eventually be used to display arbitrary information.
magit-log-author-date-cutoff: remove face
magit-ellipsis: new option

magit-make-margin-overlay: new function

To put some text in the margin one has set the `display' property of
some text appearing on that line.  One should use an overlay for that
purpose, to avoid changing the appearance of the actual buffer text.
That's more or less how it works, actually it is more complicated.
Anyways one shouldn't have to worry about this, it's just how this is
implemented on the Emacs side.  This function hides the strangeness.

magit-set-buffer-margin: new function

Add function `magit-set-buffer-margin' as a smarter alternative to
`set-window-margin'.  Margins are local to a window, not a buffer.
In practice this is inconvenient.

This new function is similar to the built-in function in that it
arranges for the margin to be setup in the current window.  Additionally
it uses the `window-configuration-change-hook' to update the margin when
appropriate.  Effectively it gives the illusion that the margin is local
to a buffer.

Currently it always sets the right margin and leaves the left margin
alone; but that could be extended if the need arises.

Merge branch 'pr/show'
magit-insert-stashes: absorb magit-wash-stash{,es}

magit-diff-stash: rename from magit-show-stash

Since `magit-show-stash' is just another variant of `magit-diff',
rename it to `magit-diff-stash'.

disband "Stash Mode" section

The command `magit-show-stash' is just another variant of `magit-diff',
much like `magit-diff-working-tree', `magit-diff-unstaged', and
`magit-diff-staged'.  It currently differs from these command in that it
does not just convert some value into something else that is understood
by `magit-diff'.  Instead it calls `magit-mode-init' directly; but it
does use the same refresher, namely `magit-refresh-diff-buffer'.  So we
move `magit-show-stash' into the same section as `magit-diff' and the
other variants.  It will be renamed in a later commit.

The functions `magit-wash-stashes' and `magit-wash-stash' are not used
to display a list of stashes, as such they are only loosely related to
`magit-show-stash'.  We move them next to `magit-insert-stashes', which
is the only function that uses them.  In a later commit these functions
will be merged into one.

magit-show-stash: remove special case

We identify stashes using a string of the form "stash@{N}".  Previously
there was one caller of `magit-show-stash' that passed a section object
instead, and the callee explicitly handled that case.  This commit
teaches the caller to respect the interface instead.

magit-currently-shown-stash: remove variable

Its value is not actually ever used.
magit-show-{commit,stash}: use magit-mode-display-buffer
magit-show-item-or-scroll: wrap around to opposing buffer boundary

magit-show-item-or-scroll: prompt for commit as fallback

Previously when `magit-show-item-or-scroll-{up or down}' was invoked but
point wasn't on a commit or stash, that caused the current buffer to be
scrolled.  But that didn't really make any sense, so now we instead
prompt for a commit to visit.

magit-show-item-or-scroll: new function

Add new function `magit-show-item-or-scroll' to decide on behalf of the
commands `magit-show-item-or-scroll-{up,down}' whether the commit buffer
should be scrolled and do it if appropriate.  Previously that was done
in `magit-show-{commit,stash}', which lead to these commands having an
interface that leaked implementation details.

Now that `magit-show-{commit,stash}' are not overloaded anymore, replace
their SELECT argument with NOSELECT, and remove the SCROLL argument.
Also change the argument order.

Remove most of `magit-show-commit's doc-string, some of that will come
back later.

magit-show-item-or-scroll-{up,down}: move definitions

These commands are not related to `magit-show' and the other commands
in "Acting>Visiting", they are related to `magit-show-commit' (and
`magit-show-stash').
magit-show-item-or-scroll-{up,down}: cosmetics

magit-checkout-branch-at-point: new command

Add the new command `magit-checkout-branch-at-point' and bind RET to it
in `magit-branch-manager-mode'.

Previously `magit-visit-item' did checkout the current branch when
invoked on a `branch' section, but that is wrong and this commit also
drops that case.  Using the buffer local keymap is the right thing to do
here - we should not abuse the `magit-section-action' functionality.  If
we always did what we were previously doing here, then section actions
would just become another way of implementing local keymaps (whether
that be buffer local keymaps or the `keymap' text property), and a
rather poor one at that.

Only actions that are fairly close to one another should ever be grouped
in a `magit-section-action' or `magit-section-case'.  This isn't the
case here.  Bringing up some information in some buffer about the thing
at point in the current buffer, as done in the other cases, is *very*
different from checking out a branch.

magit-visit-item: remove `branch' section case

The meaning of "visit" is very different for all other cases handled by
`magit-visit-item'.  Because there are several other methods for showing
more history, we don't need to keep this one.
magit-wash-log: use button for "show more history"

magit-show-stash: promote to command

It doesn't make any sense for this to be a non-interactive function when
the related `magit-show-commit' is a command.

magit-read-stash: new function

This function could be nicer, but I don't actually expect it to be used
very often, so I won't do it until my todo list has shrunk.  It is
needed because `magit-show-stash' has to be turned into a command and
for that some input reader is needed.

just use `magit-visit-item' instead.  Until some commits ago this
function had to be a command because the latter called it using

magit-wash-diff: emergency fix

Recent refactoring to the code responsible for creating sections did not
take into account that washing diffs is done in a way different from how
washing usually happens; inserting a diff involves washing git output
twice, and even though we are washing git output `magit-with-section' is
also.  That, unlike `magit-git-insert-section' does not cancel an empty
section and therefor returns t.  That led to an endless loop when for
empty diffs.

This commit is just a quick fix to avoid the loop.  A proper fix will
involve not washing twice, a change I intended to make anyway.

magit-insert-line-section: new macro

Replace the function `magit-insert-status-line' with the new macro

so the inserted text is now part of a section.

We don't actually make use of the header lines now being sections

magit-status-line-align-to: move definition

Move the definition of the variable `magit-status-line-align-to' into
the same section as the definitions of custom options, but don't turn it
into an option, just yet.  It will likely be renamed at some later time,
and doing so causes less problems if it is a variable people do not know
about.  We move it now because so that, after the next commit, is still

magit-create-buffer-sections: remove macro

Remove the macro `magit-create-buffer-sections', after moving its last
responsibilities elsewhere: inhibit read-only in `magit-with-section'
and erase the buffer in `magit-mode-refresh-buffer'.  Everything else
it used to do has already been moved in earlier commits, mostly to
`magit-with-section', though.

This theoretically makes it possible to use most functions that insert
one section (or many sections that are all children of exactly one
section) as a "buffer refresh" function.  In practice a few more
preparations are still necessary.

magit-with-section: set invisible property

Set the `invisible' property in `magit-create-buffer-sections'.

The creation of a section should, as much as possible, be "complete"
when `magit-with-section' returns.  Unfortunately this commit isn't
enough for that to come true.  The code that does set the property
is still only run once we are done creating the root section.

To change that some prior changes to the "section visibility" code
would necessary.  This will be taken care of another time.

But this commit is still beneficial is a step towards the removal of
`magit-create-buffer-sections'.

sufficiently dynamic scope is indistinguishable from magic

In past commit messages I have been bitching a lot about the variable
`magit-top-section'; grep history for a good rant :-)

This commit finally replaces it with two distinct variables, each
taking responsibility for one, and only one, of its two remaining and
very distinct objectives.

One of these variables is the new `magit-root-section'.  It is defined
as an automatically buffer-local variable, and should only ever be used
as such.  Its value is the, one and only, "root" section of the buffer.
A buffer can only have one root section; all other sections have to be
descendants of that section.

The value of `magit-root-section' is set by `magit-with-section' when
that inserts the root section.  This macro automatically detects when
that is the case, the user just has to follow the conventions.  (Which
still need to be documented.  I might also later add sanity asserts.)
Outside of this macro the value of this variable should only ever be
read.

The old `magit-top-section' was also abused to represent the "section
that is the parent of the one currently being inserted".  It has also
been used to represent the "section currently being inserted", but that
was fixed some time ago.

So the value of `magit-with-section--parent', the other new variable
to replace `magit-top-section', is the parent of the section being
inserted, not the one being inserted.

Then there also was `magit-old-top-section' whose value is the section
that used to be the root section before the buffer was erased to refresh
it, by inserting a new generation of sections.  This variable is renamed
to `magit-with-section--oldroot'.

The symbol name of these two new variables contain the full name of
`magit-with-section' because they should never ever be used anywhere
else.  They are used to "pass" information from one instance to another.
Dynamic bindings have to be used for this purpose, because the
alternative would lead to unnecessary complications.  While passing
values like this is a bit ugly, all the trickery is now contained in
`magit-with-section'.

Essentially the magic now happens in this part of `magit-with-section':

  (let ((s (car arglist)))
    `(let ((,s (make-magit-section
                ...
                :parent magit-with-section-parent)))
       ...
       (let ((magit-with-section--parent ,s)
             (magit-with-section--oldroot
              (or magit-with-section--oldroot
                  (unless magit-with-section--parent
                    (prog1 magit-root-section
                      (setq magit-root-section ,s))))))
         ,@body)
       ...))

If you think that is bad, then imagine what it was like when this logic
was spread all across magit.el; `magit-with-section--parent', `s', and
`magit-root-section' all had the same symbol name; that variable was
used for yet some other purposes; and much of the codebase was in denial
by hiding its uses inside various "getter" functions.

magit-with-section: set magit-section property

Set the `magit-section' text property in `magit-with-section'
instead of in `magit-propertize-section', which was called by
`magit-create-buffer-sections'.

Remove `magit-propertize-section', which now isn't used anymore.

The previous approach was to delay setting this property until all
sections have been inserted.  Then, starting at the root section,
recursively set the property for all sections.  This way the property
was first set to the parent section and then set again to the child
section.

Now, as soon as a section is inserted, the property is set, but only
for the part of its text that doesn't have it set yet, and therefor
does not belong to a child section.

Both approaches come with an (insignificant) performance penalty;
trade one for the other.  The approach we are now using is better
because the creation of a section should, as much as possible, be
"complete" when `magit-with-section' returns and because this is a
step towards the eventual removal of `magit-create-buffer-sections'.
magit-with-section: quote TYPE argument

magit-{git,cmd}-insert-section: new macros

Add two new macro that insert the washed output of a program as a
section: `magit-cmd-insert-section' and `magit-git-insert-section'.
These macros are convenience wrappers around `magit-with-section', just
like the functions `magit-insert-section' and `magit-git-section', which
they replace.  Unlike the latter they preserve most of the flexibility
of `magit-with-section'.

Members of the ARGS argument don't need to be strings.  If a member is
nil it is filtered out.  If a member is a list it is treated as if its
members were members of ARGS itself.  This is necessary because `apply'
can no longer be used (because we are dealing with macros).  But doing
it this way is also more convenient.

magit-wash-log: insert "show more" section here

When the log is cutoff a "show more commits" section is inserted.
Previously that was done in `magit-refresh-log-buffer' and
`magit-refresh-reflog-buffer'.  Now it is done in `magit-wash-log'.

magit-old-top-section: don't abuse for speedup

The variable `magit-old-top-section' is used to preserve state during a
refresh.  As of now the only state that is preserved when refreshing, is
whether the section is expanded or not.  Because of the way state is
preserved, determining the previous state involves a bit of work, which
is useless for sections that do not have a "body".  For such sections
being hidden holds no meaning, as the heading is always displayed, even
when hidden.

Previously `magit-old-top-section' was let-bound to nil around some code
that created such sections, effectively disabling the code that
determined the previous visibility.  That was very confusing: without
reading the code that actually used the variable's value, it was
impossible to tell what binding the variable to nil was supposed to do.

Here we just remove these let-bindings.  A later commit will make
"getting the previous state" generally more efficient and as a result
make it unnecessary to add a hack to bypass doing so.  Actually I think
that the current code also is efficient enough, making the hack being
removed here, rather pointless in the first place.
magit-diffstat-cached-sections: move definition

branch manager: make trailing newline part of section

In `magit-wash-branches' and `magit-wash-remote-branches-group' make the
empty line that separates sections part of the preceding section instead
of the parent section.

branch manager: don't highlight "branch group" sections

In `magit-wash-branches' and `magit-wash-remote-branches-group'
don't highlight "branch groups" sections.

branch manager: let magit-with-section insert headings

In `magit-wash-branches' and `magit-wash-remote-branches-group'
make full use of `magit-with-section' to insert the headings.
magit-wash-diffstats: let magit-with-section insert headings
magit-insert-wazzup-commits: let magit-with-section insert headings
magit-insert-pending-commits: let magit-with-section insert headings

magit-with-section: allow inserting HEADING verbatim

If the argument HEADING ends with a newline, then insert it verbatim.
magit-with-section: deal with content-less sections

magit-with-section: delay inserting the heading

Previously the heading was inserted, then the content, and then, for
some sections, and provided `magit-show-child-count' was non-nil,
`magit-with-section' went back to the heading and modified it.

Now the heading isn't inserted until all information that could be
required (currently the number of child sections) is available.

magit-with-section: delay adding a child to its parent

In `magit-with-section' delay adding the section being inserted to the
CHILDREN slot of its parent section.  Sections can get canceled by BODY.

In `magit-insert-section' stop removing the canceled section from the
parent.  It's no longer necessary due to the above change.

magit-insert-section: make trailing newline part of section

This has two effects:

* Some code, especially that involved with section movement, can
  (later) be simplified.

* When such a section is collapsed the newline is also hidden.
  Previously it remained and separated the heading of the collapsed
  section from the heading of the next section.

  Personally I prefer the new look better.  It doesn't waste screen
  estate.  It is also consistent with what is actually (now) happening
  behind the scene: there is no "going back to the parent, in between
  children" (resulting in the benefit mentioned above).  Also Magit
  sections are now collapsed the same way as those of Org-Mode, and I
  assume every other Emacs outline mode.

  However some users will likely see this as a regression.  For now we
  change the behavior; and if this change is commonly disliked, we can
  still add a kludge to appease those opposing the visual effect of
  this change.

magit-insert-section: properly cancel empty sections

While inserting a section using `magit-insert-section' it can turn out
that there is no output from the PROGRAM that could actually be washed
to create the section.  This is the case because the PROGRAM, usually
git, isn't run *before* calling `magit-insert-section', but as part of
calling it.

As a result this function sometimes needs to "cancel" a section.  In
other words it has to undo all setup that has already been done. The
common setup is actually done by (the expansion of) `magit-with-section'.
After `magit-insert-section' is done with inserting and washing the
section text, `magit-with-section' finalizes the section by doing some
things common to all sections.

These final steps are unnecessary for sections that were canceled, and
some commits ago `magit-with-section' has been taught not to perform
them when its BODY set SECTION to nil.  Now finally we actually do set
it to nil.

Not that the "root" or "buffer" section is never canceled; if its body
is empty the string "(empty)" is inserted instead.
magit-insert-section: minor semantic fixes

magit-with-section: take over heading insertion

Move the code responsible for inserting the heading from
`magit-insert-section' to `magit-with-section' and adapt it accordingly.

Now callers of `magit-with-section' can get the same benefit regarding
headers, as those of `magit-insert-section' and `magit-git-section' do.
We don't actually use it with `magit-with-section' yet and how exactly
headers are inserted is also still subject to change.

magit-insert-wazzup-commits: don't calculate when hidden

In `magit-insert-wazzup-commits' stop consulting `magit-old-top-section'
directly and instead rely on the value of the HIDDEN slot of the section
being inserted, as setup by `magit-with-section'.

This not only saves code and prepares for the removal of said variable,
it also gives a considerable speedup.  Previously a section, after being
expanded by the user would get recalculated on every refresh, even when
the user collapsed it again.  The result of that was that refreshing the
wazzup buffer got slower and slower, which was surprising to users who
took care to only ever have a few sections expanded.
magit-wash-remote-branches-group: rename internal variable

magit-wash-raw-diff: mark as "hidden by default"

Previously the parent section of the sections inserted by
`magit-wash-raw-diff' was marked as "hidden by default",
which was wrong because it isn't and wasn't; its children
are and were.
magit-wash-raw-diff: remove duplicated code
magit-wash-raw-diff: remove unused variables
magit-wash-raw-diff: remove a comment

magit-with-section: add HIDDEN argument

This works like, and replaces, the old `magit-section-hidden-default'
variable, which was let bound to "pass" this information to this
function.
magit-with-section: separate different concerns

magit-with-section: absorb magit-new-section

Until some commits ago `magit-new-section' was used in one other place
but `magit-with-section', but that was a mistake and has been fixed.
Now we can merge `magit-new-section' into `magit-with-section' to
prevent contributors from bypassing the additional, and required, setup
in `magit-with-section'.

Additionally this allows tiding up the code a bit, but we don't do that
in this commit.  After this commit, everything happens in the exact same
order as before, even when that means doing some things, only to
override them later.  Besides the removal of `magit-new-section' there
is one exception: the `let' which binds `magit-top-section' wraps around
less code.

magit-with-section: assert SECTION is still non-nil after BODY

The forms in `magit-insert-section's BODY may cancel a section and set
SECTION to nil, so assert this is not so after evaluating BODY of
`magit-with-section' and before setting the values of slots of SECTION.

There is not currently such a BODY that actually cancels the section but
we should not assume that remains so, it would actually be a smart thing
to do in some cases.

make section TITLE slot consistent

In the "more commits" sections created in `magit-refresh-log-buffer' and
`magit-refresh-reflog-buffer' store the same information in the struct
slot TITLE that is already stored in TYPE.  That obviously is wrong but
at least it now is consistently wrong across Magit.  The reason why we
cannot just drop that yet, is that in some places TYPE is used to
retrieve this information, while in others TITLE is used.  It's also
worth noting that in a few other cases INFO is used instead or as yet
another alternative way of accessing this value.

In the section created in `magit-wash-remote-branches-group' store an
identification string in TITLE, instead of that string prefixed with
some irrelevant noise.

After this change all sections either store the same (constant) symbol
in TITLE and TYPE, or they store a symbol in TYPE and either nil (only
buffer sections) or some information in the TITLE slot, which can be
used to uniquely identify the section and/or is necessary when
performing some action on the section.  That value usually is some
string, but it may also be a symbol, it is however in all cases an atom.

The actual TITLEs being changed here are:
* 2x  "longer"                        =>  'longer
* 1x  (concat "remote:" remote-name)  =>  remote-name

make section headings consistent

Add a colon at the end of the heading of "Pending changes".

After this commit section headings are consistent.  The headings of all
toplevel buffer sections, that actually have a heading, DO NOT end with
a colon.  Those sections that don't have a heading don't do so because
they either start out with a "line" subsection.  Or because their
content begins with something that serves well as a heading, and making
that actually a heading would cause complications but no significant
benefit.

The headings of non-buffer, non-line sections, that actually do have a
heading, DO end with a colon.

I would actually like this to be customizable using two distinct format
strings, but that can wait.  It would also be nice if the user could
choose whether the newline should be propertized as part of the heading,
which becomes relevant when the background color is set.
magit-section struct: add extra slots for diffs

magit-section struct: define CONTENT-BEGINNING as a real slot

A function `magit-section-content-beginning' already existed but it just
assumed that the content begins one line after the beginning of the
section.  However that is not always correct; sections exist that have
no heading in which case the section and its content begin at the same
position.  In the future there might also sections with multiline
headings.

In `magit-with-section' CONTENT-BEGINNING is initially set to the same
value as BEGINNING.  Provided its BUFFER-TITLE argument is non-nil
`magit-insert-section' then adjust the slot's value.

magit-section struct: bring slots into a reasonable order

The guiding principal for the order is: will it be helpful when printing
the struct vector for debugging purposes?  Previously PARENT which leads
to recursive display was first - the worst possible beginning.  Now it
begins with TYPE, TITLE, and INFO, followed by the boundaries.

magit-insert-section: rename argument BUFFER-TITLE to HEADING

This function is not only used for buffer sections and such sections may
also have headings.

magit-insert-section: don't remove empty buffer sections

Don't remove empty buffer sections, but keep doing it for other
sections, e.g. for "Staged changes" when there are not actually any
staged changes.  But do not remove empty buffer sections.  They are
not actually empty, but usually contain the header, which provides
information that is relevant when a user tries to determine why git
did not produce any input.  Previously the section was removed and
replaced with one that just said "(empty)", which is not helpful at
all.  E.g. "Changes in HEAD..HEAD\n(empty)" is much more useful than
"(empty)"; it could help the user realize that he did not actually
type "HEAD~.." as intended but "HEAD..".

Move all the code related to this into `magit-insert-section',
previously some of it was inside `magit-create-buffer-section'.

magit-insert-section: absorb magit-cancel-section

It's not used anywhere else and by providing this functionality as a
separate function we encourage its use, which we shouldn't do because
using it would likely be due to failure to understand the section api.
There is already enough abuse of that, let's make it harder for
contributors to shot themselves (and us) in the foot.

magit-create-log-buffer-sections: remove macro

Remove macro `magit-create-log-buffer-sections'.  Dong so leads to a
tiny bit of code duplication.  Actually because it was only used twice
this commit adds exactly as many lines as it removes.  It used to be
used more often but even then the existence of this macro was not
justified.

This macro is related to (and uses) `magit-create-buffer-sections'.  In
addition to what the latter does it also prepares for something else to
count how many log items were inserted and then inserts the "there are
more commits" button.  That is not really closely enough related to
the task of `magit-create-buffer-sections' (dealing with the failing
`magit-top-section'/magit-old-top-section' abstraction) that one could
easily guess what the removed macro does in addition to what the other
does.  So let's just put the code where one would expect it.

magit-insert-commit-navigation-button: new function

Add new function `magit-insert-commit-navigation-button' to avoid some
code duplication (some of which is yet to come, luckily not actually in
form of duplication).

The symbol name contains "-navigation-" because this function is not a
variation of `magit-make-commit-button', though in practice it behaves
similarly.

magit-wash-commit: avoid inserting unnecessary whitespace

... when inserting commit buttons.

magit-make-commit-button: absorb magit-set-section

Extend `magit-make-commit-button' so that it not only turns a text area
into a button but at the same time turns it into a magit section.  The
second task was previously performed by `magit-set-section'.  The latter
is removed in this commit.  And so is the noisy code that was previously
required around the calls to these functions - they only ever appeared
in combination.

Now `magit-make-commit-button' is much more useful because it does
everything related to creating a commit button, and could therefor
potentially be used elsewhere.  Actually we should consider whether the
"button as a section" concept could be used for other things besides
commits.

Regarding the removed `magit-set-section' I have to say this: It is a
colosal failure if a function is advertised as universally useful (here
by its name and placement) even though it is not, AND only has a single
caller (`magit-wash-commit'), FOR WHICH it is COMPLETELY inappropriate,
because it only serves to COMPLICATE that one caller (for which it
presumably was written), AND there already is an existing abstraction
(`magit-make-commit-button') which only has to be modified SLIGHTLY to
ACTUALLY make it easier for the caller.

magit-set-section-needs-refresh-on-show: remove function

See previous commit for motivation.

magit-set-section-info: remove function

Remove `magit-set-section-info' and the obfuscation it caused; and
instead use `setf' with the "current section"s INFO slot as PLACE.
Since the previous commit, that section is commonly available as the
value of a known symbol (with limited dynamic scope).

In some other cases where the call to `magit-set-section-info' was not
lexically within a call to `magit-with-section' the section now has to
be passed using a function argument (from the function which uses the
`magit-with-section' macro, to the function which wants to manipulate
the sections INFO slot).  That's a good thing.

magit-with-section: locally bind section to named variable

This prepares for the eventual removal of the troublesome variable
`magit-top-section'.  Three of the difficulties resulting from the
use of that variable are hinted at here, but there are more.

Add a new argument SECTION to the ARGLIST of `magit-with-section'.
It has to be a symbol and it is bound to the section being created
by `magit-with-section'.

Something similar is done in `magit-section-{action,case}'.

Do not actually make us of the new binding yet.  Except in one case
where not doing so would result in a surprising breakage (diffs can
no longer be expanded).  The main change in this commit is related,
but one would not expect this to break `magit-wash-raw-diff' - but
being predictable is not exactly a property of `magit-top-section'.

It might seem that there are not many uses of `magit-with-section'
that could actually make use of SECTION, because there are not many
that currently use `magit-top-section'.  That however is an illusion
- there are many sections that use it indirectly by calling functions
such as `magit-set-section-info' which do manipulate the section
stored in `magit-top-section', when their optional SECTION argument
is nil (which it always is).  These functions were presumably
created in the first place because having uses of `magit-top-section'
appear everywhere was troubling (or at least noisy) and someone
wanted to hide that fact (effectively obscuring `magit-top-section'
even more).

identify all buffer sections, using symbol ending in `buf'

In `magit-refresh-reflog-buffer use `reflogbuf' instead of `reflog' as
the TYPE of the inserted top section. In `magit-refresh-wazzup-buffer'
use `wazzupbuf' instead of `wazzup'.

Now all such top-level buffer sections have a symbol as TYPE and the
symbol names of all of them end with "buf" (with no separating dash,
mostly for historic reasons).

Actually this is not quiet true.  The `logbuf' and `reflogbuf' section
are wrapped in an additional, otherwise empty, and unnecessary `log'
section.  But I noticed that to late to fix it in this commit.
identify all buffer sections

identify branch-manager sections using symbols

In `magit-refresh-branch-manager' use the symbol `branchbuf' instead
of the string "branches" as the TYPE of the inserted top section.

In `magit-wash-branches' use the symbol `local' as the TYPE and so
called TITLE of the respective section.  Previously the string "local"
was used as TYPE and nil was used as TITLE.

give calls to magit-git-section a uniform appearance

As much as possible format all calls to `magit-git-section' the same.

If possible put the TYPE and BUFFER-TITLE arguments on the same line
as `magit-git-section'.  When BUFFER-TITLE is calculated "inside" the
call to `magit-git-section' and that takes more than one line or a very
long line then put it on separate line(s).  Always put WASHER on its own
line; if it is a symbol quote with #' not just ', providing semantic
information to the reader.

I am doing this now because it helps looking for inconsistencies that go
beyond appearance.

don't try to be smart about not highlighting sections

A major problem with the section implementation is that there is next to
no consistency regarding the meaning of the slots TITLE, TYPE, and INFO.
In different contexts and for different "kinds" (let's not use "type" to
avoid confusion :-) of sections are used to "identify" (what that means
also isn't consistent) sections.

As a result that code written with one use-case in mind cannot be used
elsewhere, leading to duplication and a growing number of inconsistencies.

One anomaly with likely is not only the result of this confusion but
probably the cause of many of these inconsistencies is that "a section
not having a title" is the (only) way of creating a section that is
never highlighted.

Instead add new slot HIGHLIGHT with defaults to t.
magit-set-section: change argument order
magit-new-section: change argument order
magit-with-section: switch order inside ARGLIST
magit-with-section: group non-BODY arguments as ARGLIST

remove introductory comment about sections

It's a noble goal to provide some documentation for those using the
source, but since this was the only such comment and because it was
also not informative enough, it did not really do any good.

I am all for literate programming, but that has to wait until after
the cleanup is over and after the next release.  And even then we
might not do it.

remove doc-strings of section creation functions

Remove the doc-strings of `magit-new-section', `magit-cancel-section',
`magit-with-section', `magit-insert-section', `magit-git-section',
`magit-create-buffer-sections', and `magit-propertize-section'.  Of
these only `magit-with-section' will survive the subsequent refactoring.

New doc-strings will be added once the current refactoring is over.

Keeping these doc-strings, which in some cases are insufficient, would
make refactoring harder than it need be: changes would have to be
written trice: once in Lisp and twice in English.

magit-read-rev-range: return atom if no range was read

This function is used to read a range *or a single rev*.  Changes
elsewhere assumed this function returns an atom when a single rev
was read, but until now that wasn't the case.

That broke the "ranged" log when it was used to show the history
of a branch (or any rev) different from the current branch.

Yes, there is a lot wrong here, this commit only fixes a bug that
resulted from doing some of the preparation necessary to fix the
bigger issues, not carefully enough.  Fixing the real issues still
require additional preparation.

magit-mark-item: don't refresh buffer

Commit 00718df7ba4cfdcc04cb6e87f5c0c7c3fdc41bd7 was intended
to do that but just contained a TODO instead of an actual change.

calls to magit-setup-mode: put REFRESH-ARGS on same line as fn

When calling `magit-setup-mode' put the REFRESH-ARGS on the same
line as the REFRESH-FUNC, provided they don't take up much space.
Merge branch 'pr/bisect'
magit-bisect-reset: require confirmation

magit-bisect-run: sanitize

The command `magit-bisect-run' is a wrapper around `git bisect run CMD
[ARGS...]', obviously.  All it has to do is to read `CMD [ARGS...]' from
the user and then pass that on to `git bisect run'.

But until now, after reading the input, it instead stored the user input
in a file, made it executable, called `git bisect run' with that file as
CMD, and then later and somewhere else (this was removed in the previous
commit) removed the file again.  Well, we don't need to do any of that...

Also we now read user input the same way `shell-command' does - if it's
good enough for that, then it is good enough for us too.

magit-insert-bisect-output: new function

This uses the new "command output cache" implemented in the previous
commit and replaces `magit--bisect-info-for-status', which was removed
in the commit before that (because it used the old, broken caching
mechanism).

We use a "real" section with a heading and a body, instead of a "line"
section, because while the first line usually contains the interesting
part, that is not always the case.  The body is hidden by default.

The cached output is inserted verbatim in most cases, except when we
*know* the first line does not contain the "result".  Currently this the
only covered special case is when the `run` command was run.  In that
case the last line (mentioning the "first bad commit") is copied to the
front.  Other special cases can be added as they surface.

If there is no cached information, inform the user about why that is so,
instead of throwing the arms in the air, as the old implementation did.

sanely cache the output of the last bisect command

Both the old and the new implementations dealt with this problem:
`git bisect CMD' does print some useful information, which cannot
be fully retrieved from the .git/BISECT_* files it also generates.

We could reimplement a lot of the `git-bisect' script and `bisect.c' but
that would be overkill.  In most cases the information isn't that
important; but still quite nice to have.  One case where we cannot get
to it is when the user runs `git bisect CMD' from the command line.  In
that case the information is in the shell, and we just cannot get to it
- so be it, the user probably saw it there.

--

This was the setting.
Now comes how the old implementation tried to deal with it:

`magit-run-git-bisect' (formerly known as `magit--bisect-cmd') used
`magit-git-lines' (should have used `magit-git-line') to get the first
line, and stored it in a buffer-local variable in the status buffer.

That's problematic because the user might delete that buffer at any time
in which case we would lose the cached information.  Also the buffer
might not exist in the first place, resulting in an error.

Then it went on throwing everything but the first line away.  In most
cases that is acceptable, but not when an error occurs or when using the
`run' command.

Also because `magit-git-lines' is used instead of some function that
ultimately uses `magit-run*' there is no error handling whatsoever.  If
something goes wrong the user has no choice but to rerun the whole
bisect on the command line, just to find out what went wrong.

Then, probably to deal with some of the above issues, it went on to
reimplement `magit-run*', including its own filter and sentinel, just
for the sake of `magit-bisect-run'.

--

This is what the new implementation does:  Use `magit-run-git*' (which
ultimately uses `magit-run*') like for all other user commands.  Git's
output is placed in the process buffer as usual.  The output is *also*,
and that's the *only* customization actually required, inserted into
the file .git/BISECT_CMD_OUTPUT (using a special filter function).
That's it.

That file is later used when displaying information in the status
buffer. The next commit will actually add the new "inserter" function
responsible for doing so.

magit-insert-status-local-line: don't show bisect information

That information should be displayed separately and the way the
information is currently being cached also is rather convoluted
and leaky.  So we remove this first (it is not essential) and
then, in a later commit, add a more suitable substitute.

Remove the function `magit--bisect-info-for-status' which was
used to format the bisect part of the string displayed by
`magit-insert-status-local-line'.
magit-run-git-bisect: optionally assert we are already bisecting
magit-run-git-bisect: rename from magit--bisect-cmd

magit-run{,-git}*: add FILTER argument

Due to limitations of `magit-run*', this is necessary to implement
`magit-run-git-bisect' and `magit-bisect-run' in a sane fashion.

Also due to `magit-run*' limitations this patch is a bit hackish;
looks like I finally have to refactor that.
magit-bisect-start: do reading in interactive

magit-bisecting-p: don't check bisect "status"

Previously `magit-bisectin-p' not only checked whether bisecting has
already started, but also whether it had not yet finished (found the
bad commit).  It also features an argument to NOT do the latter.

This was done for some commands that are not useful when bisecting is
already finished.  However they also do no HARM when run at that point
so we don't need that extra test, it only complicates things (like
subsequent refactorings).

magit-bisect-log: remove command

Since we now display the respective information directly in the status
buffer, we no longer need this command.

magit-refs-namespaces: new entries for the "bisect-log" log style

These strings are not actual refs.  They represent existing refs but
`git bisect log' does not return print those.  The way we currently
use "namespaces" this is not a problem, but we might have to have
another look at a later time.
magit-wash-log-line: abbreviate revs for the bisect-log style

magit-{wash-wash-bisect-log,log-bisect-log-re}: new fn/var

And use the new washer in `magit-insert-bisect-log',
and teach `magit-wash-log-line' about the new log style.

magit-log-head-label-bisect-skip: new face

Add new face `magit-log-head-label-bisect-skip' and
add a matching entry to `magit-refs-namespaces'.

magit-insert-bisect-log: new function

And new function `magit-insert-bisect-log'
and add it to `magit-status-sections-hook'.

magit-bisect-visualize: remove command

Since we now display the respective information directly in the status
buffer, we no longer need this command.

magit-{insert-bisect-rest,log-bisect-vis-re}: new fn/var

And teach `magit-wash-log-line' about the new log style
introduced by the above, and add `magit-insert-bisect-rest'
to `magit-status-sections-hook'.

magit-bisect-reset: no error if nothing to reset

Running `git bisect reset` when there is no running or finished bisect
does nothing (no error).  That's good enough for use, let's not perform
a needless test and raise an error if it fails.

That will also make it easier later on.  We start to benefit in this
commit already by removing the "reset" special case in
`magit--bisect-cmd'.
magit-bisecting-p: renamed from magit--bisecting-p

magit.el: assimilate magit-bisect.el

Copy existing code as-is, except that it is reordered and most
doc-strings and comments are removed.
magit-insert-empty-line: move definition

magit-format-ref-labels: new function
magit-wash-commit: simplify propertizing first line
magit-wash-commit: lose whitespace and a comment

magit-log-long-re: rename from magit-log-longline-re

Logs of type "long" do not consist of one long line per commit, as
opposite to a "short oneline" per entry.  They commit is represented
by *multiple* lines, which usually are *shorter* than those used by
logs of type "oneline".  The name of this variable probably used to
contain "longline" instead of "long" to achieve some misguided
consistency with "oneline"; fix that.

Revert "magit-diff-none: inherit from default face"

magit-diff-none: inherit from default face

Previously we inherited from `diff-context' but because that does not
set a background color in the default them that meant that unchanged in
diffs were highlighted.  Since we by default use a rather ugly color for
that purpose, that was not acceptable.

See issue #1042.

and `magit-commit-squash-abort'.

In `magit-mode-quit-window' run the new hook
`magit-mode-quit-window-hook'.  Do not explicitly declare the hook
variable, at this point it is not intended to be used by third-party
code.

add new commands magit-commit-{extend,reword}

Add the new commands `magit-commit-extend' and `magit-commit-reword',

add new command magit-commit-amend

magit-mark-commit: run new magit-mark-commit-hook

In `magit-mark-commit run the new hook `magit-mark-commit-hook'.
Do not explicitly declare the hook variable, at this point it is
not intended to be used by third-party code.

add option magit-commit-ask-to-stage

Add option `magit-commit-ask-to-stage'.  If it is non-nil and nothing
is staged then `magit-commit-assert' expands the unstaged changes.

This partially restores a similar feature that was available before the
switch to `git-commit-mode', and also extends it.  It is now less
flexible in that it is a simple boolean.  On the other hand it shows
the unstaged changes to the user, making it easier for him to make up
his mind.

add function magit-commit-assert

Add function `magit-commit-assert' and remove the sanity checks and
alternative exit points previously located in `magit-commit' there.

It returns either the arguments, or `t' if their are no arguments to
tell the caller to actually perform the commit.  For that reason
`magit-commit-internal' has to be taught that its ARGS being `t' now
means 'no arguments'.

New exit points will appear soon and that will make it hard to add
extend these checks and alternative code paths without resorting to
things like `return'.  This is the best alternative could see,
considering new commands will be created soon, that need the same
checks.

In `magit-commit' tell `magit-jump-to-staged' to also expand,

magit-define-section-jumper: teach created functions how to expand

Functions created with macro `magit-define-section-jumper' now take an
optional EXPAND argument, interactively a prefix argument can be used.
When that is non-nil, the section being jumped to is also expanded.
