Merge branch 'pr/consistent-Magit-Mode'

move magit-mode-quit-window to end of its section

Move the function `magit-mode-quit-window' from the middle to the end of
section "Mode Foundation".  It is closely related to the other functions
in this section but is different in that does not "create" a mode buffer
but makes it go away.  The end seems like a suitable place for that.

remove function magit-find-status-buffer

Remove function `magit-find-status-buffer' and just use generic
`magit-find-buffer'.  The latter will be renamed and extended in
subsequent commits and then more often used for other modes too;
it which point it won't makes sense anymore, to have a specialized
function for just one of the modes (and adding one for all modes
certainly isn't an option).

rename magit-display-mode-buffer to magit-mode-display-buffer

Rename function `magit-display-mode-buffer' to
`magit-mode-display-buffer', for consistency
with other similarly named functions.

rename function magit-{ => mode}-quit-window

Rename the function `magit-quit-window' to `magit-mode-quit-window'
making it more obvious that this is only useful for windows whose
current buffer's major modes are derived from Magit mode.
magit-mode-display-buffer: fix typo in doc-string

rename function magit-{ => mode}-refresh-buffer

Rename the function `magit-refresh-buffer' to `magit-mode-refresh-buffer'
making it more obvious that this is only useful for buffers whose major
modes are derived from Magit mode.

magit-refresh-{function,args}: no longer permanently local

No longer define variables `magit-refresh-function', and
`magit-refresh-args' as permanently buffer-local.  They are still
buffer-local.  Making them permanent local doesn't make any sense:

* we don't actually change the mode in buffers where these are set,
* if we did change the mode we would *not* want them to keep their
  old values, and
* they would not do so anyway, because we explicitly reset them.

merge three subsections of "Magit Mode"

Merge the subsections "Initialize Mode", "Display Buffer", and "Refresh
Buffer" into a new subsection "Mode Foundation".  The old distinctions
did make sense, but after past cleanup it is no longer *necessary* to
keep them separated to improve the odds of understanding them.  The
functions and variables are closely related, and interconnected, so
having them in the same section makes sense.

move subsection "(section kludges)" to end of "Magit Mode"

The functions in the "(section kludges)" subsection of "Magit Mode" are
hook functions that are necessary because of limitations in the section
code (or used by them).  This limitations will eventually be lifted
making these kludges unnecessary.

Until then at least move them out of sight.

rename "Hooks" subsection to "(section kludges)"

The functions in the "Hooks" subsection of "Magit Mode" are hook
functions that are necessary because of limitations in the section
code (or used by them).  This limitations will eventually be lifted
making these kludges unnecessary.

Until then at least label them accordingly.

move definitions of magit-refresh-{function,args}

Move the definitions of the variables `magit-refresh-functions' and
`magit-refresh-args' to another subsection of "Magit Mode".  Previously
they were located inside the subsection "Hook" which somewhat made sense
because they are used in a hook-like fashion.

However the other functions in that section of "Magit Mode" are hook
functions that are necessary because of limitations in the section
code (or used by them).  This limitations will eventually be lifted
making these kludges unnecessary.

The current heading of the new section, "Initialize Mode", doesn't do
the moved functions full justice and is subject to change.

move "Refresh Machinery" section to toplevel

Move the "Refresh Machinery" section to the toplevel.  Previously it
was a subsection of "Magit Mode".  The main reason it was merely a
subsection for a long time, is that moving it to the toplevel did
require some code to be moved around (see previous commits).

The refresh machinery is only loosely coupled with the code related
to the code in "Magit Mode".  This move just officializes this, and
was prone to happen eventually.  Since I have plans to improve both
the "mode" and the "refresh" logic, that moment has come now.

move  magit-{revert-buffer,update-vc-modeline} into "Refresh Machinary"

Move the definitions of the functions `magit-revert-buffer' and
`magit-update-vc-modeline into the "Refresh Machinery" section.

Previously they were located in the "Refresh Buffer" section which also
contains (now only) `magit-refresh-buffer'.  All of these functions are
used to "do a refresh", the latter for Magit buffers and the moved
functions for file-visiting buffers.  I am consolidating the various
"Magit Mode" subsections and turning "Refresh Machinery" into a toplevel
section (see later commits).  While the new (just like the old) location
isn't perfect, it is an improvement, given the above objectives.

move definition of magit-map-magit-buffers

Move the definition of function `magit-map-magit-buffers' into a new
subsection of "Magit Mode", named "Mode Utilities".  That isn't optimal
because its the only function in that new section, but that might change
over time.  Randomly sticking it into one of the section that happens to
contain a function that uses it, is what we did before.

merge two subsections of toplevel "Magit Mode"

In preparation of future changes merge two subsections of toplevel
section "Magit Mode".  Keep the heading "Display Buffer" and dispose
of "Find Buffer".  The functions previously located below the latter
heading (`magit-find-{,status}-buffer') are not actually used by the
functions now located in the same section.  The "find" functions will
later be replaced by other functions, which will then be used by the
others.  Never-the-less the definitions the latter functions are the
ones that were moved because the new location makes more sense and
also allows splitting of another subsection into a new toplevel
section (see next commit).
Merge branch 'pr/cleaner-refs'

magit-delete-branch: don't prepend refs/heads when push deleting

In `magit-delete-branch' when deleting a remote branch by pushing
"nothing" to it do not prepend "refs/heads/".  That almost always
is the full name of what we want to delete, but it not necessary
to use the full name.  On the other hand pushing to the partial
symbolic name works even with non-standard remote.<remote>.fetch.

magit-wash-branch-line: don't use magit-branch-no-remote

Don't needlessly use `magit-branch-no-remote' in
`magit-wash-branch-line'.  Simply removing the
"remote/" prefix, if any, is good enough.

remove magit--is-branch-at-point-remote

Remove `magit--is-branch-at-point-remote'.  This function was still used
by `magit-change-what-branch-tracks' which due to this change no longer
performs the respective test.  That's okay, there are quite a few (more
important) things this function fails to do, and fixing that will be
easier if the function being removed here is not used (and no temporary
substitute is hacked in).

remove magit--branch-name-at-point

All of its former uses have been replaced with `magit-guess-branch'.

magit-change-what-branch-tracks: use magit-guess-branch

In `magit-change-what-branch-tracks' use `magit-guess-branch'
instead of the very limited `magit--branch-name-at-point'.

magit--is-branch-at-point-remote: use magit-guess-branch

In `magit--is-branch-at-point-remote' use `magit-guess-branch'
instead of the very limited `magit--branch-name-at-point'.
remove unused magit--branches-for-remote-repo

remove bogus \\ from some regexps

In regular expressions replace '\\/' with just '/'.
'/' isn't a special character, so quoting it does nothing.

magit-list-interesting-refs: support branch for UNINTERESTING

When argument UNINTERESTING is a string (instead of nil or a list of
regexps) then treat it as a branch name and arrange for it as well as
the defaults in `magit-uninteresting-refs' to be ignored.

The definition of `magit-uninteresting-refs' has to be moved to avoid
a compiler warning about it not being defined.

magit-list-interesting-refs: UNINTERESTING may no longer be a function

The UNINTERESTING argument of `magit-list-interesting-refs' now has to
be a list of regexps, or nil.  A function is no longer accepted.  That
was only used by one caller and that used it to filter out refs that it
should not have filtered out (fixed in previous commit).

Since this function will be removed soon anyway, don't just adjust the
doc-string, remove it instead.

magit-change-what-branch-tracks: don't omit local branches

When reading a branch to track in `magit-change-what-branch-tracks'
don't omit local branches from the list of completion candidates.
Tracking a local branch is totally okay and nothing special at all.

consistently append ": " to prompts

I don't particularly like that we are appending ": " to the prompt
strings passed to functions that read input from the minibuffer.

But since we are already doing it, we might as well do it consistently.
magit-read-tag: move definition
magit-read-remote-branch: cosmetics
magit-read-remote-branch: move PROMPT arg first and make mandatory

magit-read-remote: rename argument DEF to DEFAULT

Just like for virtually every other user input reader.

magit-read-remote: remove incorrect doc-string

The doc-string could have been fixed instead,
but that's not worth it at this point.

remove magit-commit-at-point

It is unused by now.

magit-read-rev-with-default: don't use magit-commit-at-point

In `magit-read-rev-with-default' don't use `magit-commit-at-point'.
Instead always use `magit-guess-branch', previously that was only
done if the former returned nil.  The effect of this is that instead
of a hash we now get something like BRANCH~, which is preferable for
all callers.

magit-create-branch: use magit-guess-branch

In `magit-create-branch use `magit-guess-branch' instead
of `magit-commit-at-point' to get the default branch for
completion, the former more often returns something.

magit-reflog: use magit-guess-branch

In `magit-reflog' use `magit-guess-branch' instead of
`magit-commit-at-point' to get the default branch for
completion, the former more often returns something.

magit-read-rev-with-default: fallback to "HEAD"

In `magit-read-rev-with-default' fallback to "HEAD" instead of the
previous branch when `magit-guess-branch' cannot find anything at
point.  That makes much more sense for all of its callers.

magit-default-rev: merge into magit-read-rev-with-default

Merge `magit-default-rev' into `magit-read-rev-with-default' which by
now was its only caller.

magit-bisect-start: use magit-guess-branch

In `magit-bisect-start` use `magit-guess-branch' instead of
`magit-default-rev' to get the default for completion of the
"good" revision.

magit-tag: use magit-guess-branch

In `magit-tag' use `magit-guess-branch' to determine the default offered
during completion of the ref/rev to be tagged.

Previously `magit-default-rev' was used but in many cases that ignored a
potential default.  Also the explicit fallback "HEAD" is now much more
likely to be used.  Previously the "previous branch" was used as
fallback (in `magit-default-rev') and that almost never is nil (and
makes much less sense).

magit-reset-head{,-hard}: use magit-guess-branch

In `magit-reset-head' and `magit-reset-head-hard' use
`magit-guess-branch' to determine the default branch for completion.

Previously `magit-default-rev' was used but in many cases that ignored a
potential default.  Also the explicit fallback "HEAD" (or "HEAD^") is
now much more likely to be used.  Previously the "previous branch" was
used as fallback (in `magit-default-rev') and that almost never is
nil (and makes much less sense).

magit-checkout: use magit-guess-branch

In `magit-checkout' use `magit-guess-branch', or if that returns nil
`magit-get-previous-branch' to determine the default branch.  Previously
`magit-default-rev' was used but in many cases that ignored a potential
default.

magit-guess-branch: don't fallback to magit-get-previous-branch

Instead do what the doc-string sais: return nil if the section context
at point does not suggest a branch.

This affects the following functions:

* In `magit-default-rev' explicitly fallback to
  `magit-get-previous-branch'.  We will deal with *its* callers
  separately.

* In `magit-merge' and `magit-delete-branch' explicitly fallback to
  `magit-get-previous-branch'.  It is probably rather common that one
  wants to merge or delete the previous branch.

* In `magit-interactive-rebase' *don't* exlicitly fallback.  This might
  be desirable sometimes, but rebasing to the previous branch is not
  how *interactive* rebase is most commonly used.

* In `magit-reflog' use "HEAD" as fallback.  That was already used as
  fallback there but was never used because of the less useful fallback
  `magit-guess-branch' provided until now.

magit-delete-branch: don't use magit-commit-at-point

Neither a hash nor something like BRANCH~ is a branch; therefor it
cannot be deleted as a branch.  After this change the user is no longer
offered to delete a hash "as a branch", BRANCH~ unfortunately might
still be suggested.

magit-default-rev: remove NO-TRIM argument

Remove `magit-default-rev's now unused NO-TRIM argument.
magit-delete-branch: don't use magit-default-rev

magit-read-rev-with-default: remove NO-TRIM argument

Remove `magit-read-rev-with-default's now unused NO-TRIM argument.
Also remove the doc-string, it would have to be reworded not only
to remove the note about NO-TRIM, and that's not worth it at this
point.

magit-delete-branch: use magit-read-rev

In `magit-delete-branch' use `magit-read-rev' instead of
`magit-read-rev-with-default', which will allow simplifying the latter.
magit-commit-at-point: use magit-section-case

magit-commit-at-point: ignore `revision' text property

In `magit-commit-at-point' if there is no appropriate section at point
do not also check for the `revision' text property.  We never set that
property.
magit-read-rev-with-default: remove unused UNINTERESTING argument

magit-rename-branch: don't assert magit-read-rev returns non-nil

Because we know it always does.
If it can't then it raises an error instead of returning.

magit-create-branch: don't assert magit-read-rev returns non-nil

Because we know it always does.
If it can't then it raises an error instead of returning.

magit-checkout: don't assert magit-read-rev returns non-nil

Because we know it always does.
If it can't then it raises an error instead of returning.

magit-merge-check-clean: merge into magit-merge

Merge `magit-merge-check-clean' into `magit-merge'.

Always perform the check, not only in the interactive case.
Previously that was done inside `interactive'.
Merge branch 'pr/refspace'

magit-refs-namespaces: improve rule for patches refs

Previously the label text for a ref "refs/patches/SOMETHING" was
"patches/SOMETHING".  We don't do that for any other ref namespace, and
I think this was only done this way because of limitations with the old
code and not because someone actually wanted the prefix to be displayed.
Regardless this makes this namespace consistent with the others, and if
someone wants to keep this prefix, or all prefixes, then she can
customize this option.
magit-refs-namespaces: add rule for git-wip refs
magit-refs-namespaces: make customizable

magit-format-ref-label: don't abuse it for filtering

The last few commits were already preparing for this; here we just make
it final: Do not abuse `magit-format-ref-label', which is supposed to
put nice colors on refs and possibly change their text for display, to
also _filter out_ certain refs.  Performing an additional, completely
unrelated task, made this function unreadable, and required the addition
of several functions and a hook variable.  Remove those that remained
until now.

There is a mechanism dedicated to the filtering of refs:
`magit-list-interesting-refs'.  (That also has issues but that is
a different story).

This isn't perfect yet.  E.g. the involved faces are still named
`magit-log-head-label-{*}'; which isn't good because this, now that
sanity has been restored, could be used elsewhere (but isn't yet).  Also
these faces don't have anything to do with the HEAD, so it makes little
sense that their names contain "-head-".

magit-wip-mode: remove mode

Remove `magit-wip-mode' which was used to give "refs/wip/BRANCH" a
special appearance and nothing else; and obviously only in buffers where
it was actually enabled.  Don't confuse it with `magit-wip-save-mode'.

This commit removes the special appearance temporarily, but in a few
commits that will be restored.  Unfortunately this use of the existing
"ref formatting" code prevents changes to that code, which forces us to
do it like this.

The special appearance won't be restored exactly as it is now: it will
drop the "(WIP) " prefix.  No other "labels" for other kinds of refs use
such a prefix, and it also isn't necessary, because we already use a
different face to give it distinct look.  Also in a few commits, the
ability for users to add such a prefix using the Custom interface will
be added for all ref namespaces, not just this particular one.  But we
won't use it for any refs by default.

There will also soon be a Custom option that allows hiding certain refs.

By removing this mode we lose the ability to only give "refs/wip/BRANCH"
a special appearance in certain buffers instead of all.  However it soon
will be possible again to give these refs the fallback appearance by
customizing an option.

I don't really think this is a loose at all: if such refs exist then
that most likely means that the user makes use of `magit-wip' and/or
`git wip'; and would like them to have a special appearance everywhere
or nowhere.  If he doesn't use these tools but uses the namespace for
some other reason and doesn't want them to look any different, then
again he can just customize the option.

If the user does use `*wip' in some repositories and wants them to have
a special appearance there, but also uses refs in the same namespace for
other purposes in other repositories, then he is doing it wrong and we
shouldn't keep the mode just so that he can keep on doing that.  Just
saying, I don't expect anyone actually does that.

magit-log-head-label-wip: define in magit.el

This prepares for the next commit.  After that the face might be used
even when `magit-wip.el' isn't loaded.
magit-wash-log-line: filter refs before colorizing them

magit-wash-log-line: don't filter tag refs

In `magit-wash-log-line' do not attempt to remove tags from the list of
refs to be displayed.  Previously this was done by filtering out "refs"
that begin with "tag:", which was wrong for two reasons: (a) there are
no such refs, and (b) we would not want to filter out tags, seeing them
in logs (and elsewhere) is kinda useful.

magit-format-ref: do not also filter

Previously `magit-format-ref' did return nil for refs other than
"refs/{head,remote,tag}/...".  Stop doing that, formatting should
not be overloaded to also filter.

As a result some refs are now displayed in logs, that previously were
not.  For some users this will be a regression, for others it will be a
welcome change.

Once `magit-uninteresting-refs' is an option, it will be easy for users
in the first group to, "fix" this change.
magit-format-ref: expect the REF argument to be non-nil

magit-format-ref: remove incorrect doc-string

The doc-string describes what this function should be doing, not what it
does.  We will fix that step by step, but since the last step will be
the removal of this function there is no point in repeatably changing
the doc-string.

magit-list-interesting-refs: never trim refs

Always return  ((NAME . FULL-REF)...)
instead of     ((NAME . FULL-OR-ABBREVIATED-REF)...).

Previously the cdr in all but one case was the full ref.  The exception
was the most common case when REF began with "refs/heads/", in which
case that part was removed from the ref.

The old behavior was not helpful.  Sure, the (now) only caller needs the
refs to be abbreviated when they are branches, but that isn't an inherent
requirement - on the contrary that caller also has issues.
magit-list-interesting-refs: allow filtering list of refs

magit-log-{remote-color-hook,get-remote-color}: remove

Now that `magit-wash-log-line' filters refs before colorizing them,
we no longer need to abuse _colorizing_ to also perform _filtering_.

So the `magit-log-remote-color-hook' variable as well as the wrapper
function `magit-log-get-remote-color' can be finished off.

magit-uninteresting-refs: always ignore topgit refs

Add the regexps that cause the topgit "top-base" refs to be ignored to
the definition of `magit-interesting-refs' instead of adding them only
when `magit-topgit-mode' is turned on.

I guess it could happen that someone does not use topgit and uses
"refs/top-bases" and "refs/remotes/REMOTE/top-bases" for something else,
but I think it that is rather unlikely.  If it does happen, that user
can just remove the respective regexps from the variable - which by the
way will get easier once it is a customizable option.

magit-uninteresting-refs: improve regexps

* Anchor all regexps.
* We are not interested in submatches.
* Put each regexp on its own line; this list will grow.

magit-{,key-mode-popup-}apply-mailbox: new key binding

In `magit-mode-map' bind "J" instead of "j" to
`magit-key-mode-popup-apply-mailbox' (or `magit-apply-mailbox' if
`magit-rigid-key-binding' is non-nil).  In the apply-mailbox popup
keymap bind "J" accordingly.

Merge branch 'pr/section-hooks'

magit-define-inserter: remove macro

Remove the macro `magit-define-inserter' which, until two commits ago,
had to be used to create functions that insert sections.  It now isn't
necessary anymore that each such function runs two hooks.
magit-topgit-mode: use magit-add-section-hook
magit-stgit-mode: use magit-add-section-hook
magit-svn-mode: use magit-add-section-hook

magit-add-section-hook: new function

Add hook-manipulation function `magit-add-section-hook'.  It differs
from other such functions in that it allows inserting a new function
before or after an existing member of the hook list.

The intended use of this function are "buffer section hooks".  All
"buffer refreshers" have been using a hook to insert sections, for a
while now.  These hooks work great for user customization, but until
now modes that that need to insert additional sections (and that only
for some repositories) the old hook implementation still had to be
used.

This commit completes the new implementation the missing piece, the
specialize `add-hook' function.  The next commit will start using that
in all minor modes.  And the one after that will remove the old one.

loading magit.el now calls git-commit-auto-mode-enable

Loading `magit.el' now calls `git-commit-auto-mode-enable', unless
library `magit-log-edit' is on the `load-path', in which case that
is loaded instead.

git-commit-auto-mode-enable: don't call on load and autoload

This is a somewhat controversial issue.  Some think that simply loading
or autoloading a library should prepare its modes for use.  Others like
me think that users should have to do that explicitly.  It might be a
bit annoying that an additional step is required to use the library and
its modes - it would be more annoying to have to do something *not* to
use it.

The argument "But why would they install it if they did not want to use
it?" does not apply it - Magit does force Melpa users to install it,
even though `magit-log-edit' could be used instead.  Magit has to ensure
one of the commit modes is installed and does so by making the preferred
one a dependency.  `package does not support optional dependencies or
even dependency alternatives.

git-commit-auto-mode-{enable,disable,regexps}: new fns, var

Add new functions `git-commit-auto-mode-enable'
and `git-commit-auto-mode-disable, and variable
`git-commit-auto-mode-regexps'.

add new git-commit-kill-buffer-noop to kill-buffer-query-functions

This is necessary to protect users from bypassing `git-commit-abort',
using something like `UNKNOWN-kill-buffer' or `M-x kill-buffer'.

We do not call `git-commit-abort' here because this special hook is
about aborting a kill, not about creative killing.  Since be now show
suitable about the key bindings, users will likely stop attempting to
kill using some non-standard way fairly quickly, or in case they use
some `UNKNOWN-kill-buffer' command, inform us about the issue.

remove server-kill-buffer from kill-buffer-hook

Remove `server-kill-buffer' from `kill-buffer-hook'.  Otherwise this
would prevent sending our improved abort messages to the clients.
remap {,ido-,ibuffer-}kill-buffer to git-commit-abort
remap server-edit to git-commit-commit

git-commit-mode: show better usage information

Show better usage information to the user; inform about "C-c C-c"
and "C-c C-k" instead of the generic "C-x #".  We have to use a
timer because the server displays its message after the mode has
already been enabled.

magit-describe-item: move definition

Move the definition of `magit-describe-item' to the new "Maintenance

Rename the subsection of "Acting" where `magit-describe-item' from, from

magit-insert-section: only show child count if heading ends in colon
Merge branch 'pr/count'

optionally append the number of children to section headings

Close #548.

delimit sections with markers

Store markers instead of positions in the BEGINNING and END slots of
section structs.  This makes it possible change text before a section
after it has been washed.  Once case in which this is useful is when
washing a section properly requires information that isn't available
until another section that textually comes later has been washed.

The BEGINNING marker is initially set to not advance when text is
inserted at the place it points to (or nothing would ever become part
of the section), but once washing is done it is changed to advance.

magit-diff: fix regression

Since 4bb6cb07b9dab950742f3edd7cfa38afe1721839 `magit-diff', when the
diff buffer already existed, did not use the current `default-directory'
but that of the buffer.  Now it resets the local value again.
Merge branch 'pr/git-am'

git-am action --- apply mbox from within magit

This patch defines the git-am action and the `magit-apply-mailbox'
function and binds them to "j".

The existing interactive rebase machinery is extended to handle "git am"
mailbox applications.  Git shares structure between "git rebase" and
"git am", (e.g., they both use the .git/rebase-apply directory) so this
is a natural extension.

magit-diff-with-mark: only one argument RANGE

Replace `magit-diff-with-mark's MARKED and COMMIT arguments with just
RANGE, making it consistent with other diff commands.  Keeping these
arguments for non-interactive use would not make sense since the marked
commit is determined inside `interactive'.  Except for that part it
behaves the same ad `magit-diff', the latter should therefor be used
non-interactively.

Teach `magit-read-file-from-rev' to offer

previous-sibling falls back to previous section

This makes `magit-goto-previous-sibling-section' symmetric with
`magit-goto-next-sibling-section'.

It was falling back to parent instead, which meant that
`magit-goto-previous-sibling-section' got "stuck" in the lines between
sections (they belong to top status section so there is no parent or
siblings).
remove unused variable
Merge branch 'pr/just-long'

magit-goto-section: don't start showing details in long log

When moving between commits in the log buffer the commit buffer is
automatically updated to show the commit at point.  If the commit buffer
is not already displayed in the current frame then it is automatically
made current in another frame.

Previously this was done for both oneline and long logs.  Now it is only
done for oneline logs, because otherwise there would be little reason to
use the long log.  Since all the information displayed in long log but
not in oneline log is also displayed in the commit buffer, long log
until now did just waste space.

Of course it is still possible to explicitly display the commit buffer.
And once it is the current buffer in a window of the selected frame it
is also automatically updated, just like for oneline log.
Merge branch 'pr/wash-diff-wash'
magit-diff-item-{kind,file,file2,range}: use nth instead of c{*}r

make the INFO slot of the diffstat section struct an atom

The INFO slot of diffstat section struct previously was a list whose car
was the filename and whose cdr was a bunch of irrelevant noise.  Remove
the noise, store just the filename, as an atom.
magit-wash-diffstat: colorize like git would
magit-wash-diffstat{,s}: switch textual position

magit-wash-diffstats: cleanup

Make `magit-wash-diffstats' half as long by not doing unnecessary stuff.
Because this includes not deleting and the reinserting a newline, and
`magit-wash-diff-section' is a bit stupid

magit-wash-diffstat: cleanup

In `magit-wash-diffstat' remove... noise,
including the unused optional GUESS argument.

magit-wash-diffstat: push section onto magit-diffstat-cached-sections

In `magit-wash-diffstat' use `push' to push the current section onto
`magit-diffstat-cached-sections'.  Previously `add-to-list' was used,
which is semantically wrong; we want to push every diffstat section.

magit-wash-diffstat: remove insufficient comment

Remove the comment "Don't decode pseudo filename." because it just
states what we (don't) do not why, and the why is to long for a comment
and also likely not what the initial reason was:

We not only don't decode the filename because it could be abbreviated
and that could cause problems, but because it is actually a good thing
to display the filename "as git would format it" somewhere.  That name
is only used for display, so that won't cause any problems when acting
on diffstat sections.

magit-wash-diffstat: don't store incomplete information

In `magit-wash-diffstat' do not store the possibly incomplete
filename (as well as some information related to it which is never
used), because it will be set to the complete information later on.

remove function magit-diffstat-item-file

Remove function `magit-diffstat-item-file' because it is no longer
necessary.  We already deal with `git CMD --stat' possibly printing
abbreviated filenames elsewhere.

merge magit-diffstats-ediff into magit-ediff

What we usually do when some command has to behave differently depending
on the type of the section at point, is to use `magit-section-action'.
Here we don't do that because it only has to behave differently on one
specific type, but conceptually we are doing the same.

Before this commit something completely different was done, resulting in
an unnecessary command `magit-diffstats-ediff', and an unnecessary keymap
`magit-diffstat-keymap' which was used as the keymap of a small portion
of the buffer (the diffstat).  We don't do that anywhere else, so stop
doing it here too.
magit-wash-diff-section: jump over initial whitespace

remove function magit-wash-other-file

Remove function `magit-wash-other-file' as it did not actually ever
get called.  It was used in `magit-wash-diffs', if `magit-wash-diff'
returned nil.  The latter could actually return nil but in practice
it never did (which means that this function also have to be cleaned
up).

make variable magit-show-diffstat an option

`magit-show-diffstat' used to be a regular variable,
it now is a customizable option.
add magit-jump-to-diffstats, replacing magit-goto-diffstats

magit-wash-diffstat{,s}: use a symbol as the section "title"

The TITLE slot of section structs is not actually the "title".  It's
just another slot like TYPE used to store what kind of section it is,
except when it isn't (e.g. because it is nil, which appears to mean
"don't highlight the section".  So this is a kludge and doesn't have
to (actually cannot possibly) make sense.

don't store face section in a diffstat struct a third time

It is a common issue that the type of a section is stored in the section
struct twice, in slot TITLE and TYPE.  Sometimes one is a string and the
other a symbol, but there is little consistency which of the two is what.
And then these slots are also used as magic switches for only slightly
related functionality.  That's all pretty bad in itself, but...

For diffstat sections this was taken a step further.  The symbol
`diffstat' was additionally also stored as the car of the INFO slot.
And there even was a dedicated function to retrieve that information,
but it was never used.  Remove that function and don't cons `diffstat'
onto INFO, its "not necessary".
Merge branch 'pr/tumor'

remove variable magit-current-range

Remove the variable `magit-current-range' which is only ever set but
whose value is never actually used.  Besides its value could also be
retrieved from `magit-refresh-args'.

remove function magit-rev-range-to-git

Remove the function `magit-rev-range-to-git'.  Since that was the last
member of the section titled "worrisome to-git converters", that heading
can be removed too.  The previous commits have demonstrated that these
functions were not necessary (nothing of value (as in: not harmful) was
actually lost by removing them) and their existence did not actually
reduce code size (they, combined with their use, increased it by 60
lines).

magit-refresh-log-buffer: use RANGE as argument to Git

`magit-refresh-log-buffer' now uses its own RANGE argument as an
argument to git.  `magit-log' and `magit-log-long' no longer cons
the range onto the `magit-refresh-log-buffer's ARGS argument.

remove function magit-rev-range-describe

Remove the function `magit-rev-range-describe', as the last two commits
have made it unnecessary.  This sucker probably was the starting point
of *a lot* of accidental complexity.  Finally it is gone.

magit-refresh-diff-buffer: stop using magit-rev-range-describe

In `magit-refresh-log-buffer' stop using `magit-rev-range-describe', by
replacing several design errors with temporary kludges.  The kludges are
necessary because the errors are not locally contained and over time
have propagated throughout `magit.el'.  One of the mistakes this commit
tries to address is that revision ranges are passed around as cons
cells, which is wrong for several reasons.

This changes the buffer headings for relative-to-worktree/range/stash
diffs from:

  Changes in RANDOM-NAME-FOR-REVISION
  Changes from RANDOM-NAME-FOR-REVISION-A to RANDOM-NAME-FOR-REVISION-B
  Changes from RANDOM-NAME-FOR-stash@{N}^2^ to stash@{N}

to

  Changes in REVISION-AS-GIVEN-BY-USER
  Changes in REVISION-A-AS-GIVEN-BY-USER..REVISION-B-AS-GIVEN-BY-USER
  Changes in stash@{N}^2^..stash@{N}

That's one small step backward for prettiness, one giant leap forward
for correctness.  Currently Magit cannot tell A..B and A...B apart,
this, and other changes, will eventually make fixing this possible.
And displaying SOME-REF-MATCHING-REV isn't helpful when the user
explicitly inserted something like "HEAD~5".  In case of stash diffs
the old pretty heading was just wrong and the new heading is very
ugly - ugly is better.

magit-refresh-log-buffer: stop using magit-rev-range-describe

In `magit-refresh-log-buffer' stop using `magit-rev-range-describe'.
Currently revision ranges are passed around as cons cells, which is
wrong for several reasons.  Because this commit is only one of the
steps required to undo that design error, it does contain a kludge.

This changes the buffer headings for ranged/other logs from:

  Commits in RANDOM-NAME-FOR-REVISION
  Commits from RANDOM-NAME-FOR-REVISION-A to RANDOM-NAME-FOR-REVISION-B

to

  Commits in REVISION-AS-GIVEN-BY-USER
  Commits in REVISION-A-AS-GIVEN-BY-USER..REVISION-B-AS-GIVEN-BY-USER

That's one small step backward for prettiness, one giant leap forward
for correctness.  Currently Magit cannot tell A..B and A...B apart,
this, and other changes, will eventually make fixing this possible.
And displaying SOME-REF-MATCHING-REV isn't helpful when the user
explicitly inserted something like "HEAD~5".

magit-refresh-log-buffer: don't treat --all-match like --all

`--all' means: Pretend as if all the refs in refs/ are listed on the
command line as <commit>.

`--all-grep' means: Limit the commits output to ones that match all
given --grep, instead of ones that match at least one.

One has nothing to do with the other.  In the latter case the commits
are still limited by some revision argument.

remove function magit-rev-describe

Remove function `magit-rev-describe' as it no longer does anything but
wrap around `magit-name-rev'.  It neither manipulated the input nor the
output.

remove function magit-rev-to-git

Remove function `magit-rev-to-git', because after the last two commits
it no longer did anything but return its only argument unchanged, just
like `identity'.

instantly convert "." to the value of magit-marked-commit

Until this commit `magit-rev-to-git' converted the string "." to the
value of `magit-marked-commit', and `magit-rev-describe' replaced it
with the string "mark".

There is only one place where such a "." string to represent
`magit-marked-commit' could come from: the user providing that string
when asked for a revision by `magit-read-rev'.  So instead of passing
that ominous value through many functions that have no understanding of
its meaning, instanly convert it to the value of `magit-marked-commit'.

The only (mis-)feature this loses is that `magit-rev-describe' now
inserts the actual rev or ref `magit-marked-commit' points to instead
of the, not so helpful, "mark" string.

magit-rev{,-range}-{to-git,describe}: don't raise an error if REV is nil

The helpers `magit-rev-to-git', `magit-rev-range-to-git',
`magit-rev-describe', and `magit-rev-range-describe' should not check
whether the REV or RANGE argument passed to them is nil and in that case
raise an error.  The REV or RANGE being nil is an error that should be
caught way before it reaches this function.  In fact I believe that this
error handling was added here because in the past `magit-read-rev' and
`magit-read-rev-range' did not raise an error on empty input.  The
latter is fixed now, so this kludge can be removed.
Merge branch 'pr/wash-log-wash'

magit-wash-log-line: make complete entry part of section

Function `magit-wash-log-line' turns each line that actually represents
a log entry into a section.  (It does not do so for graph-only lines).

When washing "oneline" logs that works find, but a "long" log entry
actually consists of all lines up to the next entry.  This commit
teaches `magit-wash-log-line' how to make the complete entry part of
the section.

magit-wash-log-line: for longline, show full hash, if there is room

When washing a "long" log `magit-wash-log-line' now inserts the full
hash, iff there is enough room, that is when there are no refs that
point to the commit.

magit-wash-log-line: for longline, put hash behind graph

Function `magit-wash-log-line' used to put the commit hash before the
graph for all log styles.  In case of the "long" log this just wasted
space.  So now the graph comes first for that style.
magit-log-{oneline,longline,cherry,reflog}-re: cosmetics

add macro magit-bind-match-strings

Why can't something like `bind-match-strings' just be part of Emacs?
Even just `match-strings' (plural) would be great.  Hell, even making
`match-limit' available in lisp would be of some help.  Instead we all
have to bang on `match-data' or manually construct `let's VARLIST by
hand.  Not anymore, at least not in Magit.

explicitly number submatches in log-line regexps

In `magit-log-{oneline,longline,unique,reflog}-re' number the submatches
explicitly.  The subexpressions/parts common to more styles get a lower
number than those only relevant to one or two styles.

Then take the dance bear out of `magit-wash-log-line'.
magit-wash-log-line: rename internal variable from sha1 to hash

magit-wash-log-line: absorb magit-{parse,format}-log-line

Merge `magit-format-log-line' and `magit-parse-log-line' into
`magit-wash-log-line'.  `parse' was only used by `format', which in turn
was only used by `wash'.  Splitting the various subtasks into separate
functions did only complicate things.

In the process remove the `magit-log-line' struct which was only ever
used to pass an ordered collection of values from `parse' to `format'.
That was quite silly in itself, a simple would have been equally
powerful and much more compact.  This is just the tip of the iceberg.

magit-wash-log-line: no need to assert line is non-nil

`magit-parse-log-line' always returns a `magit-log-line' struct - never
nil.  Therefor in `magit-wash-log-line' (its only caller) do not assert
this is indeed so - we know it is.  This change is about not misleading
the reader.

magit-parse-log-line: stop misleading the reader

`magit-wash-log-line' is called repeatedly by `magit-wash-sequence'
until the latter returns nil or the end of the buffer or narrowed part
is reached.

`magit-wash-log-line' never returns nil, the explicit `t' at its end
makes sure of that.  And even without that it would never return nil.

So the reason `magit-wash-sequence' ever stops calling the washer is
that the end of the buffer or narrowed part is reached.  In practice
that means that all callers of `magit-wash-log' have to narrow to the
relevant portion before initiating the washing.

In other words `magit-parse-log-line' only ever gets to see lines that
are actual log lines.  It is therefor misleading that its body is
wrapped in a `when' form.
reverse order in which log-washing functions are defined

remove magit-{ref-nonslash-re,ref-nonchars,refname-re}

Remove the constant regexp variables `magit-ref-nonslash-re',
`magit-ref-nonchars', and `magit-refname-re'.  They were only used as
part of the constant values of the variables `magit-log-oneline-re' and
`magit-log-long-re' regexp constants.

The substrings these partial regexps were matched against either did not
exist at all, or they were guaranteed to contain only refs.  So there
really is no good reason to assert that the substrings consists of refs;
we know they always do.

magit-log-longline-re: deal with three kinds of lines

There are up to three kinds of "log lines" that the `magit-log-{*}-re'
functions have to match.

* "actual log"   appearing in   long, oneline, others
* "graph-only"   appearing in   long, oneline
* "details"      appearing in   long

That might not be such a good idea - it certainly complicates writing
the regexps.  For now just make the regexps fully aware of that fact.

For "long log" that means that a line either contains a hash (and
possibly refs) **or** it has "something else".  For other log types that
would be the "message", but for "long log" that does not make much sense
- it is better to think of it as "the rest" after the (optional) graph.

In order not to complicate things we keep pretending this is "the
message" but we adjust the regexp to reflect the distinction.  By doing
so we prepare it for future changes.

magit-log-longline-re: make definition more compact

As of now it probably looks like this is *too* compact - but
it will get better.
magit-log-{one,long}line-re: improve graph matching

magit-log-oneline-re: merge the optional shy groups

In `magit-log-oneline-re' merge the optional shy groups.  The parts they
match only appear in combination (on an actual log line) or none of them
do (on a graph-only line).
magit-log-oneline-re: improve matching that extra space

magit-log-{one,long}line-re: put "refs" pattern on single line

This results in a long line, which is okay because that will be
fixed in a subsequent commit.
magit-log-{one,long}line-re: re-indent
remove constant magit-log-format
remove function magit-log-cutoff-length-arg

Merge branch 'pr/bold-highlight'

add option magit-item-highlight-face

Add option `magit-item-highlight-face' to once and for all satisfy all
users, hopefully.  Actually, that is not possible; so what this actually
does, is to allow users to customize the appearance of the highlighting
without imposing any limitations.

The previous attempt implemented in at least the commits 66a0644,
d14a3f9 (with discussion), and d14a3f9; and discussed in the issues #743
and #865 failed.  They fixed it for some users and in turn broke it for
others.  The primary goal of this change is to help users help
themselves, in case they don't like the defaults.

The new option `magit-item-highlight-face' is necessary because face
inheritance has serious limitations when a theme is used.  It is not
possible for the user to "unset" a face attribute that was previously
set by the theme.  All that is possible is to *change* it to some other
value.  "Make unset" isn't available as a value.

This option also makes it possible to automatically set the default of
option `magit-diff-use-overlays' to nil in *one particular* case: when
`magit-item-highlight-face's value is `bold'.  (We previously tried
something similar, but that failed because of another limitation of
faces, :set-after only works for options, not faces).

This commit also changes the appearance of some faces, which might
disappoint some users.  There simply isn't anything we can do to make
this look good out of the box for everyone.  Unfortunately for some
people that will mean that we have switched from a default that worked
for them to one that doesn't.  I hope that, when pointed to this
message, it becomes obvious, that it isn't as easy as one might have
thought, and that we had to make compromises.

The following considerations went into choosing the colors used for
various themes:

* Being at least _usable_ in (hopefully) all cases is more important
  than being _pretty_ in most cases.  We are not in the business of
  designing consistent color themes.

* Inherit from default faces, hoping that doing so, results in
  consistent, semantically sound, and possibly even pretty colors.
  If that is not so that is the mistake of the theme authors.

* The colors red and green, in all its variations, have to be avoided
  because those colors are also used to indicate removed and added lines
  in diffs.

* Therefore inherit from default faces that, in the default theme (both
  the dark and light variant), don't use such colors.  Of course some
  third-party theme might have changed these faces to use red or green;
  we simply cannot do anything about that.

* The faces we inherit from also have to be semantically close to
  "highlight".  Which gives us `highlight', `region', and
  `secondary-selection'.

* `region' cannot be used because it is also used for... the region,
  which is useful when staging just a portion of a hunk, precisely *the
  region*.

* `highlight' cannot be used because it is green.

* `secondary-selection' and only that remains.  Use it.  It might not
  be pretty even when using the default theme, but if it is good enough
  for the designers of the default theme then it is good enough for us.
  Besides we don't have another option.

So make `magit-item-highlight' inherit from `secondary-selection' and
make `magit-item-mark' (which previously inherited from the former)
inherit from `highlight'.  It's okay for `magit-item-mark' to be green;
only commits can be marked, and commits don't appear next to added (or
removed, or unmodified) lines.

Merge branch 'pr/window-point'

magit-refresh-buffer: also restore the window-start

This fixes the issue of which #978 is a special case.

magit-refresh-buffer: remove bogus entry from window-buffer

In `magit-refresh-buffer' remove bogus entry from the list returned by
function `window-buffer', which effectively did throw away all the work
done further up in this function.

In most cases this did not happen because there was no such bogus entry
in `window-buffer'.  However when a command did move to some other
buffer and did only then refresh the buffer we ended up with such an
entry.  The entry is created when switching away from the buffer.
Refreshing is done by first erasing the buffer and then rebuilding it
from scratch.  Erasing the buffer causes the markers in the entry to
become invalid and since we have already switched away from the buffer
earlier then rebuilding the buffer contents neither creates a new entry
nor updates the markers in the existing entry.

This fixes issue #687.

magit-refresh-buffer: actually sync point in other windows

`magit-refresh-buffer' did already attempt to update the "window local"
point in other windows showing the same buffer.  However it failed to
request all such windows from `get-buffer-window-list'; it only
requested windows of the current frame, which in most cases equals to
the selected window.  Now we process windows from all frames.

This fixes the special case mentioned by me in issue #687.  At least
in most cases, that is when this function is *actually* called.

magit-refresh-buffer: update commit marker later

In `magit-refresh-buffer' call `magit-refresh-marked-commits-in buffer'
right after `magit-highlight-section'.  Therefor call it becomes the
very last step of refreshing; however the real point is not to do it
in between some unrelated steps (which are related to each other, just
not the commit marker).
magit-refresh-buffer: reduce nesting

magit-refresh-buffer: make sure BUFFER is non-nil

In `magit-refresh-buffer' make sure BUFFER is non-nil, instead of
using `current-buffer' instead of BUFFER.  This makes using that
buffer nicer than just passing BUFFER or else `current-buffer' to
`with-current-buffer'.

tell newcomment.el # is only comment at line start

Otherwise we get things like this:

A typical commit message referencing issue #xxx that is long enough to
                                           #need filling,

This is not related to fontifying of comments which already applies only
to lines beginning with #. It's also not related to the syntax-table;
middle of line #s still have comment syntax, but apparently this has no
effect.

Fixes #67.

`git-commit-save-message': only save commit msg if it's unique

Avoid filling up `log-edit-comment-ring' with duplicate commit messages
(and potentially clobbering useful history in the process) when cycling
through it using `git-commit-{prev,next}-message'.

Signed-off-by: Pieter Praet <pieter@praet.org>

`git-commit-save-message': only save commit msg if it contains actual text

Avoid filling up `log-edit-comment-ring' with empty commit messages
by checking whether the commit message contains any actual text
(i.e. word chars that aren't part of a comment) before saving it.

Signed-off-by: Pieter Praet <pieter@praet.org>

magit-revert-buffer: change order of two conditions

The conditions whose positions are switched are both rather cheap.

magit-revert-buffer: remove incomplete comment

Remove half truth about why we are not reverting an indirect buffer.

Merge branch 'pr/wazzup'

magit-insert-wazzup-commits: use cherry instead of regular log

Use `git cherry' instead of `git log'.
magit-wazzup: with prefix argument allow selecting another rev

reimplement wazzup from scratch

The old implementation was problematic because it did not use the
existing abstractions used elsewhere and because was very slow (521).
Because of the former issue it was needlessly complicated, while also
lacking features.  And in order to address the latter two different ways
of limiting what branches are displayed were added, again making it more
complex than it needs to be.

Additionally one of these filter mechanisms required that the user
individually marked branches he did not want to be shown.  Because doing
so results in a refresh of the complete buffer this effectively meant
that he, in order to eventually get a speedup, had to repeat the action
which he wants to speedup - several times, adding insult to injury.

This implementation takes a different approach.  Like this is also done
for diff hunks but until now nowhere else, it does not merely hide the
body of collapsed sections, it does not even calculate the commits until
they are actually being displayed.

Unfortunately the section framework has several shortcomings which
result in a lot of complexity in `magit-insert-wazzup-commits'.  In
theory this function could be almost as simple as, lets say,
`magit-insert-unpulled-commits', but as of now it consists of a
collection of kludges.  Fixing the section api to make this unnecessary
is a difficult task and requires changes throughout Magit.  So that will
have to wait until another day.

Because wazzup is much faster now this does not add a new and better
exclude mechanism.  Instead the old mechanisms are dropped without a
replacement.  This can still problematic when a user expands all
sections (e.g. using M-2) but he doing so does not make much sense -
especially not when there are many branches.
fix typo in comment

add preliminary implementation of magit-format-ref-label

Add a preliminary implementation of function `magit-format-ref-label'
which returns a list whose only element is a propertized ref label; or
nil.  It should actually return just the propertized label; always.

This function is a wrapper around `magit-ref-get-label-color' and
lessens the pain of using that somewhat.  However it also inherits some
of the limitations, including but not limited to, the above.  The
biggest problem is does both filtering and formatting.  Actually fixing
this and other issues would require some refactoring.  I am adding this
kludge instead so that I can land some other things first, that have
been on the waiting list for to long already.

git-rebase-mode : Fix auto-mode-alist

 Add an end-of-string (\') marker to avoid spurious matches
Merge branch 'pr/cherry'

add faces magit-cherry-{equivalent,unmatched}

Add the faces `magit-cherry-equivalent' and `magit-cherry-unmatched',
defining them from scratch.  Do not inherit from `magit-diff-{add,del}.
These faces are added exactly because they should not both look the same
as the diff face the corresponds to the same symbol `+' or `-'.  The +┌-
distinction for diffs is distinct from the +┌- distinction for cherries.

Use boring foreground colors that are likely to work with both light and
dark themes.  Do not set the background because that would be overridden
by section highlighting.

magit-cherry: change argument order

Switch the position of `magit-cherry's UPSTREAM and HEAD arguments.
In interactive use it makes more sense to read the HEAD first, because
that allows defaulting to the tracked branch when later reading UPSTREAM.
Do not just change the order of reading, actually change the order of the
arguments so that interactive and non-interactive use is consistent.

However do not change the order accordingly for function
`magit-refresh-cherry-buffer' and in the value of variable
`magit-refresh-args'.  Here we should instead be consistent with `git
cherry'.  Also changing the order here would complicate matters.

Don't refuse to run when HEAD (the actual git HEAD, not the argument) is
detached.  It is possible to select any rev not just refs as the cherry
head.  And why refuse to run with a detached HEAD if the user is
actually about to select some ref?

add magit-insert-{unpulled,unpushed}-cherries

Add `magit-insert-{unpulled,unpushed}-cherries', intended for use in the
status buffer.  They are more informative (but much slower) variants of
`magit-insert-{unpulled,unpushed}-commits'.  Because of the speed issue
don't use them by default and don't even advertise them.

Speedup will come later (most likely by caching cherries in elisp,
instead of using `git cherry').

magit-wash-log: when washing cherry output, reverse it first

When `magit-wash-log' washes `git cherry' output it now starts washing
by reversing the git command's output.  This makes the order of cherries
consistent with the order of unpushed/unpulled commits as displayed in
the status buffer.

The order of commits in such "preview" commit lists should probably be
customizable; for now we just make it consistent.

use existing abstractions to implement cherry

Remove `magit--refresh-cherry-buffer' which reimplemented functionality
already available elsewhere.  `git cherry' can be seen as a `git log'
with less options but an additional twist.  Teach `magit-format-log-line'
and `magit-parse-log-line' the new `cherry' style.  Define the format in
`magit-log-cherry-re'.

Define a washer `magit-insert-cherry-commits' that works like other "log"
washers in that in only washes the list of commits.  Add inserters that
insert header line sections, and add `magit-cherry-insert-sections-hook'
to allow reordering.  This can also be used remove the help text, we
display by default because the old implementation did it too.

Always make the help text less verbose.  Don't add spaces around the
cherry type indicator (+ or -), because that only looked good if the
faces used to display them did set the background color.

Note that "Head" means something else in the cherry buffer than the
status buffer.  This ambiguity is inherited from Git, but we might be
able to do something about it later.  The "Upstream" header still has
to be improved.  I had intended to use `magit-format-tracked-line' for
that purpose but that isn't able to deal with the ambiguity of user
input.  And since that is an issue that also effects other areas I'll
leave it at that for now, and don't attempt to prettify the upstream.

merge file magit-cherry.el into magit.el

Define the cherry functionality previously defined in the separate file
`magit-cherry.el' in `magit.el'.  The complexity and code size are both
to low to justify having a separate file.  This will also make it easier
to use "cherry" in other parts of Magit.

magit-file-log: with a prefix argument pass --graph to `git log'

Even before this commit showing the graph was possible but only when it
was invoked from the logging popup.  Now this is also possible when the
command is directly invoked.

magit-file-log: use magit-refresh-log-buffer

In `magit-file-log' use the generic `magit-refresh-log-buffer'
(and pass it `magit-custom-options'), instead of the inferior
`magit-refresh-file-log-buffer'.  The latter was an incomplete
reimplementation of the former "specialized" for "file logs".
In the previous commit we taught the latter the FILE argument;
nothing else was necessary to make it suitable for "file logs".

magit-refresh-log-buffer: add optional FILE argument

Add the optional FILE argument, set buffer-local `magit-file-log-file'
accordingly, extend the heading handling to deal with non-nil FILE, and
pass the non-nil FILE to `git log'.

magit-refresh-log-buffer: change argument order

Change the order of arguments to `magit-refresh-log-buffer' so that the
argument for the washer isn't located in between arguments to `git log'.

magit-file-log: require confirmation to use default file

Previously, when `magit-file-log' was invoked from a file-visiting
buffer, a prefix argument had to be used to select another file.  Now
the current file is merely the default, which the user can confirm by
simply pressing RET.  This is good for two reasons: it is similar to
how other commands (e.g. `kill-buffer') handle this, and the behavior
no longer depends on what kind of buffer is current when the command
is invoked.
magit-file-log: read the file inside interactive

magit-file-log: remove unused optional ALL argument

With a prefix argument the ALL argument was set to the value of
`current-prefix-arg'.  But it wasn't used anywhere in the function
body so it was effectively unused.  Remove the ALL argument and
ignore the prefix argument.

remove function magit-apply-hunk-item-reverse

Remove function `magit-apply-hunk-item-reverse', instead directly use

better because one instantly knows that apply a hunk in reverse is not

Merge branch 'pr/no-trim'

make variable magit-hide-diffs unnecessary

Variable `magit-hide-diffs' was used to let-bind
`magit-section-hidden-default' at the appropriate time, which is right
before ("around") creating the section whose subsections should be
hidden.

The latter variable also shouldn't exist.  While that is a different
issue, it is actually related: This commit is the first step required
to eventually remove the latter.

`magit-hide-diffs' was used to explicitly tell the code used to insert
the diff-containing sections, whether that section should be hidden.

However passing this information explicitly is not necessary because we
have implicit knowledge of then it should be hidden: when the section is
only one among other "top" sections.  Or in other words when the mode
isn't `magit-log-mode' or `magit-commit-mode'.

In `magit-wash-raw-diff' we can unconditionally hide the section,
because it is only ever used to insert sections that should be hidden.

rename magit-apply-hunk-item* to magit-apply-hunk-item

Rename `magit-apply-hunk-item*' to `magit-apply-hunk-item' and remove
the function previously named `magit-apply-hunk-item'.  The removed
function was just a very thin wrapper around the function it is being
"replaced" with.  Due to the change in the previous commit it is no

Remove `magit-apply-hunk-item*'s REVERSE argument.  One of its callers

remove magit-indentation-level

The default value was 1, the dynamically bound value always was 2; so we
might as well make it static.  However the correct value would actually
be 1 not 2.

Why didn't we notice so far? `magit-wash-typechange-section' is dead
code by now, it is never actually called.  (This has to be fixed and
is a likely cause of issue #224.)

make variable magit-ignore-unmerged-raw-diffs unnecessary

Instead of let binding `magit-ignore-unmerged-raw-diffs' inside
`magit-staged-changes' call `magit-wash-raw-diffs' with its new STAGED
argument, which is then passed on to `magit-wash-raw-diff' which happens
to be the only place where this information is relevant.  (And
`magit-staged-changes' is the only case where we have to toggle this
switch; hence the argument name "STAGED".

make variable magit-last-raw-diff unnecessary

Remove the variable `magit-last-raw-diff'.  It was let-bound inside
`magit-wash-raw-diffs' so that one call to `magit-wash-raw-diff' could
"pass" it to the next call.  We can get the same effect by having the
latter return the current file and receive the previous file as an
actual argument.
magit-wash-raw-diff: use `1+'

merge magit-wash-diff-or-other-file into its only caller

Merge `magit-wash-diff-or-other-file' into its only caller
`magit-wash-diffs', both of which are very simple - no need
to split that any further.

magit-wash-diff-section: replace a use of let* with let

In `magit-wash-diff-section' replace one unnecessary use of `let*' with
`let'.  This avoids confusion in the future about why `let*' was used in
the first place.  To keep the diff small replace "*" with a space,
instead of removing it.  This avoids having to reindent the whole thing,
resulting in a rather larger diff, for no good reason.
remove unused magit-diffstat-item-status

magit-wash-diffstat: remove comment and commented code

The comment was added in commit 293a7804b1b0b15614c0e4c826f9e70059e872ff
the commented code consists of the "removed" code and, so it seems, some
leftover experimental code.

The comment would have made a fairly good commit message, but as a
comment it does not fly with me.  Leaving the old code in the file but
comment it...

magit-wash-raw-diff: basic support for all diff states

If a state is encountered that is even more unknown than
`git diff's "unknown" (X) state then raise an error.

remove unnecessary function magit-hunk-item-diff

The parent section of a `hunk' is always a `diff'.  Function
`magit-hunk-item-diff' is therefor unnecessary.  All it did was assert
that this is indeed the case.  By removing this assert we only risk that
a user reports a harder to diagnose error message, but if that ever
happens it should be doable.  Besides I cannot remember that there ever
was a report Magit complained "Huh?  Parent of hunk not a diff".
add magit-section-content-beginning

`magit-process-keep-history': optionally don't clear the process buffer

Most calls to `magit-run*' don't set its NOERASE arg to a non-nil value,
so the process buffer is cleared pretty much every time we run a command
that makes use of `magit-run*'.

However, sometimes it's useful to be able to refer back to the log
of recent Git commands (and their output), e.g. when cleaning up stale
remote-tracking branches after having fetched with the "--prune" flag.

Now we can prevent the process buffer from ever being cleared by setting
`magit-process-keep-history' to a non-nil value. To improve readability,
individual command invocations will be delimited with an empty line.

move definition of magit-hunk-item-target-line

Move the definition of function `magit-hunk-item-target-line' below
its only caller `magit-visit-file-item'.

Previously it was define in the "Diffs and Hunks" section, but since
that is about washing and this function has nothing to do with that
defining it there was not correct.

move magit-section pseudo getters into the struct section

When a `magit-section' struct represents a `diff' or `diffstat' section
more information has to be stored inside the struct than for other
section types.  Currently this is done by storing a list in the `info'
slot.

They right way to implement this would be to add additional slots to
the `magit-section' struct and just not use them for the other types,
that don't need them.

But because the `info' slot is used to uniquely identify specific
section this is not currently possible.  Doing so would require complex
refactoring elsewhere. I have already attempted to do so, it requires
changes all over the place.

Instead, for now, move the `diff` and `diffstat` specific pseudo slot
getters below the definition of the struct.

don't require saveplace

If the user hasn't setup saveplace in their config, requiring saveplace
causes them to get a useless .emacs-places in the home directory. To
avoid triggering a compilation warning, we check if `save-place' is
bound.

f5b36db4 had changed from calling `toggle-save-place' to setting
`save-place' but still checked if `toggle-save-place' was fbound,
830b538b then required saveplace to quiet the compiler.

magit-with-emacsclient: wait longer before resetting server-window

deal with strange location of emacsclient on OS X

On OS X applications are often installed in strange "executable
directories".  The Finder presents these directories as actual
applications to the user who might be blissfully unaware that
clicking on it actually executes a binary inside the directory.

So they have been happily clicking on a flashy image to start
Emacs and we come along requiring emacsclient being on $PATH.

But it gets worse.  The emacsclient executable might not even be
located in the same subdirectory of the application directory:

  /Applications/Emacs.app/Contents/MacOS/emacs
  /Applications/Emacs.app/Contents/MacOS/bin/emacsclient

So we have to look for the emacsclient here too:

  (expand-file-name "bin" invocation-directory)

Also see:

  https://github.com/magit/magit/issues/862#issuecomment-24784266

  "Make that lazy ass lisp reader do some work."

magit-blame-{prev,next}-chunk

Always move to the previous/next chunk from *point*.  Previously that
was done interactively but non-interactively the POS argument had to
be provided.  Which is wrong for two reasons:  we did not use it
non-interactively, so even if this was a good idea in the first place
it would be of no use.  And then there is no reason for a movement
command to be have "move to next thing from point, except when I tell
you to move from somewhere else".  If one wants that - especially in
non-interactive use, one can just go to that other place *before*
going to the next thing,

`magit-insert-svn-{unpulled,unpushed}': pass STYLE arg to `magit-wash-log'

Commit 4966a044 altered `magit-parse-log-line' to no longer set STYLE
if it was nil, because `magit-wash-log' is now supposed to always pass
it an appropriate value (via `magit-wash-log-line').

`magit-insert-svn-{unpulled,unpushed}' weren't updated accordingly though,
causing `magit-svn-mode` to fail with `wrong-number-of-arguments` when
there are unpulled/unpushed commits.

Fixes #925.

Signed-off-by: Pieter Praet <pieter@praet.org>

`magit-insert-status-remote-line': define using `magit-define-inserter'

Among other things, commit f6506846 renamed `magit-svn-remote-string'
to `magit-svn-insert-status-remote-line', and added it to
`magit-after-insert-remote-line-hook', intending for it to run after
`magit-insert-status-remote-line'.

However, this could never work, since `magit-insert-status-remote-line'
wasn't defined using `magit-define-inserter' meaning the hook wouldn't exist,
and even if did, it would be called `magit-after-insert-STATUS-remote-line-hook'.

As a result, `magit-svn-mode` no longer displayed the "Remote:" line.

I would have liked to drop the "status" part in `magit-insert-status-remote-line'
(see commit 44abd449), but then I'd have to satisfy my urge to make the same
change(s) in *all* the inserter functions, thereby tainting this branch with
commits that don't belong, so I've opted to adjust `magit-svn-mode' instead.

Choices, choices...

Fixes #924.

Signed-off-by: Pieter Praet <pieter@praet.org>

move `magit-ref-get-label-color' into new "Reference Labels" section

Move the `magit-ref-get-label-color' function and all support functions
and variables into the new "Reference Labels" subsection of "Revision
and Ranges" (which is also, or mainly about References, but that's a
different story).

The support symbol names of support functions and variables sport the

is *currently* only used for logs.  However "colorizing a reference
according to its type" is also needed elsewhere.  Currently these other
places use different less flexible implementations, but that should be
changed.  So move as a first step toward using this (or rather a
generalized variant thereof) move it to a "common" place.

Also move the `magit-log-format-reflog' into the "Reflog Mode" section;
*not* to the same place as `magit-ref-get-label-color'!  These functions
do something similar and are both used by `magit-format-log-line' but
they actually are quiet different.

`magit-log-format-reflog' is about colorizing the "actions" in reflogs,
not about doing that to references, so it does not belong near code that
deals with references.  It could be left were it was previously defined,
since that is also where the only call to it is located (inside
`magit-format-log-line').  However because it is strictly only related
to reflogs the respective section is the perfect place.

Merge branch 'modes'

Conflicts:
	magit-flow.el

add missing magit-{*}-buffer-name variables, change doc-strings

Add the missing `magit-{*}-buffer-name' variables so that such a
variable exists for each Magit mode.  Two such variables have to
be declared to suppress compile warnings, so be it.

Also add doc-strings to existing variables that lack it and give
all such doc-strings the same form.

Also rename `magit{--cherry => -cherry}-buffer-name'.

give mode section a common order

Use the same definition order for all sections in `magit.el' that
contain the definition of a Magit major mode, its refresh function, and
the related entry command(s); and then possibly other things.

  This is something I wanted to do for a long time.  I didn't do so
  because it makes inspecting history more difficult.  But considering
  how much grief the disorder has caused me, messing with the history is
  the lesser evil.

  Also note that I am not switching from one common order to another.
  It appears that there was a common order at some point (which is about
  the opposite of what I am now doing).  But over time that order was
  lost because inconsistent additions were made to the various mode
  sections, effectively destroying the similarity and in some cases also
  making the section very disorganized even when looked at in isolation.

The new prototypical order is this:

1. `magit-*-mode'
2. `magit-*-buffer-name'
3. `magit-INVOCE-*' -- Creates a buffer named (2), puts it in (1) mode
   and refreshes with (4).
4. `magit-refresh-*-buffer'

See the "Diff Mode" section for the prototypical example.

  This does not only benefit my own ocd.  The new order also makes it
  easier for readers new to the source.  The doc-string of the mode
  servers as a short summary.  The "invocation" commands come next,
  because the have (should have) a useful doc-string, are usually short,
  and the "refresher" that follows is often long and not of interest to
  the casual reader.

The lack of a common order didn't just make it harder to read the mode
sections it also lead to inconsistencies.  Some of these could have
prevented with a common order, others probably not.

Also not all of the remaining inconsistencies are actually bad.  Some
are just due to differences in the complexity of these modes.

The implementation of support functionality like washing differ in
complexity between modes and/or are shared between modes.  Depending on
this some of implementation details might be defined in independent
and/or shared sections elsewhere in the file.  In some cases this should
be corrected but that's a different issue.

What is important is that at least the parts that exist for each mode
share the same definition, so that the remaining differences do not
cause to much confusion.

Some mode sections also lexically contain:

0. Additional variables that have to be defined early.
   Many of these variables should be abstracted away.
5. Section inserters used in (4).
6. Washers used in (5).
7. Wacky stuff that needs to be cleaned and generalized because
   it can also be used elsewhere.

Some mode section are now split (or were already split) into
preliminary/temporary sub-sections.  These subsection will likely
disappear after some cleanup.  If they do not they will get better
headings.  I also added some TODO markers which should also be gone
soon.

create "Stash Mode" section

Previously everything related to stashes was defined in
"Acting"/"Stashing".  Everything related to a "command"/"topic"
is not actually a bad idea, but it is not how it is done for
anything else in Magit.  So let us not do it here either.
use define-derived-mode to define magit-mode

improve doc-strings and definitions of modes and mode maps

* Explicitly define all Magit mode keymaps, even when those that do not
  have any special bindings by default (`magit-stash-mode-map',
  `magit-reflog-mode-map', `magit-diff-mode-map').

* Set the parent keymap explicitly in each mode keymap definition,
  instead of relying on `define-derived-mode' doing it for as (at a less
  than perfect time).

* Add doc-string to all mode keymaps.  Except for `magit-mode-map' use
  what would have been generated by `define-derived-mode'.

* For all modes, add a link to the parent of the modes keymap in the
  mode function doc-string.  Wrap it in a sentence similar to that about
  the parent mode and its which is automatically appended.

* Beyond the above also give the mode doc-strings a uniform form by.
  That form isn't perfect but at least we now have a reasonable summary
  in all mode doc-strings.

* Change the doc-string summary of `magit-mode' to explain that it is
  the parent mode of other Magit modes (which also implies it isn't
  intended for direct use, like `special-mode').

Merge pull request #917 from praet/interactive-resolve

`magit-interactive-resolve`: use `magit-git-lines'

`magit-interactive-resolve`: use `magit-git-lines'

Since commit f8d304a1, `magit-git-string` *actually* returns only the
first line of `git(1)`s output, causing `magit-interactive-resolve` to
fail because it now only gets the first of the three mode/SHA1 pairs it
needs to populate the `{base,our,their}-buffer's.

Instead of re-introducing something like `magit-git-output', which should
also sanitize the output (e.g. trailing newlines), use `magit-git-lines'.

Fixes #916.

definitions as well as compatibility checks for older versions of Git.
Now that we have only very simple backward definitions and all checks
for older versions of Git have been removed this is no longer necessary.

Also in the future we should avoid backporting definitions from newer
Emacsen and more aggressively require recent Git versions.  But if
we *have to* backport some huge functions then we might have to recreate
`magit-compat.el'.  Don't worry, I will do it.  And writing this message
was likely more work than doing that anyway.
