`magit-status-insert-tags-line': remove redundant option

`magit-insert-status-tags-line' can now be enabled/disabled in
`magit-status-insert-sections-hook' (see commit 9da68462), so the
`magit-status-insert-tags-line' option no longer serves any purpose.

As a side effect, it's now enabled by default, which is a good thing IMO.

Signed-off-by: Pieter Praet <pieter@praet.org>

`magit-wash-log': call `derived-mode-p' only once

Doing the same thing twice for no additional benefit is always a pain,
so `let'-bind the return value of `derived-mode-p' around the body form.

Signed-off-by: Pieter Praet <pieter@praet.org>

`magit-log-create-author-date-overlays': remove redundant check

Commit d1e19af8 merged `magit-log-create-author-date-overlay'
into `magit-log-set-author-date-overlays' (renamed to
`magit-log-create-author-date-overlays'), but didn't remove the
second check of `magit-log-author-date-overlay'.  This variable
isn't modified between the first and second check, so the latter
is redundant.

Signed-off-by: Pieter Praet <pieter@praet.org>

`magit-mark-item': fix toggling mark in status buffer

Running `magit-mark-item' on a marked commit is supposed to unmark it.

Since the value stored in `magit-marked-commit' is a string, doing
comparison using `eq' can't possibly work, so use `equal' instead.

BTW, for some odd reason (which I don't feel like investigating right
now), the previous state of affairs *did* in fact *work* in the log
buffer (as opposed to the status buffer).  Doesn't matter anymore
though.  Now it works in both of them...

Fixes #898.

Signed-off-by: Pieter Praet <pieter@praet.org>

`magit-revert-item': respect `magit-revert-item-confirm'

Commit 1c7fb237 replaced the `magit-with-revert-confirmation' macro with
the temporary function `confirm', but in doing so also removed the check
for `magit-revert-item-confirm', causing `magit-revert-item' to always
ask for confirmation, even if the user configured it not to.

Fixes #896.

Signed-off-by: Pieter Praet <pieter@praet.org>

`magit-revert-item': don't depend on `cl-flet'

Commit 1c7fb237 replaced the `magit-with-revert-confirmation' macro with
the temporary function `confirm', but defined the latter using `cl-flet'
which isn't available in cl-lib 0.3, so use `let' + `funcall' instead.

Fixes #895.

Signed-off-by: Pieter Praet <pieter@praet.org>

`magit-ignore-item': make LOCAL arg optional

Commit 15c08f9e merged `magit-ignore-item' and `magit--ignore-item', and
for some reason made the LOCAL arg non-optional, causing Emacs to signal
`wrong-number-of-arguments' when running `magit-ignore-item' ("i") on a
file in the status buffer.

Fixes #893.

Signed-off-by: Pieter Praet <pieter@praet.org>

`magit-bisect-run': properly set `buffer' and `process'

In an effort to limit the usage of `magit-process-buffer-name',
commit 54f2e7c2 modified `magit-bisect-run' to set `process' and
`buffer' based on the return value of `magit-run-git-async'.

However, `magit-run-git-async' uses `magit-run-git*', which uses
`magit-run*', which returns its `successp' variable, which is either
t or nil, *not* a process object, so `magit-bisect-run' fails when
it tries to set `buffer' by running `process-buffer' on `process':

  Debugger entered--Lisp error: (wrong-type-argument processp t)
  [...]

Fixes #891.

Signed-off-by: Pieter Praet <pieter@praet.org>

`magit--bisect-last-pos': properly set prop 'permanent-local to t

Commit 8ce80095 intended to define `magit--bisect-last-pos' as a
permanent buffer-local variable by copy-pasting and adjusting the
sexps which do so for `magit--bisect-info', but forgot to adjust
the line which is supposed to set its 'permanent-local property to t.

Signed-off-by: Pieter Praet <pieter@praet.org>

magit.el: add `magit-diff-use-overlays' to `magit-faces' as custom-VARIABLE

Visiting the `magit-diff-use-overlays' option from the `magit-faces'
group resulted in an empty Customize buffer, stating:

  "Group definition missing."

See commit 66a06442.

Fixes #889.

Signed-off-by: Pieter Praet <pieter@praet.org>

`magit-display-process': fix displaying the process buffer

Commit e26c9c79 erroneously wrapped the call to `display-buffer'
inside the `unless', meaning if we *had* a buffer to display, the
code to display it *wouldn't* run, essentially causing the process
buffer to never be displayed when the BUFFER arg was non-nil, and
thus breaking `magit-process-popup-time'-based process buffer popup.

Fixes #887.

Signed-off-by: Pieter Praet <pieter@praet.org>

README.md: add link label def for `git-modes'

Commit 41b1bb7a added a reference link for `git-modes', but forgot
to add the link label definition.

Signed-off-by: Pieter Praet <pieter@praet.org>
make commit at point the default input value for magit-show-commit

remove magit-flow.el for now

Remove the `magit-flow.el' for the time being.  Another
implementation that implements the functionality described at
http://jeffkreeftmeijer.com/2010/why-arent-you-using-git-flow
will be added at a later time.

This version is removed because it depends on external scripts
that implement this workflow (https://github.com/nvie/gitflow),
which happens to be unmaintained.  It will actually be easier
to rewrite this in directly elisp than wrap around a bugged
external implementation (and eventually having to fork and
maintain that).  Also in most distributions these scripts are
not available through the native package manager.

More importantly though this version has to be removed because
it is very incomplete.  Having this version in the Magit repo
will raise expectations we cannot fulfill at this time; for a
elisp-only implementation to be feasible some existing mess in
the Magit code base has to be cleaned up first, and extenting
the wrapper around the shell scripts would be a waste of time
considering the goal of not relying on these eventually.

See issue #881 for discussion.

add turn-on-auto-fill to git-commit-mode-hook

add git-commit-{prev,next,save}-message, git-commit-kill-buffer-hook

Restores the ability to bring back previous commit messages while
editing a new message.  Also extends the old behaviour like so:

* Add command `git-commit-save-comment'.  This allows storing the
  current message at any time.  (Do you have a suggestion for a
  better key binding.)
* Automatically save the current message when aborting (and less
  importantly when finalizing) a commit.  This replaces the old
  backup mechanism that used the `kill-ring'.
* No longer save the *initial* message by default.  Instead of
  saving when opening the message do so when leaving it.
* Make that above customizable using the new hooks
  `git-commit-mode-hook' and `git-commit-kill-buffer-hook'.
* Store the current message before switching to another message.
  With the old implementation accidentally hitting the wrong
  key would destroy the current message.

git-commit-mode.el: fix customizable max summary length

Customizing the max summary length (using `customize-variable' or `setq')
didn't have any effect since `git-commit-summary-regexp' was set using a
function in `git-commit-max-summary-line-length's ":initialize" keyword,
which runs when the `defcustom' is *evaluated* (with its default value),
instead of when it's *set* (with the custom value).

Using the ":set" keyword would make it work when using `customize-variable'
or starting a fresh Emacs session, but not when using plain `setq'.

Let's keep it simple and just generate the commit summary regexp on the fly,
making it work in all cases...

Also, fix the commentary section in the header.

See commit 246ccaf2.

Signed-off-by: Pieter Praet <pieter@praet.org>

restore previous winconf after committing

When finishing or aborting a commit restore the window configuration
stored in `magit-commit-previous-winconf'.  If that is nil or was
created from a frame different from the current one (most likely
because multiple commits are performed at the same time), do nothing.

The code that invokes the commit (e.g. `magit-commit-internal`) has
to set `magit-commit-previous-winconf' before doing so.  Library
`server' does not feature a hook that could be used for this purpose.

If the previous window configuration cannot be restored (because it
hasn't been stored or does not apply) do what was done before this
commit.  Just kill the buffer and live with the wrong window being
selected after that.

Closes #797.

commit: add -v for verbose option

Add a -v option which allows you to invoke git-commit with --verbose. I
always do this because inevitably I'll forget some of the finer points
of the patch I'm about to commit, and having it all in the same buffer
instead of having to look at "git diff --staged" in another window is
great.

Now when you press "c" the window that's brought up looks like this:

    Switches
     -r: Replace the tip of current branch (--amend)         -a: Stage all modified and deleted files (--all)
     -e: Allow empty commit (--allow-empty)                  -v: Show diff of changes to be committed (--verbose)
     -n: Bypass git hooks (--no-verify)                      -s: Add Signed-off-by line (--signoff)
     -S: Sign using gpg (--gpg-sign)
    Actions
     c: Commit

And e.g. for this change I'm about to commit the buffer opens with:

    # Please enter the commit message for your changes. Lines starting
    # with '#' will be ignored, and an empty message aborts the commit.
    # On branch master
    # Changes to be committed:
    #   (use "git reset HEAD <file>..." to unstage)
    #
    #	modified:   magit-key-mode.el
    #
    diff --git a/magit-key-mode.el b/magit-key-mode.el
    index a7d9a8c..4fd5510 100644
    --- a/magit-key-mode.el
    +++ b/magit-key-mode.el
    @@ -192,6 +192,7 @@
           ("-r" "Replace the tip of current branch" "--amend")
           ("-a" "Stage all modified and deleted files" "--all")
           ("-e" "Allow empty commit" "--allow-empty")
    +      ("-v" "Show diff of changes to be committed" "--verbose")
           ("-n" "Bypass git hooks" "--no-verify")
           ("-s" "Add Signed-off-by line" "--signoff")
           ("-S" "Sign using gpg" "--gpg-sign")))

magit.el: minimal subsection rearrangement

Rearrange subsections of disorganized sections; but do only the minimum.
In other words the order is still messed up, but at least it is... less
bad.

Also see previous commit 4d65abf7f9c9f6ca5f78d3b89a60a2810f0b10e9.

magit.el: add preliminary subsections

Add preliminary subsections to the top-level sections "Revisions and
Ranges", "Diffs and Hunks", "Logs", and "Branch Manager Mode".  Wrap
the headings with parenthesis to indicate their status and also add
comments to that effect.

I have added subsections in the past only after/when rearranging the
containing top-level section.  But because I don't want to do this for
all these sections now I am adding these preliminary subsections now
without at the same time bringing the subsections and the contained
definitions into a reasonable order.

In my cleanup efforts I am currently focusing on removing *other* code
smells.  E.g. by identifying utilities that need to generalized to be
used outside of the scope they were originally written for (and in the
process removing narrow minded simplifications) and removing functions
only used by one caller (because it wouldn't make sense to improve and
then use them elsewhere).

Given my tiny brain it helps when code is stored in little labeled
boxes.  In the past I *have* used such temporary headings like those
being added in this commit.  I just never committed them and that let
to a lot of stashing and other laborious trickery.  Not this time: this
commit gives me a structure to work in and which is to be improved.

So yes, it's ugly and doesn't make for a good first impressions but for
all that it is worth doing so helps me fix the underlying causes of the
disorganization more quickly.

Move "Commit Mode" heading, rename "Logs{ and Commits => }"

Move the beginning of the "Commit Mode" top level section up to include
definitions that were previously part of the "Logs and Commits" section.
Rename that to just "Logs" as it no longer contains code related to the
commit buffer.  (Having a section that contains both "log" and "commit"
related code didn't make sense in the first place.)

The order of the code inside the extended "Commit Mode" section is
unfortunate but we can live with it for a while.

Rename `magit-log-initialize-author-date-overlay' to

function doesn't touch any overlay) and replacing "initialize" with
"setup" (which is also not optimal but since we use the same term in
`magit-mode-setup' it makes at least some sense).

That's the term we commonly use for this action.

into new `magit-log-create-author-date-overlays'.

Old `set' was only used by old `create'.
Also what does "set" supposed to mean?

magit-log-{initialize,create}-author-date-overlay: move mode check to caller

It's better to do that there so that the reader of the caller knows
right away that these functions don't do anything (now are not called)
unless the mode derives from `magit-log-mode'.

magit-log-display-author-date: adjust margin in correct window

This partially reverts f30e76945f82602622a5023c1ffca4dd6ef6d0ee.
Before that commit we were not "unnecessarily retrictive" in making
sure *current buffer* was the correct one.  Instead made sure that
the correct *window* was selected.

The change to `magit-log-create-author-date-overlay' was correct.

magit-item-highlight: use definition similar to that of highlight

When `magit-diff-use-overlays' is non-nil set the default value of face
`magit-item-highlight' to something similar to the default value of
`highlight'.  Do not inherit from `highlight' but instead copy the
value (with some redundancy removed), because we want to use a blue
instead of green background in the "very few colors" case.  Green is
already used in diffs for "added lines".  Also this potentially avoids
problems with themes.

fix magit-refresh-reflog-buffer inconsistencies

Rename the argument REV (revision) of `magit-reflog' and
`magit-refresh-log-buffer' to REF (reference).  The reflog
deals with branches not with arbitrary revisions.

Remove `magit-refresh-reflog-buffer's ARGS argument.  Its name
was wrong it wasn't a list but an atom.  The proper name would
have been something along the line RESOLVED-REF.  Remove the
argument entirely because we might as well evaluate
`(magit-rev-to-git ref)' inside `magit-refresh-reflog-buffer'
instead of `magit-reflog'.

add variables magit-{,ref}log-format

Add variables `magit-log-format' and `magit-reflog-format' replacing
the variables `magit-git-log-options' and `magit-git-reflog-options'.

The old variables contained the same "--format:format=..." and
additional the value of function `magit-diff-abbrev-arg'.  These
variables were set at startup.  Changing the value of option
`magit-sha1-abbrev-length' and therefor `magit-diff-abbrev-arg' was
not taken into account.  When the `custom-file' was loaded before
`magit' then even the initial value was wrong.
replace some uses of cond with cl-case

add magit-diff-abbrev-arg and magit-log-cutoff-length-arg

Add `magit-diff-abbrev-arg' and `magit-log-cutoff-length-arg' so we
don't have to repeatably construct the respective Git arguments based on
the values of `magit-sha1-abbrev-length' and `magit-log-cutoff-length'.

Also always use "-1" not "--max-count=1" or ("-n" "1") to turn `git log'
into a command that shows information about exactly one commit.  Git
should really have such a command, which is as powerfull as `git log -1'.
Well there is not command `git log-1' but `git log -1' is close enougth;
consider it a command, `git log --max-count=1' is harder to see as ac
command.

drop support for Git versions older than 1.7.2.5

Version 1.7.2.5 is now the oldest supported version.  That is the

Remove the `magit-configure-have-{*}' functions and `magit-have-{*}'
variables that were used to disable certain functionality for older
Git versions.

In areas affected by this change also sort Git options so that they
are grouped, as much as possible, according to the sections in the
`git-log' man page.

refactor magit-insert-{unpulled,unpushed}-commits

function `magit-remote-branch-name' which was used to make this leaky
abstraction less visible.

add magit-get-tracked-branch

Add `magit-get-tracked-branch' replacing `magit-remote-branch-for'.
The new function is a bit to complex (contributions welcome) but it
is better than the old which just assumed that there can only be one
fetch rule: "+refs/heads/*:refs/remotes/<name>/*".

`magit-get-tracke-branch' doesn't have that limitation.  Additionally
it does only return a branch name instead of a full branch path if a
a non-standard path is used.  The new optional PRETTY argument can be
used to return the formatted name `magit-format-ref' would return.

function.

`magit-after-insert-remote-line-hook' instead of the

remove magit-with-revert-confirmation

When used with a prefix argument `magit-ignore-item{,-locally}' now

move "Submoduling" subsection into first "Acting" section

For historic reasons there are currently two top-level "Acting"
sections.  While it would be best to merge them, there is no need to do
that right away - especially as future changes will likely influence how
that should be done.

However "Submoduling" should be moved into the first instead of the

located in the second "Acting" section.

favor term "rename" over "move"

People who do not like Git often use this to demonstrate how terribly
inconsistent its interface is:

  git branch -m <old> <new>  vs.  git remote rename <old> <new>

While I don't agree that this a big deal I also don't see a reason why
we should carry that inconsistency over to magit.

Rename `magit-move-{commit,item}' to `magit-rename-{commit,item},
to make it consistent with `magit-rename-remote'.

add magit-git-success

remove magit-cmd-output, do the work insided magit-cmd-insert

`magit-cmd-insert' was the only remaining caller of `magit-cmd-output`.

use magit-git-insert where appropriate

Due to that and the changes in the last commit `magit-git-output'

define magit-git-{string,lines} more directly

Instead of returning the result of passing the value of
`magit-git-output' to `magit-trim-line'/`magit-split-lines' use
`call-process' and extract the first line / the lines directly.

Add doc-strings because we need to explain how empty lines are handled.

Change how `magit-git-lines' deals with empty lines.  Previously the
return value could contain empty lines but if the first line was such a
line then that empty string was removed, but no other.  Now all empty
lines are ignored.

magit-{cherry-pick,revert}-commit use magit-run-git

instead of `magit-run-git*'.

remove unused magit-run-git-async-with-input

No internal or external libraries use this function.  The old commit
workflow used it but even if we restore parts of that we should not
restore this function (we could just use `magit-run-git*' directly).
I would like to avoid advertizing this usage of `magit-run*' (which
this function is just a wrapper around).

magit-display-buffer: also handle the timed display

This helps relieving the burden on the overloaded `magit-run*'.

replace global magit-process-client-buffer with local variable

Instead of setting `magit-process-client-buffer' globally pass the
buffer that was current when `magit-run*' was called to the functions
that need to know about its value.  These are the process sentinels.

Because process sentinels take exactly two arguments we create a partial
application of `magit-process-sentinel' (and `magit--bisect-run-sentinel')
and use the returned function as actual sentinel.

Also limit the use of the global variable `magit-process-buffer-name',
rename some of `magit-run*'s internal variables and change were these
variables are set.

magit-stgit.el: remove colons at end of section headings

Also rename section "Customizables" to "Options".

remove magit-run, add magit-run-{stgit,topgit}

Remove `magit-run'.  It isn't used by any known external library.

Within Magit it was used by `magit-stgit.el' and `magit-topgit.el'.
Add `magit-run-stgit' and `magit-run-topgit' as replacements.  Note

Resurrect the staged version of a file

'k' on deleted file in the "Unstaged changes" section use to first reset
all change on the staged version and then checkout the file as in the
last commit. This can lead to data lost if one have already staged some
change, then deleted the file then try to resurrect the just deleted
file.

It less surprising if we resurrect the staged version of a file when it
is different from the committed version.

add magit-decode-git-path

... and use it to undo the following in some places.

(There might be some other places that could benefit from this.  Or
maybe there are event better places to do this instead, to avoid doing
it repeatedly.)

https://github.com/git/git/blob/master/quote.c

Quoting man:git-config "core.quotepath":

The commands that output paths (e.g.  ls-files, diff), when not given
the -z option, will quote "unusual" characters in the pathname by
enclosing the pathname in a double-quote pair and with backslashes the
same way strings in C source code are quoted. If this variable is set
to false, the bytes higher than 0x80 are not quoted but output as
verbatim. Note that double quote, backslash and control characters are
always quoted without -z regardless of the setting of this variable.

Thanks to Nicolas Richard for investigating this issue.  #581, #840.

add new subsections to "Status Mode" section

The "Status Mode" toplevel section contains various definitions that do
not strictly belong there.  Because there also are no other places that
would make complete sense and defining separate toplevel sections for
these definitions would also not be appropriate they are kept in the
current section.

The hope is that eventually a natural place for these definitions will
evolve.  Until then at least split the misplaced stuff into dedicated
subsections.  This can be done without moving any code around (except
for `magit-init' which was moved in the last commit).

Add a new subsection "Save File Buffers".  Because it right in the
middle of the existing "Status Refresh and Commands" subsection that is
renamed to "Status Refresh" and a new subsection "Status Commands" is
added.

Creating new toplevel sections would also be an option but that would
require that code be moved around (because "Status Commands" really does
belong in the "Status Mode" section).

In summary: "Save Buffers" and "Read Repository" should not really be
located below "Status Mode" but having them their is less bad than the
alternatives.

move definition of magit-init

Move definition of `magit-init' below that of `magit-status'.
The fact that the former may be used by the latter is the only
justification for it to be defined somewhere in the "Status Mode"
section at all.

The old location was just silly.  It was defined below the refresh
function and above the mode definition; and nowhere near that of
`magit-status'.

merge magit-insert-current-line into its only caller

It was actually not abstract enough to be used in call cases where the
caller `magit-insert-hunk-item-region-patch' had to do "something like
it".  Merging reduces both line count and makes it easier to understand
what is going on.

move magit-insert-region right below its callers

This should make it easier to grasp their somewhat strange semantic.

move definitions of magit-save-index and magit-show

These functions do not belong in the "Diffs and Hunks" section.

`magit-show' has absolutely nothing to do with that, unfortunately
there no place at all where it would naturally belong.  Add it to
the new "Miscellaneous Commands" section.

Move `magit-save-index' to section "Ediff Support" as it is only
used there.

Also move the definitions of the related variables so that their
definitions remain located before their first use.

Move `magit-show-current-version' to "Ediff Support".

Move `magit-file-name' to "String and File Utilities" as it is also
used by `magit-buffer-file-name' added in the previous commit.

add magit-buffer-file-name

This is an alternative to `buffer-file-name' which also works in buffers
that do not directly visit a file but still map to exactly one file.
More precisely this supports indirect buffer and buffers "visiting" a
file as it was in some revision.

Use it in `magit-read-file-from-rev'.

move misplace "Diff Mode" section heading

Function `magit-refresh-diff-buffer' belongs in this section.

rename section "Diffing" to "Ediff Support"

The code in this section has little to do with git-diff for which we
generally use the term "Diff".  That is only to get some information
which is then used to provide wrappers around ediff.

Merge branch 'mode-setup'

add magit-mode-setup, all but replacing magit-mode-init

Add new macro `magit-mode-setup' and use it where `magit-mode-init' was
previously used.  Keep the latter for compatibility and because we might
run into situations where the former does to much.

`magit-mode-setup' calls `magit-display-mode-buffer' to display and
select a buffer and then calls `magit-mode-init' to turn on the mode,
store refresh information and perform the first refresh.

It also makes sure that the arguments to `magit-mode-init' are evaluated
in the correct buffer - that is before switching to the mode buffer.
This helps prevent scope errors in the future.  (I am aware of at least
one instance when someone (me) has made exactly that mistake.)
Merge branch 'cleanup'
Merge branch 'diff-highlight'
merge magit-hunk-item-is-conflict-p into only caller
magit-insert-hunk-item-region-patch: merge conditionals
magit-diff-default-hunks: remove empty string inside interactive

remove unnecessary uses of let in some functions

... in the "Diffs and Hunks" section.

Local bindings should only be used when they are necessary because e.g.
(a) the value is used more than once and is costly to calculate (because
of either the computation or visual noise) or (b) the value has to be
calculated before its use because doing retrieving the value and using
it in the same place would change the outcome to to due to scope
differences (e.g. a different buffer is current).

When let is used and neither one of these or other requirements call for
it one is left wondering whether that is indeed the case, or whether one
just overlooks some subtle detail.  This cost outweights the benefit of
implicitly documenting the purpose of the function being called with the
local variables as arguments.

This doesn't full apply here, but the implicit "argument documentation"
argument is very weak in cases like this:

  (let ((very-descriptive-variable (very-descriptive-function something)))
    (only-use-of-the very-descriptive-variable))
reduce nesting of some functions in the "Diffs and Hunks" section

when THEN ends with explicit t drop the exlicit nil ELSE

When the body of a function, whose return value is significant, ends
with a conditional whose THEN part ends with an explicit `t' adding
an explicit ELSE part that contains nothing but an explicit `nil' is
overkill as it does not convey any additional meaning.

fix and refactor hunk refinement

* Fix a scope error in `magit-wash-hunk' that prevented all hunks to be
  refined when the user asks for it.

* Add `magit-diff-{,un}refine-hunk' to replace `magit-{,un}refine-section'.

  The former absorb the trivial functions `magit-maybe-diff-refine-hunk'
  and `magit-looking-at-combined-diff-p' which were only used by the
  latter but never-the-less were defined in far away region of the file.

  On the other hand the new functions expect a hunk section as argument.
  Unlike the functions they replace they do not fallback to some section
  pulled from thin air and do not perform any sanity checks that are
  only required by some of the their callers.  The callers now perform
  the appropriate checks themselves.

* Refactor caller `magit-diff-refine-hunk' to skip unnecessary actions.
* Perform some additional cleanup on the caller `magit-highlight-section'.
* Define `magit-highlight-overlay' and `magit-highlighted-sectione' as
  local variables.
* Change `magit-diff-refine-hunk's doc-string to be more like similar
  doc-strings.

use background color to hightlight current item

Visualizing added and removed lines in diffs using the background color
conflicts with also using the background color to highlight the current
item.  This can be overcome by using overlays in both cases - but this
comes with a performance penalty, which might or might not be noticable.
Never-the-less this is now default.  The alternatives are listed in the
doc-string of the new `magit-diff-use-overlays' option.

`magit-wash-diffstats-postwork' was previously one of the places where
section headers got propertized.  The same headers are also propertized
elsewhere, so that functionality is remove.  We should investigate
whether this function and the `magit-diffstat-cached-sections' variable
are needed at all (anymore?).

Merge pull request #837 from praet/git-gui-blame

Git Gui Blame fixes

`magit-create-branch': simplify

I added the `magit-create-branch-behaviour' option back in 2011
(commit 3cf57646), but made the horrible mistake of leaving the
original behavior ("create branch at HEAD") the default.
See e.g. this thread [1] from February 2013 on the ML.

Instead of making 'at-point the default, let's just get rid of
the option altogether and always try to find a rev at point first.

Note that I'm intentionally *not* using `magit-default-rev', as
that uses `magit-guess-branch', which is very likely to offer
the *previous* value of HEAD instead of the current one.

[1] mid:"87k3q9pm73.fsf@debian.org"

Signed-off-by: Pieter Praet <pieter@praet.org>

`git-rebase-show-commit': run `magit-show-commit' in correct `default-directory'

To find out the correct `default-directory' in which to initialize
`magit-commit-mode', `magit-show-commit' uses `magit-get-top-dir',
which uses "git rev-parse --show-cdup".

Unfortunately, that command doesn't return anything when run from
within (a subdir of) $GIT_DIR like e.g. "<repo>/.git/rebase-merge/",
causing subsequent commands in `magit-refresh-commit-buffer' to fail.

Fix it by setting `default-directory' to the current dir's grandparent
before invoking `magit-show-commit'.

Fixes #44.

Signed-off-by: Pieter Praet <pieter@praet.org>

INSTALL.md: add link label def for `git-{commit,rebase}-mode'

Commit e2f9c456 added reference links for `git-commit-mode' and
`git-rebase-mode', but forgot to add the link label definition.

Signed-off-by: Pieter Praet <pieter@praet.org>

AUTHORS.md: auto-generated using 'make authors'

Signed-off-by: Pieter Praet <pieter@praet.org>

.mailmap: add "Noam Postavsky"

Committed as "npostavs" in 94fddadd, but as "Noam Postavsky" in
fc6f4814, which would cause duplicates in the "AUTHORS.md" file.

Signed-off-by: Pieter Praet <pieter@praet.org>

`magit-run-git-gui-blame': pass options *before* rev and filename

When running `magit-run-git-gui-blame' and selecting the file that is
being visited in the current buffer, git-gui(1) is supposed to scroll
the view to center on the line number at which point currently resides.

For this to work, we need to pass the '--line=' option *before* the rev
and filename.

Signed-off-by: Pieter Praet <pieter@praet.org>

`magit-run-git-gui-blame': s/Git Blame/Git Gui Blame/

Rename subprocess to "Git Gui Blame", to be consistent with
`magit-run-git-gui'.

Signed-off-by: Pieter Praet <pieter@praet.org>

`magit-run-git-gui-blame': s/magit-start-process/start-file-process/

The "minimal-emacs" branch removed a number of compatibility functions,
among which `magit-start-process', replacing it with `start-file-process'.

Between the time that branch was created (commit 83dac351) and merged
(commit b872cbf7), `magit-run-git-gui-blame' was added (commit 007da202),
which also makes use of `magit-start-process', and this wasn't corrected
when merging in the "minimal-emacs" branch.

Signed-off-by: Pieter Praet <pieter@praet.org>

`magit-quote-curly-braces': fix case-insensitive matching

To make searching and matching case-insensitive, we have to set
`case-fold-search' (as opposed to `case-fold', which is a
non-existent variable) to t.  I'm guessing this went unnoticed
because `case-fold-search' is set to t by default.

Signed-off-by: Pieter Praet <pieter@praet.org>

`magit-apply-hunk-item*' call `use-region-p' only once

Commit 83dac351 replaced `magit-use-region-p' with `use-region-p',
but in doing so, caused us to call `use-region-p' twice.

Also, the function might at some point in the future be changed to do
stuff which alters or unsets the region between the first and second
check, which would result in a bug:  Defensive Programming FTW.

Signed-off-by: Pieter Praet <pieter@praet.org>

Makefile: use $(RMDIR) in magit-$(VERSION).tar{,.gz} targets

The "magit-$(VERSION).tar.gz" and "magit-$(VERSION).tar" targets should
remove the "magit-$(VERSION)" directory use $(RMDIR) instead of $(RM).

See commits d8c95a9d and 04e65579.

Signed-off-by: Pieter Praet <pieter@praet.org>

`git-rebase-move-line-up': don't swap top lines

When running `git-rebase-move-line-up' on a line that is already at the
top of the list, the first and second lines are transposed, so the line
we meant to move *up* is effectively moved *down*.

Prevent this by only transposing lines if point isn't at the beginning
of the buffer.

Signed-off-by: Pieter Praet <pieter@praet.org>

`git-rebase-mode-menu': make "Done" call `git-rebase-server-edit'

Commit ba6a5450 bound "q" and "C-c C-c" to `git-rebase-server-edit'
instead of plain `server-edit' in `git-rebase-mode-map', but didn't
update `git-rebase-mode-menu' accordingly.

I'd be surprised if anyone is actually using the menu for anything but
discovering available functionality (or even has it enabled, for that

There really is no point in delaying telling users that they do need

that's like the most fundamental git operation from a user perspective.
:-)

important as committing but it's important enough to make it a hard
dependency too.

Magit now requires GNU Emacs 23.2 or greater

The decision to officially the support for older versions of Emacs was
unanimously reached here: https://github.com/magit/magit/issues/708.

Actually the old claim in README.md that Magit works with GNU Emacs 22.1
was wrong.  Some features of Magit *might* have worked with that version
but a lot of things would not have.

Remove some old (and incomplete) backward compatibility definitions.

Since it is possible (while unlikely) that some users have successfully
used Magit with Emacs 22 in the past and because we are removing code
that might previously have allowed using a subset of Magit add a version
check to magit.el.

Check that the minimal version requirement is satisfied; else raise an
error.  It is better to raise an error at this point than to have late
adapters figure out on their own why Magit stopped working with their
beloved ancient Emacs.  I would also rather have people complain about
this decision than having them file bug reports about things that
stopped working - in which case we might fail to notice right away that
the breakage is causes by the use of an older Emacs.

This check will also cause an error when XEmacs is used (as XEmacs isn't
at 23.2 yet, and likely will never be).  The same arguments apply here
than the ones made above regarding old versions of GNU Emacs.

Merge pull request #814 from praet/magit-remove-conflicts-fix

`magit-remove-conflicts': `delete-dups' from ALIST before populating hash table

`magit-remove-conflicts': `delete-dups' from ALIST before populating hash table

When a member of `magit-repo-dirs' is a parent/child/duplicate of one of
the other members, ALIST will contain duplicate key-value mappings, and
because of the way `magit-remove-conflicts' tries to uniquify the keys,
it will keep recursing on those associations until their keys are the
canonical path to the repo, after which it blows up because it can no
longer extract a higher-level directory to prefix them with.

Fixes #811 and #311.

Signed-off-by: Pieter Praet <pieter@praet.org>
update license in README, fix other GPL notices

fix handling of magit-restore-window-configuration

When option `magit-restore-window-configuration' is non-nil
`magit-quit-window' restores the "previous window configuration" after
quitting the window and burying the buffer.  That configuration is
stored by `magit-buffer-switch'.

Until now the previous configuration was stored everytime
`magit-buffer-switch' was called, even if the buffer already existed
or even was already visible in the current frame.  This could lead to
`magit-quit-window' being unable to actually quit the window.

Now the previous configuration is only saved when it makes sense and
as an additional precaution `magit-quit-window' sets it to nil after
using it.

magit-buffer-switch: detect magit buffers using derived-mode-p

Previously a regular expression ("magit") that matched to
much ("^\*magit" would have been more appropriate) was used to detect
such buffers based on their names.

This changes how the current buffer effects switching to a magit-mode
buffer:

- Buffers whose name begins with "*magit" but do not derive from
  `magit-mode' (e.g. "*magit-process*") are now treated as non-magit
  buffers.

- Buffers visiting magit libraries (e.g. "magit.el") are now treated
  as what they are "non-magit" buffers.

magit-buffer-switch: add optional SWITCH-FUNCTION argument

This allows using this function in `magit-status' which until now
had to duplicate some of the functionality of this function.

AUTHORS.md: auto-generated using 'make authors'

Signed-off-by: Pieter Praet <pieter@praet.org>

Makefile: add 'authors' target

Commits a9ed908a/59fd7f6d removed the majority of our contributors'
copyright statements due to the maintenance overhead involved in
keeping it accurate and up to date.

However, besides being in violation of the GPL, this is rather
discourteous towards our contributors, considering all the time and
effort they've expended to improve Magit for the good of us all.

Also, if left in its current state, it's only a matter of time before
people start adding copyright lines again, and "who's maintainer" or
"who committed the most" are inherently transient metrics, so at some
point in the future, the list would need to be revised again, manually,
in every file, no matter what.

Fortunately, this can be easily solved by directly crediting only a
single entity and consolidating its constituents into an auto-generated
"AUTHORS.md" file that covers the entire project, allowing us to properly
credit our contributors as well as permanently retiring the Copyright
Cleaner hat.

- - -

I've globally replaced the copyright headers with a copyright statement
crediting "The Magit Project Developers" (do note that this is *not*
equivalent to "copyright assignment") with the correct copyright year(s),
a pointer to the "AUTHORS.md" file, and an "Author:" line, of which the
value was procured using:

  for i in *.el ; do
      printf "%s\n  %s\n\n" \
          "${i}" \
          "$(git log --pretty=format:'%h : [%ai] %aN <%aE>' -- "${i}" \
             | tail -n 1)" ;
  done

An exception was made for "magit-wip.el", which was introduced by
Ryan C. Thompson (commit b877584e) but Jonas Bernoulli coded pretty
much the whole thing (commit 5e2e992b and later).

Files containing code borrowed from other projects (specifically
"magit-blame.el" and "magit-compat.el") now state the relevant
projects' names, URLs and licenses, right below the "Author:" line.

The Makefile now contains targets which use git-log(1) to generate an
unabridged list of our contributors' names and email addresses, which
is combined with "AUTHORS.md.in" and written to "AUTHORS.md", which is
always included when rolling tarballs and installing.

To prevent incomplete/duplicate/outdated/erroneous authors' names and
email addresses, a ".mailmap" file was created, which is automatically
picked up by git-log(1) when using %aN/%aE instead of %an/%ae.

The only contributors for whom I couldn't find any conclusive info are:
- "aaa707 <aaa707b@gmail.com>"
- "acple <silentsphere110@gmail.com>"
- "rabio <rabiodev@o2.pl>"
...so these are included as-is.

And thus the only maintenance overhead left to keeping this list up to
date is running "make authors" and committing the updated "AUTHORS.md"
file, right before tagging a new release.

Signed-off-by: Pieter Praet <pieter@praet.org>

further improve magit-with-emacsclient
fix previous two commits

Merge branch 'sane-client'
magit-commit-internal: use new git-commit-commit-hook

set $GIT_EDITOR from scratch, add client-less fallback

Add new variable `magit-emacsclient-executable'.  Its default value is
set by searching for an executable in the same directory the executable
of the running Emacs instance is located in or if it cannot be found
there anywhere on `exec-path'.  This should virtually always return
something usable.  If it doesn't then something is seriously wrong with
the Emacs installation.

We first limit the search to the directory containing the invoked Emacs
executable because multiple Emacs version might be installed and the
emacsclient earliest on the `exec-path' might not be compatible with
the running Emacs.

No longer base the $GIT_EDITOR that is eventually used by Magit when
calling git on $GIT_EDITOR or $EDITOR as set in the environment of the
running Emacs.  Instead of detecting and fixing bad values optained that
way always set $GIT_EDITOR from scratch.

Add alternative code paths to `magit-commit' and `magit-tag' that do not
require a working client/server interaction.  When using tramp and when
no window system is available also use these fallbacks.

This can still be improved a lot.  But at least we are no longer set on
a path that forces us add one kludge after another on top of the
existing kludges.

`magit-interactive-rebase' most likely cannot be implemented without the
use of emacsclient so that command now refuses to run if the client
cannot be used.

Remove `magit-git-editor' in favor of `magit-emacsclient-excecutable'.
Rename `magit-with-git-editor' to `magit-with-emacsclient'.
Add `magit-use-emacsclient-p' and `magit-assert-emacsclient'.

refactor git-commit-{commit,abort} and related code

Remove option `git-commit-commit-function'.  Instead integrate most
of the functionality previously provided by `git-commit-end-session'
(the default value of the former) directory into `git-commit-commit'.

I can see not good reasons why one would want to disable the default
behavior.  However it might be necessary to perform some *additional*
action.  E.g. when `magit-commit' cannot use emacsclient it needs a
way to tell `git-commit-commit' to actually call `git commit' to that
effect.  The new hook `git-commit-commit-hook' is intended for that
purpose.

`git-commit-end-session' also contained some code wrapping around
variable `server-buffer-clients'.  Since we use that while aborting
too, create a new function `git-commit-buffer-clients' from that part.

`git-commit-abort' now tells the emacsclient to exit with a non-zero
exit status, previously we had to save an empty file to communicate to
git that the user has decided to abort creating a commit.  Thanks to
Dhruva Krishnamurthy who showed me how to do that.

`git-commit-abort' no longer warns that aborting will cause the edited
message to be lost.  The option `git-commit-confirm-abort' that allowed
turning that warning of is removed.  Instead the buffer text is always
saved to the `kill-ring'.  A message is shown in the echo area to inform
the user that this has happened.  This has the additional benefit that
the "git exited abnormally with code 1." message is less likely to be
seen by the user.

`magit-with-git-editor-setup': correct path to server socket

`server-socket-dir' == path to server socket dir *sans* trailing slash,
so we'd end up calling emacsclient(1) with e.g. "-s /tmp/emacs1000server"
instead of "-s /tmp/emacs1000/server".

Adding the slash in the format string might result in "-s nil/server",
so use an `ignore-errors'-wrapped `file-name-as-directory' instead.

Signed-off-by: Pieter Praet <pieter@praet.org>

`magit-tag': s/"-a"/"--annotate"/g

Enabling the "-a" switch in `magit-key-mode-popup-tagging' adds
"--annotate" to `magit-custom-options', however `magit-tag'
checked for the presence of "-a" to decide whether or not to use
`magit-with-git-editor-setup' + `magit-run-git-async'.

As a result, creating an annotated tag by setting the "-a" flag in
the tagging popup opened a new frame instead of using the existing
one, and blocked the parent Emacs process.

remove magit-log-edit.el and rebase-mode.el

Instead use `git-commit-mode.el' and `git-rebase-mode.el'
from https://github.com/magit/git-modes.

* `git-commit-mode' communicates the commit message to git by
  saving the commit message file. `magit-log-edit' used git's
  standard input for this purpose, which is much more fragile.

* `git-rebase-mode' is the new name of the library previously
  known as `rebase-mode'.  It was moved to `git-modes' because
  we start using that anyway and because, like the other files
  there, can be used without magit.

This was discussed at https://github.com/magit/magit/issues/675.

magit-with-git-editor-setup: add SERVER-WINDOW argument

This allows displaying a buffer created by 'emacsclient' to be displayed
differently when using this macro as opposed to the default configured
with the `server-window' option.

Also add an option `magit-server-window-for-rebase' which is used by
`magit-interactive-rebase' to set that SERVER-WINDOW.  In a later commit
`magit-server-window-for-commit' will also be added.

At least in the case of `*-for-commit' this is useful because it makes
sense to use e.g. `pop-to-buffer' here, even when one generally prefers
`switch-to-buffer-other-frame'.

remove Version header keywords from libraries

Except for `git-rebase-mode.el' all files

It better to duplicate this setting in every file than setting it in
".dir-locals.el" because this allows users to use that file for their
own settings.

git-rebase-mode-font-lock-keywords: move defintion

define actions explicitly

Functions and especially commands should always be defined
explicitly using `defun' or a custom "define" macro.  This
allows e.g. `find-function' to locate the definition.  In
this case it also help people who want to customize the
keymap.

We are getting all the benefits for free.  It turned out
being explicit does not require a single additional line
of code.  We should still generate doc-strings though.

From the git-merge(1) man page:
  #+begin_quote

Signed-off-by: Pieter Praet <pieter@praet.org>

`magit-merge': absorb `magit-manual-merge'

`magit-merge' was only called when `magit-rigid-key-bindings' == t
(does anybody even use that?), in which case `magit-manual-merge'
should have been called instead anyway (see commit dbd213ec).

`magit-merge' now defaults to `magit-manual-merge's behavior, but still
allows to skip editing the log message using the optional arg DO-COMMIT.

The new arg is mainly there to support skipping `magit-log-edit'
programmatically though, since humans will most likely be better off
just tapping "C-c C-c" in "*magit-edit-log*" instead of having to think
about it in advance.

and it doesn't pass `magit-custom-options' to `magit-run-git'.

refactor log commands

Prompt the user for the range in the `interactive' forms of
`magit-log-ranged' or `magit-log-long-ranged'.

Previously this was not only done outside of the `interactive' form
of these functions but inside of `magit-log'/`magit-log-long' which
are called by the former.

This is wrong for two reasons:

(1) Whenever possible minibuffer input should be read in the
    interactive form.

(2) `magit-log'/`magit-long-log' only ever used the range when
    called by `magit-log-ranged'/`magit-log-long-ranged'.

`magit-log'/`magit-log-long' now take a RANGE as first argument,
replacing the "ask the user for a range and use that" switch
previously used.

and move the "Logging" section into the toplevel "Acting" section.

allow using magit-add-log during rebase

Like `magit-log-edit' this function detected an progress rebase and
offered to continue that instead of committing.  When the user reply
was "no" this function acted as if that means "no I want to do
anything at all".  `magit-log-edit' already understands it correctly
"no thanks, I really do want to commit".

Change this function to behave the same way.  Because this function
used `magit-log-edit' internally the test for an in-progress rebase
can be removed here.  There is some code before the call to
`magit-log-edit' but that only collects some information, has no side
effects, and is inexpensive.

merge toplevel sections "Acting (1)" and "Acting (2)"

Until recently the toplevel section "Log Edit Mode" was between these
two sections, but that was moved to a separate file.

To merge these two sections another toplevel that was between the two
had to be made a subsection.  In the process that section "ChangeLog"
was renamed to "Commit".  In the future it will also contain a command
`magit-commit', which will be a wrapper around `magit-log-edit' or the
respective function from `git-commit-mode'.

Merge branch 'refresh'

add magit-refresh-file-buffer-hook

Call it in `magit-refresh-wrapper' for every buffer visiting a file in
the current buffer.

Bring back `magit-update-vc-modeline' as a wrapper around
`vc-find-file-hook' to update _a single_ buffer.  Do _not_ add it to the
hook's default value.  I don't expect many people to pay attention to
the Vc controlled part of the modeline (and if they do they will notice
and can add it themselves).  On the other hand many people complain
about bad performance and not using this function does improve that.
See issue #573.  We should implement our own "status in modeline" hook
function, see issue #240.

Add new function `magit-revert-buffer' to the hook.  It does the same
thing as the now removed `magit-revert-buffers' (plural) did until a
four commits ago - just for a single buffer.

only call dired-uncache when needed

When dired isn't loaded then there is no information to be uncashed.
Don't load dired just to unload a cache that doesn't even exist.
magit-refresh-wrapper: cosmetics

update modeline inside `magit-revert-buffer'

We have a mechanism for "updating buffers that need it": the refresh
mechanism implemented by the `magit-refresh-*' functions and macros.

Refreshing the modeline on behalf of vc did not make use of that but
instead relied on `magit-update-vc-modeline' being called explicitly.
Now it is refreshed whenever the regular refresh mechanism kicks in,
which can both positive or negative.

Positive because we don't have to identify each place where updating
the modeline would make sense; negative because it is a potentially
costly operation which is now done under circumstances that do not
necessarily call for it.

I will take care of the drawbacks by making this both less costly as
well as optional all together, in later commits.  (This commit already
makes refreshing slightly more efficient because it removes one looping
of the list of buffers.)

The name of this function now doesn't match all it does anymore.
That will also be taken care of.

remove magit-bug-report

I do not think having such a function is useless per se but in its
current form it is.

1. I have never actually seen a bug report that looked that it was based
   on the contents of buffer created by it.

2. It was only used in very few places and it appears these places never
   actually cause any errors.  (Actually in the case of `magit-run*'
   errors are less unlikely).

3. For this function to be useful it would have to be used everywhere
   errors can happen.  Doing so would be way to ugly without first
   converting it to a macro and then some.

4. Just writing some versions strings into a buffer and telling the user
   to do something is not particularly useful.  Something using Message
   mode might be, though.

So yes, maybe I will add back something similar, but it has to be
redesigned to be useful at all.  And there are more important things to
do first.

make reading passwords customizable

We use a process filter to detect when git or one of its subprocesses
(in many cases ssh) prompts the user for usernames, passwords and
passphrases.  Until now the prompt strings we were able to detect were
hardcoded.

Add new options magit-process-{username,password}-prompts so that users
can easily tell magit to forward the (sometimes quite unique) prompts
their setup spits out, without having to patiently having to wait for us
maintainers to agree, to support them.

Fixes to make install rules

Makefile: use install-info to install info files by default.

install-info is available in most linux distributions while
ginstall-info is not.

Makefile: removed install-loaddefs target.

There is no rule for this target and it causes an error when invoking
"make install". loaddefs are installed by the "install-lisp" target so
there is no need for it anyway.

use the semantically best conditional

Or "don't use if when there is no ELSE".

This is about semantics not just about aesthetics.

* (if COND (progn FORM...))   =>  (when COND FORM...)
* (if COND THEN)              =>  (when COND THEN)
* (if (not COND) THEN)        =>  (unless COND THEN)
* (list (if COND THEN) ...)   =>  (list (and COND THEN) ...)
* (and (if COND THEN) ...)    =>  (and (and COND THEN) ...)
* (or (if COND THEN) ...)     =>  (or (and COND THEN) ...)
* (if ... (if ... (if ...)))  =>  (cond ...)
* (if COND (progn THEN) ELSE) =>  (if COND THEN ELSE)
* (if COND (progn THEN...) ELSE...)
  =>  (cond ((COND FORM) THEN...) (t ELSE...))  ; not always
* (or COND (error ...)) (if COND THEN ELSE)
  =>  (cond (COND (error ...)) (COND THEN) (t ELSE))
* (if COND (FN A B) (FN A C))
  =>  (FN A (if COND B C))
* (when CONDA (when CONDB THEN))
  =>  (when (and CONDA CONDB) THEN)
* (cond ... (t (when COND THEN)))
  =>  (cond ... (COND THEN))

Please not that I have not inspected every single conditional.
Instead, I have "only" looked at matches for "(if".  In very few
cases I have not switched to the best conditional because the
surrounding code actually needs more extensive cleanup.

Also I have kept:

* (if COND nil ELSE)
* (if COND THEN nil)

when I felt doing so actually makes it easier to the reader.

However the latter was often used as the last form in functions, and
since in elisp functions always return a value I have in most cases come
to the conclusion that (when|unless COND RETURN-VALUE) is just as easy
to understand.  But when it is not immediately obvious that the return
value of a function is significant I have kept the old form with the nil
THEN or ELSE form.

There is never a good time to do this kind of change.  But now is a less
bad time because I have also moved code around during the past month, so
tools like git-blame will have troubles looking furthur into the past
anyway.

Also see #663.

magit-highlight-trailing-whitespace: cache style itself

Instead of having `magit-mode` caching the indentation style (even when
it is not used) do the caching inside `magit-highlight-trailing-whitespace'.

Remove the local variable `magit-current-identation' that was previously
used for that purpose and instead use set the local value of of
`magit-highlight-trailing-whitespace'.  It is okay that the custom and
local value of that variable doesn't have the same form because the
local value is only ever used inside `magit-highlight-trailing-whitespace'.

define string-prefix-p if it doesn't exist

and remove magit-string-has-prefix-p.

remove magit-goto-line

It is only used once and simply enough to be inlined.

remove with-magit-tmp-buffer

This macro had semantics very different from `with-temp-buffer', a
name that is to close to that of the latter, and no doc-string.

This could lead to tears, or at least confuse people.  Blinded by the
similarity of the names at least I did not initially see the semantic
difference.

There are multiple ways this could be addressed.  E.g. we could find a
more descriptive name and add a doc-string.  But since this macro is
only used twice it makes more sense to just remove the abstraction and
let the two callers do the necessary work themselves.  I think that in
this case _not_ moving the complexity out of sight actually improves
the readers understanding even though the code becomes a little
longer (especially considering that the abstraction would/was only
used once).

Yet another approach would be to improve `magit-run-git-async's
semantics.  This approach wasn't taken because I wanted to contain the
changes to a small area.

Merge branch 'split-apply-commit'

split magit-apply-commit into three functions

This basically reverts bded317bc81db781a7454b51a37594304cac2daa which
was horribly misguided.  Let me just say this: it doesn't make sense to
conflate unrelated functions just because they happen to share some
logic.  I guess one could argue that these functions are not completely
unrelated.  Well, it is still much easier (in context of reverting a
commit) to reason about:

  (magit-revert-commit commit)

than

  (magit-apply-commit commit nil nil t)      ; at HEAD~2

- What does reverting have to do with applying?
- What are these arguments?
After jumping to `magit-apply-commit':
- What the &*&$@# is going on here?
- What does cherry-picking have to do with reverting?
- Could it possibly makes sense for the first two optional arguments
  to be non-nil when reverting?
- Since that isn't done anywhere the "reverting" code branch contains
  dead code, or doesn't it?
- Aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaah!

magit-apply-commit: remove optional NOERASE argument

Previously when NOERASE was non-nil the output from the previous
`magit-run*' invocation was not removed from the *magit-process*
buffer when calling this function.

The only caller of this function which made use of that argument was
`magit-rewrite-finish-step' (which didn't always use it).

So allso remove `magit-rewrite-finish-step's FIRST-P argument.

Indead, in this case it would make more sense to preserve the previous
output a little longer than in others cases.  On the other hand this is
a kludge which cannot be locally contained.  To keep it would make the
cleanup that follows in the next commits much harder.

(Instead we should make it *always* possible to recover the output of
the last few git invocations.  I would be even better to present that
information in the status buffer, instead of having her resort to the
*magit-run* buffer.  I will address this one way or another eventually.)

add magit-assert-one-parent, replacing magit-choose-parent-id

As before, it is not possible to revert or cherry-pick a merge commit.
That is okay because these are advanced operations with potentially
surprising consequences.  We might support this in the future but it
is not a priority at all.

Unlike before, we don't have a function that does not do what its name
advertises (which used to result in dead code in magit-apply-commit).

Merge branch 'better-build'

improve version detection and build process

* Add new function `magit-version' which is called late when loading
  `magit.el' and sets the value of variable `magit-version'.

* Use function `magit-version' in the `Makefile' instead of the old
  messy code used to set the version.

* Improve the `Makefile'.  It doesn't modify itself anymore.  Contains a
  `help' target. etc.  Generally it is much cleaner now.

* Fix and improve `tests/magit-tests.el'.  It now even works when travis
  is under high load.

* Remove `tests/run-tests.el'.  Use `make test'.  Interactive tests will
  come back as a separate make target.

* Remove `magit-pkg.el.in'.  Instead generate `magit-pkg.el' only when
  creating the marmalade tarball.  Elsewhere that file is not
  needed (including melpa).

* Remove `magit.spec.in'.  It is neither used by its original author nor
  the Fedora distribution (anymore).  This file has to be removed
  because it depends on the name of the loaddefs file being `50magit.el'
  and insists on installing it below `/etc`.  That isn't correct for
  many distributions and certainly not when installing Magit manually.
  Once this issues were addressed the spec file did not work anymore.

* Cleanup `.gitignore', `.travis.yml' and `README.md'

* Adapt `INSTALL.md' to above changes.

PS:

* I tried splitting this up into multiple commits but did not succeed.

* When Magit is installed using Melpa `magit-version' still reports the
  "melpa time-stamp" as version, not the `git describe --tags' version.

remove contrib/magit-inotify.el

This library is deprecated in favor of magit-filenotify.el
which is available separately.

We need `flet' from `cl'.  The new `cl-flet' is mostly useless.

The regular expression "^\\S<+$" attempts to assert that there are no
comment lines anywhere before end-of-buffer, but fails to do so.  The

Fix the regular expression.

Merge branch 'collect-Acting' into cleanup

Mark "Acting" and "Act" sections

Put the commands that directly map to some git porcelain subcommand
into their own dedicated sections (one per subcommand).

These sections are conceptionally subsections of the new "Acting"
top-level section, but because there are other unrelated sections
located in between the subcommand (sub)sections there two such sections
are actually required.  The headings "Acting (1)" and "Acting (2)" are
used for those sections.  Some of the 'subsections of section "Acting"'
are not neighbors of any other such sections and for that reason are
currently top-level sections.  The headings of these sections have
" (A)" as suffix to indicate that the are at least conceptionally part
of the "Acting" section.  E.g. "Diffing (A)".

For some git porcelain subcommands a "key-mode" popup exists.  For
others there is no such popup (yet, in some cases).  To differentiate
these two kinds of Magit->Git mappings the headings eigher have a "ing"
suffix (e.g. "Merging") if a popup exists.  Otherwise they don't have
that suffix (e.g. "Rebase").

magit-stage-item: fix file-name completion

Fix #717.

fix "Git is already running"

Previously it was possible that `magit-process' was not set to nil
even though the process has finished, causing all future calls to
`magit-run*' to fail.

For asynchronous processes this happened when the
`magit-process-client-buffer' got killed while the process was still
running (e.g. because the user killed it).  In this case the sentinel
failed to set `magit-process' to nil before it first tried to write to
the deleted buffer causing an error (which are not raised in sentinels).

Now setting `magit-process' to nil is the first thing done in
`magit-process-sentinel' and additionally an attempt to modify the
buffer is only made if it is live.

For synchronous process this could not happen, except when it receives
input, in which case the process is actually asynchronous but
`magit-run*' waits for it finish before returning.

Use a new sentinel `magit-process-input-sentinel' that sets
`magit-process' to nil in that case to.

Both sentinels now only do anything if the `process-status' is either
`exit' or `signal'.

As an additional precaution `magit-run*' now tries to recover from
causes when even the above failed.  If `magit-process' is non-nil but
has finished don't fail but tell the user to create a bug report.

Thanks to @acple and @daimrod, for pointing me into the right
direction.

deal with magit-custom-options being dynamically bound

Ensure that only the command, for which the (global) value of
`magit-custom-options' was set inside a dynamic binding, can see that
value by (again dynamically) binding it to nil before refreshing other
buffers (some of which might make use of that option during a refresh).

We cannot make this variable buffer local because that would collide
with other leaky abstractions.  E.g. the buffer whose value we would
want to use is not actually current anymore when the command is
called (see `magit-key-mode-command').

The change to `magit-log-long' is not actually required, and does not
even have any visible effect.  Before entering this rabbit hole I had
hopes that this change would fix the issue.  I keep it for consistency
with all other places where `magit-custom-options' is integrated into
some bigger list: they all use `append', so stop using `nconc' here.

magit.el: change and add section headings

For every key-mode popup command there is now a corresponding section by
the same name.  These headings consist of one word ending with "-ing".

There are a few other sections ending with "-ing" (Rebasing, Resetting,
Diffing, and Grepping) but at least for some of these we might actually
want to create new key-mode popup commands.

I would like to eventually put all "-ing" sections under a common super
section but that is currently not possible because a few other sections
are mixed inbetween that aren't related to key-mode popups.

For some other sections it would also make sense for them to be nested
below another section.  Again it is not reasonable to do this now
because these sections are not next to each other.

A few of the new sections (ChangeLog, Extensions, Interactive Rebase,
and Interactive Resolve) contain but one or two functions.  In case of
ChangeLog the reason is that its function is missplaced.  In the other
cases this is because the were part of the Miscellaneous section which
also contained other things that should be defined in top-level
sections.

Move 'unpulled' section down in status buffer

At the moment 'unpulled' sits between 'untracked files' and
'changes'. This makes working in a non-clean repository pretty awkward
if the list of unpulled changes is longer than one or two commits as
it splits the important information that a user needs when working on
an unclean repository: untracked files and changes.

commits'. That way both will keep their relative order, and 'untracked
files' and 'changes' are close together. For a clean repository the
order is not even changed.

magit-delete-directory: use copy of tramp-compat-delete-directory

Previously we determined the number of arguments `delete-directory'
accepts at compile time and defined this function accordingly.  Now
`magit-delete-directory' assume `delete-directory' supports RECURSIVE
and only if that causes `wrong-number-of-arguments' it does the
recursive delete itself.

and ugly than what we have now.

Relying on `magit-completing-read' was not correct because
that meant that it could not be used to complete the end rev in

(i.e. leave the end of the range unspecified).

rename magit-add-action{ => -clauses}

refactor magit-section-case and related functions

`magit-section-case' used to return t if a clause succeeds but the
value of it's body is nil.  This was due to internal needs; it allowed
`run-hook-with-args-until-sucess' to detect that a clause and therefor
the hook function succeeded.  However, while it was documented in the
doc-string, callers should not have to deal with this.

* `magit-section-case' and `magit-section-action' always return
  the value of the BODY now.  In other words they can return nil.
* `magit-section-case' doesn't need to know about OPCODE.
  Running the OPCODE hook is done in `magit-section-action' now.
* `magit-add-section' wrap each BODY so that `magit-section-action'
  can detect whether a CLAUSE succeeded.  Previously that was done
  in `magit-section-case' for *any* CLAUSE.
* Disallow a t/otherwise CLAUSE in `magit-section-action' as that
  would prevent the OPCODE hook from running.
* Replace uses of `magit-section-action' without OPCODE to use
  `magit-section-case' instead.

fix magit-item-highlight for default theme

In the default theme both `highlight' (which `magit-item-highlight' used
to inherit from) and the various `magit-diff-*' faces set the background
color.  Making the former override the latter, which then have no effect
whatsoever.

Since our faces have to make sense when using the default theme we have
no choice but to use some other face attribute for `magit-item-highlight',
even though there is a good change that this will break some third-party
themes.

So in case people start complaining, please tell them to contact the
maintainer of their themes instead and point them to this commit.

This finally fixes issue #133.

fix #667 without adding additional cruft

The problem with my original patch wasn't (just) that I forgot to
account for the possibility of the second argument unintentionally
containing format parameter but that using it as a format string was
wrong altogether.

`magit-insert-status-line' now takes exactly two arguments the HEADING
and the INFO-STRING and inserts both literally without processing them
using `format' first.

There was _one_ instance where we could previously write
  (magit-insert-status-line "heading" "%s %s" (a) (b))
and now have to write
  (magit-insert-status-line "heading" (concat (a) " " (b)))

If there were more instances like this then using the second argument
format string _might_ be justified (more likely not: it still makes it
harder to understand `magit-insert-status-line' without actually
thinking).  As it stands using a format string just obfuscates the
functions usage, which goes against the initial motivation of making the
code easier to read pleasing to the eye.

Furthermore if we need to document this function's use despite it being
very simple then there is something wrong with it.  Now a doc-string is
not necessary anymore, because I removed the initial "design" error and
use more descriptive argument lines.

magit-push-tags: allow selecting the remote

magit-push: set branch.<name>.merge when -u is in magit-custom-options

When --set-upstream is set through magit-key-mode use the same
backward compatibility hack to ensure branch.<name>.merge is set
even when using an old git version as is used when --set-upstream
is used due to the value of the magit-set-upstream-on-push option.

magit-push: update doc-string to reflect recent changes

Actually this new doc-string - for the bigger part - would have been
correct even before these changes since most of them are actually
bugfixes.  So the new doc-string wouldn't have been more wrong than
the old one :-)

No longer say that in certain cases something "hairy" is done when
that behaviour is well defined in git-push(1) and also reasonable.
Instead explicitly say what is done (pushing to the remote branch
with the same name as the local branch) and under what conditions.

I think the new doc-string is much easier to understand.  For better
readability I removed the instructions how prefix arguments are used;
the user has to get that knowledge elsewhere.  Not every command that
supports prefix arguments documents that basics of their use; why
should this one be different?

magit-push: do not use magit-get-remote to get the branch-remote

The meaning of "branch-remote" is "the remote configured for branch"
but if no remote is configured magit-get-remote might return "origin"
instead.  This is wrong here because we later use the value of
branch-remote to determine if we we should push to branch.<name>.merge
or just <name>.

So this ensures that we do the right thing when branch.<name>.merge is
set but branch.<name>.remote is not.

magit-push: set branch.<name>.merge correctly

The backward compatibility hack that ensured that branch.<name>.merge
was set even when using an old version of git used the wrong local
variable.  In many cases that variable contains the correct value but
this does not have to be the case.  More specifically it always used
the same ref as the ref of the local branch.  When the user selected
another branch name that obviously is not correct.  So this kludge for
older git versions could actually harm users of recent versions.

magit-push: ensure we are pushing to a branch

Do this by always using the full ref instead of just the name for
the remote branch.  Without this we could end pushing to some other
non-branch ref if no branch by the specified name exists remotely
but some other ref by that name does.

magit-read-remote: require that an existing remote is selected

All current uses of magit-read-remote actually require a remote to
be returned as the behaviour of nil being returned is not defined.
E.g. magit-push would try to push to a remote with the name "nil".

It would be better to give magit-read-remote a REQUIRE-MATCH argument
but since all callers expect a match this is not strictly unnecessary
at the moment.  Also some other magit-read-* functions could benefit
from a similar change.

magit-builtin-completing-read: handle REQUIRE-MATCH safely

completing-read does allow the user to exit with null input, leaving
it to the caller to handle that case.  Possible options would be to
use some default value or raise an error.

Since magit-builtin-completing-read is a convenience wrapper for
completing-read it seems reasonable to do the latter here so that not
every caller of magit-completing-read has to do this on it's own.

A similar change is not required for magit-iswitchb-completing-read
and magit-ido-completing-read; they already don't allow the user to
exit with a null value.

always respect value of magit-set-upstream-on-push

Previously both branch.<name>.remote and branch.<name>.merge where set
under certain conditions ignoring the value of magit-set-upstream-on-push:
when both branch.<name>.remote and remote.origin.url are unset
branch.<name>.remote was always set.  When additionally no prefix argument
is used branch.<name>.merge was also set ignoring the value of
magit-set-upstream-on-push.

magit-push: only push to branch.b.merge when pushing to branch.b.remote

The branch specified by the former is only meaningful when pushing to
the remote specified by the latter.  When pushing to another remote
and the remote branch is not specified explicitly then pusing to the
remote branch with the same name as the local branch being pushed is
much more reasonable than pushing to branch.b.merge which could be
anything.  This is also how "git push <remote> <branch>" behaves.

Move variable definition before first use

Fixes a byte compilation warning.

Fix buggy insert-header logic

The current logic for inserting the header after determining header-at
is riddled with bugs.  Most significantly, it completely omits the case
when header-at is at end-of-line (which happens when your buffer is not
terminated with a newline).  Also, the logic for looking for an existing
pseudo-header is completely bogus: it just looks for a line with the
character ':'.

Redo the entire logic in a dedicated function.  This function uses
git-commit-known-pseudo-headers to find existing pseudo headers
correctly and can return either zero, one, or two newlines.  Its logic
is flawless, as it considers every corner case.

Signed-off-by: Ramkumar Ramachandra <artagnon@gmail.com>

Simplify finding pseudo-header position

The logic git-commit-find-pseudo-header-position is unnecessary buggy
and unnecessarily convoluted.  It currently makes the assumption that
only pseudo-header lines can contain the ':' character.  This faulty
assumption manifests itself as bugs when attempting to "C-c C-s" in a
commit message like this one (where the summary contains a ':').

Further, this is unnecessarily convoluted as there is no need to look
for existing pseudo headers at all.  It's sufficient to look for the
first non-empty line preceding the comments (if any).

Signed-off-by: Ramkumar Ramachandra <artagnon@gmail.com>

Remove unused binding comment-start

comment-start is bound to (point) in
git-commit-find-pseudo-header-position, but used nowhere.  Remove it.

Signed-off-by: Ramkumar Ramachandra <artagnon@gmail.com>

Give magit skip-header a face

Match git-commit-skip-magit-header-regexp to give the expression a
preprocessor face.

Fix bug where the wrong author info is used for committing

The author information is saved in the buffer-local variable 'process-environment' in
the log-edit buffer.
To reset its value, kill-local-variable must be called not after, but BEFORE
switching away from the log-edit buffer.

Merge branch 'dudebout/rewrite-magit-pull'

Uses a colon separated refspec for pull

`git pull origin master` does not store the information retrieved from
the remote in the local copy of the remote (refs/remotes/origin/master).
It uses FETCH_HEAD instead to store the information temporarily and then
does the merge. As a consequence, when comparing refs/heads/master and
refs/remotes/origin/master, it looks like the local branch is ahead and
it magit will display that there are some unpushed commits.

To alleviate the problem it is necessary to use the following command:
`git pull origin refs/heads/master:refs/remotes/origin/master`.
Fixes pull if no merge branch is specified

more portable.

Merge branch 'tarsius/section-case' into next
rename magit-add-action{ => -clauses}

refactor magit-section-case and related functions

`magit-section-case' used to return t if a clause succeeds but the
value of it's body is nil.  This was due to internal needs; it allowed
`run-hook-with-args-until-sucess' to detect that a clause and therefor
the hook function succeeded.  However, while it was documented in the
doc-string, callers should not have to deal with this.

* `magit-section-case' and `magit-section-action' always return
  the value of the BODY now.  In other words they can return nil.
* `magit-section-case' doesn't need to know about OPCODE.
  Running the OPCODE hook is done in `magit-section-action' now.
* `magit-add-section' wrap each BODY so that `magit-section-action'
  can detect whether a CLAUSE succeeded.  Previously that was done
  in `magit-section-case' for *any* CLAUSE.
* Disallow a t/otherwise CLAUSE in `magit-section-action' as that
  would prevent the OPCODE hook from running.
* Replace uses of `magit-section-action' without OPCODE to use
  `magit-section-case' instead.
